Abstract: A 3.3-cm period Nd-Fe-B hybrid undulator has been designed and successfully operated in the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR). This 2-m-long, 123-pole insertion device is a prototype of one of the undulators planned for the Advanced Photon Source. In dedicated operation, the undulator produced the expected brightness at 5.437 GeV with the fundamental x-ray energy ranging from 4.3 to 7.9 keV corresponding to a change in gap from 1.5 to 2.8 cm.

Authors: Williams G.P., Heese R.N., Vignola G., Murphy J.B., Godel J.B., Hsieh H., Galayda J., Seifert A., Knotek M.L.
Title: The superconducting x-ray lithography source program at Brookhaven (invited)
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, G.P., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Heese, R.N., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Vignola, G., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Murphy, J.B., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Godel, J.B., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Hsieh, H., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Galayda, J., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Seifert, A., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Knotek, M.L., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: A compact electron storage ring with superconducting dipole magnets, is being developed at the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven. The parameters of the source have been optimized for its future use as an x-ray source for lithography. This first ring is a prototype which will be used to study the operating characteristics of machines of this type with particular attention being paid to low-energy injection and long beam lifetime.

Authors: Lavender W., Brown G., Troxel T., Coïsson R.
Title: Observation of x-ray undulator radiation on PEP (invited)
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Parma, 43100 Parma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Lavender, W., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Brown, G., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Troxel, T., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Coïsson, R., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Parma, 43100 Parma, Italy
Abstract: A 2-m undulator magnet and associated beamline have been installed on the electron-positron storage ring PEP. The undulator is designed to produce photons at 12 keV with high intensity when the storage ring is operated at its nominal energy of 14.5 GeV. We report measurements of the spectral and angular properties of the radiation when PEP is operated in a low-emittance (ε∼6×10-9 m rad) configuration. The spectral properties are in good agreement with theoretical predictions.

Title: Luminescence excitation in BaF2-BaCl2 and BaF 2-BaBr2 synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: Moscow State University, Moscow 117234, Russian Federation; I. V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Mikhaylin, V.V., Moscow State University, Moscow 117234, Russian Federation; Terekhin, M.A., I. V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: Luminescence excitation spectra in barium fluorohalides have been studied using synchrotron radiation of the SIBERIA-I electron storage ring in the energy range from 4 to 35 eV. The energy position of edge and core exciton formation as well as that of the electronic excitation multiplication threshold have been established. These luminophors find their practical application in the novel image-plate technique.

Authors: Toor A., Csonka P., Tatchyn R.
Title: Micropole undulators: Novel insertion devices for synchrotron sources (invited)
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Toor, A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Csonka, P., Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Tatchyn, R., Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States, Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Micropole undulators (wigglers) are undulators (wigglers) with submillimeter periods and are referred to, generically, as micropole insertion devices. Compared to ordinary insertion devices, whose period λu is typically ≥1 cm, micropole devices have periods smaller by a factor f≤10. Therefore, the first-harmonic radiation emitted by a micropole undulator will have its photon energy Eγ increased by f and its spectral purity Δλ/λ by f, provided the total length of the undulator lu stays unchanged, and magnetic field errors, as well as the electron-beam emittance, are sufficiently small. Furthermore, to generate photons of the same Eγ as from the conventional device, the electron-beam energy Ee can be reduced by f 1/2, resulting in significantly lower construction and operating costs. Radiative energy losses can be correspondingly diminished for the associated storage rings. In this paper we report on results recently obtained by us in the practical implementation and design of micropole undulators at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL) and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL). Based on our work, micropole undulators with f≤104 appear feasible at the present time.

Authors: Okuda S., Nakanishi T., Itoga K., Nakata S., Yamamoto S., Yamada T., Iwamoto M.
Title: Injection, dynamic aperture, and beam instability of a small synchrotron radiation source in the hard-x-ray region
Affiliations: Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Okuda, S., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Nakanishi, T., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Itoga, K., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Nakata, S., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Yamamoto, S., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Yamada, T., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan; Iwamoto, M., Electrotechnology Department, Central Research Laboratory, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 1-1, Tsukaguchi Honmachi 8-Chome, Amagasaki, 661, Japan
Abstract: A small synchrotron radiation source in the hard-x-ray region was conceptually designed and its injection scheme, dynamic aperture, and beam instabilities were studied. Synchrotron radiation with the critical wavelength of 0.1 nm is emitted from a pair of superconducting bending magnets. The storage ring has only one pair of quadrupole magnets to save its drift space. The decay time of the kicker magnet and the angle between the central orbit and the orbit of the injected beam were optimized by computer simulation. The reduction of the dynamic aperture due to the errors of the bending field is less than 20%. Considerations of possible instabilities showed that there is no critical instability up to the beam current of 200 mA when the beam is injected with higher energy than 650 MeV.

Authors: Chang C.-N., Tseng P.-C., Song Y.-F.
Title: Optical design of a 200 eV-2.5 keV cylindrical element monochromator for the 1.3-GeV storage ring of SRRC
Affiliations: Department of Physics, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei, Taiwan; Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, C.-N., Department of Physics, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei, Taiwan; Tseng, P.-C., Department of Physics, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei, Taiwan; Song, Y.-F., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: Separate focus-function mirrors in combination with a simple-scanning spherical/cylindrical grating are to be used for an extreme grazing-incidence beamline design in the photon energy range of 200 eV-2.5 keV at the ARC synchrotron radiation of the TBA lattice of SRRC. Three mechanically ruled gratings are used to cover the spectral wavelength range of the extreme VUV and soft x rays. Both the throughput and the resolution of this optical system have been carefully calculated and compromised against the grazing angle, arm length, grating size, etc. The proper parameters of the optical elements as well as their geometrical arrangements are proposed. A resolving power of at least 2000 is obtainable at the high-energy end of the spectrum around 2 keV. At the low-energy end, the resolving power can be as high as 8000, comparable to a grazing-incidence Rowland circle type of monochromator. The overall resolving power has been found to be superior to that of either the plane grating monochromator (PGM) or the 10-m toroidal grazing monochromator (TGM) in the same spectral wavelength range.

Title: Search for the inclusive production of J/Ψ in e+e- collisions using PLUTO data
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C Particles and Fields
Affiliations: INFN Sezione di Roma, Dipartimento Fisica Universitá 'La Sapienza', Roma, I-00185, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Ferrarotto, F., INFN Sezione di Roma, Dipartimento Fisica Universitá 'La Sapienza', Roma, I-00185, Italy
Abstract: We have searched for the inclusive production of J/Ψ in e+e- hadronic events collected by the PLUTO detector at the storage ring PETRA in a range of energies from 30 to 35 GeV. The data were analyzed identifying muons in multihadronic events and looking for the decay mode J/Ψ→μ+μ-. With no candidate found, the upper limit obtained for the total cross section is σ(e+e-→J/Ψ+X)≦12 pb (90% C.L.), using an integrated luminosity ∫dL=41.7 pb-1 at the average c.m. energy {Mathematical expression}. Together with previous results, this rules out a model based on non-perturbative QCD production mechanisms. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Hydrogen desorption from crystalline silicon and its modification due to the presence of dislocations
Affiliations: Abteilung für Metallphysik, II. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Köln, Zülpicher Strasse 77, D-5000 Köln 41, Germany; Institut für Schicht-und Ionentechnik, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich GmbH, D-5170 Jülich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kisielowski-Kemmerich, C., Abteilung für Metallphysik, II. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Köln, Zülpicher Strasse 77, D-5000 Köln 41, Germany; Beyer, W., Institut für Schicht-und Ionentechnik, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich GmbH, D-5170 Jülich, Germany
Abstract: Hydrogen effusion spectra of oxidized Si samples are investigated and characteristic activation energies associated with the rupture of hydrogen bonds are estimated. Dislocation-enhanced solubility of hydrogen is found in deformed crystals and macroscopic diffusion depth (mm) can be realized. Hydrogenation is performed by exposure of the crystals to H2 gas at 800°C. Beside the desorption of hydrogen bound close to the Si surface, the rupture of hydrogen-hydrogen bonds of molecules stored in deformed crystals is observed. The storage of the H2 molecules requires the presence of dislocations or deformation-induced point defects, and the H:H binding energy ranges from 2.7 to 3.8 eV. Most likely this energy variation comes from different local strain around dislocations. Atomic hydrogen is found to dominate the effusion kinetics.

Authors: Brown Harry W., Witt James H., Pollak Robert
Title: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) RAM
Affiliations: ARINC Research Corp, Annapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, Harry W., ARINC Research Corp, Annapolis, United States; Witt, James H., ARINC Research Corp, Annapolis, United States; Pollak, Robert, ARINC Research Corp, Annapolis, United States
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) technology represents an economically attractive and technically proven approach to obtaining overall cost-effectiveness in power generation. A key to realizing the load-leveling benefits offered by CAES is the achievement of good reliability, availability, and maintainability (RAM) performance by the system and its components. With this in mind, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) sponsored the development of RAM models of the three generic types of CAES units: salt caverns, rock caverns, and aquifers. The objectives in developing these models were to evaluate the expected RAM performance of design alternatives, to investigate trade-offs among design parameters affecting RAM, and to develop an analysis tool for use by utilities interested in building CAES plants. This paper presents the generic models developed by ARINC Research Corporation, together with some initial evaluation results.
Index Keywords: Computer Software--Applications; Power Plants--Design; CAES Plant Availability; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) Technology; Generic CAES Plant Design; Software Package UNIRAM; Compressed Air

Authors: Takada H., Tsutsui Y., Tomimasu T., Sugiyama S.
Title: High beam current storage at low energy for compact synchrotron radiation rings (invited)
Affiliations: Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Osaka Research Laboratories, Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka 554, Japan; Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takada, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Osaka Research Laboratories, Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka 554, Japan; Tsutsui, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Osaka Research Laboratories, Shimaya, Konohana, Osaka 554, Japan; Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: A study of high beam current storage at a low energy is being conducted on the compact electron storage ring NIJI-1. In general, it is said that the stored beam lifetime is rapidly shortened as the beam energy decreases, and the high beam current storage is difficult to obtain. However, a stored beam current above a 350 mA was obtained at an injection energy of 100 MeV, and the lifetime of the stored beam is considerably long. For example, e-folding lifetime is about 2 h at 100 MeV. In this paper, we estimate the beam current decay rate due to the residual gas scattering, the ion trapping effect, and the Touschek effect, and make clear these contributions to the beam lifetime. It was clear that the Touschek lifetime is lengthened according to the bunch size growth, which is roughly explained by the longitudinal coupled bunch instability.

Authors: Saito N., Suzuki I.H., Onuki H., Nishi M.
Title: Angular distribution measurement of fragment ions from a molecule using a new beamline consisting of a Grasshopper monochromator
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4, Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saito, N., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4, Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Suzuki, I.H., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4, Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Onuki, H., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4, Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Nishi, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4, Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Optical characteristics of a new beamline consisting of a premirror, a Grasshopper monochromator, and a refocusing mirror have been investigated. The intensity of the monochromatic soft x-ray was estimated to be about 10 8 photons/(s 100 mA) at 500 eV with the storage electron energy of 600 MeV and the minimum slit width. This slit width provides a resolution of about 500. Angular distributions of fragment ions from an inner-shell excited nitrogen molecule have been measured with a rotatable time-of-flight mass spectrometer by using this beamline.

Title: Variable-period electrostatic and magnetostatic undulator designs for generating polarized soft x rays at PEP
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Abstract: It can been shown that the generation of soft x rays on high energy storage rings such as PEP is most effectively performed with low-field, variable-period insertion devices, in contrast to the fixed-period devices represented by conventional transverse magnetostatic (TM) technology. Moreover, variable-period undulators of arbitrary field strength can be shown to be preferable to variable-gap devices under all circumstances where the generation of excessive superfluous power is undesirable, or where the available range of tuning with a single device must be maximized. In this article, basic arguments for these claims are presented, and an electrostatic implementation of a variable-period polarizing undulator is described. Some attractive properties of a recently designed, higher-field magnetostatic analog of the electrostatic device are also mentioned.

Title: A segmented electrostatic undulator design for generating arbitrarily polarized soft x rays at the Stanford Positron Electron Project
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Abstract: The recent introduction of high-energy storage rings with very long straight sections for dedicated synchrotron radiation research has significantly expanded the parameter space accessible to insertion devices as well. In particular, when the generation of soft x rays on a storage ring such as the Stanford Positron Electron Project (PEP) is considered, its straight sections, which exceed 100 m, may be shown to be naturally amenable to low-to-medium K undulators with a large number of relatively long periods. This in turn allows for the establishment of relatively weak on-axis fields in such devices. In this paper it is shown that these conditions permit the use of electrostatic fields, as well as the concomitant development of fixed-gap, variable-period undulators. Such devices are shown to be superior in many respects to the variable-gap magnetostatic undulators currently in vogue. Two novel variable-period undulator designs, one for a transverse electrostatic undulator and the other for a helical device (HEU) are described. The performances of both devices are calculated, and the numerous advantages of the HEU configuration in producing either soft or hard x rays of arbitrary polarization on high-energy rings such as PEP are pointed out.

Authors: Kakishita K., Kawakami K., Suzuki S., Ohta E., Sakata M.
Title: Iron-related deep levels in n-type silicon
Affiliations: Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kakishita, K., Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan; Kawakami, K., Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan; Suzuki, S., Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan; Ohta, E., Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan; Sakata, M., Department of Instrumentation Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Yokohama 223, Japan
Abstract: Deep levels in iron-doped n-type silicon have been investigated by deep-level transient spectroscopy (DLTS). Three deep levels of E c-0.29 eV (E1), Ec-0.36 eV (E2), and Ec-0.48 eV (E3) were observed. The concentration of E1 and E2 levels increased during the storage at room temperature. The depth profile of the E3 level concentration indicates the out-diffusion and precipitation of the defects related to the E3 level. In addition, after annealing at 80 °C for 30 min, the E2 and E3 concentrations decreased and then recovered at room temperature. These results suggest that the defects related to these levels are mobile during quenching and storage at room temperature. The temperature dependence of the E3 level concentration shows a formation energy of about 2 eV, which is smaller than that of interstitial iron, and the E3 level concentration is two orders of magnitude lower than the concentration of interstitial iron. The origins of these levels are probably loosely associated iron-related complexes such as iron-acceptor pairs.

Authors: Nyholm R., Eriksson M., Hansen K., Sairanen O.-P., Werin S., Flodström A., Törnevik C., Meinander T., Sarakontu M.
Title: Submicrometer-resolution photoelectron-spectroscopy at MAX Lab
Affiliations: MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Instrument Laboratory, Technical Research Center of Finland, Metallimiehenkuja 8, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Nyholm, R., MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Eriksson, M., MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Hansen, K., MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Sairanen, O.-P., MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Werin, S., MAX Laboratory, Lund University, P.O.Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Flodström, A., Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Törnevik, C., Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Meinander, T., Instrument Laboratory, Technical Research Center of Finland, Metallimiehenkuja 8, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland; Sarakontu, M., Instrument Laboratory, Technical Research Center of Finland, Metallimiehenkuja 8, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Abstract: The design of a photoemission microprobe beamline at the MAX laboratory is presented. The beamline will utilize the radiation from a 26 period undulator on the 550-MeV MAX storage ring. The beamline will be capable of providing about 1010 photons/s of monochromatized radiation (bandwidth better than 0.25 eV) in the energy range of 20 to 150 eV focused into a submicrometer focal spot. It will be used for scanning photoemission experiments with a lateral resolution better than 1 μm. The optical system is comprised of a plane-grating monochromator with a Kirkpatrick-Baez objective and a specially designed ellipsoidal focusing mirror.

Authors: Baryshev V.B., Gavrilov N.G., Daryin A.V., Zolotarev K.V., Kulipanov G.N., Mezentsev N.A., Terekhov Ya.V.
Title: Scanning x-ray fluorescent microanalysis of rock samples
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Institute of Geology and Geophysics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Baryshev, V.B., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gavrilov, N.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Daryin, A.V., Institute of Geology and Geophysics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Zolotarev, K.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kulipanov, G.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentsev, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Terekhov, Ya.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Results are given concerning the two-dimensional scanning microanalysis of microsections of metallographic specimens of rocks. The monochromatized or white SR beam from a wiggler magnet installed at the electron storage ring VEPP-3 (2 GeV, 20 kG, 100-200 mA) was used for fluorescence excitation. The working energies ranged from 8 to 35 keV. Without focusing x-ray optics, the spatial resolution was 60 μm with the monochromatic beam and 30 μm with the white SR beam. The minimum detectable concentration of the elements (within the Fe-Sr region) is 10 ppm for 1-3 s exposures per point.

Authors: Helliwell J.R., Harrop S., Habash J., Magorrian B.G., Allinson N.M., Gomez D., Helliwell M., Derewenda Z., Cruickshank D.W.J.
Title: Instrumentation for Laue diffraction (invited)
Authors with affiliations: Helliwell, J.R.; Harrop, S.; Habash, J.; Magorrian, B.G.; Allinson, N.M.; Gomez, D.; Helliwell, M.; Derewenda, Z.; Cruickshank, D.W.J.
Abstract: Single-crystal x-ray diffraction data can be measured very quickly in Laue geometry compared with monochromatic methods. Alternatively, this gain factor can be used instead to reduce the sample volume for a fixed exposure time. In the latter case especially, there is a critical need to control parasitic scatter in the Laue camera. The use of Laue geometry as a means of quantitative data acquisition required the solution of some fundamental problems. The so-called "overlapping orders problem" has been found not to be limiting. It can be shown that the bulk of the Laue spots are single order, provided dhkl<2dmin where dhkl is the interplanar spacing and dmin is the resolution limit of the data. In addition, empirical wavelength normalization is required. This can be achieved by using the symmetry of the diffraction pattern. The fact that different equivalents occur at different wavelengths means that the differences in these intensities can be used to establish the "λ curve." Successful wavelength normalization to date has used a relatively broad-band pass. The multiplicity distribution is the histogram of the number of spots of a given order. This distribution is determined by the ratio λmax/ λmin (λmax =maximum wavelength, λmin =minimum wavelength in the beam). λmax is determined by the use of any filters in the beamline. λmin is determined either by the spectral curve or a critical cutoff if a mirror is used. A mirror can be usefully introduced to enhance the multiplicity distribution in favor of single wavelength spots or to focus the white beam; so far only vertical focussing has been used. The detector options used to date have been photographic film, Fuji image plate (at Photon Factory)/Kodak storage phosphor (at Cornell) and charge coupled device (CCD) (at Daresbury). It is useful to consider the joint theoretical spatial and energy distribution of spots in defining the detector specification and geometry. To date, we have processed Laue film data successfully. The attraction of using the CCD, even to look at a small portion of the Laue pattern, is to view the diffraction in real time. This will allow tight control of parasitic scatter for microcrystal Laue diffraction and real-time monitoring for time-resolved work. We performed initial experiments using a direct detection CCD imager, and have obtained satisfactory diffraction data on a 40 ms time scale. Results of this work will be presented. In order to assess the efficacy of the Laue method for quantitative crystallography, we have used Laue data from the protein pea lectin and compared it in detail with monochromatic pea lectin data. To assess the use of a vertically focussing mirror, we have successfully used a mercury derivative protein crystal to yield isomorphous and anomalous differences suitable for phase determination. In both the pea lectin and mercury derivative cases, doublet Laue spots were deconvoluted. In the latter case, the data were used in a difference Fourier calculation which showed the mercury peak. Future developments and projections based on multipole sources are given.

Authors: Maezawa H., Toyoshima A., Kagoshima Y., Mori K., Ishikawa T.
Title: Status of a beamline for a 60-period soft x-ray undulator in the low emittance operation of the Photon Factory storage ring
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho 1-1, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan; Institute of Applied Physics, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan; Department of Physics, Faculty of Science and Technology, Sophia University, Kioicho 7-1, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo 102, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Maezawa, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho 1-1, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan; Toyoshima, A., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho 1-1, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan; Kagoshima, Y., Institute of Applied Physics, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan; Mori, K., Department of Physics, Faculty of Science and Technology, Sophia University, Kioicho 7-1, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo 102, Japan; Ishikawa, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho 1-1, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan
Abstract: Progress in performance of a beamline for a 60-period soft x-ray undulator of the 2.5-GeV Photon Factory storage ring was made by implementation of low emittance operation of the storage ring and improvements of beamline and monochromator units. Monochromated photon flux of up to 1012 photons/s has now been achieved at maximum in ordinary operating conditions of the ring current of ≈200 mA with resolution of 500-1000 over the soft x-ray region from 410 eV to a few keV of photon energy.

Title: Generation of various polarization states from insertion devices: A review
Affiliations: European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BP 220, F-38043 Grenobel Cédex, France
Authors with affiliations: Elleaume, P., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BP 220, F-38043 Grenobel Cédex, France
Abstract: Most insertion devices (IDs) which have been built so far are planar with the field in the vertical plane. They are the easiest to design, and they fit well to the narrow vertical aperture available on storage rings. As bending magnets, these IDs generate essentially horizontally polarized radiation. Recently, several new proposals and prototypes have been produced in order to generate different polarization states. The Stokes decomposition of the radiation from these devices is given versus photo energy. This discussion is illustrated by taking the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) conditions in the hard x-ray range.

Title: Experiments with cement based grouts for nuclear waste containment
Affiliations: Keil and Associates Ltd, Winnipeg, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Keil, L.D., Keil and Associates Ltd, Winnipeg, Canada; Boyd, J.M., Keil and Associates Ltd, Winnipeg, Canada
Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) is researching cement-based grouts and grouting techniques to assess their potential for use in sealing nuclear fuel waste disposal vaults. Grout shakedown trials were performed at AECL's Underground Research Laboratory (URL). High-pressure jet washing was investigated as a method to selectively erode clay gouge and other deleterious materials from fracture zones. In addition, acoustic emissions monitoring and electromagnetic geotomography were performed to ascertain their potential to identify grout injection pathways.
Index Keywords: Acoustic emission testing; Clay; Concrete construction; Fracture; Grouting; Interfaces (materials); Monitoring; Nuclear fuels; Radioactive waste storage; Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL); Clay gouge; Deleterious materials; Electromagnetic geotomography; High pressure jet washing; Underground Research Laboratory; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Mitchell T.H., Ellis R.D.M., Smith S.A., Robb G., Cawthorne M.A.
Title: Effects of BRL 35135, a β-adrenoceptor agonist with novel selectivity, on glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity in obese subjects
Affiliations: Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mitchell, T.H., Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom; Ellis, R.D.M., Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom; Smith, S.A., Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom; Robb, G., Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom; Cawthorne, M.A., Beecham Pharmaceut. Res. Div., Great Burgh, Yew Tree Bottom Road, Epsom KT18 5XQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: BRL 35135 is a novel oral agent which, when dosed chronically to obese rodents with abnormal glucose tolerance, improves both insulin sensitivity and glucose tolerance. To study its effect in man, 10 obese patients on a weight-maintaining diet received BRL 35135 2 mg four times per day for 5 days and then 6 mg four times per day for 5 days. Oral 100 g glucose tolerance tests were performed 1 day prior to and 12 h after the 10-day treatment with BRL 35135. Simultaneously, energy expenditure, glucose oxidation and glucose storage were measured by open-circuit indirect calorimetry. No significant changes in body weight occurred during the 10-day treatment with BRL 35135. Areas under the curves for glucose and insulin were reduced following treatment with BRL 35135 (1518 ± 152 to 1277 ± 132 mmol/1/3 h, P < 0.001 and 13.8 ± 1.7 to 9.5 ± 1.3 U/1/3 h, P < 0.01) (mean ± s.e.m.). In addition, plasma glucose concentrations, 2 h post-oral glucose, were reduced significantly (8.7 ± 1.0 mmol/1 to 6.7 ± 0.78, P < 0.01). There was no effect of the treatment on glucose-induced thermogenesis and glucose oxidation did not change but glucose storage increased significantly. The results suggest that BRL 35135 improves glucose tolerance by an increase in insulin sensitivity that is independent of body weight. Glucose storage accounted for the increased glucose disposal.
Author Keywords: BRL 35135; Indirect calorimetry; Insulin sensitivity; Obese patients
Index Keywords: 4 [2 [[2 (3 chlorophenyl) 2 hydroxyethyl]amino]propyl]phenoxyacetic acid methyl ester; adrenergic receptor; insulin; radioisotope; adult; article; calorimetry; energy metabolism; female; glucose blood level; human; human cell; human experiment; insulin sensitivity; male; obesity; oral drug administration; priority journal; Adult; Aged; Blood Glucose; Body Weight; Calorimetry, Indirect; Energy Metabolism; Female; Human; Insulin; Male; Middle Age; Obesity; Phenethylamines; Rodentia

Authors: Kholliev B.I., Kim V.D., Khairiddinov B.Kh.
Title: Hydraulic calculations for a water thermal-storage system in a solar dryer
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Kholliev, B.I.; Kim, V.D.; Khairiddinov, B.Kh.
Abstract: Raising the efficiency of solar dryers' operation is connected, in particular, with providing the required temperature and humidity conditions for drying. Overheating usually takes place in solar dryers in the daytime, and at night the object to be dried is insufficiently heated. The article gives hydraulic calculations for a water thermal-storage system in a solar-dryer system and determines the necessary velocity of pumping air.
Index Keywords: Flow of Water - Calculations; Heat Transfer - Boundary Layer; Hot Water Supply Systems - Heat Storage; Solar Energy - Storage; Air Velocity; Hydraulic Calculations; Pipe Pressure Losses; Turbulent Heat Exchange; Water Thermal Storage System; Dryers

Title: Suppression of longitudinal coupled-bunch instability in UVSOR
Affiliations: Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kasuga, T., Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaki, Jpn; Yonehara, H., Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaki, Jpn
Abstract: The UVSOR is a 750-MeV electron storage ring used solely for vacuum ultraviolet synchrotron radiation research in molecular science and related fields. A longitudinal coupled-bunch instability excited by higher-order-mode resonances of the RF cavity was observed when routine operation of the ring was started. Two methods of curing the instability were tried, i.e., a feedback method and a decoupling method. The former system consists of 16 independent feedback loops; each of them corrects the energy deviation of one of 16 bunches. Although the system can suppress the instability, critical adjustment is required, i.e., the feedback loops have to be finely adjusting according to parameters such as the electron energy, the beam current, and the RF acceleration voltage. The latter system spreads synchrotron frequencies of individual bunches by the modulation of the effective acceleration voltage to decouple these synchrotron oscillations. The instability is damped by this method when the beam current is not high (less than 100 mA). The limitation of this method is in the maximum modulation index available in the experiment. Therefore, the former system is being used in routine operation in spite of its drawback.
Index Keywords: Molecules; Resonators, Cavity; Synchrotron Radiation; Feedback Loops; RF Cavities; Vacuum Ultraviolet Synchrotron Radiation; Accelerators

Authors: Walsh J.E., Fisch E.F., Jackson J.A., Xu Y., Marshall E.M.
Title: Dispersion and gain in generic slow-wave structures
Affiliations: Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Walsh, J.E., Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA; Fisch, E.F., Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA; Jackson, J.A., Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA; Xu, Y., Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA; Marshall, E.M., Dartmouth Coll, Hanover, NH, USA
Abstract: The dialectric-lined waveguide or Cerenkov maser and the metal-grating-based planar orotron have been operational for several years. Recently a segmented grating resonator, the planar-grating klystron, has also been introduced. A generic theory which is capable of predicting their tuning, gain, saturation, relative efficiency and sensitivity to electron beam quality has been developed. The theory will handle a wide range of coupling structures. The principle effects of resonator design on device performance are captured by a modal capacitance. This function, which has the dimensions of ordinary capacitance, is a measure of the energy storage capacity of a resonator. The beam dynamics enter through a modal conductance that is relatively insensitive to the structural details of the resonator. In the nonlinear regime, this function, together with the capacitance, determines the coefficients of the equation that governs the evolution of the mode amplitude. The limit cycle amplitude and relative efficiency can be determined from this equation. In addition, the nonlinear locking and pulling characteristics of the source can be examined.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Electron Tubes, Microwave; Masers; Resonators; Abstract Only; Orotrons; Slow Wave Structures; Microwave Devices

Title: PEP as a synchrotron radiation source: Status and review
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accel Cent, Stanford, Univ, Stanford, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Paterson, James M., Stanford Linear Accel Cent, Stanford, Univ, Stanford, CA, USA
Abstract: The electron-positron collider, PEP, is a 15-GeV storage ring built and operated for high-energy physics. Two insertion device beam lines are operational, each illuminated by 2-m-long, 77-mm period undulator magnets. In parasitic operation on high-energy-physics runs, they provide photons above 10 keV, with a peak brightness of 1016 photons/(s-mm2-mrad2) within a 0.1% bandwidth. In tests of a low-emittance mode of operation at 7.1 GeV, horizontal emittances of about 5 mm-rad were measured, which is about the same as that planned for the new third-generation X-ray sources. At a current of 15 mA at 7.1 GeV, the present undulators deliver photon beams from 2.7 to 14 keV with a peak brightness of about 1017. Higher performance can be achieved with longer insertion devices optimized for these energies. Future operation in both parasitic mode and dedicated low emittance mode is planned.
Index Keywords: Photons; Physics--High Energy; Synchrotron Radiation; Electron-Positron Collider; Horizontal Emittance; Synchrotron Radiation Source; Undulator Magnets; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Boulay Richard B., Harvey Lawrence E.
Title: Operational economics of compressed air energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Gilbert/Commonwealth, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boulay, Richard B., Gilbert/Commonwealth, Inc, United States; Harvey, Lawrence E., Gilbert/Commonwealth, Inc, United States
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) is a means of producing intermediate or peaking power. Gilbert/Commonwealth, Inc. has completed a study which examines several design and economic issues relating to CAES plants. Capital and operating costs were adjusted to present day values. The effects of cavern operating pressure on cavern capital costs and on the cost of providing charging energy was examined. The incremental cost of electricity of a CAES plant was determined and was compared with other technologies that might be used to provide intermediate or peaking power to determine how CAES would compete with these technologies on an economic dispatch scenario. In addition, a conceptual design for a 241 MW coal-fired CAES system, based on pressurized fluidized bed combustor technology, was developed, and its economics were compared with those of an oil-fired system.
Index Keywords: Gas Turbine Power Plants; Compressed Air Energy Storage; Cycling; Energy Storage

Authors: Schoenung Susan M., Ender Robert C., Walsh Terry E.
Title: Utility benefits of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schoenung, Susan M., W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, United States; Ender, Robert C., W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, United States; Walsh, Terry E., W.J. Schafer Associates, Inc, United States
Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) is being developed for use as an advanced power source for electric utilities. The most obvious use of SMES will be in load-leveling, but many other valuable applications of SMES, such as spinning reserve and frequency stabilization, are possible within a utility system. With an Engineering Test Model scheduled for operation in the near future, a number of utilities have begun to analyze quantitatively the potential benefits of SMES. These benefits are found to vary with the size and characteristics of the utility as well as with the power and energy capacity of the SMES unit, with 'operating' benefits outweighing load-leveling benefits for a small unit.
Index Keywords: Superconducting Magnets; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Nakabayashi Kenichi, Nishino Hideo, Toki Susumu, Takamuku Setsuo
Title: Valence isomerization of quadricyclane-norbornadiene derivatives via triplet state. Correlation of the mechanism with triplet conformation of the olefinic moiety
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakabayashi, Kenichi, Osaka Univ, Japan; Nishino, Hideo, Osaka Univ, Japan; Toki, Susumu, Osaka Univ, Japan; Takamuku, Setsuo, Osaka Univ, Japan
Abstract: The mechanism of the valence isomerization between methyl 5-aryl-tetracyclo[3.2.0.02,704,6]-heptane-1-carboxylate (1) and methyl 3-aryl-bicyclo- [2.2.1]hepta-2,5-diene-2-carboxylate (2) under the triplet sensitization in benzene has been studied by pulse radiolysis and stationary experiments. The valence isomerization proceeds via a 1,3-biradical intermediate favorably to 1 for the phenyl derivatives where the most stable conformation of the corresponding olefinic analogue is a twisted form. In the case of 1-naphthyl derivatives where the conformation of the olefinic analogue is a planar form, an adiabatic cycloreversion of 1 to 2 takes place. An equilibrium state between a 1,3-biradical intermediate and a triplet state with a structure of norbornadiene is estimated for 2-naphthyl derivatives. Correlation of the mechanism for the valence isomerization with the conformation of corresponding olefinic analogue has been discussed on the basis of the potential energy surfaces for the isomerization. This work is pertinent to solar energy storage.
Index Keywords: Benzene; Radiation Chemistry; Radiation Effects; Solar Energy--Storage; Olefinic Moiety; Quadricyclane-Norbornadiene Derivatives; Triplet Conformation; Valence Isomerization; Organic Compounds

Title: Regenerative drive for incorporating flywheel energy storage into wind generation systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Eng, Bristol Polytech,, Bristol, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S., Dep of Eng, Bristol Polytech,, Bristol, Engl; Larsen, N., Dep of Eng, Bristol Polytech,, Bristol, Engl
Abstract: The authors describe an asynchronous transmission scheme for a flywheel energy storage unit, which provides a reliable, rugged, but also relatively low-cost interface allowing bidirectional power transfer between the flywheel and the rest of the system. Although operation with stand-alone wind turbines is referred to in particular, the transmission can be readily modified to suit other applications. The configuration forms the basis from which an integrated electrically driven flywheel energy storage package is to be developed for transport applications.

Authors: Nogueira L.A.H., Santos A.H.M., Balestieri J.A.P., Macedo I.C.
Title: Optimal scheduling of the sugar cane harvest aiming to maximize the cogeneration by using the dynamic programming
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Federal Coll of Eng, Itajuba, Braz
Authors with affiliations: Nogueira, L.A.H., Federal Coll of Eng, Itajuba, Braz; Santos, A.H.M., Federal Coll of Eng, Itajuba, Braz; Balestieri, J.A.P., Federal Coll of Eng, Itajuba, Braz; Macedo, I.C., Federal Coll of Eng, Itajuba, Braz
Abstract: Deciding how to allocate the crop share in the combined alcohol-sugar industries using dynamic programming is discussed. This planning is based on production and storage restrictions and on market price and demand. The authors present a model for scheduling the sugar cane crop so as to increase the energy surplus from the plant, which is measured by the bagasse excess. This excess can be transformed into electrical power to the public utilities, with high economic return. The main tools used in this study were the simulation of the sugar cane plants and the dynamic programming model. A case study for a southeastern Brazil combined alcohol-sugar plant is given.

Title: Flexible response is the key to scottish fabrication strength
Affiliations: James Howden & Co Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Howen, James, James Howden & Co Ltd
Abstract: Glasgow-based James Howden comprises seven operations including the Manufacturing Division, responsible for heavy machining and fabrication, and Howden Tunnelling which manufactures tunnel boring machines. Another principal division within the Group is Howden Sirroco composed of nine operations whose products range from air/gas preheaters for oil or coal-fired power stations to wind park renewable energy projects. Babcock Energy has a diverse product range which includes nuclear and fossil-fuelled steam generators, high-integrity pipework, combustion equipment, milling plant, desox/denox plant, hydro pneumatic equipment and process plant. The company is also a manufacturer of pressure vessels and defence equipment, and is involved in the repair and maintenance of power stations. Motherwell Bridge's main products are pressure vessels, nuclear components, petrochemical storage tanks, LPG tanks & pipelines and heat exchangers, but it also has a substantial involvement in defence contracts and is a major supplier of hull sections for submarines.

Authors: de Pahissa M.H., Pahissa C.J., Ramallo T.
Title: Radioactive waste management strategy in Argentina
Source title: Low and Intermediate Level Radiactive Waste Management
Affiliations: Comision Nacional de Energia Atomica, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: de Pahissa, M.H., Comision Nacional de Energia Atomica, Argentina; Pahissa, C.J., Comision Nacional de Energia Atomica, Argentina; Ramallo, T., Comision Nacional de Energia Atomica, Argentina
Abstract: In this paper, an outline is given concerning the treatment, conditioning, characterization, storage, transport and final disposal of radioactive wastes arising in the fuel cycle, radioisotopes production plant, research centres, etc. The overall strategy of the Argentina program is to plan, develop and implement the technology and provide the facilities for the permanent isolation of commercially generated wastes, with the aim that this wastes not compromise the health and safety of the general public. To implement all these activities, CNEA has established in 1986 a Radioactive Waste Management Program. This long term project is aimed to meeting all the requirements for radioactive waste management of Argentina.

Title: Finite difference model for heat transfer in a stratified thermal storage tank with throughflow
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico, United States
Authors with affiliations: Truman, C.R., Univ of New Mexico, United States; Wildin, M.W., Univ of New Mexico, United States
Abstract: A finite difference model of stratified liquid storage tanks, STRATUNM, is presented. The model accounts for the phenomena which determine the performance of stratified liquid thermal storage tanks including: 1) conduction heat transfer and energy storage within the walls and floor; 2) vertical conduction in the liquid; 3) convection heat transfer between the liquid and the walls and floor; 4) mixing near the inlet diffuser; and 5) heat transfer between the outer surfaces of the tank and the surroundings. The liquid temperature distribution is assumed one-dimensional vertically, while the wall temperature distribution is treated as two-dimensional in the vertical and horizontal directions. Mixing near the inlet diffuser is accounted for by averaging the temperatures of a specified number of elements of liquid near the inlet. Tank characteristics such as wall composition or insulation, or operating conditions such as flow rate or the extent of charging or discharging, are easily varied. Multiple cycles of operation can be simulated by sequential execution of STRATUNM for each charge and discharge in order to model actual tank performance.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Software Package STRATUNM; Stratified Storage Numerical Model; Stratified Thermal Storage Tank; Heat Transfer

Title: Effect of a void on cyclic melting and freezing of an encapsulated PCM
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alexiades, V., Univ of Tennessee, United States
Abstract: A thermal model for cyclic melting/freezing of germanium encapsulated in a spherical pyrolytic graphite shell is developed, that takes into account the presence of a void forming due to the density change upon change of phase. The model is based on an 'enthalpy' formulation of the phase-change process and overall mass balance. The void is considered as a third phase, with zero density but non-zero thermal conductivity. Given the initial state of the system and the boundary condition operating on the outer surface of the shell, the model determines the energy and temperature fields as well as the distribution of the phases.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Graphite; Mathematical Models; Charge-Discharge Cycles; Control-Volume Discretization; Pyrolytic Graphite Shell; Germanium and Alloys

Title: Engineering testing plant for superconducting magnetic energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Phys, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Masuda, M., Natl Lab for High Energy Phys, Tsukuba, Jpn; Shintomi, T., Natl Lab for High Energy Phys, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: A 50-MJ SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage) system is proposed as a testing plant which is the first step towards commercialization for electric utilities. The coil is 5 m in diameter and 2.6 m in height. The size of the coil is the limit of what can be fabricaped in a factory, transported, and assembled on site. The coil is wound in 150 turns with an aluminum stabilized cable of Nb3Sn which may be economical in the future. The main feature of the plant is a soft structure consisting of a bobbinless coil supported with bedrock. The coil structure is analyzed using the finite-element method. One of the purposes of the plant is to accumulate the basic technical data for further SMES plants, for example, data on the fatigue strength of bedrock.
Index Keywords: Electric Coils; Electric Utilities--Energy Storage; Bedrock; Bobbinless Coil; Engineering Testing Plant; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Superconducting Magnets

Title: System engineering the selection of energy storage for emergency power
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerosp, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lacalli, Robert P., Boeing Aerosp, Seattle, WA, USA; Oman, Henry, Boeing Aerosp, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: In a system engineering analysis, the authors evaluated candidate emergency-power systems for a survivable manned underground control center. The first step was to convert all possible variables into cost. For example, the reliability of a set of lead-acid batteries can be improved by buying extra strings of cells. Other characteristics such as safety and schedule risk can be similarly equalized with increased cost. The authors evaluated the risk of not achieving the performance and the pertinent characteristics that the estimated cost was to buy. Each characteristic was assigned a risk number, ranging from one to ten. The risks were weighted from 0.3 to 1.0, considering the consequence of failure. The product of risk number and the weighting factor yields a single risk value. The comparison of the candidate concepts can then be quantified in terms of cost and the risk of not achieving the expected performance or characteristic.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Reliability; Electric Power Systems; Risk Studies; Systems Engineering; Emergency Power; Lead-Acid Batteries; Survivable Manned Underground Control; Energy Storage

Title: Dynamic study of a kinetic energy storage system for a hybrid bus
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Mech, Turin Polytech, Turin,, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Genta, G., Dep of Mech, Turin Polytech, Turin,, Italy
Abstract: The dynamic behavior of a kinetic energy storage unit for vehicular application is investigated. As the flywheel can be considered as a rigid body, the flexural behavior is highly influenced by the compliance of the rolling element bearings, whose nonlinear behavior should not be overlooked. A finite-element model, which includes the nonrotating parts of the machine as well as the flywheel and the elastomeric mounting of the unit on the vehicle, is studied using a nonlinear rotor dynamics code. The results obtained from the dynamic study are used to introduce all the required structural modifications, with emphasis on the choice of the bearings and supports. The response curves of the resulting system show a very steady running of the machine in the whole useful speed range.
Index Keywords: Elastomers; Electric Traction--Flywheel Propulsion; Flywheels; Elastomeric Mounting; Hybrid Bus; Kinetic Energy Storage System; Motor Buses

Authors: Eakin Vickie J., Rodriguez G.Ernest, Paulkovich John
Title: Power conditioning electronics for a 500 Wh inertial energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Eakin, Vickie J., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Rodriguez, G.Ernest, NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Paulkovich, John, NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: A description is given of a pulse-width-modulated buck-boost converter designed to interface a 500 Wh inertial energy storage system operating from 70 to 140 VDC to a constant bus of 150 VDC. Implementation of hysteresis feedback control provides excellent voltage regulation. The design is based on a 300-Wh, 94% Wh efficient prototype and is currently being optimized to yield 97% overall watt-hour efficiency.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Energy Storage; Hysteresis; Satellites--Power Supply; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Buck-Boost Converters; Hysteresis Feedback Control; Inertial Energy Storage; Power Conditioning Electronics; Pulsewidth Modulated Converters; Electric Converters, Power Type

Title: ENSCI, Inc. advanced electrical energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ENSCI Inc
Authors with affiliations: Clough, Thomas J., ENSCI Inc
Abstract: The author discusses the ENSCI advanced electrical energy storage systems, namely, next-generation lead-acid batteries, which are superior to nickel cadmium and conventional state-of-the-art lead-acid batteries. Major advances have resulted in the fields of electrically conductive additives and maintenance-free bipolar lead-acid batteries. The bipolar lead-acid battery offers a near-term, high-performance energy storage system that is cost competitive with conventional lead-acid batteries. It significantly outperforms conventional batteries, yet takes advantage of the existing manufacturing and market infrastructure for lead-acid batteries.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Polymers--Conductive; Bipolar Lead-Acid Battery; Bipolar Polymer Composite Structure; Lead-Acid Batteries; Positive Active Material (PAM); Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Safe long-life high energy stabilized nickel-zinc rechargeable battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrochimica Corp, Menlo Park, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reisner, D., Electrochimica Corp, Menlo Park, CA,, USA; Eisenberg, M., Electrochimica Corp, Menlo Park, CA,, USA
Abstract: A zinc/nickel-oxide rechargeable battery using a chemistry that results in stable performance of the zinc anode without adversely affecting the nickel electrode is presented. The consequence is a major enhancement of the cycle life capability with retention of the markedly high practical energy density (both gravimetric and volumetric) of the Ni/Zn system. Advanced prototype vented prismatic cells of 15-, 60-, and 225-Ah capacities were cycled at an 80% depth of discharge (DOD) and demonstrated a life of 600-1000 cycles with a capacity retention of 55 to 75% depending on conditions of use. Superior low-temperature, high-rate performance has also been obtained. The development and use of a lightweight positive plate substrate material led to a further enhancement of specific energy. A Ni/Zn battery system suitable for near-term practical applications in large-capacity cells, including passenger car and truck SLI batteries as well as long-term deep-cycle applications for electric vehicles, is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Electrolytic Cells--Service Life; Storage Battery Vehicles; Battery Cycle Life; Electric Vehicles; Nickel-zinc Rechargeable Battery; Prismatic Cells; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Applications for nickel-metal hydride batteries
Affiliations: Ovonic Battery Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Orabone, Bill, Ovonic Battery Co, United States
Abstract: The need for high energy density storage batteries has continued to grow in recent years. The push toward portable electronic products - such as cellular telephones, portable computers and cordless tools - has fueled research to investigate new battery systems. The Ovonic Battery Company has developed and is manufacturing a nickel-metal hydride rechargeable battery which is based on its proprietary and patented hydrogen storage materials technology. The use of metal hydrides to replace cadmium as the negative electrode offers several important advantages. These include the following: significantly higher energy density on a weight and volume basis, elimination of toxic and hazardous materials (such as cadmium, lead, lithium and mercury), and the lack of a memory effect.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus; Radio Telephone--Electric Power Supplies; Cellular Telephones; Hydrogen Storage Materials; Nickel/Metal Hydride Batteries; Portable Computers; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Niemeyer W.L., Studer P., Kirk J.A., Anand D.K., Zmood R.B.
Title: High efficiency motor/generator for magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Niemeyer, W.L., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Studer, P., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Kirk, J.A., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Anand, D.K., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA; Zmood, R.B., NASA Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: The authors discuss the theory and design of a brushless direct current motor for use in a flywheel energy storage system. The motor design is optimized for a nominal 4.5-in outside diameter operating within a speed range of 33,000-66,000 revolutions per minute with a 140-V maximum supply voltage. The equations which govern the motor's operation are used to compute a series of acceptable design parameter combinations for ideal operation. Engineering tradeoffs are then performed to minimize the irrecoverable energy loss while remaining within the design constraint boundaries. A final integrated structural design whose features allow it to be incorporated with the 500-Wh magnetically suspended flywheel is presented.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Flywheels--Energy Storage; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Burshless Direct Current Motor; Electrical Machine Design; Flywheel Energy Storage System; Magnetically Suspended Flywheel; Motor Generator; Spacecraft Power; Electric Motors, DC

Authors: Sedgwick L.M., Nordwall H.L., Kaufmann K.J., Johnson S.D.
Title: Brayton cycle solar dynamic heat receiver for space
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sedgwick, L.M., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA; Nordwall, H.L., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA; Kaufmann, K.J., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA; Johnson, S.D., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: The detailed design of a heat receiver developed to meet the requirements of the US space station Freedom, which will be assembled and operated in low earth orbit beginning in the mid-1990's, is described. The heat receiver supplies thermal energy to a nominal 25-kW closed-Brayton-cycle power conversion unit. The receiver employs an integral thermal energy storage system utilizing the latent heat of a eutectic-salt phase-change mixture to store energy for eclipse operation. The salt is contained within a felt metal matrix which enhances heat transfer and controls the salt void distribution during solidification.
Index Keywords: Heat Engines; Heat Transfer; Heating--Heat Storage; Salts--Phase Transitions; Solar Energy; Brayton Cycle; Space Station Freedom; Thermal Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Battery storage units in electricity supply systems
Affiliations: Technische Werke der Stadt Stuttgart, AG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Freund, H., Technische Werke der Stadt Stuttgart, AG, Germany
Abstract: Developments in the field of batteries have prompted electricity supply utilities to reconsider the technical and economic exploitation of electrochemical storage batteries for present-day network applications. The most important evaluation criteria, both in the theoretical investigations and in those projects which have actually been put into practice, are the provision of immediately available energy reserves and control power, and the conversion of stored base load energy into peak power output. Pertinent studies in several countries, are reported, including the first major project of this kind namely the 500 kWh storage unit set up in the USA in 1983; it has generally become known as the BEST installation. This installation works with zinc-chloride batteries. The maximum charge/discharge efficiency is quoted as 64%. Six further installations with storage capacities of 2 MW each have been planned to be subsequently used by other electric supply utilities.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Electrochemistry; Battery Storage Units; Electricity Supply Systems; Zinc-Chloride Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Buffalo Bill Dam modifications. Modification of an existing bureau of reclamation facility to increase power generation
Affiliations: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ruchti, Paul M., U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a joint venture between the United States Bureau of Reclamation and the State of Wyoming to increase the storage capacity and power generation capacity of Buffalo Bill Dam near Cody, Wyoming. Buffalo Bill Dam was originally built in the early 1900's to provide irrigation water for the rapidly growing agricultural industry in the area. The current construction raises the crest of the dam 25 ft, enlarges the spillway, rehabilitates the outlet works, rehabilitates the existing Shoshone Powerplant, pressurizes an existing underground conduit, and adds a new semi-outdoor powerplant and a new energy dissipation structure with space for a future generating unit. Rehabilitation of Shoshone Powerplant involves replacing Unit 3 with a new 3 MW vertical francis-type generating unit. The new powerplant will house three 6 MW vertical francis-type generating units.
Index Keywords: Dams--Modification; Hydraulic Turbines--Francis; Irrigation--Water Supply; Power Plants--Wyoming; Buffalo Bill Dam; Bureau of Reclamation; Shoshone Powerplant; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Title: Switched detector for beam position monitor
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Biscardi, R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Bittner, J.W., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: The NSLS (National Synchrotron Light Source) storage rings use sets of four button electrodes to determine the transverse position of the stored electron beam in the vacuum chamber. By means of GaAs switches, the 211-MHz component of the induced signals on each of the four buttons is measured in turn by a single amplifier-detector channel. These signals are then stored in four sample and hold circuits. The measurement cycle is repeated at a rate of 40 KHz. The required sums and differences of these signals are obtained by analog means. The results are normalized with respect to beam intensity by servoing the gain of the amplifier-detector channel such that the sum of the signals from the four buttons is maintained at a fixed value. The prototype receiver provides ± 20 μm resolution within a 300-Hz bandwidth over a 30-dB dynamic range. The receiver is relatively insensitive to beam energy and to the number of bunches stored in the machine. energy.
Index Keywords: Electrodes; Electron Beams; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide; Amplifier-Detector Channel; Beam Position Monitor; Button Electrodes; NSLS (National Synchrotron Light Source); Accelerators

Authors: Andrianov V.V., Zenkevich V.B., Zheltov V.V., Kopylov S.I.
Title: Effect of sectionalization of superconducting windings of inductive accumulators on stored energy
Authors with affiliations: Andrianov, V.V.; Zenkevich, V.B.; Zheltov, V.V.; Kopylov, S.I.
Abstract: The effect of geometric parameters of solenoidal windings and different methods of sectionalization on stored energy was investigated. The maximum possible increase in stored energy by sectionalization was obtained.
