Authors: Nakhamkin M., Swensen E.C., Hanck J.A., Hoffman P.J., Kadas J.
Title: Site analysis and turbomachinery characteristics for compressed air energy storage plants for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Swensen, E.C., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Hanck, J.A., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Hoffman, P.J., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Kadas, J., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) has been identified as one of Pacific Gas and Electric's near term energy storage options. This paper describes the first steps taken to identify potential sites and to assess the availability of turbomachinery components for these sites. A preliminary investigation was conducted to identify geologies which had good air storage potential. In the PG&E service area, abandoned petroleum gas fields are the dominant and most economical air storage media. For each of the preferred sites, and iterative computer program was utilized to evaluate the various combinations of underground storage and aboveground turbomachinery parameters by adjusting the number of wells required to deliver the total air requirements. This paper presents a brief description of the geological investigation, the method of overall plant optimization, and the reheat turbomachinery train for the various sites.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Plants; Geology; Turbomachinery--Site Selection; Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Pacific Gas and Electric Company; Reheat Turbomachinery Train; Compressed Air

Authors: Niemela Van A., Skutt Glenn R., Urling Audrey M., Chang Yain-Nan, Wilson Thomas G., Owen Jr. Harry A., Wong Ronald C.
Title: Calculating the short-circuit impedances of a multiwinding transformer from its geometry
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Niemela, Van A., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Skutt, Glenn R., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Urling, Audrey M., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Chang, Yain-Nan, Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Wilson, Thomas G., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Owen Jr., Harry A., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA; Wong, Ronald C., Duke Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Durham, NC, USA
Abstract: By considering the set of short-circuit tests which can be performed on a multiwinding transformer, analytical expressions are derived for the leakage inductances between all pairs of transformer windings, expressions which depend only on the winding geometry and the frequency of excitation. For each short-circuit test, a simplified field analysis gives the complete solution for the frequency-independent magnetic field intensity between winding layers, and the frequency-dependent distribution of magnetic field intensity within each layer. Then, for any frequency of interest, the magnetic energy stored in each winding layer and interlayer space is calculated, and the results are summed to give the total energy stored in the entire winding space of the transformer. Finally, the leakage inductance between excited and short-circuited windings is derived from the total stored energy. Experimental data are provided that illustrate the accuracy and the limitations of such leakage-inductance calculations as well as the accuracy of AC-winding-resistance calculations carried out using a similar, previously published method.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters, Static; Electric Windings, Transformer; Magnetic Fields; Energy Storage; Leakage Inductances; Magnetic Field Intensity Distribution; Multiwinding Transformer; Power Dissipation; Short-Circuit Impedances; Electric Transformers

Authors: Singh C., Patton A.D., Kumar Mudit, Wagner H.
Title: Simulation model for reliability evaluation of space station power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Singh, C., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Patton, A.D., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Kumar, Mudit, Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Wagner, H., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: A Monte Carlo simulation program to perform reliability analysis of the space station hybrid power configuration is described. The model allows photovoltaic and solar dynamic power sources to be mixed in varying proportions. This model considers the dependence of reliability and storage characteristics during the sun and eclipse periods. It also considers certain types of common mode failures. This proposed program can model the charging and discharging of energy storage devices in a more realistic manner than that of C. Singh et al. (1987). The results shown do not indicate any significant effect on computed reliability indices by this more refined modeling of charge/discharge of energy storage.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Energy Storage; Mathematical Statistics--Monte Carlo Methods; Reliability; Eclipse Periods; Solar Dynamic Power Sources; Space Stations; Spacecraft

Authors: Kordesch K., Steininger K.-H., Tomantschger K.
Title: Improved bifunctional oxygen (air) electrode for reversible alkaline fuel cell systems and for rechargeable metal-air batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tech Univ Graz, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Kordesch, K., Tech Univ Graz, Graz, Austria; Steininger, K.-H., Tech Univ Graz, Graz, Austria; Tomantschger, K., Tech Univ Graz, Graz, Austria
Abstract: A description is given of electrodes which feature a nickel layer of dual pore structure on the electrolyte side and a PTFE-bonded carbon layer on the oxygen (air) side. During the electrolysis or charging period, the oxygen evolves from the nickel surface and fills the large pores of the porous Ni structure with gas, reducing the ionic pathways to the carbon. During the discharge cycle of the fuel cell, an iron/air or zinc/air cell, the carbon layer operates as a regular oxygen electrode because the pores are refilled. This improved electrode avoids the necessity of using three-electrode systems which have mechanical-electrical switching problems when used in multicell batteries. It is noted that the combination of water electrolysis and hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells looks very attractive for space and energy storage applications. Results of electrode testing are presented.
Index Keywords: Air; Electric Batteries, Secondary--Charging; Electrodes; Oxygen; Alkaline Fuel Cell; Bifunctional Oxygen (Air) Electrode; Hydrogen-Oxygen Fuel Cells; Metal-Air Batteries; Fuel Cells

Authors: Plant David P., Anand Davinder K., Kirk James A., Calomeris Anthony J., Romero Robert L.
Title: Improvements in magnetic bearing performance for flywheel energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Plant, David P., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Calomeris, Anthony J., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Romero, Robert L., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: The authors describe recent developments at the University of Maryland and how they apply to a 500-Wh magnetically suspended flywheel stack energy storage system. Hardware testing results from a stack flywheel energy storage system, improvements in the area of noncontacting displacement transducers, and performance enhancements of magnetic bearings are discussed. The experimental results show that a stack flywheel energy storage system is technologically feasible. Position transducers are available that can be successfully incorporated on the inside of a magnetic bearing and in an off-axis sensing position. Improved understanding of magnetic bearings resulted in enhanced overall magnetic bearing performance.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Transducers; Displacement Transducers; Magnetically Suspended Flywheel; Position Transducers; Stack Flywheel Energy Storage System; Flywheels

Title: Ultralong optical pulse UV-preionized laser
Affiliations: Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, R.S., Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Leopold, K.E., Natl Research Council of Canada,, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: A UV-preionized long-optical-pulse XeCl laser is reported. The laser excitation circuit is based on the magnetic spiker concept. A fast spiker voltage pulse was applied across the laser electrodes to break down the gas mix and initiate a uniform discharge. High-frequency ferrite cores were used to isolate the spiker circuit from the main energy storage circuit, which was comprised of a pulse-forming line (PFL) formed by a number of ceramic capacitors. The laser gas mix was used to hold off the voltage applied to the PFL, so that only a small quantity of ferrite material was requiped to isolate the short-duration (approximately 30-ns) spiker pulse. The collapse of the voltage on the PFL, using a 1-torr HCl, 15-torr Xe, 3-atm Ne gas mix, is shown. The XeCl output energy was 0.5 J in a 500-ns (FWHM) laser pulse. The output beam was very uniform and had a cross section of 3 × 3 cm2. An optical pulse duration of 1 μs (100 mJ) has also been obtained.
Index Keywords: Laser Pulses; Ultraviolet Radiation; Digest of Paper; Gas Mix; Magnetic Spiker Concept; Optical Pulse; Pulse-Forming Line; UV-Preionized Laser; Lasers, Excimer

Title: Compatibility of selected superalloys with molten LiF-CaF2 salt
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cotton, J.D., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA; Sedgwick, L.M., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: A solar dynamic heat receiver incorporating thermal energy storage is being designed and will be fabricated and tested to advance this technology for use on the US space station Freedom. Corrosion testing conducted to determine the most compatible materials for this application is described. Several high-temperature alloys have been tested for compatibility with molten static LiF-CaF2 at 871°C. The alloys displayed good resistance to corrosion by the salt in a vacuum environment. Inconel 617 displayed the least reaction while Haynes 188 was subject to very slight intergranular attack. Several different metal felts were also tested, and no visible signs of interaction were detected.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Heating--Heat Storage; Lithium Compounds; Salts; Solar Energy; Calcium Fluoride; Lithium Fluoride; Superalloys; Spacecraft

Title: Progress toward disposal of LLRW in Canada
Source title: Low and Intermediate Level Radiactive Waste Management
Affiliations: Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Charlesworth, D.H., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Canada
Abstract: Low-level radioactive wastes are managed in Canada currently by interim storage methods operated by the major generators of the wastes. The potential benefits of permanent disposal have led Atomic Energy of Canada Limited to undertake a development and demonstration program to make the transition from storage to disposal at its Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories. The first stages of the demonstration are based on an enhanced version of shallow land burial for the least hazardous wastes, and a unique design of belowground concrete vault. The program includes the development and testing of the auxiliary equipment, processes and procedures necessary to support the disposal system as well as the performance assessment methods and information needed to assure its safety.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Industry--Canada; Low-Level Radioactive Wastes (LLRW); Radioactive Waste Treatment; Waste Disposal Regulations; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Haas R.J., Chawathe A.K., van Ommering G.
Title: Space station battery system design and development
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haas, R.J., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Chawathe, A.K., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; van Ommering, G., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Abstract: The space station electric power system relies on nickel-hydrogen batteries in its photovoltaic power subsystem for energy storage to support eclipse and contingency operations. These 81-Ah batteries have a five-year life capability and are configured as orbital replaceable units (ORUs), permitting replacement of worn-out batteries over the anticipated 30-year station life. The authors describe the baseline design and the development plans for the battery assemblies, the battery ORUs, and the battery system. Key elements reviewed are the cells, mechanical and thermal design of the assembly, ORU approach and interfaces, and electrical design of the battery system. The anticipated operational approach is discussed, covering the expected performance as well as the processor-controlled charge management and discharge load allocation techniques. Development plans cover verification of materials, cells, assemblies, and ORUs, as well as system-level tests and analyses.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Storage; Hydrogen; Nickel and Alloys; Photovoltaic Cells; Contingency Operations; Nickel-Hydrogen Batteries; Orbital Replaceable Units; Space Stations; Spacecraft

Authors: Jayaraman Chaitanya P., Kirk James A., Anand Davinder K.
Title: Effect of rotor dynamics on a flywheel stack energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jayaraman, Chaitanya P., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: The authors present a dynamic analysis of a magnetic bearing stack system consisting of a single flywheel supported by two magnetic bearings. To model the system, the dynamic equations of a magnetically suspended flywheel were derived. The four control systems controlling the four degrees of freedom of the stack were incorporated into the model. The resulting dynamic equations are represented as first-order differential equations in a matrix form. A computer simulation program was then used to simulate the working of the magnetic bearing stack. Real-time plots from the simulation are used to show the effect of dynamic coupling on torque response. Frequency response is used to determine the resonance frequencies of the stack system. It is found that system stability depends on flywheel speed. On the basis of the above results, suggestions are made for improving stability and allowing the stack to be spun beyond 60,000 rpm.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Dynamic Coupling; Flywheel Stack Energy Storage; Magnetic Bearing Stack System; Magnetically Suspended Flywheel; Flywheels

Authors: Sauerbrey R., Kubodera S., Warwar G., Millar P., Wisoff P.J.
Title: Ionic excimers
Affiliations: Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sauerbrey, R., Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA; Kubodera, S., Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA; Warwar, G., Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA; Millar, P., Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA; Wisoff, P.J., Rice Univ, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: It has been proposed recently to extend the excimer laser concept to VUV and XUV wavelengths by considering excimer or excimerlike transitions in ionic molecules. Molecular systems, in particular excimers, exhibit lower gain cross sections than atomic systems, because of their broader emission bandwidth. Such systems can, therefore, offer tunability and probably better energy storage capacity than atomic systems. Spectroscopic and kinetic results pertaining to these new ionic excimer laser experiments are discussed.
Index Keywords: Ions; Molecules; Digest of Paper; Excimerlike Transitions; Ionic Excimers; Ionic Molecules; Lasers, Excimer

Title: Design considerations with respect to long-term diesel saving in wind/diesel plants
Affiliations: The Norwegian Research Inst of, Energy Supply A/S
Authors with affiliations: Skarstein, Oyvin, The Norwegian Research Inst of, Energy Supply A/S; Uhlen, Kjetil, The Norwegian Research Inst of, Energy Supply A/S
Abstract: This report deals with long-term performance model simulations of wind/diesel systems. The model is called VINDEC and is developed at the Norwegian research Institute of Energy Supply, as a part of the Norwegian Wind Energy research Programme. The model is time-series based and can handle the usual configuration of wind turbines, diesel start/stop, dump load and energy storage. The time constant of the energy storage must be greater than the time step of the input wind and load data. This is typically 10 minutes, which makes the storage a long-term type, rather than short-term. The main results of the study show that oversized WTGs and splitting the diesel power between two smaller diesels give the best performance with respect to diesel fuel saving. Savings of the order 50% to 70% can be achieved. Energy prices favour wind/diesel to pure diesel for Norwegian applications for annual average wind speeds above approx 7-8 m/s.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Diesel Electric Power Plants; Diesel Fuels--Fuel Economy; Mathematical Models; Wind Turbines; Energy Conservation; Energy Storage; Vindec Simulation Model; Wind Turbine Generators; Wind/Diesel Power Plants; Wind Power; Computer Simulation; hybrid; Hybrid Diesel; Wind Power-Systems

Title: Space-based multimegawatt turbine power: A critical comparison against alternative open-cycle power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kotas, J.F., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: The author presents the results of a study comparing an advanced technology and current state-of-the-art space-based turboalternator open-cycle chemical combustion power system to six alternative open-cycle power systems in the multimegawatt power range. The alternative systems included an open-cycle fuel cell thermal storage system, mechanical rotational energy storage (flywheel) system, a potassium-Rankine reactor no energy storage system, and a magnetohydrodynamic system. Power management and distribution performance was considered for all systems. The comparison was based on specific power and specific energy extraction as a function of operation duration basis. The results indicate that no one power system is the best or most weight effective over a wide range of operating times. It is concluded that power system selection for a particular mission is strongly influenced by operation duration. In general, the advanced and current technology turbine systems and the 100-MW magnetohydrodynamic power systems have the highest specific power and energy extractions. Both advanced and current technology turbine systems exhibit the highest specific power and energy extractions past 800 s of operating time.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Magnetohydrodynamic Converters; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Chemical Combustion Power Systems; Open Cycle Power Systems; Turbogenerators

Authors: Gay R.L., Lee W.T., Pard A.G., Springer T.H.
Title: Thermal cycling tests of energy storage canisters for space applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gay, R.L., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Lee, W.T., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Pard, A.G., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Springer, T.H., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: Bench-scale tests were performed in which sealed metal canisters containing energy storage salts were thermally cycled from a state of predominantly molten material to a state of almost all frozen material. Two salt-metal systems were studied: CaF2-LiF eutectic salt contained in Haynes 188 and pure LiOH contained in nickel-201 (Ni-201). These salt-metal systems correspond to two solar dynamic thermodynamic systems: the closed Brayton cycle and the organic Rankine cycle, respectively. The heating-cooling cycle times were set to match a low Earth orbit of 58 min on-sun and 36 min off-sun. The Haynes 188 canisters were tested for up to 3245 cycles at 5084 h of testing; the Ni-201 canisters were tested for up to 12,504 cycles at 19,950 h of testing. Very good materials compatibility was observed for both salt-metal systems. Gravimetric corrosion rates for Haynes 188 of 0.01 ± 0.002 mm/year were measured. Interaction of the LiOH with the nickel was limited to a very small region at the salt-metal interface where a protective oxide film formed. These tests verified the long-term viability of using metal containment vessels for storage of inorganic salt phase change materials.
Index Keywords: Salts--Phase Transitions; Thermodynamic Properties; Brayton Cycle; Energy STorage Canisters; Rankine Cycle; Thermal Cycling; Energy Storage

Authors: Tanaka Kotaro, Abe Yoshiyuki, Takahashi Yoshio, Kamimoto Masayuki, Tanatsugu Nobuhiro
Title: Latent thermal storage for space solar dynamic power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Kotaro, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Abe, Yoshiyuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Takahashi, Yoshio, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kamimoto, Masayuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Tanatsugu, Nobuhiro, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: Fundamental research on latent thermal storage for space energy applications is presented. Materials studies for this objective are described, and advanced concepts for thermal storage in a solar receiver are considered. Particular emphasis is placed on the phase change behavior of containerized material, which is one of the most critical problems not only for the solar receiver but also in the solar dynamic power system itself. To obtain experimental information on this subject, a solidification experiment under microgravity using a trajectory flight sounding rocket has been designed. The short-period experiment is described in detail.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Rockets and Missiles--Design; Latent Thermal Storage; Microgravity; Spacecraft

Authors: Asper H.K., Von Burg P., Grieder T., Riesen H.J., Widmer J.
Title: Application oriented flywheel energy storage system research at the ETH-Zurich
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Asper, H.K., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Von Burg, P., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Grieder, T., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Riesen, H.J., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Widmer, J., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz
Abstract: The authors present a flywheel system research philosophy and design strategy for advanced fiber composite flywheel energy storage systems. Key technologies for application-oriented flywheel system development are presented. The key areas include: fiber composite rotor winding technology, rotor structure analysis, rotor dynamic system analysis, high-speed electrical machines with power electronics control, prototype system hardware (60 kW/500 Wh), a noncontacting high-speed measurement and data retrieval system, and future flywheel system applications.
Index Keywords: Fiber Composite Flywheel Energy Storage; High-Speed Electrical Machines; High-Speed Measurement; Power Electronics Control; Rotor Dynamic System; Rotor Winding; Electric Machinery; Electric Traction--Flywheel Propulsion; Flywheels

Title: Clathrate heat pump heating system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Najafi, M., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, United States; Schaetzle, W.J., Univ of Southwestern Louisiana, United States
Abstract: A closed-loop heating system utilizing clathrate as a storage medium has been operated to verify system operation and to evaluate the performance of cycle components. The system operated with direct contact heat transfer between the refrigerant, water, and clathrate. A heating cycle test facility capable of being reversed between heating and cooling utilizing a common thermal energy storage system has been developed to operate as a clathrate heat pump heating system. Experimental runs have been performed utilizing basic Refrigerant 12 clathrate as a storage medium. Algorithms have been implemented to provide energy balances and to compute the cycle overall coefficient of performance for each run. The results show that the system operates effectively with direct contact heat transfer between clathrate or water and refrigerant. With or without agitation, the system operates with zero solid formation on the cooling coil throughout the course of clathrate solidification for all of the runs.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Contacts; Refrigerants--Thermodynamic Properties; Thermodynamics--Optimization; Clathrate Refrigerant; Cooling Storage; Energy Recovery; Enthalpy Equations; Heat Pump Systems

Title: Utilization of refinery wastes for energy
Affiliations: Outokumpu Oy Engineering, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Astrom, L., Outokumpu Oy Engineering, Finland; Sumanen, P., Outokumpu Oy Engineering, Finland
Abstract: Oil refineries, harbors, and some other service facilities have a common problem: the disposal of miscellaneous wastes containing oil. Common to these are the difficulty of handling and burning wastes due to their often very heterogeneous mechanical properties and problematic composition. Neste Oy of Finland has recently built comprehensive facilities to tackle this problem. These include a new system for collecting and pretreating of waste and a very flexible fluidized bed combustion system with complete heat recovery. Although the heating value of the waste is low, it has an economical value. Through storage and combination of different wastes a steady source of process steam is made available from the plant, thus replacing more valuable fuels. The plant also comprises a desulfurization system.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution - Control; Combustors - Fluidized Bed; Industrial Wastes - Treatment; Waste Disposal - Incineration; Waste Heat Utilization; Emission Control; Oil-Containing Waste Disposal; Petroleum Refineries

Title: Simulation technique for control systems with multiple interrated nonlinear phenomena and energy storage elements
Affiliations: Michigan Technol Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, Houghton, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, Paul H., Michigan Technol Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, Houghton, MI, USA; Angeli, Paul, Michigan Technol Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, Houghton, MI, USA
Abstract: A method is described for the systematic development of computer models for control systems with complex relationships between multiple nonlinear phenomena and energy-storage elements. The specific example of an electromechanical position control system, with consideration of interrelated actions that include static friction, Coulomb friction, backlash, and a significant inertial load, is considered. The use of piecewise-linear models provides an extensive set of operational modes, but methodology is presented for consideration of the conditions for all possible changes of mode and the actions that accompany each change. Simulation results are presented.
Index Keywords: Control, Mechanical Variables--Position; Energy Storage; Backlash; Coulomb Friction; Electromechanical Position Control System; Multiple Interrated Nonlinear Phenomena; Static Friction; Control Systems

Title: Lead acid battery. 130 years old and still improving
Authors with affiliations: Culpin, Barry
Abstract: The lead acid battery has passed its hundredth birthday, but it is still alive and well. As it is a mature technology, major advances such as recombination systems are rare. However, the battery's versatility makes it a viable energy source for a 40MWh load levelling system, or for a 3Wh consumer electronics battery. It should continue to meet changing power storage requirements for many years to come.
Index Keywords: Economics; Lead Acid Battery; Load Levelling; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Beam quality in single bunch mode of UVSOR ring
Affiliations: Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Yonehara, H., Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaka, Jpn; Kasuga, T., Inst for Molecular Sci, Okazaka, Jpn
Abstract: The UVSOR storage ring is a synchrotron radiation light source for studies of molecular science and its related fields. The radio frequency of the ring is 90 MHz and its harmonic number is 16. The pulsed light is supplied with a period of 11 ns, when all buckets of the ring are filled. The storage ring can be operated in the single bunch mode when a longer pulse period is required. In this mode, the period of the pulsed light is 180 ns, which is the revolution period of the beam in the ring. The single bunch is produced in the booster synchrotron, and it is transferred to only one bucket of the ring. The usual impurity is 1 × 10-4 just after injection at the beam energy of 600 MeV. Bunch lengthening and widening were also measured in this mode. A coupling impedance for the ring of 4 Ω was obtained with this measurement.
Index Keywords: Light Sources; Molecules; Synchrotron Radiation; Beam Bunching; UVSOR Storage Ring; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: Modelling and analysis of lead acid battery operation
Affiliations: Ecole des Mines de Paris, Valbonne, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Mayer, D., Ecole des Mines de Paris, Valbonne, Fr; Biscaglia, S., Ecole des Mines de Paris, Valbonne, Fr
Abstract: A model of the lead-acid battery is presented based on a simple description of electrochemical reactions. Models of the electromotive force, the internal resistance, and the gassing phenomenon are detailed. Good agreement between simulation and measurement has led to the validation of a model for discharge and for the charge preceeding gassing at constant temperature. As regards the calculation of the state of charge, modeling of the gas emission is necessary to minimize drift over a long period of operation.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Electrolytic; Electrochemistry--Mathematical Models; Power Generation--Solar Energy; Electricity Storage; Electrochemical Reactions; Lead Acid Battery; Solar Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Bents David J., Lu Cheng Y.
Title: Estimated performance and future potential of solar dynamic and photovoltaic power systems for selected LEO and HEO missions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bents, David J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Lu, Cheng Y., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: Solar photovoltaic and thermal dynamic power systems for application to selected low-earth-orbit (LEO) and high-earth-orbit (HEO) missions are characterized in the regime 7 to 35 kWe. Input parameters to the characterization are varied to correspond to anticipated introduction of improved or new technologies. A comparative assessment is made of the two power system types for emerging technologies in cells and arrays, energy storage, optical surfaces, heat engines, thermal energy storage and thermal management. The assessment is made to common ground rules and assumptions. The four missions (space station, sun-synchronous, Van Allen belt and geosynchronous earth orbit) are representative of the anticipated range of multikilowatt earth-orbit missions. The results give the expected performance, mass and drag of multikilowatt earth-orbiting solar power systems and show how the overall system figure of merit will improve as new component technologies are incorporated.
Index Keywords: Photovoltaic Cells--Space Applications; Solar Energy--Space Applications; High Earth Orbit Missions; Low Earth Orbit Missions; Photovoltaic Power Systems; Satellites

Authors: Lovgren Jack G., Murdock C.R., Teofilo Vincent L.
Title: Electrical power system design of high orbit satellites
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lovgren, Jack G., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Murdock, C.R., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Teofilo, Vincent L., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Abstract: The electrical power subsystem (EPS) of high-orbit satellites, including geosynchronous earth orbit (GEO) satellites, have been designed to meet the requirements of power (4-6 kWe), lifetime (7-10 yr) and solar eclipse periods. Additional requirements imposed upon the EPS include fault-tolerant operation with autonomous control and fault correction. A description is given of overall design of such a satellite's EPS including its power source, power conditioning, control, distribution and energy storage equipment, and operational characteristics. Emphasis is placed on the fault-tolerance aspects of the design.
Index Keywords: Autonomous Control; Geosynchronous Earth Orbit (GEO) Satellites; High-Orbit Satellites; Power Conditioning; Solar Eclipse; Satellites

Title: Equilibrium values between intrabeam scattering and electron cooling
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Manne Siegbahn Institute of Physics, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Simonsson, A., Manne Siegbahn Institute of Physics, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: A simple relation which gives equilibrium emittances between intrabeam scattering and cooling in low energy storage rings is deduced from computer simulations. The lattice dependence is described with a constant which is independent of, e.g., energy, charge or cooling times. Different plots for CRYRING are shown. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Beam Dynamics; Ions; Cryring; Intrabeam Scattering; Ion Beams

Authors: Boersma M.D., McDonell W.R., Goodlett C.B., Thomas S.D.
Title: Long-term strategy for management of Savannah River Site defense high-level nuclear wastes (U)
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Fuel Management
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boersma, M.D., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, United States; McDonell, W.R., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, United States; Goodlett, C.B., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, United States; Thomas, S.D., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, United States
Abstract: The Defense Waste Processing Facility (DWPF) nearing completion at the Savannah River Site (SRS) is the lead installation in the U.S. Department of Energy program for ending interim storage and achieving permanent disposal of large quantities of defense high-evel nuclear wastes in the United States. At projected processing rates, the DWPF will convert the existing SRS inventory of aqueous high-level wastes to solid glass form in steel canisters in about 20 years, with process adjustments required in a terminal campaign to handle residual waste components. Following completion of the existing inventory workoff, significantly modified facilities and procedures will be needed to accommodate the down-sized waste output of a single reactor (NPR) operation. The SRS program at this time, in contrast to the other defense waste as well as commercial waste programs, will be dominated by requirements of a small-scale technology, suitable for processing low volumes of wastes as-generated in relatively high-activity form.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Defense Waste Processing Facility (DWPF); High-Level Nuclear Wastes; Savannah River Waste Management; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Exergy analysis of a reactive hydrogen-oxygen-steam cycle for peak-load power generation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Energy, Univ of Florence,, Florence, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Stecco, Sergio S., Dep of Energy, Univ of Florence,, Florence, Italy; Manfrida, Giampaolo, Dep of Energy, Univ of Florence,, Florence, Italy
Abstract: A steam power plant integrated with a hydrogen-oxygen loop provided for energy storage is examined. A thermodynamic analysis of a reactive hydrogen-oxygen-steam cycle is performed by means of the exergy method. One advantage of this methodology is that different types of losses (mixing, friction, heat transfer, combustion chemical reaction) can be effectively compared. Among the losses examined, those connected with the chemical reaction have proven to be of overriding importance. On the whole, the proposed cycle can achieve efficiencies of nearly 50% with existing technologies.
Index Keywords: Combustors; Energy Storage; Hydrogen; Oxygen; Power Generation; Exergy Analysis; Hydrogen-Oxygen Loop; Parametric Analysis; Steam Power Plants

Title: Magnetodynamic storage unit - A flywheel storage system for peak levelling, voltage and frequency regulation in island networks
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Heidelberg, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger; Reiner, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger
Abstract: The authors describe the magnetodynamic storage unit (MDS), a flywheel storage system. Tests began in 1985 on a storage unit with a power of 160 kW and 2.75 kWh of stored energy. This was installed in a diesel electric public transport bus. A larger storage unit with 20 kWh of energy and 700 kW of power is now under construction and is expected to be put into operation this year. Possible applications of this storage unit for voltage and frequency regulation in island networks are described. In particular, the advantages of combining a storage unit with batteries (hybrid system) and of cogeneration systems are discussed.
Index Keywords: Cogeneration Plants; Motor Buses; Island Networks; Magnetodynamic Storage; Public Transport Bus; Flywheels

Authors: Flanz J.B., Jacobs K.D., Biron R.D., Ihloff E., Kowalski S., Radouch Z., Russ T., Saab A., Sapp W.W., Williamson C., Zolfaghari A., Zumbro J.
Title: MIT-Bates South Hall Ring
Affiliations: MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Flanz, J.B., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Jacobs, K.D., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Biron, R.D., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Ihloff, E., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Kowalski, S., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Radouch, Z., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Russ, T., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Saab, A., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Sapp, W.W., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Williamson, C., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Zolfaghari, A., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA; Zumbro, J., MIT, Bates Linear Accel Cent,, Middleton, MA, USA
Abstract: The MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Center is in the process of constructing an electron storage ring. The 190-m ring will be used for internal target experiments with stored beams. It will also be used as a pulse stretcher to provide external beams with high duty factors. The present design incorporates a low beta region with a βx of 1 m and a 4.5 m-space between ring quadrupoles at the internal target location. The ring will contain up to 80 mA using two turn injection. Extraction using one-half integer resonance will produce up to 50 μA with a duty factor over 80%. Injection will occur at 1 kHz. Design extracted beam properties include an energy spread of 0.04% and emittance as low as 0.01 π mm-mr.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Beam Injection; Electromagnets; Beam Extraction; Electron Storage Ring; MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Center; MIT-Bates South Hall Ring; Pulse Stretcher; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Buldini Pier Luigi, Laghi Antonio, Saxena Praveen, Sharma Jawahar Lal, Toponi Alessandro
Title: Influence of traces of impurities in the lead-acid battery electrolytes
Affiliations: CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Buldini, Pier Luigi, CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy; Laghi, Antonio, CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy; Saxena, Praveen, CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy; Sharma, Jawahar Lal, CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy; Toponi, Alessandro, CNR-Lamel, Lab Analisi Chimica, Materiali, Bologna, Italy
Abstract: The authors describe a study of impurities in the electrolytes of lead-acid storage batteries for solar photovoltaic power systems. They concentrate on the determination of copper, cadmium, lead, silicate, phosphate, acetate, arsenate, chloride, formate, and nitrate in the lead-acid battery electrolytes after a known number of charging/discharges cycles. Different experimental techniques were used to analyze the various ionic species present in the battery electrolyte.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Electrochemistry; Solar Power Plants--Energy Storage; Battery Electrolytes; Ionic Species; Remote Power Systems; Solar Photovoltaic Power; Electrolytes

Title: Fabrication considerations for new generation spent fuel and waste shipping packages
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: General Atomics, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burgoyne, R.M., General Atomics, United States
Abstract: Newly instituted development programs sponsored by the Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Commercial Waste Management (OCRWM) will lead to the deployment of a new generation of shipping casks. These new casks will be used in support of the Federal Repository and Monitored Retrieval Storage System (MRS) and will operate well into the next century. The challenge of the development program involves minimizing overall system cost. This can be accomplished by maximizing capacity and improving operational efficiency while maintaining licensibility and not compromising public safety. This challenge is being met by the application of advanced design, analysis and materials technology. To be successful in delivering advanced cask systems, we must achieve advances in fabrication technology commensurate with the demands of new design and materials technology. This paper discusses some of the fabrication considerations associated with the new generation shipping systems.
Index Keywords: Materials - Evaluation; Nuclear Reactors - Spent Fuels; Packaging - Fabrication; Radioactive Wastes - Packaging; Structural Design; Cask Configuration; Licensing; Public Safety; Quality Assurance; Shipping Casks; Radioactive Materials

Authors: Mahmoud Kamel G., Ball Herbert D.
Title: Liquid desiccant systems for solar cooling applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mahmoud, Kamel G., Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA; Ball, Herbert D., Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Abstract: The authors present the analysis of a solar thermal energy system formed by the coupling of a flat-plate solar collector, an auxiliary thermal energy source, and a commercially available liquid desiccant system in a single loop. The desiccant system consists of a regenerator, a conditioner, and a storage tank (sump). The hourly ambient air temperature and humidity ratio and the incident solar radiation can be read from ASHRAE Weather Year for Energy Calculation tapes. The model can predict the hourly system outlet air temperature and humidity ratio, the hourly thermal energy availability, and the hourly LiCl-water solution temperature and concentration in the sump. The study shows the infeasibility of using a flat-plate solar collector for regenerating LiCl-water solution in such a system configuration.
Index Keywords: Heat Exchangers--Regenerators; Lithium Compounds--Solutions; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Water; Liquid Dessicant Systems; Solar Thermal Energy System; Sump; Air Conditioning

Authors: Kirk James A., Anand Davinder K.
Title: Overview of a flywheel stack energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: It is noted that the concept of storing electrical energy in rotating flywheels provides an attractive substitute to batteries. To realize these advantages the critical technologies of rotor design, composite materials, magnetic suspension, and high efficiency motor/generators are reviewed. The magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system, currently under development at the University of Maryland, consisting of a family of interference assembled rings, is presented as an integrated solution for energy storage. There are no spokes or shaft attachments to the system; the rotor is magnetically suspended using two pancake magnetic bearings. The pancake magnetic bearings use a combination of permanent magnets and electromagnets, thereby providing for a net control force on the flywheel which is a linear function of the electromagnet coil current. In addition, the permanent magnets carry a major portion of the axial loading, and because of the permanent magnets the power consumption of the magnetic bearing is exceptionally low.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Electric Energy Storage; Electromagnets; Magnets; Electromagnet Coil Current; Interference Assembled Rings; Pancake Magnetic Bearings; Permanent Magnets; Rotating Flywheels; Stack Energy Storage System; Flywheels

Authors: Mashiko K., Okiai R., Mochizuki M., Ryokai K., Tsuchiya F., Fukuda M.
Title: Development of an artificial permafrost storage using heat pipes
Affiliations: Fujikura Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Mashiko, K., Fujikura Ltd; Okiai, R., Fujikura Ltd; Mochizuki, M., Fujikura Ltd; Ryokai, K., Fujikura Ltd; Tsuchiya, F., Fujikura Ltd; Fukuda, M., Fujikura Ltd
Abstract: We have developed a heat pipe type artificial permafrost storage system by utilizing cold energy at winter time. At first, basic tests of forming frozen soil using a 8 m length corrugated heat pipe were carried out. Thereby, it was found that the temperatures of the heat pipe became uniform and the surrounding soil could be frozen uniformly. In December 1987, an experimental plant for proof tests was constructed in Hokkaido. Around the storage facility, heat pipes were installed into the ground at the intervals of 0.5 meter and the condensing sections were installed in atmosphere. In winter of the year, frozen soil was smoothly formed. At the end of January, 2 m thick frozen soil layer was completed. Even in July, the soil temperature was kept about -1°C and the storeroom temperature was also kept about 3 to 4°C. This cold storage by means of heat pipes can be practical.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Soils--Frozen; Artificial Permafrost Storage; Frozen Soil Formation; Heat Pipe Cold Energy Storage; Heat Pipes

Title: Downsized superconducting magnetic energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Combustion Eng Inc, Windsor, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, David N., Combustion Eng Inc, Windsor, CT, USA
Abstract: Scaled-down superconductive magnetic energy storage systems (DSMES) and superconductive magnetic energy power sources (SMEPS) are proposed for residential, commercial/retail, industrial off-peak and critical services, telephone and other communication systems, computer operations, power back-up/energy storages, power sources for space stations, and in-field military logistics/communication systems. Recent advances in high-Tc superconducting materials technology are analyzed. DSMES/SMEPS concepts are presented, and design, materials, and systems requirements are discussed. Problems ar identified, and possible solutions are offered. Comparisons are made with mechanical and primary and secondary energy storage and conversion systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Superconducting Magnets; Magnetic Energy Power Sources; Magnetic Energy Storage; Military Logistics; Secondary Energy Storage; Space Stations; Superconducting Materials

Authors: Winter Christopher P., Teofilo Vincent L.
Title: Electrical power system trade analyses for space surveillance satellites
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Winter, Christopher P., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Teofilo, Vincent L., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Abstract: The results of the trade studies performed to select the power source for a typical surveillance satellite, as well as for compatible power-conditioning equipment, power control and distribution architecture, and energy storage components, are described. The three sources selected (a photovoltaic concentrator and two fission reactors, STAR-C and SNAP-DYN) were evaluated against all these criteria and for their compatibility with payload operation. The solar array meets all the constraints but may not meet some of the survivability requirements. The reactors are compact, but relatively heavy, and their newer, untried technology increases cost and risk. However, it appears likely that with development the STAR-C will meet the weight limits.
Index Keywords: Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells--Arrays; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Fission Reactors; Power-Conditioning Equipment; Space Surveillance Satellites; Surveillance Satellite; Satellites

Authors: Takashima Koichiro, Kunimoto Asao, Kagawa Hiroshi, Matsui Kazumasa, Nomura Eiichi, Kita Akira, Iijima Shigeru, Kato Takehiko, Matsuo Yasushi, Nakayama Taesuke, Sera Yousuke
Title: Operation of a pilot production plant for manufacturing Na/S cells for a 1 MW/8 MWh battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The installation and operation of pilot production lines at both the Yuasa Battery Company and the NGK Spark Plug Company for manufacturing 300-Ah Na-S cells and beta″-alumina tubes at a rate corresponding to 50 cells per day is discussed. A proposed plan for assembling these cells into 20 thermally insulating casings to make up a 1-MW/8-MWh Na-S battery energy storage system to be tested at a utility site is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Alumina--Processing; Electric Energy Storage; Electrolytic Cells--Manufacture; Battery Energy Storage; Beta Alumina Tubes; High Power Batteries; Sodium Sulfur Cells; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Central-station photovoltaic plant with energy storage for utility peak load leveling
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wyoming, Dep of Electr Eng,, Laramie, WY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chowdhury, Badrul H., Univ of Wyoming, Dep of Electr Eng,, Laramie, WY, USA
Abstract: The impact of photovoltaic (PV) power generation with energy storage on the electric utility's load shape for load leveling purposes is explored. Results show that utilities employing battery storage for peak load shaving might benefit from use of photovoltaic power, the extent of its usefulness being dependent on the specific load shapes as well as the photovoltaic array orientations. Typical utility load shapes both in the eastern and in the western parts of the US are examined for this purpose. Although photovoltaic power generation seems to have a bigger impact on the load of the western utility, utilities in both areas will experience considerable savings on the size of the battery system required to shave the peak loads and also in the off-peak base capacity required to charge the battery.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation; Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Electric Utilities; Photovoltaic Array Orientations; Utility Peak Load Leveling; Photovoltaic Cells

Authors: Aristov Yu.I., Fiksel A.I., Parmon V.N.
Title: Comparative characteristics of solar catalytic reactors with transparent and opaque radiation-receiving surfaces
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Aristov, Yu.I.; Fiksel, A.I.; Parmon, V.N.
Abstract: The authors investigated the thermal properties of a model solar catalytic reactor with transparent and opaque walls of the solar-energy receiver.

Authors: Tanabe T., Watanabe T., Honma T.
Title: Electron cooler at INS
Affiliations: Inst for Nucl Study, Univ of Tokyo,, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tanabe, T., Inst for Nucl Study, Univ of Tokyo,, Tokyo, Jpn; Watanabe, T., Inst for Nucl Study, Univ of Tokyo,, Tokyo, Jpn; Honma, T., Inst for Nucl Study, Univ of Tokyo,, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: An electron cooling system for compressing phase spaces occupied by the ion beams stored in the heavy-ion synchrotron-storage ring TARN II has been developed. The cooling device was designed to cool ion beams up to the energy of 200 MeV/u, which requires an equivalent electron energy of 110 keV. All the components of the device were assembled, and the first electron beam was obtained in the complete cooler. The overall design of the electron cooling system is described, and the results of the electron beam experiments are presented.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Electron Guns; Ion Beams--Cooling; Electron Beam Experiments; Electron Cooling System; Accelerators

Authors: Tominaga Takahisa, Takashiba Osamu, Shibazaki Makoto, Fujita Hideki, Goto Masuo, Hasegawa Hiroaki, Tsuchiya Kazuhiro, Ishigaki Yukio, Toita Hirotoshi
Title: Power control experiments using a PWM GTO thyristor converter in a 1 MJ superconducting magnetic energy storage system
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tominaga, Takahisa, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Takashiba, Osamu, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Shibazaki, Makoto, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Fujita, Hideki, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Goto, Masuo, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Hasegawa, Hiroaki, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Tsuchiya, Kazuhiro, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Ishigaki, Yukio, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn; Toita, Hirotoshi, Chubu Electric Power Co Inc, Nagoya, Jpn
Abstract: The outline of a 1-MJ superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system and a p-q (active power-reactive power) control system using a pulse-width modulation (PWM) gate turn-off (GTO) thyristor converter is described. Results of p-q decoupling control experiments are also given. A plan is for investigating the attainment of transient and dynamic stability through the use of simulated transmission lines is described.
