Title: Harnessing wind power
Affiliations: Dep of Engineering, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jefferson, C.M., Dep of Engineering, United Kingdom
Abstract: A great deal of research and design work has been devoted to optimising the performance of wind turbine. As these turbines are commissioned, the problem is then how to harness the power effectively, particularly in turbulent wind conditions. Unfortunately, the wind power is not available to demand as is hydro power but fluctuates unpredictably due to the turbulence. This paper compares three broad approaches to effective use of the power, namely, grid connection, load control and wind turbine control. The role of energy storage in balancing supply with demand is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric Generators, Asynchronous; Electric Power Systems--Control; Energy Storage; Fuel Economy; Wind Turbines--Control; Load Management; Wind Power; Control Systems; Power Generation; Wind Turbines

Authors: Wunderlich Walter O., Giles James E.
Title: Quantifying uncertainty in hydropower planning
Authors with affiliations: Wunderlich, Walter O.; Giles, James E.
Abstract: Power system operators must deal with various types of uncertainties. Some are related to inputs, such as system load and water supply, while others pertain to the system itself, such as available capacity. The system load can change almost continuously, while its capacity and energy change with power unit availability and streamflow. According to the nature of the uncertainties they are treated differently. Ways of dealing with uncertainties are discussed. They affect system scheduling, generation costs and reliability. Examples include loss-of-load probability, expected value of hydro energy-in-storage, minimum required energy-in-storage, expected future cost and expected energy unserved.
Index Keywords: Economics--Analysis; Electric Power Plants--Equipment; Electric Power Systems--Loss of Load Probability; Hydrology; Energy Unserved; Future Cost; Hydro Energy in Storage; Minimum Required Energy in Storage; Uncertainty Analysis; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Negahban Mehrdad, Chen Ching-Siang, White Bert, Ouellette Maurice, Germer Warren
Title: DSP-based watthour meter
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Solid-State Circuits Conference
Affiliations: Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Negahban, Mehrdad, Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA; Chen, Ching-Siang, Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA; White, Bert, Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA; Ouellette, Maurice, Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA; Germer, Warren, Silicon Syst Inc, Tustin, CA, USA
Abstract: A high-accuracy, three-phase electronic watthour meter, implemented in a 3.5-μm double-poly CMOS technology, is described. It receives inputs from voltage and current sensors, measures both real and reactive power, and outputs pulses whose rate is proportional to energy flow. The meter is accurate to 0.3% of reading over 3.5 decades. A block diagram is presented, and the device functions are described. The DSP (digital signal processor) is developed as a macro cell with customized ROM/RAM. It has a 16-bit data path which can shift N bits and accumulate in one clock cycle. Both scalar and variable multiplications are possible.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital; Integrated Circuits; Sensors; Signal Processing--Digital Techniques; Current Sensors; Customized ROM/RAM; Digest of Paper; Double-Poly CMOS Technology; Electronic Watthour Meter; Macro Cell; Watt Hour Meters

Authors: Thomas William C., Nelson Douglas J., Waksman David
Title: Freeze protection of solar irradiated paved surfaces using integral phase-change material
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Mech Eng Dep, Blacksburg, VA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, William C., Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Mech Eng Dep, Blacksburg, VA,, USA; Nelson, Douglas J., Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Mech Eng Dep, Blacksburg, VA,, USA; Waksman, David, Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Mech Eng Dep, Blacksburg, VA,, USA
Abstract: A thermal model and calculated results for applications of phase-change thermal energy storage to delay the onset of ice formation on pavement systems are presented. In the proposed approach, the pavement would be a passive solar collector, with enhanced integral storage, exposed to daytime irradiance and diurnal temperature cycles. The systems considered are typical bridge decks and paved runways. A mixture of 10-20% tetradecane paraffin, which melts at about 5.5°C, is considered to be impregnated in conventional concrete to enhance thermal storage capacity. The model is in the form of a set of finite-difference equations which are solved explicitly. The results presented include pavement surface temperature response to relatively clear-day diurnal solar irradiation-ambient temperature profiles along with the response to an abrupt decrease in ambient temperature. It is shown that using the proposed technique, the surfaces can be protected from freezing for an additional period of several hours, when compared with systems without phase-change storage.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Solar Energy--Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Solids--Freezing; Integral Phase-Change Material; Phase-Change Storage; Solar Irradiated Paved Surfaces; Tetradecane Paraffin; Thermal Model; Pavements

Authors: Fujiwara Makoto, Sano Tamotsu, Suzuki Kiyoshi, Watanabe Shinya
Title: Thermal analysis and fundamental tests on heat pipe receiver for solar dynamic space power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujiwara, Makoto, Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Jpn; Sano, Tamotsu, Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Jpn; Suzuki, Kiyoshi, Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Jpn; Watanabe, Shinya, Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Jpn
Abstract: The conceptual design and testing of a closed Brayton cycle heat receiver are described. In the conceptual design, two types of heat receiver were compared and examined by thermal analyses. These studies have shown that the integrated heat pipe was superior to the external phase-change material receiver in terms of efficiency and the temperature fluctuation of the receiver. In fundamental tests on the phase-change material, deformation of the thermal storage tube caused by a volumetric expansion during melting was observed. The integrated heat pipe was constructed and tested, and satisfactory performance under various conditions was observed. It was verified by a simulation test that the integrated heat pipe suppresses the temperature fluctuations of the heat pipe and the outlet gas through the insolation and eclipse cycle.
Index Keywords: Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Energy; Solar Power Plants--Space Applications; Brayton Cycle; Heat Pipe Receiver; Heat Receiver; Integrated Heat Pipe; Solar Dynamic Space Power System; Thermal Storage Tube; Heat Pipes

Title: Design of a motor-generator for an energy storage flywheel
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TPI Inc
Authors with affiliations: Studer, Philip A., TPI Inc; Niemeyer, W.Leland, TPI Inc
Abstract: The authors discuss a motor-generator design capable of meeting the requirements of a mechanical energy storage system competitive with advanced battery systems for space power and capable of superior life potential. In this design, the rotor is integrated into the flywheel. Although high rotational rates are generally preferred by the motor designer, there are few precedents for the surface speeds anticipated in this energy storage application. Rotational loss considerations tend to dominate the design tradeoffs to maintain high system storage efficiency with a directly coupled unit. The authors describe some of the design alternatives as a guide to the experimental and analytical program needed to finalize a design.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Space Applications; Flywheels--Energy Storage; Advanced Battery Systems; Space Power; Electric Motor Generator Sets

Title: Magnetodynamic storage unit - Test results of an electrical flywheel storage system in a local public transport bus with a diesel-electrical drive
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Heidelberg, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger; Reiner, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, West Ger
Abstract: A diesel electrical system with a flywheel storage unit for a local public transport bus is described. The results of test drives using a vehicle fitted with a system of this type are presented. The magnetodynamic storage unit (MDS) serves to absorb the brake energy and to reduce the diesel motor power. Using this system, a small 50-kW car diesel engine can perform the same traffic service in the city as a 150-kW diesel engine in a conventional vehicle. In the test drives since 1985, the drive system and storage unit have performed well.
Index Keywords: Diesel Engines; Electric Traction--Flywheel Propulsion; Diesel-Electrical Drive; Electrical Flyweel Storage System; Magnetodynamic Storage Unit; Public Transport Bus; Motor Buses

Authors: Beauvais J., Galarneau P., Lessard R.A., Knystautas E.J.
Title: Relative influence of ion implantation mechanisms on optical recording properties of Te:He
Affiliations: Univ of Laval, Phys Dep, Ste-Foy,, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Beauvais, J., Univ of Laval, Phys Dep, Ste-Foy,, Que, Can; Galarneau, P., Univ of Laval, Phys Dep, Ste-Foy,, Que, Can; Lessard, R.A., Univ of Laval, Phys Dep, Ste-Foy,, Que, Can; Knystautas, E.J., Univ of Laval, Phys Dep, Ste-Foy,, Que, Can
Abstract: The results of a study of the relative influence of ion implantation mechanisms on the optical recording properties of Te:He thin films are reported. The measurements consist in determining the relative writing energy threshold WT of He+ implanted tellurium thin films measured with respect to a pure tellurium film. The writing beam is a pulsed Nd+:YAG laser operated either at 1064 nm or frequency doubled to 532 nm. Similar variation of WT with ion beam energy at both wavelengths suggests that the effect of implantation damage is not sensitive to the writing wavelength. A difference in starting values at 532 and 1064 nm is attributable only to the presence of the He+ implants within the films, since the effect of an increase of the implanted dose on WT seems highly dependent on the writing beam wavelength.
Index Keywords: Laser Beams; Tellurium--Thin Films; Digest of Paper; Implanted Tellurium Thin Films; Optical Recording; Writing Beam; Data Storage, Optical

Title: Heat transfer in phase change storage materials
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Northern Illinois Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Majumdar, P., Northern Illinois Univ, United States; Sharma, R.K., Northern Illinois Univ, United States
Abstract: The storage of heat as latent heat of phase change materials represent a well known and an attractive approach to thermal energy storage. The heat transfer and design aspects of phase change are complex owing to the non-linearity of the problem resulting from the motion of solid-liquid interface separating two regions of different thermo-physical properties. A differential model for this moving boundary problem is developed. The governing equations and conditions are transformed into a set of integral equations. A numerical solution to these equation is obtained using an iterative scheme. This numerical scheme is used to obtain temperature distribution and interface position as a function of time. The results are also presented for different Stefan numbers.
Index Keywords: Heat Pump Systems--Performance; Heat Transfer; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Heat Recovery; Phase Change Materials; Thermal Energy Storage; Heating

Title: Operating experience with the Chino 10 MW/40 MWh battery energy storage facility
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Southern California Edison Co,, Rosemead, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rodriguez, George D., Southern California Edison Co,, Rosemead, CA, USA
Abstract: A two-year demonstration test program at the Chino 10-MW-40-MWh Battery Energy Storage Facility, designed to demonstrate the costs, benefits and technical feasibility of the plant operating in a substation environment for energy management purposes, is described. Since startup, the Chino facility has undergone 46 cycles under various charge and discharge regimes. The primary purpose of the first series of tests was to establish baseline operating parameters for the facility for later comparison. These tests are discussed in some detail. The operation of the facility during these tests also afforded the opportunity to establish facility operating and maintenance procedures for this first-of-a-kind plant. Several capital improvements that were made to enhance the operation, monitoring and security of the plant are also described.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Transmission, DC--Equipment; Electric Utilities--Energy Storage; Battery Energy Storage; Battery Power Plant; Cost Benefit Analysis; Substation Environment; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Evaluation of the efficiency of various ways of storing energy from solar photoelectric stations
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Pleskov, Yu.V.; Pshenichnikov, A.G.
Abstract: As solar photoelectric stations (SPES) are improved, the problem of accumulating and storing the converted energy of solar radiation becomes more critical. At present, the most promising ways are conversion of electric energy into chemical energy of hydrogen by electrolysis of water and the use of secondary chemical sources of current (batteries), or a combination of the two. On the basis of overall computation of the efficiency of a system of converters, the article discusses the efficiency of different variants of storing electric energy from an SPES with the use of batteries, electrolyzers, and fuel cells, with final consumption in the form of electricity or chemical energy of hydrogen. According to calculations the efficiency of the SPES-electrolyzer-fuel cell path is 60%.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Efficiency; Fuel Cells; Solar Power Plants

Title: Nickel/hydrogen battery for solar applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bush, D.M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Sindorf, J.F., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: A nickel/hydrogen battery which was developed for energy storage in communication satellites is described. Advantages offered by this battery include long life, low maintenance, and high reliability. These attributes would also be desirable for terrestrial applications, but the cost is prohibitively high. A 7-kWh battery which is currently being evaluated in a series of solar tests using a photovoltaic array for charging is discussed. It incorporates a number of design changes from aerospace technology that enhance performance of the nickel/hydrogen system for terrestrial service. Individual prismatic cells are housed in a common pressure vessel. Thicker positives are used, which lowers the cost by reducing the number of components as well as increasing specific energy. An electrolyte management system increases cycle life, and a peripheral seal, used as an aid in assembly, enhances oxygen recombination. The use of additives along with a change in electrolyte concentration improves high-temperature performance.
Index Keywords: Communication Satellites--Energy Storage; Electric Batteries--Charging; Solar Cells--Arrays; Solar Energy--Storage; Electrochemical Enhergy Storage; Nickel Hydrogen Battery; Prismatic Cells; Satellite Batteries; Solar Applications; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Flight experiment of thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Namkoong, David, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: Thermal energy storage (TES), which enables a solar dynamic system to deliver constant electric power through periods of sun and shade, is discussed. Brayton and Stirling power systems under current considerations for missions in the near future require working fluid temperatures in the range from 1100 to above 1300 K range. Test of the fluoride family of salts which meet these requirements are described. The principle feature of fluorides that must be taken into account is the change in volume that occurs with melting and freezing. Analysis of the transient, two-phase phenomenon, which is being incorporated into a three-dimensional computer code, is discussed. The objective of a planned flight program is to verify the predictions of the code, particularly the void location and its effect on containment temperature. The four experimental packages comprising the program represent the first tests of melting and freezing conducted under microgravity.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Heat Engines; Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Energy; Brayton Power Systems; Solar Dynamic Systems; Stirling Power Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Authors: Simons Stephen N., Willhoite Bryan C., van Ommering Gert
Title: Energy storage and thermal control system design status
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Simons, Stephen N., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Willhoite, Bryan C., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; van Ommering, Gert, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: The space station Freedom electric power system (EPS) will initially rely on photovoltaics for power generation and Ni/H2 batteries for electrical energy storage. A discussion is presented of the current design for and the development status of two major subsystems in the PV power module, namely, the energy storage subsystem, comprising high-capacity Ni/H2 batteries, and the single-phase thermal control system that rejects the excess heat generated by the batteries and other components associated with power generation and storage.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Storage; Photovoltaic Cells; Power Generation; PV Power Module; Space Station Freedom; Thermal Control System; Spacecraft

Title: Experimental and theoretical studies of spur processes in hydrocarbons
Affiliations: Univ of Sheffield, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brocklehurst, Brian, Univ of Sheffield, United Kingdom
Abstract: The role of spurs in the radiolysis of hydrocarbons is far from clear. Magnetic field effects on luminescence suggest the presence of significant numbers of initially triplet ion pairs, but molecular triplets have not been detected at short times. While recombination of solute ions in alkanes is known to be a major source of excited states, there is doubt about its role in aromatics. New results are presented for solutions in benzene solutions excited by β-particles and two new approaches to these problems are described - the use of pulsed vacuum ultraviolet radiation from a synchrotron storage ring to produce spurs with a specific energy content and a theoretical model of spur processes including spin effects.
Index Keywords: Molecules--Ionization; Organic Compounds--Dissociation; Radiation Chemistry; Radiolysis; Spin Effects; Spur Processes; Synchroton Radiation; Hydrocarbons

Authors: Edwards J.A., Johnson R.R., Mangum J.
Title: Laboratory performance of domestic hot water systems under simulated field conditions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: North Carolina State Univ, Mech, & Aerosp Eng, Raleigh, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, J.A., North Carolina State Univ, Mech, & Aerosp Eng, Raleigh, NC, USA; Johnson, R.R., North Carolina State Univ, Mech, & Aerosp Eng, Raleigh, NC, USA; Mangum, J., North Carolina State Univ, Mech, & Aerosp Eng, Raleigh, NC, USA
Abstract: A side-by-side laboratory test was conducted on two commercially available solar domestic water heating systems for the purpose of comparing the thermal performance of each system. One system was a drain-back system which utilized a small storage tank that collected the working fluid when the collectors were not in operation. The other system used a slightly pressurized antifreeze solution for the collector working fluid. The following key measurements were made for each system: energy collected by the collectors, energy delivered to storage, hot water consumption, electric energy used for both system operation and auxiliary heating, and solar insolation. Comparison of the systems was based upon the following performance ratings: collector efficiency, system efficiency, thermal efficiency, solar fraction, coefficient of performance, and fractional energy savings. It was found that the glycol system collected and delivered more energy to storage in every test period. The percent loss associated with the amount of available solar energy collected and delivered to storage was approximately 6% for the glycol system and 6% for the drain-back system. The drain-back system required more auxiliary heat to replace the depleted energy in storage in every test period.
Index Keywords: Glycols; Heating--Hot Water Systems; Solar Energy--Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Auxiliary Heating; Collector Working Fluid; Drain-Back System; System Thermal Performance; Water Heaters

Title: Aluminum-hydrogen peroxide fuel cell power system for ocean bottom electrical power
Affiliations: TRW Federal Systems Group, Fairfax,, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gorman, Richard, TRW Federal Systems Group, Fairfax,, VA, USA
Abstract: An ambient pressure system that uses an existing modular automotive aluminum-air fuel cell has been synthesized. Oxygen for the cell is supplied by existing mechanisms for catalytic dissociation of hydrogen peroxide. The system can use a 50% to 90% concentration H2O2-H2O solution as the oxidizer supply. The weight and volume (as well as the neutral buoyancy equivalent dry weight) for each of two alternative high energy density power systems (LiSOCl2 primary batteries, H2-O2 fuel cells) have been derived. The results show that at a 20,000-ft depth, the dry weight of a neutrally buoyant aluminum-hydrogen-peroxide system is less than one third that of LiSOCl2 primary batteries inside spherical pressure vessels, and less than that of an H2-O2 fuel cell using subcritical liquid cryogenic storage inside spherical pressure vessels. In addition, the advantage, other than cost, of the ability to employ soft bags for storage of hydrogen peroxide vice pressure vessels is not readily quantifiable, but it is real, as is the greater depth capability, storability, and ease of handling of noncryogenic liquids.
Index Keywords: Aluminum and Alloys; Hydrogen Peroxide; Ocean Engineering--Electric Power Supplies; Oceanography--Electric Power Supplies; Pressure Vessels; Aluminum-Air Fuel Cell; Aluminum-Hydrogen Peroxide Fuel Cell; Noncryogenic Liquids; Ocean Bottom Electrical Power; Soft Bags; Spherical Pressure Vessels; Fuel Cells

Title: 50 MHz microcomputer-based data acquisition and analysis system for ultrasound tissue characterization
Affiliations: Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale,, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Botros, N., Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale,, IL, USA; Xu, Ke, Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale,, IL, USA
Abstract: The authors present an ultra-high-speed microcomputer-based data acquisition and analysis system to be coupled to an ultrasound scanner machine. The primary application of the system in this study is to measure the backscattered ultrasound energy from human liver tissue and use this measurement to differentiate between normal and abnormal liver tissue. The system digitizes the ultrasound signal with a sample rate of 50 megasamples/second and stores the digitized data in an intermediate storage. When the storage is full, the data are transferred to an IBM-PC where a fast Fourier transform algorithm is applied to calculate the power spectrum of the ultrasound signal. The measurement of the power spectrum is used to estimate the acoustic attenuation and backscattering coefficients of the tissue as function of the frequency. By investigating these coefficients, the biological status of the tissue (normal or abnormal) can be determined. The six main system componenets are described in some detail: 1) the conditioning circuit, 2) the analog/digital converter unit, 3) the latching circuit unit, 4) the intermediate storage unit, 5) the communication unit, and 6) the control-delay circuit unit.
Index Keywords: Acoustic Imaging--Medical Applications; Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Ultrasonic Equipment--Medical Applications; Microcomputer-Based Data Acquisition; Tissue Characterization; Ultrasound Scanner; Biological Materials

Title: Computer simulation of the plasma-filled diode
Affiliations: Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Geary, James, Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA
Abstract: The plasma-filled diode (PFD) consists of a low-density plasma injected into a diode in a pulse-powered device. The PFD has been used as a prepulse suppression switch and as a combination opening switch/e-beam diode for use in inductive energy storage devices. The plasma initially provides a low-impedance load. However, as the current increases the impedance eventually rises rapidly, opening the switch. The behavior of this device has been examined using the 2-1/2-D electromagnetic particle code ISIS. A TEM wave was launched down a coaxial transmission line that feeds into a PFD. Particle emission was allowed from the electrodes in an azimuthally symmetric cylindrical geometry. The investigation included an examination of the magnetic field penetration of the plasma, the motion of the electron beam, and the formation of sheaths at the electrodes. The plasma density and injection speed were varied as were wave parameters.
Index Keywords: Electron Tubes, Diode; Plasmas; Abstract Only; Fast Opening Switches; Plasma Filled Diodes; Software Package ISIS; Electric Switches

Title: Waste Heat Utilization: Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the ASME
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This publication contains 10 meeting papers. The papers deal with the problem of using and reclaiming energy rejected by other systems. Several papers are on the direct use of waste heat in greenhouses, heat pumps, and economizers. Others concentrate on improving existing systems to reduce waste heat. Two of the papers deal with demonstration projects, and one deals with a novel means of storing energy to be used in starting diesel engines. There is also a paper on power generation from municipal waste.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Heat Pipes - Applications; Heat Pump Systems - Design; Heating - Heat Storage; Ceramic Recuperators; Economizers; EIREV; Energy Recovery; Municipal Waste; Thermal Storage; Waste Heat Utilization

Authors: Singh C., Patton A.D., Kumar Mudit, Wagner H.
Title: Simulation model for reliability evaluation of space station power systems
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Industrial and Commercial Power Systems Technical Conference
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Singh, C., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Patton, A.D., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Kumar, Mudit, Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA; Wagner, H., Texas A&M Univ, Dep of Electr, Eng, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: A Monte Carlo simulation program to perform reliability analysis of the Space Station hybrid power configuration (consisting of photovoltaic and solar dynamic systems) is presented. The model considers the dependence of reliability and storage characteristics during the sun and eclipse periods. It also considers certain types of common-mode failures. In particular, the charging and discharging of the energy-storage modules can be modeled in a more accurate fashion on a continuous basis than in the approach of C. Singh et al. (1987). The model has been implemented in a computer program. All the relevant system reliability indices including the probability, frequency, and mean duration of failure can be calculated.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Mathematical Statistics--Monte Carlo Methods; Reliability--Evaluation; Solar Power Plants--Orbiting; Monte Carlo Simulations; Space Station Power Systems; Space Platforms

Authors: Chang C.S., Yeh H.Y., Fang L.J.
Title: Freezing and melting behaviour of sodium acetate trihydrate
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Industrial Technology Research Inst, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, C.S., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Taiwan; Yeh, H.Y., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Taiwan; Fang, L.J., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Taiwan
Abstract: The main objectives of the work described in this paper were to lessen the subcooling, to study freezing and melting behavior, and to obtain charging and discharging rates of sodium acetate trihydrate (NaCH3COO-3H2O). The subcooling problem was alleviated by adding an adequate amount of both sulfur (a nucleating agent) and xanthan gum (a suspension medium). The melting and freezing behavior were experimentally investigated with a double pipe structure in the vertical direction. The storage medium was stored in the shell, and water was passed through the tube.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Pipe--Fluid Dynamics; Double Pipe Structure; Sodium Acetate Trihydrate; Subcooling; Sodium Compounds

Title: CROSSATRON switch applications in power-conditioning and pulsed-power- modulator systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schumacher, R.W., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Abstract: The author describes the CROSSATRON switch, a high-power modulator device that combines the best features of thyratrons, vacuum tubes, and power semiconductor switches. It features instant start and rugged operation while enduring high temperatures, high radiation, electromagnetic pulse, and repeated overvoltage and overcurrent events. The author presents an array of circuit approaches for which the CROSSATRON switch can be used to solve power-conditioning and pulsed-power-modulator problems. CROSSATRON switch applications in power conditioning include high-voltage phase-control-rectifier service, high-frequency DC-to-AC inverter modulation, voltage regulation, command charging, and fault protection. Pulsed-power applications include high-speed discharging of capacitors and pulse-forming networks, repetitive forming of inductive-energy-storage circuits, modulation of square-wave pulses in hard-tube modulators, and fault protection.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic Pulse; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Energy Storage; Spacecraft--Power Supply; CROSSATRON Switch; Power Conditioning; Electric Switches, Semiconductor

Authors: Haider Nazar S., Sayeh Mohammad R.
Title: Discrete Lyapunov system as an efficient associative memory
Affiliations: Southern Illinois Univ, Dep of, Electr Eng, Carbondale, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haider, Nazar S., Southern Illinois Univ, Dep of, Electr Eng, Carbondale, IL, USA; Sayeh, Mohammad R., Southern Illinois Univ, Dep of, Electr Eng, Carbondale, IL, USA
Abstract: A discrete Lyapunov system that functions essentially like the Hopfield model (i.e., with feedback and thresholding) is developed. When expanded into a binomial series, the energy function for the discrete Lyapunov system is shown to be approximately equal to the energy function of the Hopfield model and also of models that utilize higher order discriminant functions. The discrete Lyapunov system is used to develop its continuous counterpart by utilizing a differential equation very similar to the one used for the Hopfield continuous model of neurons with graded response.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital--Associative; Mathematical Techniques--Differential Equations; Binomial Series; Discrete Laypunov System; Feedback; Hopfield Model; Thresholding; Systems Science and Cybernetics

Authors: Jaffe L., Beatty R., Bhandari P., Chow E., Deininger W., Ewell R., Fujita T., Grossman M., Kia T., Nesmith B., Newell T., Shih C.F., Spanos J., Stallkamp J., Stevens J., Stultz J., Wanchoo A.K., White L., Bell C., Carlson D., Metzger J., Voss S., Bloomfield H., Heller J.
Title: Nuclear reactor power as applied to a space-based radar mission
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jaffe, L., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Beatty, R., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Bhandari, P., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Chow, E., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Deininger, W., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Ewell, R., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Fujita, T., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Grossman, M., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Kia, T., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Nesmith, B., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Newell, T., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Shih, C.F., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Spanos, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Stallkamp, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Stevens, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Stultz, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Wanchoo, A.K., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; White, L., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Bell, C., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Carlson, D., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Metzger, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Voss, S., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Bloomfield, H., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA; Heller, J., California Inst of Technol, Jet, Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: Examination of nuclear reactor power for a 300-kW space-based radar indicates that such a mission should be feasible, using the technology currently being developed by the SP-100 space nuclear reactor power project. The radar would be capable of quickly detecting targets with low radar cross sections. Continuous power generation by the reactor source would obviate the need for energy storage and allow continuous operation of the radap for coverage of multiple areas of interest. The power system uses a fast-spectrum reactor fueled with enriched uranium and cooled with liquid lithium. The radar system studied uses a very large and heavy antenna and, with present launch vehicles, would require multiple launches and orbital assembly. Six shuttle launches bring the various spacecraft assemblies and a chemically propelled upper state to the assembly orbit. After assembly, the upper stage places the spacecraft in operational orbit, at 61°, 1088 km, where it is deployed on radio command, the upper stage separates, the power system is started, and the spacecraft becomes operational.
Index Keywords: Radar--Cross Sections; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Enriched Uranium; SP-100 Nuclear Reactor; Nuclear Reactors

Authors: McKee T.J., Boyd G., Znotins T.A.
Title: High power long pulse excimer laser
Affiliations: Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: McKee, T.J., Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can; Boyd, G., Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can; Znotins, T.A., Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can
Abstract: Spiker-sustainer circuitry with magnetic switch isolation, when applied to XeCl excimer lasers, provides the capability of scaling to high pulse energies without undue stress on electrical components. Long optical pulses are achieved by providing a current pulse sufficient to sustain lasing for times in excess of 200 ns (and up to 1.5 μs) in a discharge that is impedance matched to the energy-storage pulse-forming network. Using this technology, pulse energies in excess of 1 J at a repetition rate of 220 pulses per second (pps) have been achieved in a relatively simple device operating at 14 kV DC on XeCl. Pulse energies of 200 mJ were observed for KrF. Time-averaged temporal pulse shapes at 220 pps are shown for an oscilloscpe trigerred externally by the laser fire pulse.
Index Keywords: Laser Pulses; Digest of Paper; Long Pulse Excimer Laser; Magnetic Switch Isolation; Optical Pulses; Pulse-Forming Network; Spiker-Sustainer Circuitry; Lasers, Excimer

Authors: Boenig H.J., Rogers J.D., McLelland G.R., Pelts C.T.
Title: Transportation of a 451-ton generator stator and a 234-ton generator rotor from Hartsville, TN, to Los Alamos, NM
Affiliations: Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Boenig, H.J., Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA; Rogers, J.D., Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA; McLelland, G.R., Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA; Pelts, C.T., Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: A 1430-MVA steam turbine generator was acquired from a cancelled nuclear power plant in Tennessee to be used as the pulsed-power and energy storage unit for the Confinement Physics Research Facility (CPRF) being built at Los Alamos, NM. The transportation from Hartsville, near Nashville, TN, to Los Alamos, NM, of the two largest single pieces of the generator (a 451-ton stator and a 234-ton rotor) presented a special challenge. Details of the move, by barge from Hartsville to Catoosa, near Tulsa, OK, by rail from Catoosa to Lamy, near Santa Fe, NM, and by road from Lamy to Los Alamos are described. The greatest difficulty in the successful move was the crossing of the Rio Grande River on an existing reinforced concrete bridge. The two-lane-wide road transporters for the stator and rotor were fitted with outriggers to provide a four-lane-wide vehicle, thus spreading the load over the entire bridge width and meeting acceptable load distribution and bridge safety factors.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Steam Turbines; Confinement Physics Research Facility (CPRF); Electric Generators

Title: Enhanced mission duration for an underwater vehicle using a proton exchange membrane fuel cell power source
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Unmanned
Affiliations: US Naval Res Lab, Washington, DC,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, Christopher, US Naval Res Lab, Washington, DC,, USA; Margiott, Victoria, US Naval Res Lab, Washington, DC,, USA
Abstract: A one-kilowatt (80 ampere-hour) prototype fuel cell based on proton exchange membrane (PEM) technology is being developed to replace the silver-zinc batteries of an existing prototype deep-ocean observation vehicle. Initial tests indicate that mission duration capabilities will be doubled, and mission turn-around times decreased. The fuel cell stack, reactant storage, support systems, and microprocessor controls have been designed to occupy the same volume as the existing battery system, and to meet existing weight and thermal specifications. Thus, mechanical and electrical modifications to the vehicle are minimal. For relatively short mission durations or small vehicles, the PEM fuel cell can exceed the performance of most battery systems. For long duration missions or larger vehicles, the energy density of a fuel cell (ampere-hours per unit mass, and per unit volume) significantly outperforms battery systems. As the energy capacity (ampere-hours) is increased, the size of the fuel cell stack will remain constant; only the volume of fuel increases. Thus, the energy density per available volume of the fuel cell system improves as the system is scaled up. It is concluded that when cost/availability, load cycle degradation, shelf life, and ease/speed of refueling are considered, the PEM fuel cell is the preferred power source for underwater vehicles.
Index Keywords: Fuel Cells - Evaluation; Ocean Engineering; Deep-Ocean Observation Vehicle; Load Cycle Degradation; Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) Technology; Silver-Zinc Batteries; Submersibles

Authors: Korovin N.V., Tel'nov V.P., Kuleshov N.V., Akulov V.A.
Title: Role of nontraditional energy carriers in the development of electrical power
Authors with affiliations: Korovin, N.V.; Tel'nov, V.P.; Kuleshov, N.V.; Akulov, V.A.
Abstract: A mathematical model and equivalent problem of linear programming are proposed for evaluation of the system efficiency of using new technologies for energy conversion and nontraditional energy carriers in power engineering. Special attention is paid to modelling of conversion processes and energy storage. It is demonstrated that combined use of pumped-storage power plants, electrochemical storage batteries and hydrogen energy storage cycles can contribute a noticeable economic effect to solving the problem of load smoothing in advanced electrical power systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Conversion; Energy Resources; Energy Storage - Research; Hydrogen - Energy Storage; Mathematical Programming, Linear; Electrochemical Storage Batteries; Hydrogen Energy; Hydrogen Energy Storage Cycles; Nontraditional Energy Carriers; Nuclear Power Plants; Pumped Storage Power Plants; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Sato T., Miyazaki K., Hasama T., Yamashita I., Kato M., Takahara S., Mizui J.
Title: Recent progress on multikilowatt excimer laser research
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting-LEOS
Affiliations: Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, T., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Miyazaki, K., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Hasama, T., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Yamashita, I., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Kato, M., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Takahara, S., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan; Mizui, J., Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Ibaraki,, Japan
Abstract: A UV-preionized self-sustained-discharge XeCl laser has been studied with the aim of developing repetitively pulsed high-power excimer lasers. The laser discharge circuit includes two identical thyratrons connected to the storage capacitors which are isolated electrically using appropriate charging inductances and are closed at the same time. The laser pulse energy obtained was 1.15 and the pulse width (full width of half maximum) was 33 ns at a charging voltage of 32 kV for a 0.66/0.66/99.3% gas mixture of Xe/HCl/Ne at a total gas pressure of 6 atm. The laser efficiency was 2.4% at a charging voltage of 24 kV. The laser average power is shown as a function of repetition rate at 30 kV, where the gas flow velocity measured between the electrodes was 80 m/s. The maximum average power is 260 W at a repetition rate of 500 pp.
Index Keywords: Laser Pulses; Neon; Ultraviolet Radiation; Xenon; Digest of Paper; Xenon Chloride; Lasers, Excimer

Authors: Belyakov A.P., Dul'nev G.N., Savintseva L.A., Sakhova E.V.
Title: Mathematical model of a solar loop for a heating system
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Belyakov, A.P.; Dul'nev, G.N.; Savintseva, L.A.; Sakhova, E.V.
Abstract: In designing heating systems, it is necessary to determine the calculated heating load; parameters of the solar unit, heat exchanger, and thermal storage tank; and the portion of the total heat demand provided by solar energy, together with consideration of design, performance, technological and meteorological peculiarities of the system's operation. A mathematical model is given for a heating system, on the basis of which parameters of a heating system for a residential room over the course of several days are calculated. A relationship is revealed between solar and supplemental energies for given meteorological conditions. This model was used to calculate a heating system for a residential room with a volume of 60 m3 in Bakuriani, USSR.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Radiation; Mathematical Models; Heating Load; Water Heaters

Title: Report on the Symposium on Heavy Ion Inertial Fusion, Darmstadt, Germany, June 1988
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Keefe, D., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA
Abstract: Progress on high-current, low-emittance heavy ion beams in both RF linacs and induction linacs was reported at the Symposium on Heavy Ion Inertial Fusion. Significant current amplification in a proof-of-principle multiple-beam induction linac was described. Experimental results from France and Germany show enhanced energy deposition by low-energy heavy ions in hot dense plasmas. The GSI heavy ion synchrotron (SIS) and the experimental storage ring (ESR) are under construction; when completed, the beams will be used for experiments to study hot dense plasma phenomena.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear; Accelerators, Synchrotron; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Plasmas; Heavy Ion Inertial Fusion; Induction Linacs; RF Linacs; Ion Beams

Title: High luminosity operation of the Cornell Electron Storage Ring
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Wilson Lab, Ithaca,, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rice, D., Cornell Univ, Wilson Lab, Ithaca,, NY, USA
Abstract: The high energy physics (HEP) performance of the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) improved by a factor of 2.5 since the beginning of seven-bunch operation in February, 1987. In addition to the gains provided by multiple bunches, other improvements, including very low beta (micro-beta) insertions and increased injection rates, have played a role in these advances. Presently, performance is limited by sparking in the horizontal separators used in multiple bunch operation. Since performance is current, not beam-beam, limited, optimum luminosity is obtained by lowering βv* to 0.9 times the bunch length.
Index Keywords: Particle Optics; Physics--High Energy; CESR Luminosity; Cornell Electron Storage Ring; Electron-Positron Collider; Micro-Beta Insertions; Seven-Bunch Accelerator Operation; Accelerators

Authors: Jackson Lorna G., Bush Jr. John R., Lanier Jr. John R.
Title: Hubble Space Telescope six-battery nickel-cadmium mission simulation test
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Marshall Space Flight Cent,, Huntsville, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, Lorna G., NASA Marshall Space Flight Cent,, Huntsville, AL, USA; Bush Jr., John R., NASA Marshall Space Flight Cent,, Huntsville, AL, USA; Lanier Jr., John R., NASA Marshall Space Flight Cent,, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: A simulation test of the six-battery nickel-cadmium mission to determine battery life and electrical power system (EPS) performance characteristics for the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) program, is described. The basic HST power system requirements are to provide power generation, energy storage, and EPS control and distribution for 2.5 years with the nickel-cadmium (NiCd) batteries at an end of life solar array of 2 years. Mission simulation life testing begain in April of 1986, and the batteries have completed their 2.5 year mission requirement. Conditions as close as practical to the actual predicted mission profiles were used. These included solar array degradation, load variations, beta angle changes, temperature changes (with excursions to 10°C), battery reconditioning, safemode simulations, and off-normal roll activities. Discounting system cycling interruptions caused by hardware, software, human error, and periodic updates and revisions, the HST EPS breadboard hardware operated continuously for 30 months and demonstrated the power system's ability to meet the HST requirement.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Service Life; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Aerospace Batteries; Hubble Space Telescope; Mission Simulation; Nickel-Cadmium Batteries; Telescopes

Authors: Kesseli James B., Lacy Dovie E.
Title: Cavity heat pipe Stirling receiver for space solar dynamics
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sanders Associates, Nashua, NH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kesseli, James B., Sanders Associates, Nashua, NH, USA; Lacy, Dovie E., Sanders Associates, Nashua, NH, USA
Abstract: The receiver/storage unit for the low-earth-orbiting Stirling system is discussed. The design, referred to as the cavity heat pipe (CHP), has been optimized for minimum specific mass and volume width. A specific version of this design at the 7-kWe level has been compared to the space station Brayton solar dynamic design. The space station design utilizes a eutectic mixture of LiF and CaF2. Using the same phase change material, the CHP has been shown to have a specific mass of 40% and a volume of 5% of that of the space station Brayton at the same power level. Additionally, it complements the free-piston Stirling engine in that it also maintains a relatively flat specific mass down to at least 1 kWe. The technical requirements, tradeoff studies, critical issues, and critical technology experiments are discussed.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Heat Engines; Heat Pipes; Lithium Compounds; Solar Energy; Free Piston Stirling Engine; Space Station Brayton; Spacecraft

Authors: Dixson John E., Lenhart Steve, Waterman Peter, Wallin Wayne
Title: Advanced power system component test bed module for testing advanced technology at the space station
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dixson, John E., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Lenhart, Steve, Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Waterman, Peter, Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Wallin, Wayne, Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Abstract: An overview is presented of a study undertaken for the NASA-LeRC on an advanced power system component testbed designed to be attached to the space station. The study was a continuation of NASA's efforts to identify and exploit the benefits of the space station to provide a platform for science and technology development. A candidate set of advanced technology experiments was devised in the photovoltaic, energy storage, solar dynamic and electric propulsion disciplines. The testbed and the proposed experiments are described.
Index Keywords: Electronic Equipment Testing--Space Applications; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells; NASA; Space Station; Spacecraft

Title: Effects of storage parameters on the energy requirements for closed water loop heat pump systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howell, R.H., Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States; Zaidi, J.H., Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States
Abstract: The energy efficiency of a closed-loop water storage heat pump system has been investigated using the AXCESS Version 7.0 building energy analysis computer program. The results of the analysis show that the addition of 50,000 gallons of water storage can save up to 6% of the HVAC energy requirements and that the addition of more storage volume yields diminishing returns. It was also shown that a smaller temperature difference for the water storage (10°F instead of 40°F) results in improved energy efficiency (4%) for the complete system. The internal building load significantly affects the system energy requirements and they are strongly related to the thermal storage capacity of the system.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning - Calculations; Heating - Heat Storage; Closed Loop Piping; Heat Recovery; Thermal Storage; Heat Pump Systems

Title: Proceedings of the 1989 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Abstract: This volume contains 204 conference proceedings papers on accelerator technology. Beam dynamics, pulsed power devices, low-, medium-, and high-energy accelerators, storage rings, superconducting components, magnets, and colliders are the main topics covered.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear; Particle Beams; Superconducting Magnets; Beam Dynamics; Colliders; EIREV; High-Energy Accelerators; Low-Energy Accelerators; Pulsed Power Devices; Accelerators
