Title: Amsterdam Pulse Stretcher Project (AMPS)
Affiliations: NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Luijckx, G., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Bijleveld, J.H.M., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Rookhuizen, H.Boer, NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Bruinsma, P.J.T., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Kaan, A.P., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Kroes, F.B., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Kuijer, L.H., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Maas, R., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Noomen, J.G., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Post, J.C., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Spelt, J.B., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; de Vries, C., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth
Abstract: To obtain electron beams with a high duty factor, a stretcher and storage ring will be added to the existing Medium Energy Accelerator (MEA) facility. The ring will operate at energies between 250 and 900 MeV and with circulating currents up to 200 mA. The storage mode will be used for internal target physics. Discussed in detail are the basic ring design; the ring hardware; linac modifications; and time schedule, manpower, and budget.
Index Keywords: Electromagnets; Amsterdam Pulse Stretcher Project (AMPS); Linac Modifications; Medium Energy Accelerator; RF System; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Consonni S., Lozza G., Macchi E.
Title: Optimization of cogeneration systems operation. Part B. Solution algorithm and examples of optimum operating strategies
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Princeton Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Consonni, S., Princeton Univ, United States; Lozza, G., Princeton Univ, United States; Macchi, E., Princeton Univ, United States
Abstract: Following the linear model discussed in Part A, in this paper we show how the determination of the optimum control strategy of cogeneration plants can be accomplished by solving a sequence of Mixed Integer Linear Programs. Plant operation is discretized in time, and at each time step the best engine operating point is identified on the basis of the electric and thermal loads, the characteristics of the cogeneration plant and the instantaneous marginal costs of fuel, heat and electricity. Possible operating conditions include selling or buying power from the grid, matching thermal or electric demand, shutting the plant down. The optimization procedure is repeated and properly integrated to simulate a complete year of operation. Such simulation provides the inputs for an economic analysis aimed at verifying the plant viability. The paper closes by describing the implementation of this procedure to actual applications subject to the energy prices and the electric rate structure currently applied in Italy.
Index Keywords: Economics; Mathematical Techniques--Algorithms; Cogeneration System Fuel Costs; Cogeneration Systems Operation; Heat Storage Analysis; Mixed Integer Linear Programs; Cogeneration Plants

Title: Effects of peat quality control
Affiliations: Technical Research Cent of Finland, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Impola, R., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Finland; Miettinen, M., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Finland
Abstract: Studies carried out at large pulverized peat combustion power plants have shown the significance of fuel peat quality control. Moisture content, energy density and particle size, and their variations are important characteristics in the peat flow into the boiler. The combustion experiments were carried out at the Rauhalahti peat and coal-fired power plant and in a 5 MW combustion test laboratory. The particle size of the pulverized peat was shown to be more significant for the stability of the combustion and the final combustion of the particles than the moisture content of the fuel. The control of fuel peat quality can be developed in many phases between peat production and combustion. Main methods for the quality control of peat are stockpiling on the peat bog, management of transport from the bog to the power plant and intermedite storage at the power plant. With the aid of experiments in the boiler, the lower and upper limits for the moisture content and energy density of fuel peat were found out on different load levels.
Index Keywords: Boiler Firing - Low Grade Fuel; Flue Gases - Treatment; Peat Combustion; Peat Homogenization; Peat

Title: Calculation of solar hot-water systems with a daily cycle of thermal storage
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Zhdanov, Yu.A.
Abstract: On the basis of solution of a differential equation describing the joint operation of solar-energy receivers and a thermal-storage unit, a procedure is suggested for calculating double- and single-loop solar hot-water systems operating in the optimum conditions of daily storage of solar heat.
Index Keywords: Hot Water Supply Systems--Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Differential Equations; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Tanks--Heat Losses; Hot Water Storage Tank; Solar Heat Daily Storage; Solar Hot Water Systems; Thermal Storage Tank; Water Heaters

Authors: Santana E.A., Rastogi S., Stiel L.I.
Title: Thermal energy storage with liquid-liquid systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Polytech Univ, Chem Eng Dep,, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Santana, E.A., Polytech Univ, Chem Eng Dep,, Brooklyn, NY, USA; Rastogi, S., Polytech Univ, Chem Eng Dep,, Brooklyn, NY, USA; Stiel, L.I., Polytech Univ, Chem Eng Dep,, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Abstract: The use of liquid-liquid mixtures for heat and cool storage applications has been investigated. Analytical procedures were developed to estimate heats of mixing from liquid-liquid equilibrium data and were utilized to select potential mixtures. It was found that aqueous systems with lower critical solution temperatures could exhibit suitable effective heat capacities. Heats of mixing were measured for a number of potential mixtures, and the results of the analytical studies were generally confirmed. Experimental data were also obtained for additional binary and ternary systems, which are promising for further study.
Index Keywords: Calorimetry; Refrigerants; Heat/Cool Storage; Immiscibility; Liquid-Liquid Equilibrium; Liquid-Liquid Systems; Mixing Heats; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Song Yeong K., Midkiff K.Clark, Schaetzle Walter J., Brett C.Everett
Title: Control of aquifer flow for improved aquifer thermal energy storage system performance
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Song, Yeong K., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Midkiff, K.Clark, Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Schaetzle, Walter J., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Brett, C.Everett, Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Abstract: Operation of a 150-ton chill aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) system used to air-condition the University of Alabama Student Recreation Center has been monitored for several years. The ATES system chills water in the winter, stores it in a water-table aquifer, and recovers cold water for summer air-conditioning. A program has been implemented to reduce losses of chilled water resulting from natural aquifer flow. Analysis of data to determine the effectiveness of flow control measures is reported. Demonstration of improved overall energy efficiency (coefficient of performance or COP) requires further performance monitoring, but flow control measures clearly result in lowered water recovery temperatures, thus improving dehumidification.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids--Control; Aquifer Flow Control; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES); Cold Water Recovery; Air Conditioning

Title: Development of encapsulated lithium hydride thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA; Siman-Tov, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: A packed-bed thermal storage (TES) unit using encapsulated LiH spheres has been proposed as a means of reducing the mass and size of space-based heat rejection systems in applications with pulsed power needs. Assessment of the concept indicated that mass and area savings are possible for applications having power generation periods as long as 1600 s. The major area of technical uncertainty is associated with shell stresses during heating, when the melting (and expanding) LiH at the shell surface is trapped between the encapsulating shell and the solid LiH core. A series of feasibility tests demonstrated that the LiH cracks during cooldown and that the LiH uses these paths to communicate with the central void during charging. The feasibility of the concept was proved conclusively in a reliability demonstration test series, when the 50-mm-diameter encapsulated LiH test article completed 50 thermal cycles (twice the application lifetime). The work completed to date indicates that the proposed TES system has merit for pulsed space power systems and that the encapsulated-LiH concept is feasible.
Index Keywords: Lithium Compounds; Lithium Hydride; Pulse Power Systems; Space Based Heat Rejection Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Title: Moving boundary model for heat transfer in phase change material
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Northern Illinois Univ, DeKalb, IL,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Majumdar, Pradip, Northern Illinois Univ, DeKalb, IL,, USA; Sharma, Rakesh K., Northern Illinois Univ, DeKalb, IL,, USA
Abstract: A differential model for the moving boundary problem that can be used to study the performance of phase change materials of various compositions, during the heat absorption and heat rejection period, is discussed. The governing equations and necessary initial and boundary conditions are transformed into a set of integral equations. Numerical solutions to these equations are obtained using an iterative scheme. Results are presented in terms of solid and liquid phase temperature distributions and interface position as a function of time for different Stefan numbers.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer--Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Boundary Value Problems; Heat Absorption; Heat Rejection; Integral Equations; Iterative Methods; Phase Change Materials; Stefan Problem; Materials

Title: Practically usable electric vehicle charged by photovoltaic cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujinaka, Masaharu, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The development of electric vehicles (EVs) charged by photovoltaic cells is discussed. In this system, the principal photovoltaic cells were installed on the roof of a private house, and subcells were mounted on the roof of an EV. Electric energy thus obtained was used in charging a secondary battery mounted on the EV. The energy stored in the secondary battery was then used in driving the motor and propelling the EV. It takes time to charge the secondary battery with energy output from the photovoltaic cells, whereas it discharges in a short amount of time. Thus low-density solar energy is converted to high-density electric energy to provide constant power output.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Energy; Electric Vehicles; High-Density Electric Energy; Low-Density Solar Energy; Storage Battery Vehicles

Title: Development of the zinc/bromine battery at Johnson Controls, Inc
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bolstad, J.J., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA; Miles, R.C., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA
Abstract: The development of a zinc/bromine battery system which combines attractive energy density and a potential for long cycle life at low cost is presented. The battery uses an all-plastic construction that includes carbon-filled polyethylene electrodes. Complexation of bromine lowers its reactivity, thereby minimizing self-discharge and corrosion problems. A 50-kWh zinc/bromine battery designed for testing in a Ford Aerostar minivan is described, and test results are presented. Test results from its use as a 20-kWh load management battery are also presented. A third potential application of the system, as a high-power reserve-type battery, is discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Applications; Electric Energy Storage; Advanced Energy Density Technology; High-Power Battery; Load Management Battery; Specific Energy Density; Zinc Bromine Battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Status of zinc-bromine battery development at Energy Research Corporation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Leo, Anthony, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA
Abstract: The author describes development work on a new generation of battery hardware, with a larger active cell area and improved electrolyte flow characteristics. Key issues such as flow uniformity, zinc deposition quality, shunt current losses, and pumping power requirements were examined in the design of the hardware. Results of design studies and battery tests on the hardware are presented, along with information on the status of older batteries on test with the baseline hardware.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Design; Electric Energy Storage; Battery Cells; Battery Hardware; Battery Stacks; Stationary Energy Storage; Zinc-Bromine Battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Power application of superconductivity
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd, Tiruchirapalli, India
Authors with affiliations: Rajaram, R., Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd, Tiruchirapalli, India; Sridharan, S., Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd, Tiruchirapalli, India
Abstract: Some large-scale applications of superconductivity are discussed, focusing on Indian developments. The review is confined to magnets for fusion reactors, magnetohydrodynamics, and energy storage. The cost of some of the Indian programs is discussed. Pertinent details of Tore Supra of French design are given, since it has a unique refrigeration system using helium-II.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Magnetohydrodynamics; Superconductivity--Applications; Fusion Reactors; Helium-II; Indian Programs; Tore Supra; Nuclear Reactors

Title: Twin regenerative burners increase energy efficiency of new reheat furnace at marion steel
Affiliations: Columbia Gas of Ohio, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maynard, Mitchell, Columbia Gas of Ohio, United States
Abstract: A steel reheat furnace at the Marion Steel Co., Marion, Ohio, is operating successfully, utilizing regenerative type burners. This new gas-fired furnace with its energy saving burners has been significant in the economic recovery of this company. The heart of the new furnace is the burner system (North American Twin-bed). The burners utilize the principle of regeneration coupled with state of the art materials and controls to remarkably reduce fuel consumption. It consists of a pair of burners, each with a heat storage bed attached (typically aluminum oxide nuggets). When one burner is firing, the other acts as a flue and the nuggets recover most of the heat of the exhaust. The short storage intervals and advances in material for this use permit compact (as compared to traditional regenerators) storage beds, thus reducing overall size and providing economy.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Energy Conservation; Gas Burners; Heat Exchangers--Regenerators; Steelmaking; Marion Steel Co; Regenerative Burners; Reheat Furnaces; Furnaces, Heating

Title: Evaluation of a sealed, lead-acid battery for electric vans
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Idaho, Moscow, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, Dean B., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, ID, USA; Carter, Boyd, Univ of Idaho, Moscow, ID, USA
Abstract: A novel lead-acid battery has been designed specifically for an electric van application. The design consists of horizontally oriented, dual lugged plates in a sealed configuration. Thin plates are used in the design to obtain improved energy performance. High specific power is achieved with dual lugs and a grid aspect ratio that shortens conductor paths. Axial pressure applied to the face of the cell stack allows the thin plates to be used in a deep cycle application. Fifteen cells representing the design concept were fabricated by a battery manufacturer. Twelve of these cells were cycled. The cells attained approximately 600 cycles (80% depth of discharge, DOD, at the 2-h rate) and had not failed before the tests were stopped. The projected specific energy for these cells operated at 110°F is about 35 W-h/kg (2-h rate). The specific power was calculated to be approximately 200 W/kg (80% DOD) when new and 140 W/kg (80% DOD) after 364 cycles. The power performance, while still high, did degrade more rapidly than the energy performance.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Storage Battery Vehicles; Electric Vans; Glassmat Separators; Propulsion Battery; Sealed, Lead-Acid Battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: State of the works performed by Aerospatiale in kinetic energy storage and associated fields
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Aerospatiale, Les Mureaux, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Gauthier, M., Aerospatiale, Les Mureaux, Fr; Roland, J.P., Aerospatiale, Les Mureaux, Fr
Abstract: Work performed by Aerospatiale in the field of kinetic energy storage (KES) shows that KES is a suitable solution for low-earth-orbiting satellites with a life duration of 5 years or more. For space applications, KES requires the use of composite material rotors and magnetic bearings. The advantages of an integrated system using pairs of contrarotative wheels to ensure simultaneously attitude control, energy storage, and bus voltage control are described. Two different types of magnetic bearing using permanent magnets have been developed. The first is a very suitable solution due to a permanent power consumption of a few watts only, but it requires a rotor with a high balancing stability. If such a rotor cannot be achieved the second technology can be the preferred solution. The increase of servoloop power consumption due to residual unbalance can be reduced by a special narrowband filter synchronized with the rotation speed. Some experimental subassemblies of KES systems, such as magnetic bearings, different types of rotors, and motor/generators, have been developed and tested. The results obtained are discussed.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Electric Machinery; Rotors; Satellites--Energy Storage; Contrarotative Wheels; Kinetic Energy Storage; Low-Earth-Orbiting Satellites; Narrowband Filter; Permanent Magnets; Energy Storage

Authors: Widmer Johann, Genta Giancarlo, von Burg Peter, Asper Hans K.
Title: Prediction of the dynamic behaviour of a flywheel rotor system by FE-method
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Widmer, Johann, Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Genta, Giancarlo, Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; von Burg, Peter, Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz; Asper, Hans K., Swiss Fed Inst of Technol, Zurich, Switz
Abstract: The authors describe finite-element (FE) computations of the dynamic behavior of a prototype stationary composite flywheel energy storage system. Two FE codes, MADYN and DYNROT, were used. The results obtained by the two codes are compared. The simulations performed using DYNROT permit a high degree of confidence in the dynamic performance of the system, whereas the MADYN simulations show some uncertainties in the stiffness values assumed for the rotor material. An electric motor element was implemented in DYNROT, and the influence of electromagnetic stiffnesses on the dynamic behavior of the rotor system was studied.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic Stiffnesses; Flywheel Rotor System; Software Package DYNROT; Software Package MADYN; Electric Motors; Electric Traction--Flywheel Propulsion; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method; Rotors; Flywheels

Title: On using a superconducting linac to drive a short wavelength FEL
Affiliations: Continuous Electron Beam Accel, Facility, Newport News, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Krafft, G.A., Continuous Electron Beam Accel, Facility, Newport News, VA, USA; Bisognano, J.J., Continuous Electron Beam Accel, Facility, Newport News, VA, USA
Abstract: In order to determine the suitability of using a superconducting radio frequency (SRF) linac to generate XUV radiation, the beam dynamics in such a linac have been simulated using a vectorized two-dimensional beam breakup code, TDBBU. The energy spread and emittance of the accelerated beam are determined as a function of current for a linac like CEBAF (Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility) and for a linac optimized for high peak currents. The results indicate that significant improvements in transverse emittance growth are possible by going to lower RF frequencies and by utilizing BNS phasing in the accelerating cavities. The transverse and longitudinal wakes typical in superconducting cavities are discussed. The results of the simulations are given, followed by a comparison of a linac-driven FEL (free-electron laser) and a typical storage-ring-driven FEL. It is concluded that the former scheme looks promising because higher average power is possible.
Index Keywords: Lasers, Free Electron; Superconducting Magnets; Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility; RF Linacs; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Walls W.A., Gully J.H., Weldon W.F., Woodson H.H.
Title: Homopolar generator power supplies for the IGNITEX experiment
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Walls, W.A., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA; Gully, J.H., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA; Weldon, W.F., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA; Woodson, H.H., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA
Abstract: The IGNITEX toroidal field coil requires a high-power, low-impedance, 10-s, 150-MA pulse. Combined resistive and magnetic energies consumed by the coil are 9.5 GJ. To provide flexibility, a set of 12 homopolar generators (HPGs) are designed to drive the coil in parallel. Each machine stores 1 GJ, generates up to 50 V, and delivers 12.5 MA peak current to a 1/12th pie-shaped sector of the coil. Five pairs of single-turn, poloidal field coils are separately excited by five HPGs. A pulsed HPG is a low-impedance, direct-current generator that converts kinetic energy stored in a spinning rotor into a single, high current pulse. The IGNITEX generators use an iron-core magnetic circuit for voltage generation and current collection and an attached fiberglass/epoxy composite flywheel for energy storage. Relative to existing pulsed HPGs, technology requirements for the IGNITEX generators are moderate. Due to the simple nature of the proposed HPG power supplies and the relatively low grid power needs (less than 35 MW for the TF and PF generators combined) compared with conventional alternator/rectifier systems, the proposed power supply should have a low cost.
Index Keywords: Electric Generators; Electromagnets--Electric Power Supplies; Abstract Only; Homopolar Generator Power Supplies; IGNITEX Tokamak; Magnet Power Supplies; Tokamak Devices

Title: Energy use in hydrocooling stone fruit
Affiliations: Natl Taiwan Univ, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, J.F., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taiwan; Chen, Y.L., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taiwan
Abstract: Energy use per unit of product cooled is reported for two commercial hydrocoolers. Energy use by major components is listed. Heat input measurements and operational data are used to evaluate possible energy conservation methods such as minimizing external heat gain, operating coolers at maximum capacity, minimizing water flow, and reducing water reservoir capacity.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation; Energy Utilization--Measurements; Food Products--Storage; Hydrocoolers; Stone Fruit; Agricultural Products

Authors: Howell R.H., Sauer Jr. H.J., Wang Z.
Title: Effective use of combined heat reclaim - economizer systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howell, R.H., Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States; Sauer Jr., H.J., Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States; Wang, Z., Univ of Missouri-Rolla, United States
Abstract: This study looks at potential energy savings of combined building heat recovery systems and outside air economizer systems including the effects due to geographic location, and the efficiency levels of both the chilling and heating units. The use of electric heat for a heating unit is compared with the use of a heat pump having a realistic annual coefficient of performance. The effect of variation in the coefficient of performance of the chiller unit is also considered. For systems without thermal storage, annual energy savings up to 60% are predicted with the use of heat reclaim systems in conjunction with economizers when the heat reclaim has priority. These results strongly demonstrate the necessity of complete engineering evaluations if proper selection and operation of combined heat recovery and economizer cycles are to be obtained. This paper includes the basic methodology for making such evaluations.
Index Keywords: Heat Exchangers - Efficiency; Heat Pump Systems - Energy Conservation; Chilling Units; Economizers; Heat Recovery; Heating

Title: Boiling/evaporative heat transfer from spheres in packed-bed thermal energy storage units
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arimilli, R.V., Univ of Tennessee, United States; Moy, C.A., Univ of Tennessee, United States
Abstract: An experimental study was conducted to study boiling/evaporative heat transfer from heated spheres in vertical packed beds with downward liquid-vapor flow of Refrigerant-113. Surface superheats of 1 to 50°C, mass flow rates of 1.7 to 5.6 Kg/min, sphere diameters of 1.59 and 2.54 cm, quality (i.e., mass fraction of vapor) of the inlet flow of 2 to 100%, and two surface conditions were considered. Instrumented smooth and rough aluminum spheres were used to measure the heat transfer coefficients under steady state conditions. Heat transfer coefficients were independently determined for each sphere at three values of surface superheat. The quantitative results of this extensive experimental study are successfully correlated. The correlation equation for the boiling heat transfer coefficients is presented in terms of a homogeneous model. The correlation may be used in the development of numerical models to simulate the transient thermal performance of packed bed thermal energy storage unit while operating as an evaporator.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids--Two Phase; Heat Exchangers--Cryogenic; Refrigerants; Temperature Measurement; Boiling Heat Transfer Coefficients; Boiling/Evaporative Heat Transfer; Packed Bed Thermal Energy Storage Units; Refrigerant 113; Surface Superheat; Transient Thermal Performance; Heat Transfer

Title: Optics of the Amsterdam Pulse Stretcher (AmPS)
Affiliations: NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Maas, R., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth; Wu, Y.Y., NIKHEF-K, Amsterdam, Neth
Abstract: The AmPS machine has been designed as a dual-purpose machine: it will be used as a pulse stretcher (PS) and as a storage ring for electrons. In the latter mode, the stored beam will be used in conjunction with an internal (jet) target. Since the internal target will limit the lifetime of the beam to minutes, the storage requirements (e.g., vacuum) will be modest. In PS mode, the energy range is 250-800 MeV; in storage mode the range is extended to 900 MeV. It is anticipated to store a current of up to 200 mA.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Optical Systems; Amsterdam Pulse Stretcher; Internal Target; Pulse Stretcher; Stored Beam; Accelerators

Authors: Walter C.E., Hedtke R.R., Doll D.W.
Title: Design consideration for a stored energy electron beam absorber
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Lawrence, Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Walter, C.E., Univ of California, Lawrence, Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA,, USA; Hedtke, R.R., Univ of California, Lawrence, Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA,, USA; Doll, D.W., Univ of California, Lawrence, Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA,, USA
Abstract: The stringent requirements placed on the design of the electron beam absorber of high-average-power electron accelerators by applications such as the ground-based free-electron laser are discussed. Preliminary design characteristics of a rotating electron-beam absorber made of graphite, which operates in a stored energy mode, are presented. The thermophysical and mechanical properties of graphite make it a suitable material for this application. Several features are incorporated in the design to minimize radiation levels resulting from operation.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Electron Ring; Energy Storage; Graphite; Lasers, Free Electron; Electron Beam Absorber; Ground-Based Free-Electron Laser; High-Average-Power Electron Accelerators; Electron Beams

Authors: Verma Ratna, Prakash J., Garg H.P.
Title: Study of thermal performance of a black liquid shallow solar pond under various operating conditions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technol, Cent of, Energy Studies, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Verma, Ratna, Indian Inst of Technol, Cent of, Energy Studies, New Delhi, India; Prakash, J., Indian Inst of Technol, Cent of, Energy Studies, New Delhi, India; Garg, H.P., Indian Inst of Technol, Cent of, Energy Studies, New Delhi, India
Abstract: A black liquid solar collector cum storage system is studied. The liquid, being black, absorbs most of the radiation; also there is litle reflection loss from the water surface. The performance of the system has been predicted by the finite-difference method for various operating conditions, such as intermittent flow, instantaneous flow, and constant flow. The thermal performance of the black liquid system was compared with that of a conventional and plastic bag shallow solar pond (SSP), and the SSP containing black liquid was found to be more efficient than other systems.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Black Liquid Solar Pond; Shallow Solar Pond; Solar Radiation

Authors: Petr R.A., Schaefer R.B., Kushner M.J.
Title: Cryogenic semiconductor-switched thyratron inverter switches for superconducting inductive energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: W.J. Schafer Associates Inc,, Chemsford, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Petr, R.A., W.J. Schafer Associates Inc,, Chemsford, MA, USA; Schaefer, R.B., W.J. Schafer Associates Inc,, Chemsford, MA, USA; Kushner, M.J., W.J. Schafer Associates Inc,, Chemsford, MA, USA
Abstract: A semiconductor-switched thyratron (SST) concept that uses a light-activated GaAs cathode to eliminate the grid-cathode structure found in conventional thyratron tubes is described. This collapses the size and weight of the SST by an order of magnitude and gives the device an instant-on cold-cathode emission capability. The GaAs cathode supplies emission current through an electron avalanche effect, so that only a low-intensity, short-duration light signal (0.1 mJ at 100 nS) is needed to trigger the device for high-current (10-kA) operation. Consequently the SST has an extremely high switch gain.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide; Semiconductor Devices--Switching; Superconducting Materials--Energy Storage; Semiconductor-Switched Thyratron; Superconducting Inductive Energy Storage Systems; Thyratron Inverter; Electric Inverters

Title: 3rd International Symposium on Turbomachinery, Combined-Cycle Technologies and Cogeneration
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 62 papers discussing various aspects related to turbomachinery used in power plants and cogeneration plant facilities. The use of ceramic materials in gas turbines, as well as thermal barrier coating surfaces on gas turbine boundary layers are evaluated. Combined cycle plants, especially gas and steam turbine combined plants, and advanced hybrid fossil/nuclear gas turbine power plant concepts are discussed. Turbomachinery site selection for compressed air energy storage plants is considered. An economic analysis of steam and gas turbine stages is presented, and various computer codes are employed to determine aeroelastic stability in bending airfoil cascades, and to determine total energy by gas engines or turbines in processing industry.
Index Keywords: Cogeneration Plants; Gas Turbine Power Plants; Power Generation--Gas and Steam Turbine Combined; Steam Power Plants; Waste Heat Utilization; Combined Cycle Cogeneration Technology; Eirev; Machine Condition Monitoring; Power Generation Alternatives; Transonic Turbine Cascade Model; Waste Heat Boiler Circulation; Turbomachinery

Authors: Baird S., Bosser J., Chanel M., Hill C., Kramer D., Ley R., Manglunki D., Mohl D., Tetu P., Tranquille G.
Title: Stochastic cooling and storage tests with oxygen ions in LEAR
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Baird, S., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Bosser, J., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Chanel, M., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Hill, C., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Kramer, D., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Ley, R., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Manglunki, D., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Mohl, D., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Tetu, P., CERN, Geneva, Switz; Tranquille, G., CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: O8+ and O6+ ions were stored in the CERN Low-Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR) during a machine experiment session. The aim was to obtain some hints on the lifetime of heavy ion beams in a good cooling ring vacuum and to test cooling and stacking of ions. Stochastic cooling was used to compensate the beam decay due to multiple scattering on the residual gas, which is the most important effect on lifetime. An equilibrium momentum spread of less than 5 × 10-4 was measured, thus proving the efficiency of stochastic cooling for multiply charged ions. With the vacuum conditions of LEAR (2.6 × 10-12 torr gauge reading with a residual gas of 90% H2), measured beam lifetimes are 25 min for O6+ at 7.2 MeV/u and 600 min for O8+ at 11.5 MeV/u. These numbers set favorable limits for low-energy ion storage rings.
Index Keywords: Ion Beams--Measurements; Beam Lifetime Measurements; Beam Multi-Injection; Heavy Ion Beams; Low-Energy Antiproton Ring; Oxygen Ions; Stochastic Cooling; Accelerators

Authors: Garren A., Chattopadhyay S., Chin Y., Oddone P., Zisman M.S., Donald M., Feldman G., Paterson J.M., Rees J.
Title: Asymmetric B-meson factory at PEP
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Garren, A., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Chattopadhyay, S., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Chin, Y., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Oddone, P., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Zisman, M.S., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Donald, M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Feldman, G., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Paterson, J.M., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA; Rees, J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA
Abstract: A preliminary design for a B-factory has been made using asymmetric collisions between positrons in the Positron-Electron Project (PEP) storage ring and electrons in a new, low-energy ring. The design utilizes small-aperture, permanent-magnet quadrupoles close to the interaction point (IP). Optimization of optical and beam parameters at the IP is discussed, as well as the lattice design of the interaction region and of the rings. The preliminary design for a 12-GeV × 2-GeV B-factory, called Apiary I, gives the rather modest luminosity of 0.5 × 1033 cm-2s-1. A major limitation was the power that can be absorbed by the PEP vacuum chamber. It is suggested that, by going to a more symmetrical system such as 9 GeV × 3 GeV, it may be possible to go to a luminosity that is almost a factor of four higher.
Index Keywords: Magnets; Particle Beams; B-Meson Factory; Low-Energy Ring; Luminosity; Permanent-Magnet Quadrupoles; Positron-Electron Project (PEP); Vacuum Chamber; Accelerators

Title: Parametric study and optimization of phase change thermal energy storage systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Kansas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, B., Univ of Kansas, United States; Adami, M., Univ of Kansas, United States
Abstract: Numerical models were developed to study, and optimize phase change thermal energy storage systems for applications in space. Parametric studies were first performed in order to assess the effects of various thermal and geometric parameters on the heat-transfer process and on the performance of the system. The high-temperature energy storage device utilizes LiH for heat-sink applications to store waste heat during peak periods. The stored heat is then discharged into space through radiators during the off-peak periods. The model was optimized with respect to total system mass subject to geometric and thermal parameter constraints.
Index Keywords: Materials--Phase Transitions; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Gauss-Seidel Iterative Scheme; Phase Change Material; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Energy Storage

Title: Space station nickel-hydrogen cell design and development
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haas, R.J., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Chawathe, A.K., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Abstract: The space station electrical power system uses 1800 nickel-hydrogen battery cells in its photovoltaic power subsystem to provide energy storage for eclipse and contingency operation. The authors describe the design considerations for these 81-Ah cells, including the critical parameters that must be selected and controlled in order to ensure satisfactory battery performance over the 6.5-year life goal. These include nickel electrode void volume, loading levels, current density, and chemical and mechanical parameters. Other key cell design factors related to oxygen management, mechanical and thermal design, and pressure vessel material integrity are reviewed. It is noted that the baseline design is refined during a carefully structured development and verification process aimed at maximizing information in a limited amount of time to support a sound design decision. Attention is given to the mass, life, and producibility trade approach. Producibility aspects are emphasized, including the necessary product and process controls and documentation requirements that must be imposed to ensure reliable, reproducible cell production.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Storage; Hydrogen; Nickel and Alloys; Photovoltaic Cells; Contingency Operations; Nickel-Hydrogen Battery Cells; Space Stations; Spacecraft

Authors: Akiyama H., Shimomura N., Maeda S.
Title: Compact pulsed power generator using fuses and plasma erosion opening switches
Affiliations: Dep of Electr Eng, Kumamoto Univ,, Kumamoto, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Akiyama, H., Dep of Electr Eng, Kumamoto Univ,, Kumamoto, Jpn; Shimomura, N., Dep of Electr Eng, Kumamoto Univ,, Kumamoto, Jpn; Maeda, S., Dep of Electr Eng, Kumamoto Univ,, Kumamoto, Jpn
Abstract: A compact pulsed power generator based on an inductive energy storage system has been constructed and tested. The generator, which has been named ASO-1, is about 210 cm high. Parallel fuses and plasma erosion opening switches are used as two-stage opening switches. The operation of the generator is described. It has been confirmed by experiment that the parallel fuses vaporize simultaneously. Pulsed power of about 250 kV and several tens of kiloamperes is obtained with a risetime <150 ns.
Index Keywords: Electric Fuses; Plasma Devices; Abstract Only; Inductive Energy Storage; Plasma Erosion Opening Switches; Pulsed Power Generators; Pulse Generators

Title: Radiative polarization in high-energy storage rings
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accel Lab, Batavia, IL,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mane, S.R., Fermi Natl Accel Lab, Batavia, IL,, USA
Abstract: Electron and positron beams circulating in high-energy storage rings become spontaneously polarized by the emission of synchrotron radiation. The asymptotic degree of polarization that can be attained is strongly affected by depolarizing resonances. Detailed experimental measurements of the polarization were made at Stanford Positron Electron Asymmetric Ring (SPEAR) about ten years ago, but due to the lack of a suitable theory only a limited theoretical fit to the data has so far been achieved. The author presents a general formalism for calculating depolarizing resonances, which has been coded into a computer program called SMILE, and uses it to fit the SPEAR data. By using suitable approximations, the author is able to fit both higher order and nonlinear resonances, and thereby to interpret many hitherto unexplained features in the data as well as to resolve a puzzle concerning the asymmetry of certain resonance widths seen in the data.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Particle Beams; Depolarizing Resonances; High-Energy Storage Rings; Positron Beams; Radiative Polarization; Software Package SMILE; Stanford Positron Electron Asymmetric Ring (SPEAR); Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: O'Callaghan W.B., Fitzpatrick N.P., Peters K.
Title: Aluminium-air reserve battery - A power supply for prolonged emergencies
Affiliations: Alcan Int Ltd, Kingston, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: O'Callaghan, W.B., Alcan Int Ltd, Kingston, Ont, Can; Fitzpatrick, N.P., Alcan Int Ltd, Kingston, Ont, Can; Peters, K., Alcan Int Ltd, Kingston, Ont, Can
Abstract: An aluminum-air battery has been developed that can be stored for extended periods in the reserve condition and will provide over 360 Wh/Kg (>350 Wh/dm3) when discharged at a power output in the 1 kW range. Its rated power is developed within 30 minutes of activation. In combination with a sealed rechargeable lead-acid battery, the aluminum-air battery provides an emergency power supply that will function automatically for several days. The lead-acid battery supplies the power during mains outages lasting a few hours, with the aluminum-air battery taking over if the emergency is protracted. The exceptionally high energy density for this battery owes much to the development of a highly efficient aluminum anode alloy and to an electrolyte lifetime. A low-cost proprietary cathode makes this battery an economical attractive source of extended power supply. The described combination of rechargeable and reserve batteries is thought to be especially suitable as a source of emergency power for telecommunications systems to cover short or extended power failures.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Telecommunication Systems--Electric Power Supplies; Aluminum-Air Battery; Emergency Power Supply; Lead-Acid Battery; Reserve Battery; Electric Batteries, Primary

Authors: Skiles James J., Boom Roger W., Kustom Robert L., Helfrecht Donald J., Lowe B.James
Title: Experimental experience with a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) device on line
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference

Authors with affiliations: Skiles, James J., Univ of Wisconsin, United States; Boom, Roger W., Univ of Wisconsin, United States; Kustom, Robert L., Univ of Wisconsin, United States; Helfrecht, Donald J., Univ of Wisconsin, United States; Lowe, B.James, Univ of Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: Power conversion system interfaces and utility operation with a Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system have been studied at the University of Wisconsin-Madison as part of a 18-year research program on SMES for utility applications. The university's small laboratory SMES system, which is connected to Madison Gas and Electric, has been used for research on power electronics circuits for about six years. This paper summarizes the experience in on-line operation of the laboratory SMES system in studies of power conversion systems and operations typical of the manner an electric utility would use a full-size SMES unit.

Authors: Ilkjaer J., Petersen P.M., Qvale B., Boldt J., Pedersen S.Lauge

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den
Authors with affiliations: Ilkjaer, J., Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den; Petersen, P.M., Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den; Qvale, B., Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den; Boldt, J., Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den; Pedersen, S.Lauge, Lab for Energetics, Tech Univ of, Denmark, Denmark, Den
Abstract: A theoretical investigation of the economics of cogeneration supplemented by warm-water storage and subjected to a three-step price schedule for electricity, has been carried out. Some general guidelines can be derived, but no simple design rules, such as those for cogeneration plants operating with a two-step schedule, seem to govern the design of such plants subjected to the new conditions. Simulation studies have been initiated in order to arrive at sufficiently accurate optimal store dimensions and operational strategy. The results from simulation studies which give the store as a function of cogeneration plant size relative to the total heat demand in the geographical region supplied by the plant are shown.

Authors: Misawa Y., Suzuki A., Shimizu S., Sato H., Ashizawa K., Sumii T., Ohtomo M.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The authors present their research on the operation and utilization of a 60-kW-class zinc/chlorine rechargeable battery using a 60-kW module constructed in 1987. Experiments on the electrocatalyst for the electrochemical chlorine evolution reaction show that RuO2 electrocatalyst has a higher stability and chemical reactivity than a RuO2-PdO complex oxide electrocatalyst, so it has been used in the 60-kW-class module. The results of an operating test of the battery is presented. Plans to investigate the safety and reliability of battery, the relaxation of its operating conditions, the improvement of its total energy efficiency, and the operation of its battery system and invertor, together with laboratory experiments to increase battery energy efficiency, are discussed.

Authors: Fujii T., Igarashi M., Fushimi K., Hashimoto T., Hirota A., Itoh H., Jin-nai K., Tagami Y., Kouzuma I., Sera Y., Nakayama T.
Title: 4 MW zinc/bromine battery for electric power storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Igarashi, M., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Fushimi, K., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Hashimoto, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Hirota, A., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Itoh, H., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Jin-nai, K., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Tagami, Y., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Kouzuma, I., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Sera, Y., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Nakayama, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The development of a flowing-electrolyte zinc/bromine battery for electric power storage is presented. The battery exhibited the following features, in addition to well-known features such as abundant availability of materials and high energy density: (1) The aqueous-electrolyte battery, when operated at ambient temperature, is characterized by easy maintenance and control. (2) With conductive carbon-plastic electrodes, it is suitable for mass production at low cost and for large-capacity applications. The design of a 50-kW battery module is reviewed from the points of view of efficiency, construction, reliability and safety. The results of application tests and cycle life tests are reported. The design of a 1-MW pilot plant is discussed. An investigation of the long-life electrode is described.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Testing; Electric Energy Storage; Electrodes, Electrochemical--Morphology; Advanced Batteries; Battery Life Cycle; Electric Power Storage; High Power Batteries; Zinc Bromine Battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Takahashi Y., Abe Y., Sakamoto R., Tanaka K., Kamimoto M.
Title: High temperature fluoride composites for latent thermal storage in advanced space solar dynamic power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Y., MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn; Abe, Y., MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn; Sakamoto, R., MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn; Tanaka, K., MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kamimoto, M., MITI, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: Composite materials containing silicon carbide and fluorides that have been developed for latent thermal storage in advanced space solar dynamic power systems have been studied. One of the materials examined consists of lithium fluoride which is adapted to a conventional closed gas turbine with 1000-1100 K inlet temperature. SiC composites using the eutectic of LiF-CaF2 (80.5-19.5 mol%) which currently is receiving particular attention have also been developed. A higher temperature SiC composite consisting of magnesium fluoride has been developed for a gas turbine with 1500 K inlet temperature, for use in the advanced stage of a space solar dynamic power system. In addition to the material study, an experimental setup for studying thermal performance of space receiver component was designed, the details of which are described.
Index Keywords: Heating--Heat Storage; Silicon Carbide; Solar Energy; Calcium Fluoride; Lithium Fluoride; Solar Dynamic Power Systems; Spacecraft

Title: Options for a multikilowatt modular power subsystem
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Corp, St Louis,, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mackowski, Michael J., McDonnell Douglas Corp, St Louis,, MO, USA
Abstract: Three approaches have been proposed to achieve a modular spacecraft electrical power processing and energy storage system with a load capability of up to 10 to 20 kW. All of the approaches are based on using modified versions of the flight-proven modular power subsystem (MPS), a portion of NASA's multimission modular spacecraft bus. The three concepts being developed are: a distributed microprocessor-based control system to coordinate the workings of the multiple units; a separate central digital controller to achieve coordinated operation; and the use of transformer-isolated buck-boost regulators to combine the parallel outputs of three independent units. The differences among approaches, which vary in sophistication, in terms of performance, complexity, cost and development schedule are discussed.
Index Keywords: Control Equipment, Electric; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Buck-Boost Regulators; Central Digital Controller; Modular Spacecraft Bus; Multikilowatt Modular Power Subsystem; NASA; Spacecraft Electrical Power Processing; Spacecraft

Authors: Rodriguez George D., DeHaven Norm J.
Title: Chino 10MW/40MWh battery energy storage project
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Southern California Edison Co, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rodriguez, George D., Southern California Edison Co, CA, USA; DeHaven, Norm J., Southern California Edison Co, CA, USA
Abstract: The Chino 10 MW/40 MWh battery energy storage project began construction in August, 1987. The facility is scheduled to be completed in May, 1988, after an extensive startup and acceptance test program. Subsequently, a two-year demonstration test program will be conducted. The project objectives are to validate capital and installation cost and to quantify operational benefits to the Edison system. The battery facility will supply the energy needs of 5000 customers. It is planned to store off-peak power and to discharge energy during on-peak periods when the electricity demand is highest. The plant has a rated energy capacity of 40 MWh which is stored in 8256 large lead-acid load-leveling batteries. The batteries are arranged into eight strings of 1032 batteries for a nominal string voltage of 2000 V DC. A facility monitoring and control system is the heart of the energy storage plant and digitally controls all the functions of the plant while monitoring the status of all critical parameters.
Index Keywords: Electric Utilities--Energy Storage; Lead-Acid Load-Leveling Batteries; Off-Peak Power; On-Peak Periods; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Faymon Karl A., Rudnick Stanley J.
Title: High temperature superconducting magnetic energy storage for future NASA missions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Faymon, Karl A., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Rudnick, Stanley J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: A preliminary qualitative evaluation of the attributes of HTSC (high-temperature superconductor) magnetic storage indicates that this technology can have significant benefits when applied to a low Earth orbit mission such as that of the proposed NASA space station. The attributes of superconducting magnetic energy storage technology are compared to competing technologies for the low Earth orbit application. It is noted that, at this time, it is not possible to say how high a specific energy will be attainable for HTSC magnetic energy storage, but there is a good possibility that it will surpass the alternative technologies, given sufficient research and technology development.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Devices--Energy Storage; Spacecraft; High Temperature Superconductor; Low Earth Orbit; Magnetic Energy Storage; NASA Missions; NASA Space Station; Superconducting Devices

Authors: Yang Xi Chun, Yang Di, Guo Zheng Yu, Frank Andrew A.
Title: Computer aided design of a flywheel-forklift transmission system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The authors discuss a design technique for a flywheel/CVT (continuously variable transmission) system for driving an industrial forklift. The design procedure is general and can be applied to automobiles or trucks. The main objective is to determine the feasibility of modifying a 2500-lb capacity forklift truck to operate on flywheel-engine-rubber V-belt CVT power. The modification should allow the truck to operate one standard military indoor forklift test cycle without running the engine. This is to be accomplished with a large energy storage flywheel. Component system characteristics necessary to perform the design task are presented and discussed. Results show the advantage of this system for industrial, military, and food-processing industries.

Authors: Ito K., Yokoyama R., Yamaguchi T., Matsumoto Y.
Title: Optimal operation of a cogeneration plant including a heat storage tank
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, K., Osaka Univ, Japan; Yokoyama, R., Osaka Univ, Japan; Yamaguchi, T., Osaka Univ, Japan; Matsumoto, Y., Osaka Univ, Japan
Abstract: The effect of heat storage on a cogeneration plant is investigated using a mathematical programming approach. For a diesel engine plant, an optimal planning method is presented by which the operational policy of constituent equipment is determined together with the charging history of a heat storage tank so as to minimize the daily operational cost. An algorithm is designed to solve this optimization problem efficiently by combining the dynamic programming method with the mixed-integer programming one. Through a case study, it is made clear how the volume of the heat storage tank influences the daily operational policy and the long-term economy of the total plant.

Authors: Manzo Michelle, Lenhart Stephen, Hall Arnold
Title: Bipolar nickel-hydrogen battery development - A program review
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
