Authors with affiliations: Manzo, Michelle, NASA Lewis ResCenter, Cleveland, OH,, USA; Lenhart, Stephen, NASA Lewis ResCenter, Cleveland, OH,, USA; Hall, Arnold, NASA Lewis ResCenter, Cleveland, OH,, USA
Abstract: An overview of spacecraft power system design trends, focusing on higher power bus voltages and improved energy storage systems, is followed by a discussion of bipolar Ni/H2 battery development efforts. Several 10-cell batteries and one 50-cell battery are described, and performance results are presented. A comparison of individual-pressure-vessel and bipolar Ni/H2 technologies is used to suggest a new direction for bipolar Ni/H2 battery development efforts, toward a large number of passively cooled cells in parallel.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Nickel and Alloys; Satellites--Power Supply; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Bipolar Batteries; Nickel Hydrogen Batteries; Spacecraft Power System Design Trends; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Analysis of clathrate solidification
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Najafi, M., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Schaetzle, W.J., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Abstract: A heat pump/thermal storage system has been constructed to evaluate clathrate thermal energy storage in simulated heating and cooling cycles. The system includes a clathrate builder (crystallizer) system, a heat pump cycle, and subsystems for cooling and heating simulation. The authors report on the experimentally operated clathrate builder system, for which the problem of solid formation on the evaporator coils is nonexistent. This allows forced correction agitation around the cooling surfaces, increasing the heat transfer rate by as much as an order of magnitude per unit area. The solidification of clathrate is macroscopically analyzed.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Heat Pump Systems; Heat Transfer; Refrigerants; Clathrate Solidification; Clathrate Thermal Energy Storage; Cooling/Heating Simulation; Energy Storage

Title: Circuit description of pulsed power systems
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Electr Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rhee, M.J., Univ of Maryland, Electr Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Fine, T.A., Univ of Maryland, Electr Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: The results of a comprehensive analysis of basic pulsed power systems are summarized. Two capacitive energy storage systems, lumped capacitor bank and LC generator, are described. Counterparts in the transmission line system, a voltage-charged transmission line and Blumlein line, are also described. The proposed inductive energy storage systems, which are duals of the capacitive energy storage systems, are described by the dual solutions obtained for the capacitive systems.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric Power Transmission; Blumlein Line; Capacitive Energy Storage Systems; Capacitor Bank; LC Generator; Pulsed Power Systems; Voltage-Charged Transmission Line; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Hosokawa T., Kitayama T., Hayasaka T., Ido S., Uno Y., Shibayama A., Nakata J., Nishimura K., Nakajima M.
Title: Injector linac for Super-ALIS
Affiliations: NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Hosokawa, T., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Kitayama, T., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Hayasaka, T., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Ido, S., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Uno, Y., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Shibayama, A., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Nakata, J., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Nishimura, K., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn; Nakajima, M., NTT Corp, Atsugi, Jpn
Abstract: An injector linac is described for Super-ALIS, the dedicated superconducting storage ring for X-ray lithography at NTT LSI Laboratories. Super-ALIS uses a low-energy injection scheme which requires the injection efficiency to be raised, since stacking is unavailable due the low injection energy levels. Improving the efficiency of the injector required a large current, low transverse emittance, and a narrow energy spread; a low-emittance electron gun, double pre-bunchers, standing-wave accelerator cavities, and an energy compression system were used in the injector to fulfill these strict requirements. The characteristics of the system are summarized; acceleration frequency is 2856.65 MHz; beam energy and current are 15 MeV and 270mA, respectively; beam energy spread is 1% (FW); beam pulse width is 2 μs; and the maximum repetition rate is 3 Hz.
Index Keywords: Electron Guns; Lithography; Superconducting Devices; X-Rays; Accelerator Cavities; Double Pre-Bunchers; Injector Linac; Low-Energy Injection Scheme; Super-ALIS; Superconducting Storage Ring; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Akridge James M., Sitz Joe H.
Title: Technical tour of the Georgia power corporate headquarters building
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology
Authors with affiliations: Akridge, James M., Georgia Inst of Technology; Sitz, Joe H., Georgia Inst of Technology
Abstract: Georgia Power Company's corporate headquarters building, is located at 333 Piedmont Road. This study will highlight the building's unique 300,000-gallon chilled water thermal storage system, which has been successfully operated for over eight years. The 333 Piedmont building was designed to be a working laboratory of energy-saving ideas and features. The 765,000 sq ft building combines a 24-story office tower with a 3-story low-rise. Passive and active solar features are combined with conservation measures to arrive at a building that uses one-third less energy than comparable office buildings of similar size and function. In this article, the system design is described and the daily and annual performance evaluated.
Index Keywords: Cooling Water - Cold Storage; Energy Conservation; Refrigeration - Solar; Solar Radiation - Collectors; Chilled Water; Passive Solar Features; Peak Cooling Period; Thermal Storage System; Office Buildings

Title: Current limiting protector for low voltage, high current applications
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Industrial and Commercial Power Systems Technical Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Emery, F.T., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Wu, J.L., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Abstract: A pyrotechnic current-limiting interrupter (CLI) has been developed for use in high-current 60-Hz 480-V three-phase electrical bus circuits. The interrupter design combines a high continuous current rating (4800 A rms) with a high current interruption capability (210 kA rms symmetrical). Its electrical power loss is low and its mechanical construction uses no complex moving mechanisms. The CLI is used with a current sensor, electronic logic, and energy storage circuitry. The current sensor continuously monitors the current through the CLI and provides input to logic circuits which analyze and determine the validity of the fault condition. Both the fault current magnitude and rate of current increase are used in combination to make the decision when to activate the CLI. Using stored electrical energy, a detonator is activated causing an explosive cord to generate shock waves sufficient to cut the current-carrying conductors. Detection and initiation of the interruption process occurs within 1/4 cycle for a symmetrical fault and within 1/2 cycle for an asymmetrical fault. The first peak in the fault current is limited to the first half-cycle.
Index Keywords: Detonation; Electric ARCS, Circuit Breaking; Electric Circuit Breakers; Electric Fault Currents; Logic Circuits; Current-Limiting Interrupter; Energy Storage Circuit; Firing Circuit; Pyrotechnic Current Limiting; Overcurrent Protection

Title: SDSU-NRECA battery powered skid-steer loader. Test procedures and results
Affiliations: South Dakota State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hanson, Gregg A., South Dakota State Univ, United States; Alcock, Ralph, South Dakota State Univ, United States
Abstract: Experimental procedures for testing a prototype battery powered, skid-steer loader are described. Battery discharge tests were conducted to determine the capacity of the battery. Vehicle tests established values for the maximum acceleration of the vehicle, as well the battery energy required to maintain different draft loads at four operational speeds. Turning tests established the turn rate and the battery power required for different bucket loads. Loader tests were also conducted to determine the influence of load lifted on the battery energy required and on lift and lower times for the loader arms. A simple duration test involving a repetitive cycle of activities was used to determine the range potential of the vehicle. The acceleration of the vehicle was within the design range expected. The turning tests indicated that insufficient torque was available when the loader bucket was carrying its maximum load.
Index Keywords: Storage Battery Vehicles--Testing; Skid-Steer Loaders; Earthmoving Machinery

Title: Record capture and acceleration efficiency in the SURF-II 300 MeV circular storage ring
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Stand & Technol,, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hughey, L.R., Natl Inst of Stand & Technol,, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Abstract: SURF-II is a 300-MeV, single-magnet, weak-focusing, circular storage ring. It is dedicated to the production of VUV (vacuum ultraviolet) and soft X-ray radiation for research and for absolute radiometry. The injector is a 10-MeV microtron. A single output pulse from the microtron is injected into the storage ring (SR) and accelerated to operating energy. The microtron delivers 1-μs-long, 80-mA pulses. With multiturn capture, more than 300 mA have been accelerated to full energy. On March 13, 1989, the average beam current was 262 mA and every beam was greater than 250 mA. This capture and acceleration efficiency is being achieved by improved transport line optics, the kicker magnet pulse, the SR's magnetic field gradient, and the RF system.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Microtron; Ultraviolet Radiation; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production; Circular Storage Ring; Kicker Magnet; Soft X-Ray Radiation; Accelerators

Title: Product differentiation in the electric power industry
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Electr Power Research Inst, Palo, Alto, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chao, Hung-Po, Electr Power Research Inst, Palo, Alto, CA, USA
Abstract: As a result of rapidly changing technologies, economics, and general business environment, product differentiation has become a key element of long-term business strategy in the electric power industry. An examination is made of the implications of this development for a utility's strategic planning and results of existing research that supports new decision needs are reviewed. Priority service, a special form of product differentiation based on unbundling service reliability, is highlighted.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Industry; Priority Service; Product Differentiation; Smart House; Electric Utilities

Title: Studies on step-type solar still made from Fibre-glass Reinforced Plastic
Affiliations: Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, India
Authors with affiliations: Maru, L.V., Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, India; Gomkale, S.D., Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, India
Abstract: Solar stills are now widely used for the production of distilled water for topping storage batteries and for routine analysis in testing laboratories. Single-sloped basin type solar stills made from Fibre-glass Reinforced Plastic (FRP), sold with Government subsidy, have been installed in several hospitals and educational institutions in India. Experiments have been carried out on a step-type inclined solar still made from FRP. Such a still - with as well as without insulation - gives higher output as compared to those presently in use. The use of an inclined step-type FRP still with insulation is recommended.
Index Keywords: Plastics, Reinforced--Glass Fiber; Solar Energy; Solar Stills; Distillation Equipment

Title: Transient charge decay in lined vessels and silos
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of, Rochester, Rochester, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, T.B., Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of, Rochester, Rochester, NY, USA
Abstract: A simple model for the transient charge decay dynamics in lined vessels is presented with reference to the hazard due to electrostatic discharges in powder or liquid storage vessels. A simple canonical form is given for the extrinsic circuit time constant. It can be used to estimate the time required for the decay of the charge accumulated on the liner. Methods of calculating the time-dependent potential drop and capacitive energy per unit area of a vessel liner are presented. Such calculations provide the means to estimate time-dependent ignition hazard probabilities associated with energetic Lichtenberg and propagating brush discharges.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Relaxation Processes; Electroconvection; Electrostatic Discharges; Ignition Hazard Probabilities; Liquid Storage Vessels; Powders Handling; Transient Charge Decay; Materials Handling

Title: Generalized topologies for converters with reactive energy storage
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Cottage Grove, OR, USA
Authors with affiliations: Severns, Rudy, Cottage Grove, OR, USA
Abstract: A generalized model for resonant and nonresonant converters is proposed which allows the systematic exploration of circuits using a given number (n = 0 to infinity) of AC (reactive) energy storage elements. The method is simple, intuitive and is particularly useful for resonant converters. By way of illustration, the process is applied to the family of two-AC-element resonant converters to determine if any undiscovered circuits exist. Examples are also given for the important three-element family of resonant converters.
Index Keywords: Electric Networks, Switching--Resonant Circuits; Electric Networks--Topology; Multielement Resonant Topologies; Nonresonant Converters; Reactive Energy Storage; Resonant Power Conversion; Switch Mode Converters; Electric Converters, Static

Authors: McNamara J.E., Kohlwes H.C., Misin R.L., Hosick D., Allen W.H.
Title: Photovoltaic power subsystem design for space station
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: McNamara, J.E., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Kohlwes, H.C., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Misin, R.L., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Hosick, D., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA; Allen, W.H., Ford Aerospace Corp, Palo Alto, CA,, USA
Abstract: The photovoltaic (PV) power subsystem within the space station electrical power system is described. This subsystem produces 75 kW of baseload power to support payloads, housekeeping, and power system operations. It comprises four PV modules, each with two solar array wings for primary power generation and five batteries for energy storage. The subsystem main bus is regulated to a nominal 160-VDC level, with setpoint flexibility, using a pulse-width-modulated, switching sequential shunt approach. Batteries are managed with individual charge/discharge regulators, permitting controlled load sharing and low-stress charging. These power sources interface with the main DC bus via a DC switching unit, the output of which is provided to main inverters that produce 20-kHz, 440 VAC distribution power. The authors describe the subsystem, major features of the components, and the control and management aspects of the design. Control functions are allocated between hapdware and software loops, the latter resident in a dedicated controller in each module. The rationale for design selection and hardware development plans are discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Storage; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells--Arrays; Charge/Discharge Regulators; Photovoltaic Power; Space Stations; Spacecraft

Title: Devil Canyon second afterbay
Affiliations: State of California Dep of Water, Resources, United States
Authors with affiliations: Becker, Terry, State of California Dep of Water, Resources, United States
Abstract: This project is located in the City of San Bernardino (Southern California). The addition of a second afterbay for the Devil Canyon Powerplant has been in the planning stages since October, 1983, and was approved in July, 1988. The Second Afterbay will enhance the power plant enlargement which is currently in progress. Two additional 80 MW units are being added to the two existing 60 MW units at this plant as a part of the East Branch Enlargement of the California Aqueduct. The Second Afterbay will provide additional storage to enable the Devil Canyon Powerplant to provide peaking capacity and spinning reserve, and respond to frequency changes in the energy grid. This paper presents the history, operation, and economics of the Devil Canyon Second Afterbay.
Index Keywords: Economics--Analysis; Electric Power Systems; Water Distribution Systems--California; California Aqueduct; Peaking Capacity; Power Plant Enlargement; Spinning Reserve; Storage Capacity; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Diamantoglou S., Rhizopoulou S., Kull U.
Title: Energy content, storage substances, and construction and maintenance costs of Mediterranean deciduous leaves
Affiliations: Institute of General Botany, University of Athens, Panepistimiopolis GR-15784, Athens, Greece; Biologisches Institut, Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart 80, D-7000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Diamantoglou, S., Institute of General Botany, University of Athens, Panepistimiopolis GR-15784, Athens, Greece; Rhizopoulou, S., Institute of General Botany, University of Athens, Panepistimiopolis GR-15784, Athens, Greece; Kull, U., Biologisches Institut, Universität Stuttgart, Stuttgart 80, D-7000, Germany
Abstract: At monthly intervals water content, crude fibre, total and protein nitrogen, sugars, starch, total lipids, ash content and calorific total energy were measured throughout the lifespan of the leaves of the deciduous mediterranean shrubs Pistacia terebinthus L. and Cotinus coggygria Scop. From these data the construction costs and maintenance costs, as well as the construction costs of non-storage compounds and energy expenditure values were calculated. The latter values were also calculated for the evergreen stemmed shrub Ephedra distachya for reasons of comparison with an evergreen mediterranean species. The water status in the deciduous leaves is stable for a long time during the drought period until the beginning of senescence in August/September. In Cotinus an early and considerable increase of storage compounds is found, whilst in Pistacia terebinthus the accumulation is more uniform until August. The N-content is rather low compared with other deciduous leaves, the calorific energy is in the lower range of the values reported for similar species. The construction costs of the leaves of both deciduous species are significantly lower than those calculated by Williams et al. (1987) for two drought deciduous chaparral species but are in agreement with the data reported by other authors on deciduous leaves. Contrary to the findings of Williams et al. they are lower than those of evergreen species; this is also true when the construction cost of the non-storage compounds alone is considered. The values found for Ephedra are similar to the maintenance costs do not show a significant variation in the deciduous leaves. They are higher than those known for evergreen leaves but somewhat lower than the values calculated for deciduous chaparral leaves. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Calorific energy; Cotinus; Ephedra; Pistacia; Storage componds
Index Keywords: energy budget; leaf; Greece, Malakassa

Authors: O'Donnell P.M., Cataldo R.L., Gonzalez-Sanabria O.D.
Title: Energy storage considerations for a robotic Mars surface sampler
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: O'Donnell, P.M., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Cataldo, R.L., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Gonzalez-Sanabria, O.D., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: Two power system options are evaluated for a MRSR (Mars rover/sample return) mission. One option consists of an RTG (radioisotope thermoelectric generator)/energy storage device, where the energy storage is used to provide power for peaking and load leveling, while the second option consists of a photovoltaic (PV) array/energy storage power system where storage is used for motive power. Only storage systems with demonstrated cycle life and peaking capabilities that might be available by the technology cutoff date were evaluated. These were compared for each power system design, and then the two power systems were compared for the advantages and disadvantages of each particular design with respect to total system weight and volume. When the RTG and PV options are compared, it is found that the PV/fuel cell system could provide a 60% weight savings. It is thus concluded that the primary MRSR mission and extended mission could be accomplished utilizing photovoltaics and electrochemical storage.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Space Applications; Photovoltaic Cells--Space Applications; Planets; Mars Rover/Sample Return; Mars Surface Sampler; Photovoltaic (PV) Array; RTG (Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator); Spacecraft

Authors: Fujii T., Igarashi M., Fushimi K., Hashimoto T., Kumai Y., Hipota A., Itoh H., Jin-nai K., Kanazashi M., Hiramatsu T., Nakayama T.
Title: 400 kWh zinc bromide battery for electric power storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Igarashi, M., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Fushimi, K., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Hashimoto, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Kumai, Y., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Hipota, A., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Itoh, H., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Jin-nai, K., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Kanazashi, M., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Hiramatsu, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Nakayama, T., Meidensha Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The authors describe the results from a continuing series of evaluation tests conducted on previously constructed 10-kW and 1-kW batteries and also report the construction of a 50-kW (400-kWh) zinc bromide battery that showed an overall AC energy efficiency of 68% and a self-discharge rate of 7.3% over a one-week period. The cycle life test of the 10-kW battery showed stable operation up to 400 cycles with only a slight efficiency drop. The cycle life tests of 1-kW batteries were continued up to 700 cycles, their energy efficiency staying at 67 and 68%, respectively. Fault simulation tests taking into account conditions such as the stopping of pump motors, abnormal operation of valves, and over-charge and over-discharge were performed for the 10-kW battery. A short circuit test of a 1-kW class stack (50V, 20A, 30 cells) showed a linear increase of current up to 400 A and a very quick current rise of 0.1 msec.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Storage; Zinc Bromide Battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Abe Yoshiyuki, Kanari Katsuhiko, Kamimoto Masayuki
Title: Molten salt latent thermal storage for MCFC cogeneration systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Abe, Yoshiyuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kanari, Katsuhiko, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kamimoto, Masayuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: The authors present results of an assessment and evaluation of molten salt latent thermal storage systems in molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC) cogeneration systems. The cogeneration systems considered were 350-kW and 17,000-kW MCFC systems. These examples were selected after the evaluation of daily and hourly electricity and thermal energy demands for a number of possible application industries. Appropriate latent thermal storage systems were designed in accordance with the hourly demands. The storage systems consisted of molten salt latent thermal storage units with either a NaOH-NaNO3 or a NaOH-NaNO2 eutectic. The MCFC cogeneration systems with the molten salt latent thermal storage systems were evaluated by comparing them with alternative cogeneration systems with steam accumulators or without thermal storage systems.
Index Keywords: Cogeneration Plants; Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Salt Deposits--Thermal Effects; Sodium Compounds--Eutectics; Latent Thermal Storage; Molten Carbonate Fuel Cell (MCFC); Molten Salt; Thermal Energy; Sodium Chloride

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Patel M., Louks B.M.
Title: Integrated compressed air energy storage concepts with utilization of coal gasification
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Patel, M., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States; Louks, B.M., Energy Storage and Power Consultants, Inc, United States
Abstract: This paper presents results of a comparative analysis of various Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) power plant concepts utilizing coal gasification (CG). The analysis is based upon a proven CG technology, and CAES plant characteristics similar to those for the first CAES plant to be built in the U.S., the Alabama Electric Cooperative 110 MW plant. The developed CAES plant concepts significantly reduce the required coal gasifier capacity per MW of net electricity generated as compared to other power generation types. This, in turn, reduces the capital cost associated with the CG. Also, the modified CAES concepts significantly increase the CG capacity factor to values approaching 100%, thereby improving the overall plant economics.
Index Keywords: Coal Gasification; Steam Generators; Coal Gasifier Concepts; Heat Recovery Generator; Integrated Compressed Air Energy Storage; Compressed Air

Authors: Arnold Jr. Charles, Assink Roger A.
Title: Preparation and evaluation of composite membranes for zinc/bromine storage batteries
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arnold Jr., Charles, Sandia Natl Lab, United States; Assink, Roger A., Sandia Natl Lab, United States
Abstract: The energy needed to cool the battery also detracts from the overall energy efficiency. The authors' approach to this problem was to impregnate and/or coat the microporous separators with small quantities of a cationic polyelectrolyte that is soluble in some organic solvent. This should serve to reduce the rate of bromine transport by two mechanisms: 1)Donnan exclusion of negatively charged bromine complexes by the fixed, negatively charged groups in the polyelectrolyte; and 2)physical closure of some fraction of the pores. If the ion exchange capacity of the impregnating agent is sufficiently high, energy losses due to higher membrane resistance should be minimal. The ideal polyelectrolyte should be stable and insoluble in the battery electrolyte and soluble in a solvent that does not attack the microporous separator. Sulfonated polysulfone (SPS) resins, developed in earlier work3, were found to satisfy these general requirements.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials; Electric Batteries, Secondary--Separators; Polyethylenes--Thin Films; Silica; Battery Separators; Dimethyl Formamide; Potassium Iodide; Zinc/Bromine Storage Batteries; Membranes

Title: Nitrogycerin SPC. Don't say 'out of control'
Affiliations: Hercules Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reip, Robert W., Hercules Inc, United States
Abstract: Nitroglycerin (NG) has been used successfully and safely for over a hundred years. There is still danger in the enormous energy that a small amount can unleash very quickly, but ironically one of its most common uses is in medicines, to lower blood pressure and relieve angina pectoris. Hercules Incorporated manufactures and uses NG mostly in rocket propellants and gunpowder. One of the earliest tests for stability was the potassium iodide-starch paper (or 'KI') test. Although the method detects decomposition, it has been criticized as invalid. Besides its questionable value, there are other reasons to eliminate the KI test. Reduction of storage time of batches of NG and reduction in sample handling both are desirable safety practices. What was needed was other evidence of process stability to substitute for the KI test. Statistical Process Control (SPC) can be useful in this case. SPC also promotes continuous improvement, which is a high priority in NG production. The production process was examined for possible SPC applications. An SPC plan might be acceptable as a substitute for the KI test, to verify that the process has not changed over time. This paper demonstrates how one operation was chosen in which SPC can be successfully applied.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Nitration; Drug Products--Testing; Process Control; Quality Control; Statistical Methods; KI Test; Nitroglycerin; Statistical Process Control (SPC); Explosives

Authors: Stovall Therese K., Arimilli Rao V.
Title: Transient thermal analysis of three fast-charging latent heat storage configurations for a space-based power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stovall, Therese K., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA; Arimilli, Rao V., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA
Abstract: A model of a lithium hydride phase change energy storage system was used to estimate reasonable physical dimensions for a space-based thermal storage system which included the use of a liquid metal heat transfer fluid. A finite-difference computer code was developed and used to evaluate three methods of enhancing heat transfer in the phase-change material energy storage system. None of these three methods, inserting thin fins, reticulated nickel, or liquid lithium, significantly improved the system performance. The use of a 95% void fraction reticulated nickel insert was found to increase the storage capacity (total energy stored) of the system slightly with only a small decrease in the system energy density (energy storage/system mass). The addition of 10% liquid lithium was found to cause minor increases in both storage density and storage capacity with the added benefit of reducing the hydrogen pressure of the lithium hydride.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Lithium Compounds; Liquid Lithium; Liquid Metal Heat Transfer Fluid; Lithium Hydride; Phase Change Energy Storage; Reticulated Nickel; Space-Based Thermal Storage System; Electric Power Systems

Title: Space power technology to meet civil mission requirements
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronaut & Space Adm,, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: VanLandingham, Earl, Natl Aeronaut & Space Adm,, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The author examines the past history of the US role in space with respect to space power, explores the present status of this technology, and attempts to project how this technology will advance in the future to meet the needs of the NASA civil missions space program. Attention is given to the following emerging power technologies for future NASA missions: photovoltaic systems, energy storage technologies, solar dynamic systems, the SP-100 advanced technology program, Stirling engine technology, thermal management, power management and distribution, high-temperature superconductivity, space power materials, and environmental interactions.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Environmental Engineering; Photovoltaic Cells; Superconducting Materials; High Temperature Superconductors; Stirling Engine Technology; Spacecraft

Authors: Strumpf Hal J., Coombs Murray G., Lacy Dovie E.
Title: Advanced space solar dynamic receivers
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Allied-Signal Aerosp Co, Torrance,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Strumpf, Hal J., Allied-Signal Aerosp Co, Torrance,, CA, USA; Coombs, Murray G., Allied-Signal Aerosp Co, Torrance,, CA, USA; Lacy, Dovie E., Allied-Signal Aerosp Co, Torrance,, CA, USA
Abstract: A study has been conducted to generate and evaluate advanced solar heat receiver concepts suitable for orbital application with Brayton and Stirling engine cycles in the 7-kW size range. The generated receiver designs have thermal storage capability (to allow power production during the substantial eclipse period which accompanies typical orbits) and are lighter and smaller than state-of-the-art systems, such as the Brayton solar receiver being designed and developed for the NASA space station. Two receiver concepts have been developed in detail: a packed bed receiver and a heat pipe receiver. The packed bed receiver is appropriate for a Brayton engine; the heat pipe receiver is applicable to either a Brayton or Stirling engine. The thermal storage for both concepts is provided by the melting and freezing of a salt. It is noted that both receiver concepts offer substantial improvements in size and weight compared to baseline receivers.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Engines; Heat Pipes; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Brayton Engine; Solar Dynamic Receivers; Stirling Engine; Thermal Storage; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Song Seung Jin, Louis Jean F., Wendte James C.
Title: Liquid lithium thermal energy storage for solar dynamic power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Song, Seung Jin, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA; Louis, Jean F., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA; Wendte, James C., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: Eight receiver concepts with various thermal energy storage (TES) systems are compared, and the use of liquid lithium TES is recommended for its lack of containment problems, simplicity, and low specific mass. Using lithium TES instead of LiF TES decreases the TES mass by a factor of two. Results from an optimization analysis of the collector-receiver system mass suggest that the system specific mass is most sensitive to the cycle efficiency and the maxiumum lithium temperature. The preliminary design of each component in the system was done for a reference cycle with 42% efficiency and a maximum lithium temperature of 1400 K. A system specific mass of 5.90 kg/kWt or overall specific mass of 28 kg/kWe seems attainable with current technology.
Index Keywords: Heating--Heat Storage; Lithium and Alloys; Solar Energy; Liquid Lithium; Solar Dynamic Power Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Solar Power Plants

Title: High energy density capacitors for space power conditioning
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rose, M.Frank, Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, AL, USA
Abstract: Several advanced capacitor designs are described for average power space applications. Each type is fundamentally limited by breakdown phenomena. All are intrinsically limited to maximum fields on the order of 1000 MV/m. None of the units have been space rated for energy storage applications. Several problems which must be solved before their use in space are presented as well as the current state of the art and estimates of developmental potential.
Index Keywords: Electric Fields; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Energy Density; Space Power Conditioning; Capacitors

Title: Novel diesel engine cold start aid system using exhaust waste heat
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Tufts Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Selvidge, M., Tufts Univ, United States; Miaoulis, I.N., Tufts Univ, United States
Abstract: A new concept for an intake air preheater system for diesel engine cold starts was developed. The preheater system stores waste heat extracted from the exhaust flow of a diesel engine in the form of chemical energy by dehydration of lithium bromide. The energy is retrieved during a cold start by direct hydration of the lithium bromide, and the intake air is heated. Thermal design requirements for the preheater were analyzed. A prototype of the diesel engine intake air preheater was designed, built and tested. A series of experiments verified that the prototype preheater met the design requirements for dehydration time and intake air heating. Testing demonstrated that the preheater storage material could be fully dehydrated within 2 hours of engine operation, and that the intake air temperature could be raised by 46 °C during a cold start.
Index Keywords: Air Preheaters - Applications; Heat Exchangers - Applications; Air Preheating Device; Cold Starting; Heat Sinking; Lithium Bromide Hydration; Diesel Engines

Authors: Geoffroy J., Dobremelle M., Fabre J.C., Bonnet C.
Title: Dry storage facility for spent fuel or high-level wastes
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Fuel Management
Affiliations: CEA, France
Authors with affiliations: Geoffroy, J., CEA, France; Dobremelle, M., CEA, France; Fabre, J.C., CEA, France; Bonnet, C., CEA, France
Abstract: The French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) has specific irradiated fuels which, due to their properties, cannot be reprocessed directly in existing industrial facilities. Accordingly, for the spent fuels from the EL4 and OSIRIS power plants, the CEA has been faced with the problem of selecting a process that will allow the storage of these materials under satisfactory technical and economic conditions. Three conditions must be satisfied to store irradiated fuels releasing heat: containment of radioactive materials, biological shielding, thermal cooling to guarantee an acceptable temperature-level throughout.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Fuels--Reprocessing; Radioactive Wastes; Fuel Cooling; High-Level Wastes; Navier-Stokes Equations; Nuclear Fuel Dry Storage; Nuclear Fuel EL4; Nuclear Interim Storage Pits; Nuclear Reactors

Title: Space station Freedom power management and distribution design status
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Javidi, S., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Gholdston, E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Stroh, P., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: The design status of the power management and distribution electric power system for the space station Freedom is presented. The current design is a star architecture, which has been found to be the best approach for meeting the requirement to deliver 120 VDC to the user interface. The architecture minimizes mass and power losses while improving element-to-element isolation and system flexibility. The design is partitioned into three elements: energy collection, storage and conversion, system protection and distribution, and management and control.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Distribution; Energy Collection; Power Management; Space Station Freedom; Star Architecture; Spacecraft

Authors: Aminov R.Z., Khrustalev V.A., Doronin M.S.
Title: Selecting the basic parameters for turbine plants in nuclear power stations with a heat-storage system
Authors with affiliations: Aminov, R.Z.; Khrustalev, V.A.; Doronin, M.S.
Abstract: Nuclear power stations (AES) with water-moderated water-cooled reactors are presently (and for the foreseeable future) the basis on which nuclear power will expand in the USSR. AES of this type can be effectively operated with variable electrical load graphs when different types of heat storage systems are used. This article discusses how heat storage systems on AES can be used in the variable part of the electrical load graph with constant reactor capacity.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Storage; Nuclear Power Plants

Authors: Dinelli Giorgio, Lozza Giovanni, Macchi Ennio
Title: Feasibility study of CAES plants for peak load generation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ENEL-CRTN, Pisa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Dinelli, Giorgio, ENEL-CRTN, Pisa, Italy; Lozza, Giovanni, ENEL-CRTN, Pisa, Italy; Macchi, Ennio, ENEL-CRTN, Pisa, Italy
Abstract: The thermodynamic and economic performance of various CAES (compressed air energy storage) plant configurations is calculated. The possibility of using turbomachinery components derived, with minor changes, from state-of-the-art gas turbine engines is considered. It is found that a CAES plant could provide a cost-effective solution for modulating the power output of base-load stations in a wide range of fuel-cost scenarios. A description of an experimental 20-MW CAES facility recently built is given.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Gas Turbine Power Plants; Compressed Air Energy Storage; Peak Load Generation; Power Modulation; Compressed Air

Title: Mathematical model development of a solar noctural radiation assisted water source heat pump for space heating and cooling
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dama, Tesfaye, Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA; Ball, Herbert Dean, Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Abstract: The authors report the development of a mathematical model with which hour-by-hour computations can be made to predict energy consumption and economic consequences of a system consisting of a collector/radiator, collector heat exchanger, thermal storage, and a water source heat pump. The model links these devices to building heating and cooling loads, utilizing weather data from the ASHRAE Weather Year for Energy Calculation tapes or other sources. The predicted performance can be compared to conventional heating and cooling systems. A unique feature of the model is the ability to perform the energy calculations when the radiator plate temperature is varying above and below the ambient temperature. With the heating and cooling loads as the input this mathematical model can be used to determine the energy input of a comparable air source heat pump satisfying the same heating and cooling load. The characteristics of the energy savings thus found can be analyzed by varying the plate area, the storage volume, load and climate, and the initial set-point temperature of the water in the storage tank. The model can also be used with any specified economic parameters to determine economic feasibility.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Solar Energy Systems; Energy Utilization--Calculations; Heat Exchangers; Heating--Solar; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Ashrae Weather Year for Energy Calculation; Collector Heat Exchanger; Energy Consumption; Solar Nocturnal Radiation; Thermal Storage; Water Source Heat Pump; Heat Pump Systems

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Thoolen, Frans J.M., CCM, Nuenen, Neth
Abstract: The system design of the EMAFER (ElectroMechanical Accumulator For Energy Reuse) energy storage system is described. Descriptions are given of the flywheel, the electrical machine, and the converter. The present status of EMAFER is discussed, and measurement results are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters, Static; Electric Machinery; EMAFER (ElectroMechanical Accumulator For Energy Reuse); Flywheel System EMAFER; Flywheels

Title: Diagnosing high-energy piping problems with an expert system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP

Authors with affiliations: Robleto, R.A., Brown and Root U.S.A. Inc, United States; Tseng, M.S., Brown and Root U.S.A. Inc, United States
Abstract: Brown and Root U.S.A., Inc. has reviewed many high-energy piping systems in fossil power plants. These reviews have produced a large base of data, including the accumulated experience of our senior staff of engineering specialists. Many technical papers, procedures, and reports also result from these reviews. The challenge is how to best use this expanding base of valuable knowledge and experience. Recent breakthroughs in computer software in knowledge storage and control and the increasing power of personal computers (PCs) have produced an opportunity for piping data and expertise to be used more efficiently, comprehensively, and accurately. Artificial intelligence is one of these computer breakthroughs.
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence--Expert Systems; Fossil Fuel Power Plants; Backward Chaining; Forward Chaining; High-Energy Piping Problems; Knowledge Base; Piping Systems

Authors: Abe Yoshiyuki, Takahashi Yoshio, Kanari Katsuhiko, Tanaka Kotaro, Sakamoto Ryuji, Kamimoto Masayuki
Title: Molten salt latent thermal storage using NaOH-based eutectics
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Abe, Yoshiyuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Takahashi, Yoshio, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kanari, Katsuhiko, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Tanaka, Kotaro, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Sakamoto, Ryuji, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Kamimoto, Masayuki, Electrotech Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: A series of compatibility tests of metal materials with NaOH-NaNO3 (81.5-18.5 mol%) and NaOH-NaNO2 (73-27 mol%) is described. The effects of impurities in salt and matrix elements in metals are considered. In addition to the compatibility tests, experimental studies on 30-kWh storage units are described, with attention given to a finned-tube storage unit. A numerical simulation that makes it possible to obtain an accurate performance prediction of a wide variety of storage units is presented.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Salt Deposits--Thermal Effects; Sodium Compounds--Eutectics; Finned-Tube Storage Unit; Latent Thermal Storage; Molten Salt; Sodium Chloride

Title: Supercold air HVAC system design and application
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Gershon Meckler Assoc, New York, NY,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Gershon, Gershon Meckler Assoc, New York, NY,, USA
Abstract: The installation of ice thermal storage in commercial buildings is growing, based on its potential to reduce energy costs for cooling 30-50% by shifting electric utility demand off-peak. An efficient way to integrate ice storage into HVAC functions is to ice-chill and distribute supercold air (40°F; 4.4°C). It is demonstrated that the supercold air/water systems reduce the size of the primary air distribution system (air handler, ductwork) by 60-80% (and the cost by 40-50%) compared with a conventional all-air VAV system. This first cost savings offsets the cost of ice thermal storage equipment for medium-to-large commercial buildings. The ice plant, in turn, can reduce the annual energy operating cost for cooling by 30-50% in many regions (where the electric demand charge is high) by producing ice at night for day cooling. The author has developed and applied several supercold air/water systems integrated with ice storage and sprinkler piping. Systems include all-electric or partial-gas options. The author describes the basic system configurations and operation and a specific building application. A summary of the comparative system cost analysis that was the basis for the selection of the ice/air-water system is included.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Ice--Thermal Effects; Air Distribution System; Commercial Buildings; Ice Thermal Storage; Sprinkler Piping; Supercold Air HVAC System; Supercold Air/Water Systems; Buildings

Authors: Borger William U., Massie Lowell D.
Title: Space power technology for the twenty-first century (SPT21)
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Aero Propulsion Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Borger, William U., Aero Propulsion Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA; Massie, Lowell D., Aero Propulsion Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Abstract: A description is given of a government/industry/university strategic plan for space power technology development, called SPT21. Following a kickoff meeting in May 1987, detailed strategic planning was accomplished through seven space power technology discipline workshops commencing in June 1987 and concluding in August 1987. Technology discipline workshops were conducted in the following areas: (1) solar terminal dynamic power systems, (2) solar photovoltaic cells and arrays, (3) thermal management technology, (4) energy storage technology, (5) nuclear power systems technology, (6) power conditioning, distribution, and control, and (7) systems technology/advanced concepts. The authors summarize the planning process and describe the salient findings and conclusions of the workshops. Recommended funding for key technology disciplines for the total program based on detailed workshop findings and technology planning roadmaps is shown.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Energy Storage; Nuclear Energy; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells--Arrays; Power Conditioning; Solar Terminal Dynamic Power Systems; Thermal Management Technology; Spacecraft

Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Unmanned
Affiliations: Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Calgary,, Alta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Reader, G.T., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Calgary,, Alta, Canada; Walker, G., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Calgary,, Alta, Canada; Hawley, J.G., Dept of Mech Eng, Univ of Calgary,, Alta, Canada
Abstract: Likely nonnuclear power source alternatives for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) are examined, and methods which may be used to aid the selection process between these alternatives are discussed. It is concluded that the three main candidates, the closed-cycle diesel, the Stirling, and the fuel cell, are viable systems and that all three could find potential uses in the underwater environment. It is found that the Stirling can achieve an overall system energy density of between 150 and 170 kWh/m3 when installed in medium-sized vessels. The closed cycle diesel using chemical scrubbers cannot achieve these densities, but, using the water management system of scrubbing, it appears that energy densities approaching 200 kWh/m3 are possible. Equivalent data for fuel cells are not available as far as it is known, but if gaseous hydrogen is used as a fuel, then the above energy densities cannot as yet be achieved because of the hydrogen storage problem. Various theoretical and experimental studies have shown that all these contenders can be used to extend the submerged endurance of underwater vessels between 300% and 800%. Deficiencies in current powerplant selection techniques are discussed.
Index Keywords: Diesel Engines - Selection; Electric Batteries - Selection; Fuel Cells - Selection; Heat Engines - Selection; Submarines - Power Supply; Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV); Closed-Cycle Diesel; Non-Nuclear Autonomous Underwater Vehicle; Non-Nuclear Powerplants; Submersibles

Authors: Lee Arthur, James Brian D., Kuhn Jr. Ira F., Baum George N.
Title: A comparative analysis of electrochemical power sources for the DARPA UUV Program
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Unmanned
Affiliations: Directed Technologies, Inc,, Arlington, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Arthur, Directed Technologies, Inc,, Arlington, VA, USA; James, Brian D., Directed Technologies, Inc,, Arlington, VA, USA; Kuhn Jr., Ira F., Directed Technologies, Inc,, Arlington, VA, USA; Baum, George N., Directed Technologies, Inc,, Arlington, VA, USA
Abstract: Alternative electrochemical power sources are under consideration for use in the unmanned underwater vehicle (UUV) prototype program of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. The current configuration uses a silver-zinc secondary battery to demonstrate the propulsion, structures, electronics, and mission systems of the UUV. An eightfold improvement in energy capacity can be realized, within the same volume, through various fuel cell and metal anode semicell options. A systems-level analysis has been conducted to determine the overall energy capacity enhancement, vehicle performance, safety, cost/availability, and logistic considerations of these alternative electrochemical sources. The lithium/seawater semicell is closely competitive in size with the hydrocarbon fuel cells, but it has a much greater logistic burden in terms of fuel cost and refueling difficulty due to the solid lithium. The APEM (advanced proton exchange membrane) cell is found to be the most suitable for a compact, mobile application like the UUV. The cell can be made to run with very few moving parts, offering quiet, reliable operation. Wide utility with logistically available liquid hydrocarbon fuels depends greatly on the development of a compact reformer and waste disposal mechanisms. Liquid oxygen (LOX) is found to be the most volumetrically efficient means of oxidant storage for mission durations of at least six months. The combination of a chemical hydride and LOX can offer as much as eightfold to ninefold improvement in UUV mission time over the baseline silver-zinc system, but the combination of hydrocarbon fuel and LOX is found to be the best overall performer in terms of enhancement of mission capability and minimization of logistic burden.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries - Evaluation; Fuel Cells - Evaluation; Ocean Engineering; Submarines - Power Supply; Advanced Proton Exchange Membrane (APEM); Electrochemical Power Sources; Silver-Zinc Secondary Battery; Underwater Power Systems; Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUV); Submersibles

Authors: Torre W.V., Petersen P., Kellman A.
Title: Modeling energy output of inertial storage devices for the DIII-D tokamak
Affiliations: Gen Atomics, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Torre, W.V., Gen Atomics, San Diego, CA, USA; Petersen, P., Gen Atomics, San Diego, CA, USA; Kellman, A., Gen Atomics, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: The DIII-D fusion experiment utilizes two large motor-generator sets for supplying energy to the toroidal and poloidal field coils of the tokamak. One generator has an energy capability of 2250 MJ and the other of 794 MJ. The authors document the development of a computer program which models the energy requirements of a fusion tokamak and compare them to the limitations of a large motor-generator set. The program models the energy requirements of the magnetic confinement coils and also determines the current requirements (as a function of time) imposed upon the generator, which depend on the physics parameters under study for the plasma. The program is used on a daily basis, and by optimizing for minimum energy usage, significant annual cost savings are realized.
Index Keywords: Computer Programming; Electric Coils; Electric Motor Generator Sets; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Plasmas--Confinement; DIII-D Tokamak; Inertial Storage Devices; Tokamak Devices

Authors: Brown Paul J., Kirk Robert S., Patil Pandit G.
Title: Overview of U.S. government programs on electric vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Dep of Energy, Office of Transp, Syst, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Brown, Paul J., US Dep of Energy, Office of Transp, Syst, Washington, DC, USA; Kirk, Robert S., US Dep of Energy, Office of Transp, Syst, Washington, DC, USA; Patil, Pandit G., US Dep of Energy, Office of Transp, Syst, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The authors give an overview of the ongoing electric-vehicle development effort supported by the US government. The major thrust of this work is battery and propulsion subsystems development up to the level of the testing and evaluation of proof-of-concept vehicles. Principal energy storage technologies being pursued include sodium-sulfur, zinc-bromine, lead-acid, iron-air, lithium-metal sulfide, nickel-iron, nickel-cadmium, aluminum-air, zinc-air, and fuel cells. Two AC propulsion system development efforts, including batteries, are being implemented with the involvement of major automotive firms and their suppliers. The ongoing program includes test and evaluation activities performed on newly developed and existing technologies to characterize their performance potential in laboratory and field environments.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Research; Storage Battery Vehicles--Research; AC Propulsion System; Electric Vehicles; Metal-Air Batteries; Proof-of-Concept Vehicles; Automobiles

Authors: Nakano T., Hayakawa K., Shimizu M.
Title: Design study of a 5GWh SMES
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Kobe, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Nakano, T., Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Kobe, Jpn; Hayakawa, K., Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Kobe, Jpn; Shimizu, M., Mitsubishi Heavy Ind Ltd, Kobe, Jpn
Abstract: The authors investigated a commercial-scale toroidal type of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system and compared it with a solenoid-type SMES system. It was found that the toroidal type was superior to the solenoid type in terms of control of leakage magnetic field, production of coil, maintenance, and ease of installation, although the toroidal system was approximately two-to-three times more expensive than the solenoid system.
Index Keywords: Solenoids; Superconducting Materials; Leakage Magnetic Field; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Toroidal System; Superconducting Magnets

Title: Tritium handling safety and operating experience at the Tritium Systems Test Assembly
Affiliations: Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Carlson, Richard V., Los Alamos Nat Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: The Tritium Systems Test Assembly (TSTA) is designed to develop and demonstrate, in full scale, technologies necessary for safe and efficient operation of tokamak fusion reactors. The TSTA currently consists of systems for pumping DT-gas mixtures; for removing impurities; for separating the isotopes of hydrogen; for storage of hydrogen isotopes; for gas analysis; and for assuring safety by the necessary control, monitoring, and detritiation of effluent gaseous streams. TSTA also has several small-scale experiments to develop and test new equipment and processes necessary for fusion reactors. Data on component reliability, failure types and rates, and waste quantities are presented. Operational experience under normal, abnormal, and emergency conditions is presented. The DOE (US Department of Energy) requirements for the operation of a tritium facility like TSTA include specifications on personnel training, emergency preparedness radiation protection, safety analysis, and preoperational appraisals.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Tokamak Devices; Tokamak Fusion Reactors; Tritium Systems Test Assembly (TSTA); Tritium

Authors: Bevacqua Francesco, Cipollone Enrico, Morviducci Alberto, Venditti Luigi
Title: Lightning hazard and data safety
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility
Affiliations: Musorb Italia, Rome, Italy

Abstract: Summary form only given. The effects of lightning on magnetic storage media (tapes, floppy disks, hard disks) and computing equipment have been studied. An analysis of the source energy in the time-frequency dimensions has been conducted in order to define the different relevant paths of the coupling with the media and equipment. An extensive analysis is conducted on shielding solutions.

Title: Proceedings - 82nd A&WMA Annual Meeting
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 82 papers one of which appears in abstract form only. Topics covered include: federal underground storage tank regulatory program overview; risk management tools for tank management strategies; tracing sources of indoor aerosols; climate change effects on water quality; wind tunnel modeling of roadways; measurement of atmospheric elemental carbon; size-resolved aerosols, and visibility; solid waste assessment test results from land fills; testing for land fill gas collection; adaptation of auto colorimetry for filter pack analysis; the role of ammonia in sulfate formation; dry deposition of nitrogen oxides; modeling for air toxics; personal exposures to acidic aerosols and gases; toxic human exposure; Harrisburg waste-to-energy; bioremediation of contaminated soil and sludges; design criteria for biofilters; comparison of air pollution control devices; and, health risks and the alternative of resource recovery versus landfills for municipal solid waste.

Title: Main aspects of technical-economic analysis of flexible nuclear power plants
Authors with affiliations: Boldyrev, V.M.; Lozgachev, V.P.
Abstract: The main aspects of technical-economic analysis of flexible nuclear power plants are presented. Primary attention is focused on the method of reducing the different nuclear power plant variants with storage systems to a single energy effect without involving additional flexible capacities using organic fuel. A method is described for reducing the daily electrical load graph to the calculation method on equivalenting. Types of flexible nuclear power plants are considered.
Index Keywords: Economics; Electric Power Systems - Load Management; Energy Storage; Graphic Methods; Equivalenting Method; Flexible Nuclear Power Plants; Nuclear Power Plants

Title: Advanced underwater power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Unmanned
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ruggeri, R.T., Boeing Aerospace & Electronics,, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: A long-endurance underwater power system has been under investigation at Boeing since 1985. The objective of this program is to develop a power system capable of providing at least 1000 kilowatt hours of energy, and of operating continuously for more than 10 days. A number of systems are capable of meeting these requirements. The performance of power sources using artificial gills, cryogenic oxygen storage, chemical energy storage, and advanced batteries are compared. The relative merits of each system are discussed for different mission requirements. It is apparent from the data that no single type of power system can provide the requirements for power and energy of future UUVs (unmanned underwater vehicles). Most batteries and thermal cycle engines are far from meeting the desired goals, and it is unlikely that dramatically new systems or fundamentally different technology will be developed in the near future. Artificial gills could increase the energy density of UUV power systems by a factor of 5 over the lithium-thionyl chloride system and a factor of 8 over silver-zinc batteries. These systems also provide longer endurance.
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence; Electric Batteries - Evaluation; Fuel Cells - Evaluation; Ocean Engineering; Ship Propulsion - Electric; Artificial Gills; Chemical Energy Storage; Closed Brayton Cycle; Underwater Power System; Unmanned Undersea Vehicles (UUV); Submersibles

Authors: Andrianov V.V., Zheltov V.V., Kopylov S.I., Arkhangel'skii A.Yu.
Title: Optimization of segmented superconducting windings
Authors with affiliations: Andrianov, V.V.; Zheltov, V.V.; Kopylov, S.I.; Arkhangel'skii, A.Yu.
Abstract: Using an infinitely long superconducting winding we analyze the efficiency of segmentation from the point of view of the winding storage energy. We investigate two versions of optimization: with respect to the superconductor's critical characteristics and with respect to mechanical loading. The latter version is applicable for magnetic system at high levels of magnetic field and structure current density.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Magnetic Fields; Solenoids; Superconducting Magnets; Superconducting Materials; Segmented Superconducting Windings; Electric Windings

Title: VLSI applications in implantable medical electronics
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Intermedics, Inc, Freeport, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stotts, Larry J., Intermedics, Inc, Freeport, TX, USA
Abstract: Compact, high-energy batteries and hermetic packages have made it possible to implant increasingly sophisticated electronic circuitry within the human body. CMOS, with its low standby current and mixed analog/digital signal capability, has revolutionized the field of implantable medical electronics. BiCMOS promises to regain the low noise and excellent drive capability of earlier bipolar processes. Rad-hard design techniques are utilized to protect medical devices from external electrical influences. In addition, it is suggested that improvements in future VLSI technologies, such as improved dynamic range, mixed low-voltage and high-voltage processes, low-voltage EEPROMs (electrically erasable programmable ROMs), and special processes for sensors, will lead to advances in implantable medical devices.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital--PROM; Integrated Circuits, CMOS; Integrated Circuits, VLSI--Medical Applications; BiCMOS; EEPROM; Hermetic Packages; High-Energy Batteries; Implantable Medical Electronics; Biomedical Engineering

Title: Studies and calculations of transverse emittance growth in high-energy proton storage rings
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accel Lab, Batavia, IL,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mane, S.R., Fermi Natl Accel Lab, Batavia, IL,, USA; Jackson, G., Fermi Natl Accel Lab, Batavia, IL,, USA
Abstract: The theory for stimulated transverse emittance growth of proton beams is presented. Given a random dipole kick each turn, quantitative predictions for the RMS (root mean square) beam centroid betatron oscillation amplitude and average emittance growth rate are made. Because the particles undergo deterministic betatron oscillations between kicks, the effects of successive kicks are correlated; hence, only the noise harmonics at the betatron frequency and multiples of the revolution frequency contribute to the emittance growth. An experiment was performed at the Fermilab Tevatron, where the effect of RF phase noise on transverse emittance growth was measured. The RF system was chosen because it was quantitatively understood, thus enabling an absolute calibration between the emittance growth rate and the injected phase noise amplitude. Applying the above theory to this experiment, it was found that the predicted and measured emittance growth rates were in agreement.
Index Keywords: Particle Beams; Probability--Random Processes; Protons; Dipole Kicks; Emittance Growth Rates; Fermilab Tevatron; Proton Beams; Proton Storage Rings; Transverse Emittance; Accelerators, Betatron

Authors: Heinemann Detlev, Luther Joachim, Wiesner Wolfgang
Title: Design of a solar/wind power supply for a remote data acquisition station
Affiliations: Univ of Oldenburg, Dep of Phys,, Koln, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Heinemann, Detlev, Univ of Oldenburg, Dep of Phys,, Koln, West Ger; Luther, Joachim, Univ of Oldenburg, Dep of Phys,, Koln, West Ger; Wiesner, Wolfgang, Univ of Oldenburg, Dep of Phys,, Koln, West Ger
Abstract: The authors report on simulation calculations carried out to determine the system configuration of an autonomous renewable power supply for a remote ecological station monitoring concentrations of O3 and NO2. The system has a mean electric load of 100-120 W, is powered by photovoltaics and a wind-energy converter, and includes a Pb-battery storage. No backup energy source is used. The same system design should be valid for telecommunication stations having a power demand in the same range. Although the given site is characterized by a rather poor wind climate (v10m = 3.7 m/s), the utilization of two to-some-extent complementary energy sources leads to a considerable saving in hardware investments. The levelling of the energy production is beneficial for the system's battery. Only 30-35% of the load is supplied by the battery, thus yielding a low effective cycling rate which extends the lifetime of the battery. Load management strategies may improve the matching of load profile and renewable energy production considerably. Reductions in system hardware up to a factor of 2 (depending on the applied strategy) are possible.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Monitoring; Power Generation--Solar Energy; Wind Power; Air Quality Monitoring; Hybrid Solar Wind Power; Remote Data Acquisition; Renewable Power Supply; Electric Power Generation

Title: Consequences of the discontinuous replacement of radiated energy on the performance of LEP 200
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Ruggiero, F., CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: It is pointed out that, owing to synchrotron radiation, electrons and positrons circulating in a storage ring lose energy almost uniformly along the arcs of the machine, while this radiated energy is replaced only by a few localized RF stations. Therefore, even for a machine without imperfections, the orbits of electrons and positrons are different: the maximum orbit separation scales with the cube of the particle energy and is inversely proportional to the number of RF stations. Some tracing results are presented showing the consequent reduction of dynamic aperture in the case of LEP (Large Electron Positron collider) for different combinations of particle energy and numbers of RF stations. The conclusion is that, with four RF stations symmetrically installed around the ring, there is no appreciable reduction of dynamic aperture and, therefore, no deterioration of the machine performance up to a particle energy of 100 GeV. With only two RF stations, however, the aperture of the standard LEP lattice with 90° phase advance per cell is reduced by nearly 50% above 70 GeV. The strong dependence of this reduction of dynamic aperture on the choice of machine tunes is analyzed, and the example of a modified 90° lattice whose aperture is reduced only by 20% at 100 GeV with two RF-stations is discussed.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Synchrotron Radiation; LEP (Large Electron Positron Collider); RF Stations; Accelerators

Authors: Fernandes P., Massarino R., Parodi R., Tarditi A., Massarotti A.
Title: Design of the R.F. cavities for Elettra
Affiliations: Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fernandes, P., Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy; Massarino, R., Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy; Parodi, R., Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy; Tarditi, A., Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy; Massarotti, A., Instituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: The authors discuss the optimization of the RF cavities for the Elettra Storage Ring, the synchrotron radiation light facility now under construction in Trieste, Italy. On Elettra's cavities a very high accelerating voltage is needed due to the tight requirements on the beam quality, together with the very small dimension, of the electron bunches: the high bunch charge (0.7 nC) and repetition rate; and the 2.0 GeV of total energy of the storage ring. At the operating frequency of 500 MHz, and at the accelerating voltage of 1 MV per cavity, 3.3 MV/m of accelerating field are needed. A great deal of care was used to define the cavity geometry in order to avoid electron discharges, resonant or not. The optimization results in a multipactor free cavity with a very low nonresonant electron loading current.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electron Beams; Resonators, Cavity--Optimization; Synchrotron Radiation; Electron Bunches; Electron Resonant Discharges; Elettra Storage Ring; Resonator Shunt Impedance; RF Cavities; Synchrotron Radiation Light Facility; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Bisoffi G., Blum M., Friedrich A., Geyer C., Grieser M., Holzer B., Heyng H.W., Habs D., Jaeschke E., Jason A., Jung M., Kramer D., Matl K., Noda A., Ott W.
Title: Heidelberg heavy ion cooler storage ring TSR
Affiliations: Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Bisoffi, G., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Blum, M., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Friedrich, A., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Geyer, C., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Grieser, M., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Holzer, B., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Heyng, H.W., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Habs, D., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Jaeschke, E., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Jason, A., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Jung, M., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Kramer, D., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Matl, K., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Noda, A., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger; Ott, W., Max Planck Inst fuer Kernphysik, Heidelberg, Heidelberg, West Ger
Abstract: Commissioning of the Heidelberg Test Storage Ring (TSR) started in May 1988. The TSR is a low-energy cooler storage ring for heavy ions with energies up to 30 MeV/amu at a charge-to-mass ratio q/A = 0.5. Phase space cooling for coasting beams as well as for bunched beams is routinely done by electron cooling. As the ring is fed by a tandem linac combination, stored intensities of up to 1 × 1010 particles are obtained by combined stacking into transversal and longitudinal phase space (multiturn injection and RF stacking). This stacking method gives 800 times the number of stored ions compared to single-turn injection. Cooling oxygen and carbon beams resulted in a typical emittance of 0.3 π mm-mrad and a momentum spread of Δp/p = 10-4. The equilibrium was mainly determined by intrabeam scattering, and the heating in the residual gas was mainly determined by multiple scattering. An overall increase of phase space density by 6 orders of magnitude was observed, similar to cooling results at proton machines. Results on the first year of operation with heavy ions at the TSR are reported.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Ion Beams--Cooling; Electron Cooling; Heavy Ion Cooler Storage Ring; Heidelberg Test Storage Ring; Particle Stacking; Phase Space Cooling; Accelerators

Authors: Zenkevich V.B., Zheltov V.V., Kopylov S.I.
Title: Effect of sectionalization of superconducting windings on their economic efficiency relative to hysteresis losses
Affiliations: Izvestiya Akad Nauk SSSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zenkevich, V.B., Izvestiya Akad Nauk SSSR, Russian Federation; Zheltov, V.V., Izvestiya Akad Nauk SSSR, Russian Federation; Kopylov, S.I., Izvestiya Akad Nauk SSSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: The hysteresis losses in sectionalized superconducting magnetic systems are compared with the losses in equivalent nonsectionalized windings. It is demonstrated that, although sectionalization increases the losses, their ratio to the level of energy stored by the system diminishes, which increases the economic efficiency of the system as a whole. Two methods were used in the calculations: the point method, which considers the effect of all the main factors, and the approximate method, which considers only the main parameters. The latter proves convenient for general analysis of the situation.
Index Keywords: Electric Losses; Energy Storage; Hysteresis; Superconducting Devices; Superconducting Magnets; Hysteresis Losses; Sectionalized Superconducting Magnetic Systems; Solenoids; Superconducting Windings; Electric Windings

Authors: Kusaka T., Yoshiyuki T., Miura A., Hara M.
Title: RF system for the STA SR ring
Affiliations: RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility Design Team, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kusaka, T., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility Design Team, Tokyo, Jpn; Yoshiyuki, T., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility Design Team, Tokyo, Jpn; Miura, A., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility Design Team, Tokyo, Jpn; Hara, M., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility Design Team, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The RF system for the STA (Science and Technology Agency of Japan) 8-GeV storage ring consists of four 1-MW klystrons and 508-MHz cavities, which are located in four 6.5-m straight sections with low betatron functions. The accelerating voltage amounts to 12 MV to compensate for the energy loss due to synchrotron radiation in bending magnets (8.3 MeV) and in insertion devices (3.2 MeV) and parasitic energy loss (0.5 MeV). An overvoltage ratio of 1.33 gives a sufficient quantum lifetime. Since 32 single-cell cavities or 14 three-cell cavities are used in this RF system, a single-cell cavity and a three-cell cavity, in which each cell is coupled with off-axis slots, were studied. The RF characteristics were calculated with the computer codes developed in RIKEN and were measured by using model cavities. Methods to overcome the coupled-bunch instabilities will be taken for a beam current of 100 mA.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Power Supply; Electron Tubes, Klystron; Resonators, Cavity--Design; RF Power System; Single-Cell Cavity; Synchrotron Radiation Facility; Three-Cell Cavity; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Ferranti M., Ferraris P., Fratta A., Profumo F.
Title: Solar energy supply system for induction motors and various loads
