Authors with affiliations: Ferranti, M., SITRA Automazione, Alessandria, Italy; Ferraris, P., SITRA Automazione, Alessandria, Italy; Fratta, A., SITRA Automazione, Alessandria, Italy; Profumo, F., SITRA Automazione, Alessandria, Italy
Abstract: The authors consider end-user energy transformation in standby solar energy power plants and analyze various possible solutions for utilizing the energy stored in the battery to supply electrical motors, lights, etc. The conversion efficiency and the reliability of the whole system are among the parameters selected to define the optimum system design. The solar and wind energy conversion technology and the end-user energy transformation are efficiency-dependent. The results obtained based on a lossless step-up chopper and six-step inverter seem to be very attractive from the efficiency point of view and also with regard to ruggedness and reliability, very important quality factors owing to the probable locations of the systems under examination.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Plants--Loads; Control Strategy; Induction Motors; Power Conversion; Standby Solar Power Plants; Solar Power Plants

Title: Domestic remote-area power supplies: Modeling battery usage for energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Zmood, R.B., R Inst of Technol, Dep of Commun, & Electr Eng, Melbourne, Aust; McCluskey, T.A., R Inst of Technol, Dep of Commun, & Electr Eng, Melbourne, Aust; Rand, D.A.J., R Inst of Technol, Dep of Commun, & Electr Eng, Melbourne, Aust; Baldsing, W.G.A., R Inst of Technol, Dep of Commun, & Electr Eng, Melbourne, Aust
Abstract: The authors report on the development of methods for simulating the typical operating duty cycle of lead/acid batteries in remote area power supply (RAPS) systems. In developing test cycles for batteries, a RAPS computer simulation program called SOLSIM was used. The structure of SOLSIM and the effect on overall RAPS performance of the variation in key system and control algorithm parameters is discussed. The approach results in the derivation and application of battery load-current profiles for assessing the performance of both prototype and commercial lead/acid batteries.

Title: Prototype of a magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system

Abstract: The authors describe recent progress in the development of a 500-Wh magnetically suspended flywheel stack energy storage system. The design of the system and a critical study of the noncontacting displacement transducers and their placement in the stack system are discussed. The storage system has been designed and constructed and is currently undergoing experimental analysis. The results acquired from the noncontacting displacement transducer study show that currently available transducers will not function as desired and that further research is essential.

Title: Thermal performance of specific heat receiver concepts for advanced solar dynamic applications

Authors with affiliations: Crane, Roger A., Univ of South Florida, Dep of Mech, Eng, Tampa, FL, USA; Bharadhwaj, Gannesh, Univ of South Florida, Dep of Mech, Eng, Tampa, FL, USA
Abstract: The thermal performance of three concepts for thermal energy storage as applied to solar dynamic applications is described. It is recognized that designs providing large thermal gradients or large temperature swings during orbit are susceptible to early mechanical failure. Concepts incorporating heat pipe technology may encounter operational limitations over sufficiently large ranges. The thermal performance of basic designs is reviewed and their relative merits compared. The effect of thermal enhancement and metal utilization as applied to each design is examined, providing a partial characterization of the performance improvements to be achieved by developing these technologies.
Index Keywords: Heat Pipes; Heating--Heat Storage; Solar Energy; Specific Heat Receiver Concepts; Thermal Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Experimental investigations of solar desalinization units of various designs
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Abdullina, N.D.; Dzhubailleva, P.A.
Abstract: At the experiment station of the Institute of Hydrogeology and Hydrophysics of the Academy of Sciences of the Kazakh SSR, at a well with thermal mineralized water (t = 55°C), the authors set up a solar testing ground for experimental desalinization units of various types. We will consider peculiarities of these units. The first design is a desalinization unit of the inclined type, with the use of a porous evaporator, sand. The next unit is a solar desalinization unit with thermal storage, the distinctive feature of which is a thermal storage filling of cheap local construction materials (sand). A prefabricated design of a solar desalinization unit was made of asbestos-cement sheeting. A test unit of shell rock was also tested.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Applications; Solar Applications; Desalination

Title: Effect of the induced voltage on the bunch motion at the transition energy
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.Y., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Wei, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: The requirement of the two RF systems in the RHIC (Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider), 26.7 MHz for the particle acceleration and 160 MHz for storage collision mode, raises the difficult problem of the induced high-frequency RF voltage during the bunch acceleration through the transition energy. Analysis of the induced 160-MHz RF voltage on the bunch distribution indicates that the tolerable remnant 160-MHz RF voltage is V2 < 25 kV at the transition energy region. The phase space growth is found to be proportional to V2/V1, where V1 is the accelerating voltage. These remnant fields are not important outside the transition energy region due to synchrotron mixing. Since the bunch length in the accelerating RF system is approximately 2π radians in the high-frequency RF phase, the error in the high-frequency RF stable phase plays little role in the phase space area growth.
Index Keywords: Electric Field Effects; Ion Beams; Relativity; Relativistic Heavy Ion Colliders; RF Systems; Accelerators

Title: Tests of K15-10 high-voltage capacitors under conditions of oscillatory discharge
Authors with affiliations: Kapishnikov, N.K.
Abstract: Low-inductance capacitors with a ceramic dielectric have recently found use in the development of high-voltage nanosecond generators as storage elements, among which the K15-10 capacitors intended for use in direct and impulse current circuits possess the maximum specific energy reserve and minimum intrinsic resistance. This article cites the results of lifetime tests of ceramic capacitors K15-10 under conditions of oscillatory discharge with a frequency of the discharge current of 300-700 kHz and an attenuation ratio of 1.3-1.7. Three types of capacitors were tested: 31.5 kV, 4700 pF (type A), 40 kV, 10,000 pF (B), and 50 kV, 15,00 pF (C). The principal reason for failure of K15-10 capacitors is sparkover along the side surface of the capacitors. Coating the side surface of the capacitors with high-strength insulation lacquer increases the sparkover voltage along the surface by a factor of 1.2-1.5.
Index Keywords: Ceramic Materials; Dielectric Materials; Electric Discharges; Pulse Generators; Oscillating Discharges; Sparkover; Capacitors

Authors: Ellison T.J., Jones W.P., Collins J.C., Friesel D.L., Schwandt P., Sloan T.
Title: Progress in commissioning the IUCF cooler
Affiliations: Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ellison, T.J., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA; Jones, W.P., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA; Collins, J.C., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA; Friesel, D.L., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA; Schwandt, P., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA; Sloan, T., Indiana Univ, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA
Abstract: Some of the techniques used and results observed during the commissioning of the IUCF (Indiana University Cyclotron Facility) electron cooled storage ring are described. Measurements of machine properties and their comparison with design values, methods of closed-orbit corrections, and the methods used in ramping the beam to higher energies are discussed. Plans for enhancing the performance of the ring are described.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams--Cooling; Particle Beams; Closed-Orbit Corrections; Electron Cooled Storage Ring; IUCF (Indiana University Cyclotron Facility); Accelerators, Cyclotron

Authors: Wehrle R., Nielsen R., Kim S.
Title: Vacuum system development status for the APS storage ring
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wehrle, R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Nielsen, R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Kim, S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: The status of the design and fabrication of a prototype sector of the storage ring vacuum system for the Advanced Photon Source (APS) is described. The 26.5-m-long prototype sector will be assembled within a full-scale magnet and tunnel mockup to study interspatial component relationships for maintenance, as well as the vacuum system operational performance. Each completed vacuum section is mounted as an integral part of the modular structure that contains the magnets and magnet power supplies on a common base. Unique automatic machine welding designs and techniques are employed in the fabrication of the aluminum vacuum chambers from extrusions. Special chamber bending procedures and measurement checks are used to maintain the required flatness of the inside chamber light gap surfaces. Photoelectron yields due to low-energy photons in the narrow channel gap of the vacuum chamber and their potential effects on the overall outgassing rate are found to be negligible.
Index Keywords: Photons; Vacuum Technology; Advanced Photon Source (APS); Aluminum Vacuum Chambers; APS Storage Ring; Low Energy Photons; Photoelectron Yield; Storage Ring Vacuum System; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Schuchman Joseph C., Aloia J., Hsieh H., Kim T., Pjerov S.
Title: X-ray lithography source (SXLS) vacuum system
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schuchman, Joseph C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Aloia, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Hsieh, H., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Kim, T., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Pjerov, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: In 1988 Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) was awarded a contract to design and construct a compact light source for X-ray lithography. The contract is for an electron storage ring designed for 690-MeV 500-mA operations. It has a racetrack configuration with a circumference to 8.5 m. The machine is to be constructed in two phases. Phase I (200 MeV, 500 mA) will primarily be for low-energy injection studies and will incorporate all-room-temperature magnets. For phase II the two room-temperature dipole magnets will be replaced with (4 T) superconducting magnets and operation will be at 690 MeV. The vacuum system for this machine is described. This vacuum system must satisfy three basic requirements. First, it must provide a dynamic pressure (pressure with stored beam) of 10-9 torr or better to minimize electron-beam-residual-gas interaction. Second, it must be able to recover from venting to atmosphere, deliberately or accidentally, in a reasonably short time. Third, it should require little operator intervention for normal operation.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Vacuum Pumps; Electron Storage Ring; X-Ray Lithography Source; Lithography

Title: Kicker magnets for the Advanced Light Source
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Univ of, California, Barkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gabor, G., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Univ of, California, Barkeley, CA, USA; Voelker, F., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Univ of, California, Barkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: Fast pulsed kicker magnets will be used in the Advanced Light Source (ALS) Booster to accept injected 50-MeV electrons from the source linac and then eject the full energy 1.5-GeV beam into the storage ring. Their design has incorporated a number of unique elements to achieve the tight requirements for efficient beam transfer. The booster orbit time of 250 ns and a maximum of 12 electron bunches, spaced 8 ns apart, define the maximum required injection and extraction kicker magnet flat top time. A 100-ns injection falltime and extraction risetime were selected, with the 50-ns balance left for pulse setting and timing errors. The injected beam is deflected 59 mrad and the extracted beam 4 mrad. This can be accomplished with a 0.5-m 200-G magnet for injection and a 1-m 200-G magnet for extraction. A uniformity of ±0.5% temporally and spatially is required of the nominal 200-G flat top field to maintain a low loss/dispersion system.
Index Keywords: Electromagnets--Switching; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Advanced Light Source; Beam Injection/Extraction Magnets; Kicker Magnets; Accelerators

Title: IUCF Cooler ring status 1989
Affiliations: Indiana Univ, Dep of Phys,, Bloomington, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pollock, Robert E., Indiana Univ, Dep of Phys,, Bloomington, IN, USA
Abstract: The IUCF (Indiana University Cyclotron Facility) Cooler is a synchrotron-storage ring with electron cooling. The construction was funded in 1983, with beam tests beginning in 1987. After a year of commissioning, the ring is beginning to provide beams for research users. The author reviews some of the recent accomplishments and summarizes some of the operating characteristics as presently understood. The IUCF Cooler is in transition to operational status with first experiments underway and an appreciable fraction of its large parameter space explored. There have been signs of good resolution, small emittance, good reproducibility, and easy energy variability.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron--Storage Rings; Electron Cooling; IUCF Cooler Ring; Synchrotron-Storage Ring; Accelerators, Cyclotron

Title: Raising the efficiency of a radiation-type solar-drying unit
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Tairov, Z.; Rakhmatov, I.
Abstract: Experimental units are suggested which shorten the drying process by 2.5-3 times and make it possible to use 4-5 times less area in comparison with air-sun drying.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Products - Drying; Drying - Efficiency; Solar Energy - Storage; Fruits Drying Rates; Grapes Drying Rates; Radiation Type Solar Drying Units (RSDU); Thermal Storage Chamber; Dryers

Authors: Takahashi Isao, Itoh Youichi, Andoh Itaru
Title: Development of a new uninterruptible power supply using flywheel energy storage techniques
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Dep of Electr & Electron Syst, Eng, Nagaoka Univ of Technol,, Nagaoka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Isao, Dep of Electr & Electron Syst, Eng, Nagaoka Univ of Technol,, Nagaoka, Jpn; Itoh, Youichi, Dep of Electr & Electron Syst, Eng, Nagaoka Univ of Technol,, Nagaoka, Jpn; Andoh, Itaru, Dep of Electr & Electron Syst, Eng, Nagaoka Univ of Technol,, Nagaoka, Jpn
Abstract: An uninterruptible power supply (UPS) with a flywheel for an energy storage unit is described. An electrical main circuit consisting of a half-bridge converter, a symmetrical half-bridge inverter, and an inverter/converter is used to drive the flywheel induction motor/generator. Charging or discharging control of the mechanical energy is achieved by controlling the slip frequency of the induction machine. The converter is controlled by a current follow-up method using a hysteresis comparator to get the sinusoidal input current and the unity power factor. The inverter is controlled to obtain the sinusoidal voltage by using a voltage follow-up method. Experimental results are given.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters; Electric Generators, Asynchronous; Electric Inverters; Electric Motors, Induction; Flywheels; Flywheel Energy Storage; Flywheel Induction Motor/Generator; Half-Bridge Converter; Half-Bridge Inverter; Uninterruptible Power Supply; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus

Title: Advanced solar dynamic power systems for future space missions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Friefeld, J.M., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Wallin, W.E., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: A design and analysis study has been conducted to evaluate the applicability of solar dynamic power generation systems to a wide variety of future space missions. The most promising approach is to limit peak power cycle temperatures to approximately 1090 K by the utilization of lithium fluoride as a thermal energy storage medium which allows energy to be stored at a moderate temperature (1121 K). It was found that the Stirling system has potentially the highest performance, assuming that future test results of space systems fulfill theoretical predictions. Brayton systems, such as those being developed for the space station Freedom, will provide competitive performance with lower development risk.
Index Keywords: Air Engines--Space Applications; Satellites--Power Supply; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Brayton Systems; Solar Dynamic Power Systems; StirlingEngines; Thermal Energy Storage; Solar Cells

Title: Environmental issues associated with superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) plants
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Blanchard, Janie Page, Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA,, USA
Abstract: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is discussed as a developing technology for storing electric energy. Its efficiency is significantly greater than any existing energy storage method. Most of the environmental concerns associated with present-day energy storage devices do not exist with SMES: it does not use or produce harmful chemicals, no dams or other radical changes to the landscape are required, and it is silent in its operation. The author explores the current state of knowledge on magnetic-field effects upon animals (including man) and electronic devices and communications.
Index Keywords: Electronic Equipment--Magnetic Field Effects; Magnetic Field Effects; Superconducting Magnets; Ferromagnetic Interactions; High Intensity Magnetic Fields; Paramagnetic Interactions; Static Magnetic Field Effects; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES); Electric Energy Storage

Authors: Gadalla M.A., Schaetzle W.J., Heikal H.A.
Title: Basic heat transfer in latent heat thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gadalla, M.A., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Schaetzle, W.J., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Heikal, H.A., Univ of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA
Abstract: The concept of direct-contact heat transfer between the phase-change storage medium (clathrate) and the heat-transfer cyclic fluid in which heat-transfer enhancement is achieved is experimentally and theoretically investigated. The aim is to provide clear insights into the phase change of the storage medium and present a mathematical model that is compatible with the latent-heat release rate. A finite-difference computer code utilizing the apparent heat capacity model has been developed to predict the experimental temperature fields inside an insulated cylindrical horizontal thermal energy storage tank as time progresses.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Heat Transfer; Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Refrigerants--Phase Transitions; Latent Heat Release; Phase-Change Storage Medium (Clathrate); Thermal Energy Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: Bacci C., Fasso A., Furetta C., Rispoli B.
Title: Some theoretical observations on the behaviour of thermoluminescent response as a function of storage, irradiation and temperature
Affiliations: Rome Univ La Sapienza, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bacci, C., Rome Univ La Sapienza, Italy; Fasso, A., Rome Univ La Sapienza, Italy; Furetta, C., Rome Univ La Sapienza, Italy; Rispoli, B., Rome Univ La Sapienza, Italy
Abstract: Using first and second order kinetics, the behaviour of thermoluminescence (TL) emission as a function of the storage temperature and activation energy has been computed. A second approach consists of computation of the occupancy function n(t) when the decrease of the TL signal is in competition with its increase, due to a continuous background (i.e. environmental irradiation). The mathematical expressions for the first and second order have been obtained in both cases; for the second order, an expression has been obtained which allows simple calculation of the environmental dose rate by direct reading of the TL emission.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Boundary Value Problems; Probability; Radiation Effects; Thermal Effects; Activation Energy; Occupancy Functions; Thermoluminescence

Authors: Kirkman G., Figueroa H., Gundersen M.A.
Title: Device for producing uniform plasmas for advanced accelerator experiments
Affiliations: Univ of Southern California, Dep of, Electr Eng-Electrophys, Los Angeles,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kirkman, G., Univ of Southern California, Dep of, Electr Eng-Electrophys, Los Angeles,, CA, USA; Figueroa, H., Univ of Southern California, Dep of, Electr Eng-Electrophys, Los Angeles,, CA, USA; Gundersen, M.A., Univ of Southern California, Dep of, Electr Eng-Electrophys, Los Angeles,, CA, USA
Abstract: The authors report the development of a device that produces uniform plasmas of density 1014-1015 cm-3 over volumes >1 cm3 and discuss applications for the realization of plasma lens and plasma accelerator experiments. The device is based on a high-current hollow-cathode pulsed discharge that has demonstrated a uniform, repeatable plasma and can be operated at high repetition rates with low energy storage and dissipation. The high current and electron densities are possible due to a superemissive self-heated cathode. The cathode is molybdenum that has a thin surface layer heated to its melting point (approximately 2900 K) by ion bombardment during the transient phase of the pulsed discharge. This hot surface layer produces a significant field-enhanced thermionic emission from an initially cold cathode.
Index Keywords: Cathodes, Thermionic; Ion Beams; Abstract Only; Ion Bombardment; Pulsed Discharges; Plasma Devices

Title: Spectroscopic study of potential magneto-optic storage layers
Source title: Applied Physics A Solids and Surfaces
Affiliations: Central Research and Development, Siemens AG, ZFE F1 TPH 11, Erlangen, D-8520, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weller, D., Central Research and Development, Siemens AG, ZFE F1 TPH 11, Erlangen, D-8520, Germany; Reim, W., Central Research and Development, Siemens AG, ZFE F1 TPH 11, Erlangen, D-8520, Germany
Abstract: We present an experimental investigation of magneto-optic (MO) thin film materials of interest in optical storage. XPS valence band spectra of ultrahigh vacuum deposited rare earth - Fe50Co50 alloys are correlated to magneto-optic and reflectivity spectra measured ex-situ in the photon energy range 0.5 ≦Eph ≦ 5.5 eV. It is found that 4 fn →4 fn-15 d1 optical transitions contribute to room temperature Kerr spectra in Pr-FeCo and Nd-FeCo, but only in the UV spectral region (λ≦300 nm). Eu is found to enter Eu-FeCo intermetallic alloys with a 4 f7 ground state at -2 eV binding energy. However, no substantial contribution to the Kerr effect from excitations of this electronic state has been observed n either at room temperature n or at 100 K. We present a general argument that 4 f excitations of RE ions in typical intermetallic alloys can never be expected to contribute more than some tenths of a degree to θk in contrast to the well known huge rotations in RE-chalcogenides. For Yb-FeCo we have observed in XPS a mixed valence behavior of Yb showing a discontinuous transition from divalent Yb2+ in the pure metal to mixed valent Yb2.55+ in amorphous Yb-FeCo films. No f→d contributions to the room temperature MO spectra have been detected. Strong optical enhancement effects are presented for metallic bilayer and multilayer structures of the type MO-layer/reflector. The total thickness of an optimized structure corresponds to about two times the penetration depth of light. Enhancement occurs predominantly at photon energies below the plasma frequency of the reflector material and is caused by low values of the optical constants n and k of the reflector. In storage materials like Tb-FeCo the read-out performance can be improved by about a factor of 2 with a bilayer of 30 nm Tb-FeCo on Cu. Quantitative modelling of the optical and magneto-optic properties of these films is discussed. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical--Thin Films; Iron Cobalt Alloys; Light--Reflection; Magnetooptical Effects; Spectroscopy; Kerr Rotation; Rare Earths; X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy; Magnetic Materials

Title: Solar distillation of sea water
Affiliations: Kakatiya Inst of Technology and, Science, India
Authors with affiliations: Subramanyam, S., Kakatiya Inst of Technology and, Science, India
Abstract: Indian coastal and fishing villages suffer from scarcity of potable water. Solar distillation could provide a solution to this problem provided the following criteria are adopted: (a) Distillation and storage systems are integrated with the house design; (b) There is a public supply of sea water and a public drain pipe system to drain away the concentrated brine in the system periodically; (c) Efforts are made to harvest and store rain water to tide over cloudy rainy periods. In India there has been a thrust towards centralised non-conventional energy systems. Decentralised non-conventional energy devices and centralized service support units may offer a better solution.
Index Keywords: Distillation Equipment; Dyes and Dyeing - Absorption; Solar Energy; Decentralized Energy Devices; Nonconventional Energy Systems; Solar Stills; Seawater

Authors: Hara M., Be S.H., Nagaoka R., Sasaki S., Wada T., Kamitsubo H.
Title: Storage ring design for STA SR project
Affiliations: RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Hara, M., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn; Be, S.H., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn; Nagaoka, R., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn; Sasaki, S., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn; Wada, T., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn; Kamitsubo, H., RIKEN-JAERI Synchrotron Radiat, Facility, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The design study for the 8-GeV high-brilliance synchrotron radiation X-ray source ring in Japan is outlined. The facility consists of a main storage ring, a full-energy injector booster synchrotron, and a 1.5-GeV preinjector electron (positron) linac. The storage ring is optimized for insertion devices. The designed energy of the ring is raised from 6 to 8 GeV. The ring has 48 unit cells, a circumference of 1428.9 m, and 6.5-m-long straight sections for insertion devices. The low emittance and sufficiently large dynamic aperture are achieved in a Chasman-Green-type lattice structure. R&D work on the vacuum system, magnet system, and RF system are also in progress.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear; Electromagnets; Synchrotron Radiation; Vacuum Technology; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production; Beamlines; Chasman-Green-Type Lattice Structure; Injector Booster Synchrotron; RF System; X-Ray Source Ring; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: Operating results of the Electron Ring of Saskatchewan (EROS)
Affiliations: Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatchewan, Accel Lab, Saskatoon, Sask, Can
Authors with affiliations: Dallin, L.O., Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatchewan, Accel Lab, Saskatoon, Sask, Can
Abstract: The pulse stretcher ring EROS is designed to convert the pulsed electron beam of the linear accelerator of the Saskatchewan Accelerator Laboratory to a CW beam, increasing the duty factor from 0.036% to near 100%. The ring has been operating since December 1986, when a low-intensity beam was stored for a few seconds. By the following spring, beam storage times up to 20 min were achieved and some machine parameters were measured. The measurement of the betatron tunes, νx and νy, and the machine beta functions, βx and βy, showed that the ring lattice was operating as designed. Resonant extraction was first confirmed in the fall of 1987, with an extraction efficency of 95%. The extracted emittances were about 1.0 (π) mm-mrad in both planes and the energy spread less than the injected energy spread of 0.1%. The nuclear experimental program began in the summer of 1988 with up to 4 μA of CW beam routinely extracted from 150 to 200 MeV. In February 1989 the ring RF was used to increase the duty factor from 12% to 52% at 250 MeV. Future commissioning plans include the introduction of multiturn injection to increase the current and the adjustment of the chromaticities, and to reduce the extracted emittances and energy spread.
Index Keywords: Electron Beams; Betatron Functions; Chromaticity; Electron Ring of Saskatchewan (EROS); Pulse Stretcher Ring EROS; Resonant Extraction; RF Extraction; Accelerators, Linear

Authors: Heder J.L., Budney P.A., Andrew M.G.
Title: High specific energy lead-acid battery system for electric vehicle propulsion
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Heder, J.L., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA; Budney, P.A., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA; Andrew, M.G., Johnson Controls Inc, Milwaukee, WI,, USA
Abstract: The design and development of an advanced lead-acid battery system for electric delivery vehicles is described. Progress to date is based on the concept of forced flow of electrolyte through the cells comprising the battery pack. A forced convection pumping configuration circulates the acid parallel to the electrode surfaces in order to provide stable electrical performance throughout cycle life. More recently, activities have been directed toward improving life beyond the 130-cycle benchmark. These efforts are directed toward the fabrication of a 180-V, 39-kWh battery system for electric van propulsion.
Index Keywords: Propulsion--Electric Energy; Storage Battery Vehicles; Electric Delivery Vehicles; Electric Vehicle Propulsion; Lead-Acid battery; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Heidenreich G.R., Downing R.S., Lacey Dovie E.
Title: Brayton advanced heat receiver development program
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sundstrand Corp, Rockford, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Heidenreich, G.R., Sundstrand Corp, Rockford, IL, USA; Downing, R.S., Sundstrand Corp, Rockford, IL, USA; Lacey, Dovie E., Sundstrand Corp, Rockford, IL, USA
Abstract: NASA Lewis Research Center is managing an advanced solar dynamic (ASD) space power program. The objective of the ASD program is to develop small and lightweight solar dynamic systems which show significant improvement in efficiency and specific mass over the baseline design derived from the space station Freedom technology. The advanced heat receiver development program is a phased program to design, fabricate and test elements of a 7-kWe heat-receiver/thermal-energy-storage subsystem. Receivers for both Brayton and Stirling heat engines are being developed under separate contracts. Phase I, described here, is the current eighteen month effort to design and perform critical technology experiments on innovative concepts designed to reduce mass without compromising thermal efficiency and reliability.
Index Keywords: Heat Engines; Solar Energy; Brayton Heat Engines; Space Station Freedom; Stirling Heat Engines; Spacecraft

Title: Progress on PRISM, an advanced liquid metal reactor power plant concept for the future
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: GE Nuclear Energy, San Jose, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Berglund, R.C., GE Nuclear Energy, San Jose, CA, USA; Tippets, F.E., GE Nuclear Energy, San Jose, CA, USA
Abstract: The US program for development of an advanced liquid metal reactor (ALMR) is discussed. The PRISM reactor concept originated by General Electric, in conjunction with the metal fuel cycle under development by Argonne National Laboratory, has been selected as the reference concept for the ALMR. The design emphasizes passive safety features, modular construction, factory fabrication, capability (when needed) to breed substantially more fissionable material than it consumes, recycle and burning of actinides to reduce the storage time requirements for long-life, high-level radioactive wastes, and testing of a full-size reactor prototype for design certification and licensing. The plant design is described, and shutdown heat removal, reactivity control and shutdown, fuel cycle and waste management, and economics are discussed.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Energy--Fission Reactions; Nuclear Power Plants; Argonne National Laboratory; Metal Fuel Cycle; Passive Safety Features; PRISM Reactor concept; Shutdown Heat Removal; Nuclear Reactors, Liquid Metal Cooled

Title: Recommendations for improvements in the design and operation of future solar central receiver power plants based on experience gained from the Solar One Pilot Plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kolb, Gregory J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: The Solar One Pilot Plant successfully demonstrated the feasibility of solar central receiver power plants. During its operating years many data were collected regarding the efficiency and availability of the various plant systems. The author summarizes these statistics and compares them with goals developed by the Department of Energy. On the basis of this comparison, design and operation improvements are recommended.
Index Keywords: Solar Radiation--Heliostats; Turbogenerators; Solar Central Receiver Power Plants; Solar One Pilot Plant; Solar Plant Availability; Solar/Thermal Energy Conversion; Stretched-Membrane Heliostat; Thermal Storage; Solar Power Plants

Title: Development of aluminum-air batteries for electric vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ELTECH Research Corp, Fairport, Harbor, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Homa, A.S., ELTECH Research Corp, Fairport, Harbor, OH, USA; Rudd, E.J., ELTECH Research Corp, Fairport, Harbor, OH, USA
Abstract: Progress made toward the development of a viable aluminum-air battery system is presented. The general aluminum/air reaction is discussed. Results from aluminum anode and air cathode experiments are presented. Solids separation technology, a heat exchanger unit, and cell design are also discussed. The projected specific energy and power of the battery can provide electric vehicle driving ranges comparable to those of the internal combustion engine (250-400 mi).
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Design; Storage Battery Vehicles; Air Cathode; Aluminum Anode; Aluminum-Air Batteries; Electric Vehicles; Traction Battery; Fuel Cells

Authors: Nakayama Taesuke, Sera Yousuke, Mitsuda Atsushi
Title: Current status of development of advanced battery electric energy storage systems in Japan
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The authors report on the Advanced Battery Electric Energy Storage Systems Project, which has as its goal the development of a 1-MW/8-MWh-class advanced-battery electric energy storage pilot plant having an AC-AC energy efficiency of 70% and a service life of 1500 cycles. The project includes research and development on advanced battery concepts and the development of system technology. The research and development items and the development schedule are illustrated. The total budget for a 12-year program, of which 8.5 years have elapsed, is 17 billion yen. The achievements so far and the current status of the project are described with emphasis on the R&D on advanced batteries.
