Title: 120 VDC power systems for Columbus space programme
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: AEG AG, Holstein, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Leisten, Volker, AEG AG, Holstein, West Ger
Abstract: A brief description of the three different Columbus elements is followed by a presentation of the main requirements to the electrical power system (EPS). The main part of the work is dedicated to the actual technical concepts, covering such aspects as effective utilization of solar array power, energy storage, power distribution and power management. A summary of areas which require further efforts prior to or during the first phase of hardware development is given.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Distribution; Electric Power Systems; Solar Cells--Arrays; Columbus Space Program; Power Management; Solar Array Power; Spacecraft

Authors: Goldstein J.R., Branover H., El-Boher A.
Title: Battery storage concept for magnetohydrodynamic generator systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Cent, for MHD Studies, Beer-Sheva, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Goldstein, J.R., Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Cent, for MHD Studies, Beer-Sheva, Isr; Branover, H., Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Cent, for MHD Studies, Beer-Sheva, Isr; El-Boher, A., Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Cent, for MHD Studies, Beer-Sheva, Isr
Abstract: The authors describe a battery storage and voltage conversion concept appropriate to liquid metal magnetohydrodynamic (LMMHD) generator systems. LMMHD generators in principle provide a low-voltage, very-high-amperage direct current power output, and hence there is a need to develop a simple, efficient and cost-effective power conditioning system to handle this output power. Various approaches and their drawbacks are discussed. These include use of a homopolar DC/AC inverter and use of conventional storage batteries. An alternative approach is suggested for DC/DC voltage conversion to more useful voltage levels that also has built-in energy storage capability. It uses advanced flow batteries, incorporating liquid-phase reactants.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Energy Storage; Magnetohydrodynamic Converters; Battery Storage; Magnetohydrodynamic Generator; Power Conditioning; Voltage Conversion; Electric Power Generation

Title: SPE regenerative hydrogen/oxygen fuel cells for extraterrestrial surface applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United Technology Corp, Windsor, Locks, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: McElroy, J.F., United Technology Corp, Windsor, Locks, CT, USA
Abstract: The use of hydrogen/oxygen regenerative fuel cells in selected extraterrestrial surface energy storage applications is discussed. Continuous photovoltaic electric power for a lunar base, for instance, requires an energy storage system with a two-week charge and a two-week discharge cycle. The hydrogen/oxygen regenerative fuel cell system is projected to have a specific energy of 1000 Wh/kg or more. This is an order of magnitude greater than advanced batteries. As an additional benefit, the hydrogen/oxygen regenerative fuel cell integrates well with life support requirements. A slight oversizing of the electrolyzer subsystem of the regenerative fuel cell could supply all the required life support oxygen and hydrogen.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage--Space Applications; Moon--Bases; Energy Storage Applications; Extraterrestrial Surface; Hydrogen Oxygen Fuel Cells; Life Support Requirements; Lunar Base; Regenerative Fuel Cells; Fuel Cells

Authors: Bezsmertnyi A.I., Gandzeichuk G.A., Markov V.A., Radimov I.N., Slobodyanik V.N.
Title: Traction motor for an electric car
Authors with affiliations: Bezsmertnyi, A.I.; Gandzeichuk, G.A.; Markov, V.A.; Radimov, I.N.; Slobodyanik, V.N.
Abstract: The use of thyristor (transistor) pulse control systems (TPCS) in traction electric equipment revealed definite advantages of a dc motor with independent excitation in comparison with a series-excited motor widely used in electric traction with contactor-rheostat control schemes. The use of TPCS also favorably affects the operating conditions of the traction motor (TM), in which the reduction in peak and actual (rms) armature currents in the calculated motion cycles of the electric car is most noticeable. For a microelectrobus of the RAF type with a total weight of 3000 kg, capable of overcoming rises with a slope of 100 per mill up to 150 m long and operating for long periods during motion along a horizontal road based on traction-energy calculation, the following initial data for designing the TM were obtained, calculated equivalent power at a rotational speed of 2240 min-1 - 11 kW, starting and braking armature currents - 270 A and 145 at a nominal source voltage of 110 V. Design of TM for independent excitation of the drive of an electric car especially for use with TPCS permitted a reduction in power, dimensions, and weight of the motor by 35% in comparison with the base TM 3DT84.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Motor Buses--Electric; Storage Battery Vehicles; Thyristors; Transistors; Computer Aided Design; Microelectrobuses; Thyristor Pulse Control Systems; Traction Motors; Transistor Pulse Control Systems; Electric Motors, DC

Title: Stirling machines and atmospheric emissions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Battilli Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ross, B.A., Battilli Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The impact that widespread implementation of Stirling machines can have on the reduction of atmospheric emissions is discussed. Stirling engines operate within a closed cycle, which allows thermal input to be independent of the engine itself. When combustion is used as the heat source, it takes place under relatively stable conditions. As a result, the engine and burner tend to generate little noise and low levels of emission. The heat input can come from a number of sources including solar, nuclear, biomass combustion, liquid-fuel combustion, solid-fuel combustion, exothermic chemical reactions, and thermal energy storage. Applications to vehicles, space heating and cooling, and refrigeration and their environmental impact are discussed.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Particulate Emissions; Fuels--Combustion; Heating; Atmospheric Emissions; Exothermic Chemical Reactions; Liquid-Fuel Combustion; Solid-Fuel Combustion; Stirling Machines; Air Engines

Authors: Nayar C.V., Lawrance W.B., Phillips S.J.
Title: Solar/wind/diesel hybrid energy systems for remote areas
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Curtin Univ of Technol, Sch of, Electr & Comput Eng, Bentley,, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Nayar, C.V., Curtin Univ of Technol, Sch of, Electr & Comput Eng, Bentley,, Aust; Lawrance, W.B., Curtin Univ of Technol, Sch of, Electr & Comput Eng, Bentley,, Aust; Phillips, S.J., Curtin Univ of Technol, Sch of, Electr & Comput Eng, Bentley,, Aust
Abstract: The economics associated with the major system components for remote-area power supplies is discussed, and a detailed description of the various system configurations is given. The discussion covers diesel generators, battery storage, inverters, and photovoltaic and wind-powered generators. Series, switched and parallel hybrid systems are considered. Results and conclusions based on tests carried out at Murdoch University Energy Research Institute are included.
Index Keywords: Diesel Electric Power Plants; Electric Batteries; Electric Inverters; Solar Cells; Wind Power; Battery Storage; Photovoltaic Generators; Remote-Area Power Supplies; Solar/Wind/Diesel Hybrid Energy Systems; Solar Power Plants

Title: Status of ELETTRA
Affiliations: Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Wrulich, A., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: ELETTRA is conceived as an insertion device dominated facility with a large number of straight sections for wigglers and undulators, with high flux of radiation from wigglers, and high brilliance from undulators in the photon energy range from 10 eV to 1-2 keV. These design goals will be achieved by a low-emittance storage ring with beam energies between 1.5 and 2 GeV. The status of the lattice, the radiation sources, the storage ring magnets, the vacuum, the injection system, the instrumentation, and the control system are reviewed.
Index Keywords: Electromagnets; Ultraviolet Radiation; Vacuum Technology; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production; Beam Injection System; Booster Synchrotron; ELETTRA Radiation Source; Linac; RF Cavities; Storage Ring Magnets; Accelerators

Title: Temperature limiting systems for environmental reliability of telecommunication equipment enclosures
Affiliations: Telecom Australia, Melbourne, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Prudhoe, Robert K., Telecom Australia, Melbourne, Aust; Doukas, Louis, Telecom Australia, Melbourne, Aust
Abstract: Recently, Telecom Australia has pioneered practical cost-effective methods for using the relatively high latent heat of fusion of phase-change chemicals (PCC) to provide thermal storage reserve cooling and conservation of energy in the building environment. The authors identify and outline performance characteristics of currently used PCC systems They also introduce a novel passive building-cooling system for special high-reliability applications in remote-area communication sites. Such a low-cost minimum-maintenance system combines a thermally transparent equipment room that will maintain equipment within satisfactory environmental limits for most of the year with a special PCC thermal storage unit to give additional reserve cooling on hot days. The cool PCC storage may be provided through either a small air-conditioner or a fresh-air cycle during times of cooler weather. Mention is made of PCCs that are currently available in Australia and their suitability for application in PCC systems. PCC systems that are successfully being used by Telecom as well as exploratory PCC systems that are being investigated are briefly reviewed.
Index Keywords: Chemicals--Heat Transfer; Heat Exchangers--Cooling; Heat Storage; Phase-Change Chemicals; Reserve Cooling; Telecommunication Equipment Enclosures; Temperature Limiting Systems; Telecommunication Equipment

Authors: Lenz Robert W., Gross Richard A., Brandl Helmut, Fuller R.Clinton
Title: Poly (β-hydroxyalkanoates). Natural biocompatible and biodegradable polyesters produced by bacteria
Source title: Chinese Journal of Polymer Science (English Edition)
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lenz, Robert W., Univ of Massachusetts, United States; Gross, Richard A., Univ of Massachusetts, United States; Brandl, Helmut, Univ of Massachusetts, United States; Fuller, R.Clinton, Univ of Massachusetts, United States
Abstract: A wide variety of different types of microorganisms are known to produce intracellular energy and carbon storage products, which have been generally described as being poly(β-hydroxybutyrate), PHB, but which are, more often than not, copolymers containing different alkyl groups at the β-position. Hence, PHB belongs to the family of poly (β-hydroxyalkanoastes), PHA, all of which are usually formed as intracellular inclusions in bacteria under unbalanced growth conditions. Recently, it became of industrial interest to evaluate these PHA polyesters as natural biodegradable and biocompatible plastics for a wide range of possible applications, such as surgical sutures or packaging containers. For industrial applications, the controlled incorporation of repeating units with different chain lengths into a series of copolymers is desirable in order to produce polyesters with a range of material properties because physical and chemical characteristics depend strongly on the polymer composition.
Index Keywords: Copolymers--Structure; Microorganisms; Packaging Materials--Plastics; Plastics--Composition Effects; Polymers--Biodegradation; Beta-Hydroxyalkanoates; Biocompatible Plastics; Intracellular Energy; Polyesters

Authors: Sridhar Kumar M.P., Viswanathan B., Swamy C.S., Srinivasan V.
Title: Surface properties of CaNi5 hydrogen storage alloy
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India
Authors with affiliations: Sridhar Kumar, M.P., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Viswanathan, B., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Swamy, C.S., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Srinivasan, V., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India
Abstract: The Ca 2p, Ni 2p and O 1s emissions of the air-exposed sample of CaNi5 indicate that all the calcium and most of the nickel are present in the oxidized state. Interestingly, it is observed that all the peaks are shifted by 3 to 4 eV towards higher binding energy values. This observation has been attributed to the presence of insulating oxide phases leading to partial charging of the sample during the experiment. Depth profiling by argon-ion sputtering removes the insulating oxide species and the sample etched for 7300 sec shows the presence of metallic nickel and mostly metallic calcium. XPS analysis indicates that preferential segregation of calcium in the CaNi5 alloy is mainly due to induced surface reaction with oxygen. © 1989 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: Calcium Nickel Alloys--Surface Properties; Energy Storage--Materials; Hydrogen Storage; Intermetallics

Authors: Lashley C.M., Ries D.M., Zmood R.B., Kirk J.A., Anand D.K.
Title: Dynamics considerations for a magnetically suspended flywheel
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lashley, C.M., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Ries, D.M., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Zmood, R.B., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Kirk, J.A., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, D.K., Univ of Maryland, Mech Eng Dep,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: The design of a magnetically suspended flywheel energy storage system for satellite applications is optimized. An inner-ring interference of 0.006 is found to be greatly beneficial for an inner radius growth of 8.7 mil at speed. The optimum amount of iron present in the inner ring is shown to be 5.5 lb for this flywheel. Modal testing is used to obtain the natural frequencies and mode shapes of a flywheel system prototype. These results are used to suggest design modifications to remove resonances from the operating range. If this is found to be impossible, the results can be used to verify a mathematical model which can be used to study improved control system designs.
Index Keywords: Bearings--Magnetic; Satellites--Energy Storage; Flywheel Energy Storage System; Magnetically Suspended Flywheel; Modal Testing; Satellite Applications; Flywheels

Title: Power management and distribution for future spacecraft
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ARINC Research Corp, Fountain, Valley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yousef, Hassan, ARINC Research Corp, Fountain, Valley, CA, USA
Abstract: The current and future spacecraft power system is described, covering its major subsystems consisting of energy generation, energy storage, energy management, energy conditioning, and energy control/distribution. The increasing power requirements for spacecraft are discussed. Efficient, autonomous, and environmentally protected power systems are addressed. Spacecraft power system modularization and standardization for the same class of spacecraft, such as communication and sensor spacecraft, are considered.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Aerospace Applications; Energy Management; Sensors; Energy Conditioning; Future Spacecraft Power System; Sensor Spacecraft; Spacecraft

Authors: Suddarth Steven C., Bourrely Jean C.
Title: Back-propagation associative memory for both positive and negative learning
Source title: IJCNN Int Jt Conf Neural Network
Affiliations: Natl Office of Aerosp Research, Studies, Chatillon, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Suddarth, Steven C., Natl Office of Aerosp Research, Studies, Chatillon, Fr; Bourrely, Jean C., Natl Office of Aerosp Research, Studies, Chatillon, Fr
Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. A method is proposed for using a multilayer network, such as one trained using backpropagation as an associative memory. Such networks may be used for a variety of purposes, of which two principal applications could be a nonlinear associative memory with fast convergence, or as a means for testing multilayered systems after training. The basic principle involves the use of an output error signal as an energy function. Gradient descent with simulated annealing can then be used to reconstruct the inputs. The use of a 'quality' hint neuron also allows some input patterns to be inhibited, while others are encouraged.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital--Associative; Optimization; Abstract Only; Back-Propagation Associative Memory; Gradient Descent; Nonlinear Associative Memory; Output Error Signal; Positive/Negative Learning; Systems Science and Cybernetics

Title: RADARSAT electrical power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Fairchild Space Co, Germantown, MD,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chetty, P.R.K., Fairchild Space Co, Germantown, MD,, USA
Abstract: The author presents the general Radarsat mission and power requirements, detailed power requirements analyses, and a description of the EPS (electrical power system) that was conceived and developed, including energy management and battery charging methods, to meet the identified power requirements. The average power requirement of the Radarsat payload is about 2508 W during orbital day and 2019 W during orbital night. The payload peak power requirement is about 4042 W for 20 min during orbital day and for 8 min during orbital night. There is a built-in 10% margin in these average and peak power requirements. The EPS is designed to meet the above-mentioned power requirements, and its performance is expected to exceed the Radarsat mission requirements. The power modules selected have been flown on several multimission modular spacecraft missions, and they exhibited excellent performance. The missions and they exhibited excellent The Ni-Cd storage batteries also performed well. Thus, the EPS performance meets or exceeds the Radarsat power requirements under all specified operating conditions.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Management; Satellites--Power Supply; Battery Charging Methods; Radarsat Mission; Electric Power Systems

Title: Progress towards the development of power generation and power conditioning technologies for SDIO
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: SDIO/T/SL, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Verga, R., SDIO/T/SL, Washington, DC, USA; Buden, D., SDIO/T/SL, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Progress in ongoing projects of the SDIO (Strategic Defense Initiative Organization) space power program is described along with the goals and concepts of a number of newly initiated efforts. The areas that play an important role in the Space Power program that are discussed include superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES), the neutral particle beam power system demonstrator, the solar survivable power module, and nuclear multimegawatt burst power systems. It is noted that for baseload power, the lower-scale power requirements will be met by solar power systems. The higher-scale requirements will be achieved through nuclear power from the SP-100 program. Burst power options include chemical, electrochemical, and nuclear. Ground power development includes SMES to fulfill the ground-based free-electron laser requirements.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Lasers, Free Electron; Nuclear Energy; Superconducting Magnets; Neutral Particle Beam Power; Nuclear Multimegawatt Burst Power Systems; Strategic Defense Initiative Organization; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems

Title: Multiphase Flow, Heat and Mass Transfer - Presented at the 1989 National Heat Transfer Conference
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This conference contains 20 papers. The subject matter includes fundamentals of phase change, freezing, melting and sublimation, multiphase heat transfer, interfacial heat and mass transfer, and boiling flow instabilities. Analytical and experimental work was performed which considered natural and forced convection during phase change, and simultaneous stress fields. Simultaneous heat and mass transfer from spherical droplets is considered in three contributions. These studies are concerned with the effects of acoustic transport enhancement, droplet-droplet interaction and droplet evaporation adjacent to a heated porous material. The theme of heat and mass transfer associated with porous media is continued with two contributions which consider interfacial transport within and at the surface of a porous material. The role of noncondensible gas in decreasing the transport of a condensing vapor through porous media containing coarse textured foam is examined while heat transfer and evaporation rates at the surface of a partially wetted porous material is investigated.
Index Keywords: Acoustic Wave Effects; Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Interferometry, Holographic; Mass Transfer; Double Pipe Structure; EIREV; Fixed Grid System; Phase Change Material; Steady State Solidification; Temperature Transformation; Flow of Fluids

Title: Parametric study of a solar and nocturnal radiation assisted heat pump mathematical model for space heating and cooling
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dama, Tesfaye, Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA; Ball, Herbert Dean, Kansas State Univ, Dep of Mech Eng,, Manhattan, KS, USA
Abstract: A mathematical model of a system consisting of a collector/radiator, collector heat exchanger, thermal storage, and a water source heat pump has been developed. The model has been linked to building heating and collection loads and utilizes weather data from the ASHRAE Weather Year for Energy Calculation tapes. The performance of such a comfort conditioning system depends on the properties and characteristics of the major components, the storage tank base temperature, the ratio of collector area to storage volume, the building heating and cooling loads, and the local climate. A parametric investigation of the effect of varying a number of these quantities, individually and, in some cases, in concert, is presented. Initially, the model is used to determine the optimum collector area/storage tank volume to handle the design day cooling load for a given location. Then, the annual energy savings, as compared to an air-source heat pump, are determined for three different climate conditions using hour-by-hour computations. It is predicted that maximum annual energy savings would be realized in locations with moderate climates (Dodge City, KS), less in cold climates (Madison, WI), and least in warm climates (Brownsville, TX).
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Solar Energy Systems; Energy Utilization; Heat Exchangers; Heating--Solar; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Air-Source Heat Pump; Design Day Cooling Load; Nocturnal Radiation; Thermal Storage; Water-Source Heat Pump; Heat Pump Systems

Authors: Schoenung Susan M., Hassenzahl William V., Filios Paul G.
Title: U.S. program to develop superconducting magnetic energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: W.J. Schafer Assoc Inc, Pleasanton,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schoenung, Susan M., W.J. Schafer Assoc Inc, Pleasanton,, CA, USA; Hassenzahl, William V., W.J. Schafer Assoc Inc, Pleasanton,, CA, USA; Filios, Paul G., W.J. Schafer Assoc Inc, Pleasanton,, CA, USA
Abstract: The US program to develop superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is designed to answer questions of technical and economic viability by the mid-1990s, thereby paving the way to commercialization. The authors present a brief description of SMES technology and a review of the programmatic aspects of the ongoing program, including Electric Power Research Institute and US Department of Defense objectives, critical issues, and program milestones. The potential impact of high-temperature superconductors on SMES is discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Superconducting Materials; Electric Power Research Institute; High Temperature Superconductors; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; US Department of Defense; Superconducting Magnets

Authors: Keddy E., Sena J.T., Merrigan M., Heidenreich Gary, Johnson Steve
Title: Transient performance evaluation of an integrated heat pipe-thermal storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Keddy, E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Sena, J.T., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Merrigan, M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Heidenreich, Gary, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Johnson, Steve, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Abstract: Details of test procedures and results from transient performance tests of heat-pipe-thermal-storage system are presented. This system was developed as a part of an organic Rankine-cycle-solar dynamic power system receiver for future power systems. The integrated system consists of potassium heat-pipe elements that incorporate thermal energy storage canisters within the vapor space and an organic fluid (toluene) heater tube used as the condenser region of the heat pipe. The transient performance tests determine the operating characteristics and power input limits of the integrated heat-pipe-thermal-storage unit under conditions corresponding to reacquisition of the sun during emergence from eclipse conditions and to the initial start-up of the solar dynamic power system. The tests demonstrate that the heat-pipe-thermal storage element is not limited under conditions corresponding to emergence from eclipse during normal orbital operations and that the heat pipe will start from the frozen condition with the full input power at the outset.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Storage; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Rankine Cycle; Solar Receiver; Space Power; Test Procedures; Thermal Storage; Transient Performance; Heat Pipes

Authors: Hyman Barry, Kunkle Rick, Bernstein Sam
Title: Selecting commercial building types most suitable for electric thermal storage technology
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hyman, Barry, Univ of Washington, United States; Kunkle, Rick, Univ of Washington, United States; Bernstein, Sam, Univ of Washington, United States
Abstract: Multiattribute utility theory is used to select those commercial building types that are most suitable for application of packaged crushed rock electric thermal storage systems. Each of 11 building types are evaluated with respect to 5 different attributes in each of 10 geographical regions across the United States. The results indicate that small office buildings and retail stores are the most attractive building types in all 10 regions. A sensitivity analysis demonstrates that the relative attractiveness of these two building types is insensitive to substantial changes in the weighting factors that are applied to the attributes.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Space Heating; Energy Utilization; Mathematical Techniques--Sensitivity Analysis; Electric Thermal Storage Technology; Multiattribute Utility Theory; Off Peak Loads; Heating

Title: Experimental solar unit for curing tobacco with solar-energy storage
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Artykov, S.A.; Umurzakov, E.U.
Abstract: The greater part of the tobacco harvest in Central Asia is dried during the summer months, which are characterized by high temperatures and low humidity. The duration of sunshine reaches 367-397 hr. In order to intensify the curing of tobacco in a solar unit it is important to maintain the temperature during the night. For the purpose of raising the intensity of the curing process at night, the authors designed, built, and tested a solar unit for curing tobacco with thermal storage of solar energy. It was shown that storage of solar energy makes it possible to significantly raise the productivity of a solar unit for curing tobacco.
Index Keywords: Farm Buildings--Heating; Solar Energy--Storage; Solar Curing Unit; Tobacco Leaves Yellowing; Tunnel Type Solar Unit; Tobacco

Title: Automated inspection and handling system in Lan-Yu radwaste storage site
Source title: Low and Intermediate Level Radiactive Waste Management
Affiliations: Atomic Energy Council, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Yang, C.T., Atomic Energy Council, Taiwan; Lo, L.F., Atomic Energy Council, Taiwan
Abstract: Lan-Yu Low-level Radwaste Storage Site which is operated by Radwaste Administration, Atomic Energy Council of Executive Yuan, R.O.C. This site has been in operation since 1982. Through November, 1988, the site has received 58,452 drums of low-level radwaste from Taiwan Power Company and Institute of Nuclear Energy Research. In 1987, Radwaste Administration has developed remote-controlled radwaste drum off-loading system and purchased one 25 ton remote-controlled mobile crane. It commenced operation in February 1988. The operator in the control room can operate through TV) screen to handle 3 drums of radwaste to the desired position. The distance between each drum grappler can be automatically adjusted to the desired clearance. We'll give you a brief explanation of the Lan-Yu radwaste handling system and radiation dose received by personnel before and after the operation. Statistical comparison of labor savings and the reason of decreasing the dose successfully.
Index Keywords: Inspection--Automation; Radioactive Materials--Inspection; Lan-Yu Radwaste Handling System; Low-Level Radwaste Storage Site; Radwaste Handling System; Radwaste Receiving Criteria; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Overview of the U.S. program for the disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level waste
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Fuel Management
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frei, M.W., U.S. Dep of Energy, United States; Dayem, N.J., U.S. Dep of Energy, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a brief overview of the geologic repository program being conducted in the United States by the Department of Energy (DOE). The development of a geologic repository remains the focus of the U.S. program, even though the waste-management system authorized by the U.S. Congress in recent legislation includes a facility for monitored retrievable storage. The Congress decided to select one site - Yucca Mountain in Nevada - as the candidate site for characterization, and the DOE's major effort in the near term is determining that this site is technically suitable. Included in this paper are regulatory requirements, a brief description of each element of the repository system (the repository, the waste package, and the site), the DOE's general plans for the future, licensing and quality assurance, the current schedule, and institutional activities.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Radioactive Materials--United States; Geologic Repository Program; High-Level Waste; Nuclear Waste Disposal Requirements; US Nuclear Waste Management; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Algazi V.R., Ford G.E., Hildum E.
Title: Digital representation and storage of high quality color images by anisotropic enhancement and subsampling
Source title: ICASSP, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing - Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Algazi, V.R., Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA; Ford, G.E., Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA; Hildum, E., Univ of California, Davis, CA, USA
Abstract: The application of novel anisotropic filter design techniques based on properties of human vision to the processing of luminance and chrominance components of color images is considered. Applied independently, these anisotropic filters can be used for the sequential digital representation of images by subsampling. By using them with two-dimensional quadrature modulation of chrominance signals, they led to a novel scheme for color composite images in which the skewing of energy due to the anisotropy of the filters improves the juxtaposition of luminance and chrominance in the two-dimensional frequency domain. It is found that the image quality is substantially better than that of NTSC images for either sequential or composite techniques.
Index Keywords: Signal Filtering and Prediction; Television, Color; Vision; Anisotropic Enhancement; Color Images; Digital Representation; Human Vision; Image Processing

Title: Comparison of solar photovoltaic and nuclear reactor power systems for a human-tended lunar observatory
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hickman, J.M., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Bloomfield, H.S., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: In a study for the NASA Office of Exploration, photovoltaic (PV) and nuclear surface power systems in the 20- to 100-kWe range were examined for use at a human-tended lunar astronomical observatory, and estimates of the power system masses were made. The candidate systems consisted of three photovoltaic arrays with gaseous reactant RFC storage, a GaAs PV power system with cryogenic reactant RFC storage, a nuclear power system with Stirling cycle energy conversion, and a nuclear power system with thermoelectric energy conversion. The last system, consisting of a completely assembled SP-100 nuclear reactor power system using thermoelectric conversion and integrated with a lunar lander, is recommended for further study due to its low system mass, potential for modular growth, and applicability to other surface power missions, particularly in the Martian system.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Reactors; Radio Astronomy; Solar Cells; Spacecraft--Lunar Landing; Astronomical Observatory; Cryogenic Reactant RFC Storage; Lunar Observatory; Martian System; Nuclear Reactor Power systems; Photovoltaic Arrays; Photovoltaic Cells

Title: Cooling of accelerator beams to improve focal properties
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nucl Study,, Tanashi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Katayama, Takeshi, Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nucl Study,, Tanashi, Jpn
Abstract: For inertial fusion with a heavy ion beam, several storage and buncher rings will be used to accumulate a high-current beam and produce a bunch shape as narrow as approximately 50 ns. The beams extracted from these rings will be transported to the target and used for the implosion of fuels. The key issues among the many accelerator beam dynamics problems are: (1) the suppression of coherent instabilities of high-current, short bunched beams of relatively low energy (approximately 50 MeV/u); (2) focusing the beam uniformly on the small target through the long beam transport line in the presence of chromatic aberration; and (3) the selection of a structure and materials to achieve a plasma temperature of several hundreds of electron-volts. Present research is focused on beam cooling devices to be installed for the improvement of beam emittance and momentum spread, to assure a small focal spot of the extracted beam on the target. Stochastic and electron beam cooling techniques are being developed.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Energy--Fusion Reactions; Abstract Only; Accelerator Beam Dynamics; Electron Beam Cooling; Inertial Confinement Fusion; Stochastic Cooling; Ion Beams

Title: Space station photovoltaic power module design
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vogt, S.T., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Proeschel, R.A., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: A description is given of the space station photovoltaic power module, which is designed to provide 18.75 kW of electrical power. Four such modules supply the 75 kW of electrical power used on the Phase I station. The function of each module is to generate photovoltaic DC power, store a portion of it for use during eclipse, and convert the net DC output to AC for distribution to users throughout the station by the power management and distribution system. Power is generated by planar solar array assemblies with silicon solar cells. Energy storage is provided by multiple individual pressure vessel Ni-H2 batteries contained in the energy storage assemblies. Provisions for thermal control, pointing and tracking, and DC-to-AC power conversion are also included in the module design.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters; Energy Storage; Photovoltaic Cells; Solar Cells--Arrays; DC-to-AC Power Conversion; Photovoltaic Power Modules; Spacecraft

Authors: Nakayama Taesuke, Hiramatsu Toshio, Ohtaka Eiji
Title: Current status of development of advanced battery electric energy storage system in Japan
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: New Energy Dev Organ, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Nakayama, Taesuke, New Energy Dev Organ, Tokyo, Jpn; Hiramatsu, Toshio, New Energy Dev Organ, Tokyo, Jpn; Ohtaka, Eiji, New Energy Dev Organ, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The Advanced Battery Electric Energy Storage System Project has been in progress since 1980. The final goal of this project is the development of a 1-MW/8-MWh-class advanced battery electric energy storage pilot plant having an AC-AC energy efficiency of 70% and a service life of 1500 cycles. The objective is to establish the feasibility of its practical application by the end of 1991. The development of this system includes research and development of advanced battery concepts and development of system technology. Cycle life tests of 1-kW-class and 10-kW-class batteries are continuing smoothly and are gradually moving toward the goal of 1500 cycles. The performance of the modules is generally satisfactory.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Japan; Advanced Battery Concepts; Cycle Life Tests; Energy Storage Pilot Plant; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Tashiro S., Banba T., Mitamura H., Kamizono H., Kikkawa S., Matsumoto S., Muraoka S., Nakamura H.
Title: Safety examination of HLW solidified products at WASTEF
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Fuel Management
Affiliations: Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tashiro, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Banba, T., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Mitamura, H., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Kamizono, H., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Kikkawa, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Matsumoto, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Muraoka, S., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan; Nakamura, H., Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Japan
Abstract: Studies have been carried out on solidified forms of the high-level radioactive wastes at WASTEF in order to obtain source term data useful for safety evaluations of the waste management techniques on glass forms and to develop a new technology on Synroc. The present paper briefly describes specifications of the facility and reviews the experimental results obtained under the storage or disposal conditions. In connection with the glass storage, volatilization behaviors of radioactive substances from glass forms were investigated. For the long-term evaluation, leachability has been researched on glass forms containing various radionuclides such as transuranic elements. Radiation stability of glass forms and Synroc has been studied using a 244Cm-doping method for > 10,000 years equivalent.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Industry--Japan; Radioactive Materials--Management; Acceleration Alpha Radiation Stability Test; High-Level Radioactive Wastes; Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI); Nuclear Waste Vitrification; Radioactive Glass Forms; Waste Safety Testing Facility (WASTEF); Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Brauner G., Pesch H., Wahi A.
Title: Load management and dynamic stability improvement in industrial networks by battery energy storage plant
Affiliations: AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Brauner, G., AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Germany; Pesch, H., AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Germany; Wahi, A., AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Germany
Abstract: While planning industrial networks large motor loads have to be taken into account. In case of faults motor re-acceleration causes significant reactive power deficits. Loss of network connection results in active power imbalances. As a new principle a battery storage plant can be introduced. A new field of application of BSP is describe from fast active and reactive power balancing to improvement of stability and oscillation damping. This is not only applicable for load control under normal operating conditions but also for network recovery after dynamic events.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems--Reactive Power; Industrial Plants--Power Supply; Battery Energy Storage; Dynamic Stability; Industrial Grids; Motor Loads; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Circuit description of inductive energy storage pulsed power systems
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Dep of Electr Eng,, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kung, C.C., Univ of Maryland, Dep of Electr Eng,, College Park, MD, USA; Rhee, M.J., Univ of Maryland, Dep of Electr Eng,, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: A comprehensive circuit analysis of basic inductive energy pulsed power systems has been conducted. In most practical systems, the inductive energy is stored in a lumped inductor by a slow current charging and then rapidly released to a load by means of an opening switch. Such a system may be practical for generation of a relatively slow output pulse. It has been shown by M. J. Rhee et al. (1987) that, as in capacitive systems, a fast square pulse can be produced by using a transmission line for energy storage in lieu of the lumped inductor, resulting in a high power multiplication. In addition, the authors have proposed a few other inductive energy circuits that may be useful for practical applications. These are the duals of well-known capacitive energy circuits such as the LC generator and the Blumlein line. The output pulse waveforms, with relevant circuit parameters, have been derived for a number of basic inductive energy storage circuits.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus--Analysis; Abstract Only; Fast Opening Switches; Inductive Energy Circuits; Inductive Energy Storage; Pulsed Power Systems; Electronic Circuits, Switching

Authors: Hartjen G.L., Applewhite A.Z., Hall A.M.
Title: Storage and testing of 220 ampere-hour nickel-hydrogen battery cells in low Earth orbit
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ford Aerosp Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hartjen, G.L., Ford Aerosp Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Applewhite, A.Z., Ford Aerosp Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Hall, A.M., Ford Aerosp Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Abstract: Seven 220-Ah, nickel-hydrogen battery cells were produced with the primary goal of reducing cell weight and volume and expanding the range of available cell capacities. This effort has demonstrated the feasibility of advanced high-power cells incorporating the best features of state-of-the-art cell designs while combining features of producible and cost-effective cells. After acceptance testing, characterization testing, and 160 low Earth orbit (LEO) cycles, the test cells were placed into storage for 18 months. Upon removal from storage, two reconditioning cycles were performed, and characterization testing was repeated. A comparison of test results indicated no degradation in cell performance. LEO recycling was resumed at 40% depth of discharge. Approximately 3000 cycles have been performed with interim capacity measurements taken every 1000 cycles, showing no measurable degradation.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Cell Weight; High-Power Cells; Low Earth Orbit; Nickel-Hydrogen Battery; Reconditioning Cycles; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Takagi S., Okamoto N., Kakizaki K., Satoh S., Goto T., Ishikawa K.
Title: High repetition rate excimer laser
Affiliations: Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Takagi, S., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn; Okamoto, N., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn; Kakizaki, K., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn; Satoh, S., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn; Goto, T., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn; Ishikawa, K., Toshiba Corp, Yokohama, Jpn
Abstract: A very-high-repetition-rate excimer laser for many kinds of industrial applications is being developed. As the first step an experimental apparatus capable of circulating gas uniformly at flow rates up to 100 m/s was constructed. To investigate the fundamental relationship between discharge stability and gas velocity, a discharge in a triple sequential pulse mode with varied pulse interval was used. The arcing discharge rate in percent versus the inverse of pulse interval time for various gas velocities and gas mixtures is shown. The discharge size was 8 mm × 10 mm × 280 mm, and the applied voltage was 23 kV with a 13-nF storage capacitor. With Xe:HCl:He = 26:3:2061 Torr and gas velocity of 70 m/s, stable operation was achieved in a triple pulse mode with 0.3-ms intevals and no arcing. The laser output energy was 40 mJ/pulse.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Helium; Xenon; Digest of Paper; Discharge Stability; Triple Pulse Modes; Lasers, Excimer

Authors: Gay R.L., Pidcoke L.H., Munaim A.I., Springer T.H.
Title: Tests of heat transfer enhancement for thermal energy storage canisters
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gay, R.L., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Pidcoke, L.H., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Munaim, A.I., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Springer, T.H., Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: The use of phase change materials (PCMs) for storage of thermal energy for space power systems during the eclipse portion of orbit is being investigated. The PCMs are typically contained in metal canisters, and a heat transfer fluid is used to transfer thermal energy in and out of the canisters. The major limitation to heat transfer is the thermal conductivity of the PCM. Incomplete freezing or melting can occur due to this limitation, and as much as 25% of the PCM may be underutilized. To improve heat conduction to the PCM, heat transfer enhancement designs were made and analyzed by a finite-difference technique. Radial fins of 0.25- and 0.51-mm thickness were recommended as a result of this analysis. In this design, the fins were stacked on a central rod at a spacing of 2.5 mm. The heat transfer enhancement designs were tested in 25.4-mm OD, 1.3-mm wall cylindrical tube calorimeters, which were filled with the fin material and PCM. Simple copper bar fins and a coiled copper screen improved the overall heat transfer by up to 110% in pure LiOH. Nickel fins of 0.25- and 0.51-mm thickness improved the heat transfer by up to 160% in 80.5 mole% LiF-19.5 mole% CaF2. The use of internal structure can significantly improve heat transfer, and this option should be considered in the overall design to minimize system mass.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Thermal Conductivity; Phase Change Materials; Thermal Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Thermal performance deterioration in solar energy system due to the flow nonuniformity in its collector heat exchanger
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Mech Eng Dep, Univ of Detroit,, Detroit, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chiou, J.P., Mech Eng Dep, Univ of Detroit,, Detroit, MI, USA
Abstract: A mathematical method to predict the deterioration of the thermal performance of a solar energy system using a double-loop arrangement and a collector heat exchanger in place of a single-loop system is presented. 50/50 aqueous ethylene glycol solution is used in the collector loop; water is used in the storage tank loop, i.e., in the rest of the system. The collector is a flat-plate type with all the flow passages connected in parallel. A single-pass, plate-type liquid-to-liquid crossflow heat exchanger is used to transfer the heat energy from the collector loop to the storage tank loop. The two-dimensional flow nonuniformity on the water flow side in the collector heat exchanger is taken into account. It was found that if the fluid flow distribution through the collector heat exchanger is nonuniform, as is the case under actual operating conditions, the performance of the exchanger will deteriorate. Accordingly the performance of the entire solar system will deteriorate. A simple factor has been developed to assess the system performance penalty imposed by the collector heat exchanger in a double-loop system. This factor makes it relatively simple to determine the optimum size of the solar collector for various conditions.
Index Keywords: Glycols; Heat Exchangers--Flow; Mathematical Models; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Collector Heat Exchanger; Double-Loop Solar Water Heating System; Ethylene Glycol; Flow Nonuniformity; Liquid-to-Liquid Crossflow Heat Exchanger; Hot Water Supply Systems

Title: Design considerations, operating and maintenance experience with wet storage of Ontario hydro's used fuel
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Fuel Management
Affiliations: Ontario Hydro, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Frost, C.R., Ontario Hydro, Canada
Abstract: The characteristics of Ontario Hydro's fuel and at-reactor used fuel storage water pools (or used fuel bays) are described. There are two types of bay, known respectively as primary bays and auxiliary bays, used for at-reactor used fuel storage. Used fuel is discharged remotely from Ontario Hydro's reactors to the primary bays for initial storage and cooling. The auxiliary bays are used to receive and store fuel after its initial cooling in the primary bay, and provide additional storage capacity as needed.
Index Keywords: Cost Accounting; Heat Exchangers--Cleaning; Nuclear Energy--Canada; Canadian Deuterium Uranium Reactor (CANDU); Candu Fuel Storage Costs; Hydro Nuclear Station; Ontario Hydro's Used Fuel; Nuclear Reactors

Authors: Su S.T., Dean G.Thomas, Rodda Kenneth V.
Title: Modification of Leroy Anderson Dam
Affiliations: Tudor Engineering Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Su, S.T., Tudor Engineering Co, United States; Dean, G.Thomas, Tudor Engineering Co, United States; Rodda, Kenneth V., Tudor Engineering Co, United States
Abstract: An extensive modification program has been implemented to improve the safety and enhance the performance of the Leroy Anderson Dam. The Leroy Anderson Reservoir has a maximum storage of 91,000 acre-feet and is the largest reservoir in Santa Clara Valley Water District's water supply system. The modification program consists of raising the crest of the embankment dam to meet the current freeboard requirement, enlarging the spillway to safety pass the probable maximum flood, and installing a new multiport intake structure to ensure a reliable supply of water. In addition, an 800-kW small hydroelectric power plant for energy recovery has been constructed. This paper presents the actual experience on the design and construction of the modfication works.
Index Keywords: Power Plants--California; Reservoirs--Inlets; Spillways--Design; Crest Raising; Leroy Anderson Dam; Modification Program; Probable Maximum Flood; Santa Clara County; Dams, Embankment

Authors: Malesani L., Rossetto L., Tenti P.
Title: Active power filter with hybrid energy storage
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of Padova,, Padua, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Malesani, L., Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of Padova,, Padua, Italy; Rossetto, L., Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of Padova,, Padua, Italy; Tenti, P., Dep of Electr Eng, Univ of Padova,, Padua, Italy
Abstract: An active power filter is presented which uses an impressed current converter and an inductive-capacitive energy storage circuit, also including a switching section. This solution allows an independent choice of the converter configuration and of the kind of storage system which, in the case being considered, is mainly capacitive. The theory of operation is analyzed, together with control strategy and design criteria. Experimental results are reported.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters, Static; Active Power Filter; Current Converter; Filter Control; Hybrid Energy Storage; Inductive-Capacitive Energy Storage circuit; Electric Filters, Active

Authors: Offringa Lodewijk J.J., Sluiters Hans E., Smits Eugenio J.
Title: Power electronics for the flywheel system EMAFER
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tech Univ Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Offringa, Lodewijk J.J., Tech Univ Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Neth; Sluiters, Hans E., Tech Univ Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Neth; Smits, Eugenio J., Tech Univ Eindhoven, Eindhoven, Neth
Abstract: The EMAFER (ElectroMechanical Accumulator For Energy Reuse) energy storage system is driven by a specially developed and designed advanced power electronic converter. The power electronic converter is designed to meet the demands of the synchronous permanent magnet three-phase motor/generator drive used in EMAFER. The demands cannot be fulfilled with power electronic converters presently available on the market. Therefore, a new type of current source inverter with forced commutation by means of a commutation bridge has been developed. This converter is able to drive and brake the machine at full rated power in an operating range from 8500 to 17,000 rpm. A 30 kW converter has been tested. Measurements of current and voltage waveforms in the converter are given. The results with the 30 kW test indicate the possibility of scaling up to the final desired prototype power level of 300 kW.
Index Keywords: Electric Inverters; Electric Traction--Flywheel Propulsion; Electronic Equipment; Flywheels; Flywheels--Energy Storage; Current Source Inverter; Electronic Converter; EMAFER (ElectroMechanical Accumulator For Energy Reuse); Flywheel System EMAFER; Power Electronics; Synchronous Permanent Magnet; Electric Converters, Static

Authors: Bennett Timothy J., Lacy Dovie E.
Title: Advanced sensible heat solar receiver for space power
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, Timothy J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA; Lacy, Dovie E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA
Abstract: A study to generate a conceptual design of a sensible heat solar receiver and to determine the feasibility of this system for space power applications was carried out. The sensible heat solar receiver generated in this study uses pure lithium as the thermal storage medium and was designed for a 7-kWe Brayton (PCS) operating at 1100 K. The receiver consists of two stages interconnected via temperature-sensing variable-conductance sodium heat pipes. The lithium is contained within a niobium vessel, and the outer shell of the receiver is constructed of third-generation rigid, fibrous ceramic insulation material. Reradiation losses are controlled with niobium and aluminum shields. By nature of its design, the sensible heat receiver generated in this study is comparable in both size and mass to a latent heat system of similar thermal capacitance. The heat receiver design and thermal analysis were performed through the combined use of PATRAN, SINDA, TRASYS, and NASTRAN software packages.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Heat Pipes; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Sensible Heat Solar Receiver; Software Package NASTRAN; Software Package PATRAN; Software Package SINDA; Software Package TRASYS; Varible-Conductance Sodium Heat Pipes; Solar Energy

Abstract: The proceedings contain 408 papers in four volumes. The topics covered include: stirling engines, heat engines, thermoelectric power, thermal rejection systems, nuclear power, thermionic power, mechanical energy storage, thermal energy storage, fuel cells, battery energy storage, superconductivity, aerospace and space power, photovoltaics, space nuclear power, magnetohydrodynamic conversion, wind energy, solar energy, alternative fuels, and solid waste energy.

Title: Energy systems for increased endurance of unmanned untethered submersible vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Unmanned
Affiliations: Marine Syst Eng Lab, Univ of New, Hampshire, Durham, NH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sedor, Gerald, Marine Syst Eng Lab, Univ of New, Hampshire, Durham, NH, USA
Abstract: The author investigates the available technology suitable for application to unmanned untethered submersible vehicle (UUV) energy systems, based on published data, and develops appropriate selection criteria for evaluating alternative concepts. The selection criteria, together with such factors as potential mission endurance requirements and vehicle size constraints, are applied in the selection of candidate systems which are recommended for future UUV energy systems. The evaluation of relative costs is not included in this study. A thermal conversion system using a gas turbine engine and a nuclear reactor heat source appears to be the optimum energy system for a long range/high endurance UUV. Based on nontechnical considerations and the lack of sufficient data on small nuclear reactors, the use of a nuclear reactor heat source is not recommended at this time. A gas turbine-metallic fuel system using lithium fuel and sulfur-hexafluoride oxidant is recommended for use in UUVs for missions beyond the endurance capabilities of electrical storage batteries. Current developmental efforts involving primary batteries and acid fuel cells using solid polymer electrolytes appear to offer promising alternatives for future underwater vehicle applications. It is also noted that developments can improve the reliability of the Stirling engine, and it could become the optimum heat engine for underwater vehicles in the future.
Index Keywords: Diesel Engines - Evaluation; Electric Batteries - Evaluation; Fuel Cells - Evaluation; Gas Turbines - Evaluation; Heat Engines - Evaluation; Acid Fuel Cells; Gas Turbine-Metallic Fuel System; Polymer Electrolytes; Sulfur-Hexafluoride Oxidant; Unmanned Untethered Submersible Vehicle (UUV); Submersibles

Title: Compact Ignition Tokamak (CIT) power system design studies
Affiliations: Plasma Phys Lab, Princeton Univ, NJ,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Huttar, D., Plasma Phys Lab, Princeton Univ, NJ,, USA; Bronner, G., Plasma Phys Lab, Princeton Univ, NJ,, USA
Abstract: One of the advantages of the Princeton site for the CIT is that the existing Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR) power systems can be applied to CIT requirements, saving on cost and time. However, the peak pulse power and energy required for CIT are four times the corresponding values for TFTR. In addition, the dynamic response required of the plasma-position control system of the CIT is well beyond what is practical for conventional rectifier systems, and therefore less familiar technology has been investigated. The approaches to power- and energy-supply augmentation considered include additional flywheel/generator-type storage, direct pulsing of the utility feed, upgrading of existing motor/generator sets, and the use of lead-acid batteries. Subtopics within these categories include drive techniques for added flywheel storage units, power-factor control for utility pulsing, and modern battery technology. The relationship between the alternative techniques and the proposed two-stage implementation of the CIT power system is reported.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Generators; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Plasmas--Control; Compact Ignition Tokamak (CIT); Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR); Tokamak Devices

Title: Energy spectra of pulsed random processes at the output of encoding devices having absorptive states
Source title: Radioelectronics and Communications Systems (English translation of Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenii Radioelektronika)
Authors with affiliations: Rozorinov, G.N.; Eidel'man, S.D.
Abstract: In solving the engineering problems which arise in digital magnetic recording, optical storage devices and communications systems, finding the energy spectrum of the pulsed random process at the output of encoding devices whose internal states include absorptive states is essential. A procedure is advanced for the efficient calculation of the energy spectra of pulsed random processes which arise at the output of encoding devices having an absorptive set of internal states. An example is given of the calculations of the spectrum for a signal used in digital magnetic and optical storage devices.

Authors: Buckman Frank D., Conley Frank W., Shen Thomas T.
Title: Evaluation of continuous emission monitoring data from municipal solid waste incineration
Affiliations: NYS Dep of Environmental, Conservation, Albany, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buckman, Frank D., NYS Dep of Environmental, Conservation, Albany, United States; Conley, Frank W., NYS Dep of Environmental, Conservation, Albany, United States; Shen, Thomas T., NYS Dep of Environmental, Conservation, Albany, United States
Abstract: Evaluation of continuous emission monitoring (CEM) readings from municipal solid waste (MSW) incineration from compliance with excessive emission limitations requires considerable processing of process combustion and composition variables. General screening criteria which can be applied to microcomputer data acquisition systems have been proposed. Using available process and combustion gas sensors to generate profiles of emissions with respect to process tracking with telemetry allows immediate agency analysis and response to malfunctions. In this manner, the public and source owners can be assured that the criteria for decisions and practices for permitted operation are uniformly enforced. Ongoing surveillance demonstrates a vastly superior analysis compared to scheduled submission of quarterly excessive emission reports, both in timeliness of action to a potentially hazardous situation, and in quality by reducing the levels communication needed to describe and reconstruct actual events in generating and reviewing periodic reports. Remote engineering workstations supplied by raw data inputted through on-site data storage modules can be routinely used with either general or custom software to reduce the effort involved.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Monitoring; Combustion; Flue Gases--Analysis; Standards; Waste Disposal--Incineration; Computerized Routines; Continuous Emission Monitoring; Energy and Mass Balances; Municipal Solid Waste Incineration; Refuse Incinerators

Authors: Scholl G., Christ A., Grassl H.P., Ruile W., Russer P., Weigel R.
Title: Efficient design tool for SAW-resonator filters
Affiliations: Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Scholl, G., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany; Christ, A., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany; Grassl, H.P., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany; Ruile, W., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany; Russer, P., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany; Weigel, R., Lehrstuhl fuer Hochfrequenztechnik,, Tech Univ Muenchen, Munich, West, Germany
Abstract: The advantages of the coupling-of-modes (COM) formalism and the transmission-matrix approach are combined to create exact and computationally efficient analysis and synthesis CAD tools for the design of SAW-resonator filters. The models for the filter components, especially gratings, interdigital transducers (IDTs), and multistrip couplers (MSCs), are based on the COM approach, which delivers closed-form expressions. In order to determine the relevant COM parameters, the integrated COM differential equations are compared with analytically derived expressions from the transmission-matrix approach. The most important second-order effects such as energy storage, propagation loss, and mechanical and electrical loading are fully taken into account. As an example, the authors investigate a two-pole, acoustically coupled resonator filter at 914.5 MHz on AT quartz. Excellent agreement between theory and measurement is found.
Index Keywords: Acoustic Surface Wave Filters--Computer Aided Design; Resonators; Surface Waves--Transmission; CAD Tools; Coupling-of-Modes Formalism; Microwave Network Analysis; SAW-Resonator Filters; Transmission-Matrix Approach; Acoustic Surface Wave Devices

Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Kholliev, V.Ch.; Kim, V.D.; Khairiddinov, B.Kh.
Abstract: Results are given from comparative tests of a solar dryer-greenhouse with water thermal storage, which makes it possible to raise the productivity of the drying unit by 25-20%.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Greenhouses; Solar Dryer-Greenhouses; Water Thermal Storage; Dryers

Authors: Osman Z., Soliman M., El-Shibini M., Abou-Hussein M.
Title: Economic feasibility study of a solar refrigeration system in Aswan, Egypt
Affiliations: Cairo Univ, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Osman, Z., Cairo Univ, Egypt; Soliman, M., Cairo Univ, Egypt; El-Shibini, M., Cairo Univ, Egypt; Abou-Hussein, M., Cairo Univ, Egypt
Abstract: Among the refrigeration processes available, an intermittent low temperature absorption refrigeration system would appear to be the most suitable for solar refrigeration. The operation of such system needs output temperature of the solar collector, in general, higher than 80°C. This can be achieved by using a flat plate solar collector which has selective coating on its absorber surfaces, and double glass covers to increase its efficiency. An energy storage system can be added to the solar refrigeration system. It is preferable to operate this system at community level, rather than at private household level. The study in this paper is for a solar refrigeration system which freezes 850 kg of fish and makes 800 kg of ice. Subjects covered include refrigeration load calculations, collector sizing, thermal storage system, and economic assessment.
Index Keywords: Economics--Analysis; Food Products--Refrigeration; Mechanical Engineering--Aswan, Egypt; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Economic Feasibility; Refrigeration

Authors: Toledo Alejandro, Botello Alfonso V., Herzig Monica, Bozada Lorenzo, Contreras Francisco
Title: Impacts of oil industry in Mexican coastal areas
Source title: Coastal Zone: Proceedings of the Symposium on Coastal and Ocean Management
Affiliations: Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Toledo, Alejandro, Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico; Botello, Alfonso V., Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico; Herzig, Monica, Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico; Bozada, Lorenzo, Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico; Contreras, Francisco, Cent de Ecodesarrollo, Mexico
Abstract: Activities related with storage, shipment and refining of crude oil in the southeast coastal area of the Gulf of Mexico have been have singular impacts on the coastal ecosystems and human settlements mainly in Coatzacoalcos, Veracruz, Mexico and adjacent regions. In order to evaluate the extent of these impacts, the Center for Ecodevelopment in conjunction with other Universities, research institutes and regional centres performed a multidisciplinary research project during 1983 to 1987 which included the following areas of study: geochemical evaluation of pollution, air quality, ecology of mangroves and swamps, biological productivity, bird population and migration, vegetation diversity and abundance, aquatic and marine fauna, marine food resources, environmental education and energy.
