Affiliations: Korea Advanced Inst of Science &, Technology, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Byung, Chul Shin, Korea Advanced Inst of Science &, Technology, South Korea; Sang, Done Kim, Korea Advanced Inst of Science &, Technology, South Korea; Park, Won-Hoon, Korea Advanced Inst of Science &, Technology, South Korea
Abstract: The heat transfer characteristics of a latent heat storage system of ternary carbonate eutectic mixture (Li2CO3:K2CO3:Na2CO3) have been studied in a shell-tube type heat exchanger. The eutectic exhibits a distinct phase change temperature during the thermal cycles. In the heat storage stage, the thermocline in the axial direction is pronounced. In the heat release stage, the heat transfer rate increases with the Biot number but the quality of thermal energy decreases. The thermal conductivity of the eutectic and the heat transfer coefficient have been determined.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Temperature Distribution; Heat Transfer Coefficients; Latent Heat Storage; Ternary Carbonate Eutectic; Heat Transfer

Title: Topics in gradient maintenance and salt recycling in an operational solar pond
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swift, A., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States; Golding, P., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Abstract: The 3355 square meter solar pond facility located at Bruce Foods Corporation in El Paso, Texas has been in continuous operation for almost two and one half years. The salt gradient solar pond has maintained a temperature difference between the upper and lower zones of 55 to 70 degrees C while demonstrating the regular delivery of industrial process heat, grid-connected electrical power, and the experimental production of desalted water utilizing the thermal energy of the solar pond. Since this facility is inland it requires the ability to recycle the salt that reaches the surface of the pond. After measuring salt transport in the pond, which initially averaged approximately 60 kg per square meter per year, it was evident that the original evaporation pond system was undersized. In order to address this problem, a method that uses the main pond surface for initial brine concentration and short term storage was developed. The method involves adding a surface layer of fresh water to the pond and creating an internal convective zone near the surface. After a description of the El Paso solar pond facility and status update, this paper examines this method for brine concentration and storage, the effects of the internal convective zone on pond operation, and the installation of an enhanced evaporation net system and an automatic scanning injection system.
Index Keywords: Sodium Chloride--Recycling; Brine Concentration; Salt Gradient Solar Ponds; Solar Radiation

Title: Integration of customer-owned generation into the electric utility load dispatching technique
Affiliations: Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Dep of Electr Eng, Blacksburg,, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bouzguenda, Mounir, Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Dep of Electr Eng, Blacksburg,, VA, USA; Rahman, Saifur, Virginia Polytech Inst & State, Univ, Dep of Electr Eng, Blacksburg,, VA, USA
Abstract: The authors discuss the integration of customer-owned generation into the electric utility generation dispatch. They show how high-resolution load and generation data can be used to closely match the supply and demand of electricity, thereby reducing the capacity requirements and overall operating cost. This technique is especially valuable when the customer-owned generation is intermittent in nature, as is the case with photovoltaics. The authors study the load, system generation, and photovoltaic output data for an electric utility in Virginia. The impacts of various levels of photovoltaic (PV) generation on various types of days, e.g., low, medium, and peak load, are shown. It is seen that large amounts of photovoltaic energy do not automatically displace high cost peaking generation. As the peaking generation (e.g., combustion turbines) cannot always change fast enough to accommodate the variable PV generation, the impact is felt on other dispatchable units as well as on hydro and pumped storage. A technique is provided which allows the optimum commitment of hydro, pumped storage, and large fossil units to maximize the utilization of customer-owned generation (such as PV) while keeping the overall cost down.
Index Keywords: Electric Utilities--Costs; Photovoltaic Cells; Customer-Owned Generation; Peaking Generation; Electric Power Systems

Title: On the use of finite elements and dynamic programming for prediction of electromagnetic device geometries
Affiliations: Florida Int Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Miami, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mohammed, Osama A., Florida Int Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Miami, FL, USA
Abstract: The author presents a novel technique for the design of a transformer using a numerical synthesis method which utilizes finite elements and dynamic programming for predicting the core and winding geometries of magnetic circuits. This technique is applicable to both low- and high-frequency designs, as well as in handling the material's nonlinearity. The designed transformer was placed in a DC-DC converter circuit used in an energy-producing medical device to verify the numerical design results. This converter was inserted in such a device and was used to boost the voltage from a low-voltage implanted battery to high-voltage energy storage capacitors in a short period of time. The stored energy is then delivered, when needed, through an energy delivery circuit to stimulate or defibrillate the heart. The final transformer design satisfied the performance criteria and provided means for selecting the various converter components. The performance results obtained for the transformer and the complete DC-DC converter circuit were in excellent agreement with laboratory performance tests.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electric Transformers; Magnetic Circuits; DC-DC Converter Circuit; Electromagnetic Device; Energy Delivery Circuit; Implanted Battery; Medical Device; Electric Converters, Static

Authors: Swift A., Golding P., Roy S., Knudsen J.
Title: Investigation of the effects of gradient thickness on solar pond performance
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swift, A., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States; Golding, P., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States; Roy, S., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States; Knudsen, J., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Abstract: Two finite element computer programs for use in simulating the performance of salt gradient solar ponds have been verified by comparing data from the simulation models with operational data from the 3355 square meter El Paso solar pond facility in El Paso, Texas. The two programs SOLPOND, developed at the Solar Energy Research Institute and GTPROFILE, developed at U.T. El Paso, model pond performance using only conduction heat transfer and radiation absorption in the pond elemental nodes. After verification, the GTPROFILE simulation has been used to investigate the effects on pnod performance that result when gradient (nonconvective zone) thickness is increased at the expense of storage zone (lower convective zone) thickness in an operational salt gradient solar pond of fixed depth. In the study, the upper convective zone of the pond is held fixed at 0.50 meters (approximately the average annual upper convective zone depth experienced at the El Paso solar pond), while the thickness of the gradient and storage zone are varied such that the total depth of the two layers remains constant at 2.55 meters. The study investigated monthly and annual performance for a 55 to 65 degree C temperature difference between the storage zone and upper convective zone and showed significant increases in energy delivery, especially in the winter months, as gradient thickness increased.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method; Computer Applications; Gradient Zones; Salt Gradient Solar Ponds; Software Package GTPROFILE; Software Package SOLPOND; Solar Radiation

Title: Thermal energy storage flight experiments
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Namkoong, D., Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: Thermal energy storage is a critical element in a solar dynamic system - providing the system with constant power while receiving energy periodically, as in earth orbit. High heat-of-fusion salts are particularly suited to fulfill this function. A characteristic of salts that must be accommodated in such usage is the density change accompanying phase change. This density difference results in void formation in a closed container during the shade part of the orbit. A void immediately adjacent to a high heat flux area of the container as the spacecraft emerges into the sun, can cause burn-out. In the other extreme, where such an area is filled with solid salt, the melting salt seeking to expand can deform the container. The Oak Ridge National Laboratory has been contracted to NASA-Lewis to analyze three-dimensionally, the process of heat transfer, energy storage, fluid movement and void location under microgravity conditions. The results will form the basis for comparison with the test results to be obtained from a Lewis In-Reach flight program. Four experimental packages are being planned for flight, each package containing thermal energy storage (TES) material applicable for advanced solar heat receivers. TES candidate materials include fluoride salts, salt eutectics, silicides, and metals.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Space Applications; Germanium and Alloys--Space Applications; Gravitational Effects; Heat Transfer--Solids; Salts--Space Applications; Fluoride Salts; Lithium Compounds; Phase Change Materials; Silicides; Solar Space Power Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Solar Power Plants

Title: Notes on the relationship between polymer glass transition characteristics and sound and vibration damping behavior
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Lehigh Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sperling, L.H., Lehigh Univ, United States
Abstract: The science of sound and vibration damping with polymers utilizes the professions of chemistry, chemical engineering, materials, mechanical engineering, and polymer science and engineering. Each contributes its genius to the solution of an important technological question: How best shall noisy aircraft, cars, ships, machinery, etc., be quieted? The objective of this paper is to provide a brief review of the problem, introducing those terms and concepts which will appear throughout the symposium. Reviews of both the polymer characteristics and the acoustic requirements are available.

Authors with affiliations: Dorri-Nowkoorani, F., Oklahoma State Univ, United States; Dougherty, R.L., Oklahoma State Univ, United States
Abstract: Solar ponds are a method for collecting and storing solar energy in a liquid medium. The Oklahoma State University Radiation Heat Transfer Laboratory is investigating methods for improving the efficiency of trapping the radiation within the solar pond, instead of allowing the energy to be scattered into the atmosphere from the top surface or be transmitted into the ground beneath the pond. The experimental setup for this study consists of an argon-ion laser used as a well-defined, carefully controlled source of light; a container which holds the liquids which simulate the pond; three photodetecting probes for the top, side and bottom measurements; fiber optics; and an IBM compatible data acquisition system which includes an analog to digital (and digital to analog) control adaptor and an IBM compatible AT for data reduction, storage, and analysis.

Authors: Abu-Hamdan M.G., Zurigat Y.H., Ghajar A.J.
Title: Experimental study of a stratified thermal storage under variable inlet temperature for different inlet designs
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abu-Hamdan, M.G., Oklahoma State Univ, United States; Zurigat, Y.H., Oklahoma State Univ, United States; Ghajar, A.J., Oklahoma State Univ, United States
Abstract: A single stratified thermal storage tank operating under variable inlet temperature conditions has received little attention in the past. This paper presents an experimental study to evaluate the performance of a stratified tank under the mentioned conditions. A new inlet design (a modified version of E.S. Davis and R. Bartera's inlet design) was used and compared with two most widely used conventional inlets. The results indicate that passive devices of the kind used by Davis and Bartera and this study, offer no advantage over the conventional inlets under inlet temperature conditions.
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids--Inlets; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Stratified Thermal Storage; Thermal Storage Tank; Variable Inlet Temperature; Tanks

Title: Analyzing vibration characteristics of viscoelastic material systems using complex modulus
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Philip Morris Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ganeriwala, S.N., Philip Morris Research Cent, United States; Hartung, H.A., Philip Morris Research Cent, United States
Abstract: The vibration response of a mechanical system near its resonance frequency is largely controlled by damping, i.e., the capacity to dissipate energy. Polymeric materials are very useful for damping applications because of their viscoelastic characteristics. A proper understanding and representation of the damping property of polymers should help in optimizing these applications and in the design of new materials with useful properties. The dynamic viscoelastic properties of polymers are commonly represented by complex moduli. These are not very useful in analysis of vibration problems because they are strong functions of temperature and frequency. An equation of motion of a dynamic system typically contains: an inertia term, expressions for energy storage and dissipation, and the input force. To keep this formulation manageable, the material properties are needed in terms of frequency-independent constants.
Index Keywords: Equations of Motion; Vibrations--Damping; Viscoelasticity--Mathematical Models; Complex Modulus; Dynamic Viscoelastic Properties; Frequency Independent Constants; Vibration Characteristics; Vibration Responses; Viscoelastic Material Systems; Polymers

Authors: Newell T.A., Smith M.K., Cowie R.G., Upper J.M., Cler G.L.
Title: Characteristics of a solar pond brine reconcentration system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newell, T.A., Univ of Illinois, United States; Smith, M.K., Univ of Illinois, United States; Cowie, R.G., Univ of Illinois, United States; Upper, J.M., Univ of Illinois, United States; Cler, G.L., Univ of Illinois, United States
Abstract: An active brine reconcentration system has been incorporated into the design of the University of Illinois half-acre salt gradient solar pond facility. The system filters out substantial rainfall during the April through October period when surface water is being reconcentrated for reinjection into the solar pond storage zone. Experimental data are in good agreement with a numerical simulation model of the evaporation process. The film type evaporation process has a higher capacity per surface area than an evaporation pond which experiences no rainfall. The system can also be beneficial in dry locations in which precipitation falling on the evaporation surface can be directed to the solar pond for surface washing. An economic projection on salt recycling is included.
Index Keywords: Economics; Mathematical Models; Sodium Chloride--Recycling; Brine Reconcentration; Energy Balance; Salt Gradient Solar Ponds; Solar Radiation

Authors: Bhandari P., Wu Y.C., Roschke E.J.
Title: Simplified calculation of solar flux distribution on the side wall of cylindrical cavity solar receivers
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: JPL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhandari, P., JPL, United States; Wu, Y.C., JPL, United States; Roschke, E.J., JPL, United States
Abstract: A solar dynamic space power system consists of a solar concentrator, solar heat receiver including thermal storage for eclipse phase operation and the energy conversion (heat engine) system. A simple solar flux calculation algorithm for a cylindrical cavity type solar receiver has been developed and implemented on an IBM PC-AT. Using cone optics, the contour error method is utilized to handle the slope error of a paraboloidal concentrator. The flux distribution on the side wall is calculated by integration of the energy incident from cones emanating from all the differential elements on the concentrator. The calculations are done for any set of dimensions and properties of the receiver and the concentrator, and account for any spillover on the aperture plate. The results of this algorithm compare excellently with those predicted by more complicated programs. Because of the utilization of axial symmetry and overall simplification, it is extremely fast. It can be easily extended to other axi-symmetric receiver geometries.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Algorithms; Solar Energy--Space Applications; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Computer Applications; Solar Flux Distribution; Solar Receivers; Solar Space Power Systems; Solar Power Plants

Title: On the determination of the average temperature in a horizontal storage tank and its use in monitoring system performance
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bannerot, R.B., Univ of Houston, United States
Abstract: The mass weighted average storage temperature is a useful parameter for evaluating the performance of thermal storage systems. This paper examines the evaluation of the average storage temperature, specifically from the point of view of reproducibility and how much data is required for a confident calculation. This issue was not completely resolved and was shown to be strongly dependent on the locations of the measurements. Two examples are presented that demonstrate the usefulness of knowing the average storage temperature. The examples also give a quantitative demonstration of the effect of withdrawal flow rate on the amount of thermal energy that can be withdrawn from a given system. A reduction in flow rate by a factor of four increased the delivered energy to 70%.
Index Keywords: Tanks--Temperature Measurement; Water--Temperature Measurement; Storage Temperature; Water Storage Tanks; Withdrawal Flow Rate; Water Heaters

Title: Industrial electrochemistry
Affiliations: Dow Chemical Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leddy, James J., Dow Chemical Co, United States
Abstract: The history of industrial electrochemistry parallels the development of the electrical industry itself. Both contain fascinating blends of good science mingled with trial and error methods. These also paralleled the development of physical chemistry and engineering science, the latter being especially influenced by the accelerating demands for the invention of new processes and devices to take advantage of the availability of large amounts of relatively inexpensive electrical energy. Similar incentives also drove the development of electrical storage systems, as well as the growing need for remote energy sources. Most fascinating of all are the entrepreneurs who in their fledgling years gave us the foundations of great commercial enterprises whose roots remain in industrial electrochemistry. This paper reviews the history of industrial electrochemistry and its prime movers.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Electrical Engineering; Electrolysis; Chlor Alkali Industry; Electrolytic Processes; Electrothermic Processes; Electrochemistry

Title: Battery storage plants in power systems
Affiliations: Asea Brown Boveri, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Seele, Wolfgang, Asea Brown Boveri, Germany
Abstract: Being of modular design, battery storage plants have the advantage that they can be used in a distributed configuration in power supply systems. The cost-effectiveness of such a configuration depends on the first-time costs, the existing network conditions, and the electricity tariff rate concerned. Studies have shown that battery storage plants with high-energy batteries are technically sound and can be profitable in operation. Two pilot plants with high-energy sodium-sulphur batteries are currently being operated, one by an urban power utility and one in production centre, in order to study their behaviour in the field. Such plants can be used for voltage back-up, load-frequency control, and in combination with alternative energy sources in isolated networks.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Battery Storage Plants; Electricity Tariff Rate; High-Energy Batteries; Sodium-Sulphur Batteries; Urban Power Utility; ELectric Power Plants

Title: Hybrid solar HVAC cogeneration/desiccant cooling combined cycle
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Meckler Group, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, M., Meckler Group, United States
Abstract: The proposed Hybrid Solar HVAC/Cogeneration/Desiccant Cooling (HS HVAC/C/DC) combined cycle overcomes the basic limitation of earlier proposed adaptations of solar-powered Rankine cycle engines by recognizing the transient nature of solar insolation and thermodynamic processes which convert thermal energy into useful work. It was developed to demonstrate the innovative solar-/ wasteheat-powered Rankine combined cycles can be made economically feasible for a current generation of building HVAC systems. Studies of large building HVAC systems are presented which suggest a reduction of 50% in compressor size and peak power requirements and 6% in total energy that can be achieved for a continuously operating system employing thermal storage. A prefabricated solar/wasteheat (assisted) central desiccant regeneration package cogeneration (SCDRPC) module represents the key to the operational success of the proposed HS HVAC/C/DC combined cycle. A case history concerns a 12-story office building in Los Angeles, Calif.
Index Keywords: Lithium Compounds--Applications; Office Buildings--Solar, Active; Case Histories; Hot Water Storage; Hybrid Solar HVAC Cogeneration/Desiccant Cooling Combined Cycle; Liquid Desiccant Dehumidifiers; Lithium Chloride; Rankine Cycle; Air Conditioning

Title: Performance of flat plate collector used for solar refrigerator
Affiliations: Cairo Univ, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Osman, Z., Cairo Univ, Egypt
Abstract: In many tropical and developing countries, a substantial quantity of foodstuffs cannot be preserved and therefore perish. For some foods, refrigeration is required, and, for areas without electricity, solar refrigeration may well be the answer. The operation of such refrigerators needs output temperature of solar collectors, in general higher than 80°C. This can be achieved by using concentrating collectors flat plate solar collectors. The aim of this paper is to determine the performance of a flat plate collector with single-and double-glazed cover as affected by different climatological data. The energy balance equations have been formulated for these two types of collector. The equations are solved using iterative technique.

Abstract: A computerized optimization study is performed to compare cooling thermal storage to gas air-conditioning for a test building in San Diego, CA. The economics were compared with and without utility incentives. But the unusual analysis provided for both quantitative and qualitative comparisons of a large number of systems. This paper provides a description of the analytical procedure in selecting a load leveling ice storage system with centrifugal chillers.

Title: New 'prime mover' for electric cars
Affiliations: Asea Brown Boveri, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dustmann, Cord H., Asea Brown Boveri, Germany; Angelis, Juergen, Asea Brown Boveri, Germany
Abstract: Electric cars are a clean and noiseless alternative to vehicles with combustion engines for journeys in cities and their environs. ABB has developed an efficient electric drive system featuring modern power electronics and a high-energy, sodium-sulphur battery. The energy-to-weight ratio of this battery is four times that achieved with conventional lead-acid batteries. To recharge the battery, a charger mounted next to the motor has only to be connected to a household power socket. Road testing of electric cars is already under way, with production of commercially significant series planned for the early 1990s.

Authors: Campoli Alan A., Oyler David C., Chase Frank E.
Title: Performance of a novel bump control pillar extracting technique during room-and-pillar retreat coal mining
Source title: Report of Investigations - United States, Bureau of Mines
Authors with affiliations: Campoli, Alan A.; Oyler, David C.; Chase, Frank E.
Abstract: Retreat pillar mining concentrates stresses on workings directly outby gob areas, which can result in coal mine bumps. The development of bump-control design criteria by the U.S. Bureau of Mines was furthered by data from a novel bump control mining method at the Olga Mine, McDowell County, WV. The pillar splitting, retreat mining system induced large pillar pressure increases and roof-to-floor convergence. Roof-to-floor convergence monitoring proved to be a valuable tool in evaluating the pillar splitting mining method and localized destressing techniques. Maximum strain energy storage in chain pillars appears to have occurred just prior to the first of four split cuts. At that point a 15-ft-wide, highly fractured perimeter confined the core of the 55- by 70-ft pillars, permitting the pillar core to support tremendous pressures. Splitting the chain pillars into two 17.5- by 70-ft wings removed the confinement load, resulting in pillar yield. Thus, the pillar splitting mining method successfully redistributed the weight of the roof away from the pillar line. Shot fire and auger drilling destressing techniques augmented the pillar splitting mining method by redistributing the weight of the roof.
Index Keywords: Accident Prevention; Mines and Mining--Roof Control; Coal Mine Bump Control; Coal Mine Pillar Splitting; Room and Pillar Retreat Coal Mining; Coal Mines and Mining

Title: Cure monitoring and process control of a thermosetting magnetic memory disk
Source title: Annual Technical Conference - Society of Plastics Engineers
Affiliations: IBM General Products Div, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prime, R.B., IBM General Products Div, United States; Moy, C.H., IBM General Products Div, United States
Abstract: A description is given of a methodology for monitoring and controlling cure processes, and its application to the cure of rigid magnetic memory disks. Minimum cure was defined in terms of unreacted, soluble binder resins while maximum cure was related to abrasion resistance of the coating. Upper and lower limits were defined in terms of degree of cure as measured by grazing angle Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) measurements on the actual disk. A time-temperature superposition method, utilizing Arrhenius kinetics, was developed to establish master cure curves (degree of cure vs EIt) from a series of isothermal cure experiments. The same technique was used to convert actual time-temperature profiles into equivalent isothermal times (EIt), where EIt uniquely contains contributions to cure from the process (time/temperature profiles) and from the material (activation energy).

Abstract: There are four reasons for artificial recharge of ground water in Finland: 1. The replenishment of aquifers by lake water. 2. To use aquifers as part of surface water treatment process. 3. Recirculating of cooling water through an aquifer. 4. Aquifer thermal energy storage.

Title: CAES plant performance and economics as a function of underground salt dome storage transient processes
Affiliations: Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, United States

Abstract: This paper presents a discussion of the computer model developed to quantify the effects of transient processes occurring during injection, storage and withdrawal of compressed air from underground storage in a salt dome. The following mechanisms are considered when modelling the thermodynamic behavior of the compressed air within the cavern: (1) Temperature variations due to the compression and expansion of the air. (2) Heat transfer by convection at the cavern wall. (3) Heat transfer by conduction inside the salt formation. (4) Enthalpy changes as air is injected into and withdrawn from the cavern.

Title: Mist lift process as an adjunct to the open cycle net power experiment
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: R&D Associates, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ridgway, S.L., R&D Associates, United States
Abstract: There is worldwide interest in harnessing the heat stored in the tropical oceans with engines that operate on the temperature difference between the surface water and the deep water. It is proposed that the cold and warm water pumping power for the STF 165-kW Open-Cycle Experiment be provided by attaching a mist lift process that uses the residual temperature difference in the waters discarded from the open-cycle to do this work. In the present study the mist lift has been added on to the system that was optimized using electrically driven warm and cold seawater pumps.
Index Keywords: Seawater--Heat Storage; Cloud Cycle; Mist Lift Process; Open Cycle Net Power Experiment; Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion

Title: Pumped storage hydro station at La Muela ups the voltage
Authors with affiliations: Martin, David
Abstract: Spain's recent modernisation and industrialisation programme depends on the increased use of electricity, which will include some from hydroelectric sources. Plans were made to upgrade the venerable Cortes de Pallas plant, which was producing 190GWh annually at 30 000kW. There are two aspects to the development: first, the new Cortes II power plant which, with an output of 323GWh annually, will have twice the capacity of the old 1920s plant which it is now replacing; and secondly, the new pumped storage scheme of La Muela, which is currently just being completed. Both projects depend on the lake created by the new arch-gravity concrete dam. Both elements are connected hydraulically through the reservoir, and electrically through the 400KV switchyard. This paper describes the project, including the underground power station and wildlife protection measures.
Index Keywords: Dams, Concrete--Construction; Electric Power Generation--Energy Resources; Environmental Protection; Lakes; Power Plants--Underground; Flexible Electric Source; Spain; Hydroelectric Power Plants; Power Stations-Hydroelectric; Pumped Storage

Title: Iron and immunity
Affiliations: Department of Gastroenterology, St. Bartholomew's Hospital, West Smithfield, London EC1A 7 BE, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Farthing, M.J.G., Department of Gastroenterology, St. Bartholomew's Hospital, West Smithfield, London EC1A 7 BE, United Kingdom
Abstract: Review of animal and human studies concerning the impact of iron deficiency on immune function in vivo indicates that in many instances there is no firm concensus of opinion as to the relationship between iron status and immunity. One major problem with almost all human studies is that other micro- and macronutrient deficiencies are inadequately controlled for and thus it is often unclear as to whether reported abnormalities of immune function can be attributed specifically to iron deficiency. Even when anbnormalities of immune function have been detected it is often uncertain as to the biological and clinical relevance that these may have for the host. Within these restraints the available studies suggest that iron deficiency may at least contribute to impaired T lymphocyte function as judged by DTH responses in skin and impaired mitogen-induced proliferation. As in protein energy malnutrition, humoral immunity is largely spared in humans, the balance of evidence suggesting that immunoglobulin production and function is normal, as are serum concentrations of complement. The only other abnormality of non-specific immunity which has been reported consistently to be abnormal is that of reduced bactericidal activity of polymorphonuclear leucocytes. The clinical relevance of these abnormalities remains to be established. There is, however, no evidence to suggest that individuals with iron deficiency suffer the devastating infective complications of well defined immunodeficiency syndromes either congenital or acquired. It seems likely therefore that despite the fundamental importance of iron in maintaining the integrity of immune function, humans can tolerate the extremes of deficiency and excess and survive in a relatively healthy state.
Author Keywords: immune function; iron status; nutrition.
Index Keywords: iron; article; bactericidal activity; human; immunity; infection; iron deficiency; iron storage; priority journal; theoretical study; animal; immunity; physiology; review; Animal; Human; Immunity; Iron; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: A review of the studies on the wholesomeness of irradiated wheat, conducted at the national institute of nutrition, India
Affiliations: National Institute of Nutrition, Indian Council of Medical Research, Jamai Osmania, Hyderabad 500 007, Andhra Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Vijayalaxmi, National Institute of Nutrition, Indian Council of Medical Research, Jamai Osmania, Hyderabad 500 007, Andhra Pradesh, India; Srikantia, S.G., National Institute of Nutrition, Indian Council of Medical Research, Jamai Osmania, Hyderabad 500 007, Andhra Pradesh, India
Abstract: The wholesomeness of irradiated wheat was investigated in a series of experiments involving several species of animals and a small number of children, at the National Institute of Nutrition in India. Our observations indicated some effects following the feeding of freshly irradiated wheat while no such changes were found in the groups fed either unirradiated or stored irradiated wheat. Also, there were no significant differences between the groups fed unirradiated and stored irradiated wheat. Based on these results, a recommendation had been made to the government that when subjected to irradiation, wheat should be stored for at least 3 months before considering it as safe for human consumption. Similar experiments conducted in an establishment of the Department of Atomic Energy in India indicated no undesirable effects, unlike those found in our studies, and this had led to the development of a serious controversy. In this paper, we have not only reviewed our studies in the light of subsequent research independently carried out in other laboratories but also have tried to answer some of the criticisms made against our studies, so that some of the misunderstandings of our work are seen in proper perspective.The wholesomeness of irradiated wheat was investigated in a series of experiments involving several species of animals and a small number of children, at the National Institute of Nutrition in India. Our observations indicated some effects following the feeding of freshly irradiated wheat, while no such changes were found in the groups fed either unirradiated or stored irradiated wheat. Also, there were no significant differences between the groups fed unirradiated and stored irradiated wheat. Based on these results, a recommendation had been made to the government that when subjected to irradiation, wheat should be stored for at least 3 months before considering it as safe for human consumption. Similar experiments conducted in an establishment of the Department of Atomic Energy in India indicated no undesirable effects, unlike those found in our studies, and this had led to the development of a serious controversy. In this paper, we have not only reviewed our studies in the light of subsequent research independently carried out in other laboratories but also have tried to answer some of the criticisms made against our studies, so that some of the misunderstandings of our work are seen in proper perspective.

Authors: Kasser T.R., Harris R.B.S., Martin R.J.
Title: Level of satiety: In vitro energy metabolism in brain during hypophagic and hyperphagic body weight recovery
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Regulatory Integrative and Comparative Physiology
Affiliations: Dept. of Foods and Nutrition, College of Home Economics, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kasser, T.R., Dept. of Foods and Nutrition, College of Home Economics, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Harris, R.B.S., Dept. of Foods and Nutrition, College of Home Economics, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Martin, R.J., Dept. of Foods and Nutrition, College of Home Economics, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Abstract: Rates of in vitro glucose and fatty acid oxidation were examined in four brain sites during hypophagic and hyperphagic recovery of normal body weight. Rats were fed 40, 100, or 160% of normal intake, via gastric intubation, for 3 wk. Another group of rats were starved until body weight loss was equivalent to weight loss in 40%-fed rats. Groups of rats were killed at the conclusion of tube feeding or fasting and at specific periods during recovery of body weight. Brain sites examined were the ventrolateral hypothalamus (VLH), ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH), a caudal brain stem site encompassing the area postrema-nucleus of the solitary tract (AP-NTS), and cortex. During recovery, rats previously fed 160% of normal intake (anorectic) maintained low rates of VLH fatty acid oxidation and were hypophagic until most excess fat was depleted. Conversely, rats previously fed 40% of normal intake (hungry) maintained high rates of VLH fatty acid oxidation and were hyperphagic until most deficient fat was repleted. Rats previously starved maintained high rates of VLH fatty acid oxidation during hyperphagic recovery, although levels of VLH fatty acid oxidation and food intake were initially low on refeeding. Rates of glucose oxidation in the brain sites examined did not relate well to energy balance status and the needed adjustments in food intake. The results indicated that the level of glucose oxidation in the VLH and AP-NTS responded to the level of energy immediately coming into the system (food intake). These data support the concept that the level of VLH fatty acid oxidation is inversely proportional to the level of peripheral fat storage and that high or low rates of VLH fatty acid may be a component of the mechanism that elicits the compensatory hyperphagic or hypophagic response, respectively.
Author Keywords: body weight regulation; brain metabolism; food intake control
Index Keywords: radioisotope; animal cell; animal experiment; anorexia; article; brain; energy metabolism; female; food intake; hunger; hyperphagia; hypophagia; nonhuman; priority journal; rat; satiety; tube feeding; zona incerta; Animal; Anorexia; Body Weight; Brain; Carbon Radioisotopes; Eating Disorders; Energy Metabolism; Feeding Behavior; Female; Glucose; Hyperphagia; Palmitic Acid; Palmitic Acids; Radioisotope Dilution Technique; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Reference Values; Satiation; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: Pulverizer control a tutorial review
Source title: Instrumentation, Control, and Automation in the Power Industry, Proceedings
Affiliations: Leeds & Northrup Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hubby, R.N., Leeds & Northrup Co, United States
Abstract: The key to obtaining optimum response of the boiler to the energy demand imposed on it by the turbine is to make the firing system fully responsive to changes in demand. For pulverized-coal fired power plants, the control strategy must accommodate the mill response and storage characteristics to optimize the mills' coal delivery response. This paper will review the various mill types commonly used in coal fired plants as well as the control strategy to optimize mill response.
Index Keywords: Boiler Firing--Pulverized Fuel; Control Systems; Grinding Mills; Steam Power Plants--Control; Pulverizer Control Dynamics; Coal Pulverizers

Authors: Kwon J.-H., Belanger J.M.R., Pare J.R.J.
Title: Effects of ionizing energy treatment on the quality of ginseng products
Affiliations: Food Research and Development Centre, Canada Department of Agriculture, Saint-Hyacinthe, Que. J2S 8E3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kwon, J.-H., Food Research and Development Centre, Canada Department of Agriculture, Saint-Hyacinthe, Que. J2S 8E3, Canada; Belanger, J.M.R., Food Research and Development Centre, Canada Department of Agriculture, Saint-Hyacinthe, Que. J2S 8E3, Canada; Pare, J.R.J., Food Research and Development Centre, Canada Department of Agriculture, Saint-Hyacinthe, Que. J2S 8E3, Canada
Abstract: Pre-established doses were applied to Panax ginseng powders for determining the effects of γ-irradiation on the quality of samples from the microbiological, some physico-chemical and organoleptic points of view. Irradiation at 5 kGy was sufficient not only to reduce total bacterial counts (1.28 x 105/g) by about 3 orders of magnitude but to eliminate coliforms, yeast and molds during three months of storage at 30°C and 50 - 60% RH. An established dose of 5 kGy caused little change in pH, acidity, TBA number, pigments, color, and overall acceptability of the sample, however there was a significant change in color and appearance of the irradiated sample at 10 kGy where all microorganisms were destroyed.Pre-established doses were applied to Panax ginseng powders for determining the effects of γ-irradiation on the quality of samples from the microbiological, physico-chemical and organoleptic points of view. Irradiation at 5 kGy was sufficient not only to reduce total bacterial counts (1.28 × 105/g) by about 3 orders of magnitude but to eliminate coliforms, yeast and molds during three months of storage at 30°C and 50-60% RH. An established dose of 5 kGy caused little change in pH, acidity, TBA number, pigments, color, and overall acceptability of the sample. However, there was a significant change in color and appearance of the irradiated sample at 10 kGy, where all microorganisms were destroyed.

Title: Influence of protein-calorie malnutrition on reproductive performance of young and mature rats
Affiliations: Departamento de Educacao Fisica, Instituto de Biociencias Universidade Estadual Paulista Rio Claro - SP - 13.500, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: De Mello, M.A.R., Departamento de Educacao Fisica, Instituto de Biociencias Universidade Estadual Paulista Rio Claro - SP - 13.500, Brazil; Cury, L., Departamento de Educacao Fisica, Instituto de Biociencias Universidade Estadual Paulista Rio Claro - SP - 13.500, Brazil
Abstract: The effect on reproduction and fetal growth of a protein-deficient diet administration during pregnancy was studied in young and adult rats. Young (50-55 days old) and adult (90-100 days old) pregnant or nonpregnant rats were fed a normal diet (25% protein) or a protein-deficient diet (6% protein) during pregnancy or for a 22-day period (nonpregnant rats). All females were weighed during the experiment and body length measured in the young rats. After parturition, pups were counted, sexed and individually weighed. Litter size, number of stillbirths and presence of body lesions in the neonates were also recorded. Alimentary protein deficiency caused reduction in weight gain during pregnancy and in the postpartum period in young and adult rats. Pups from protein deficient dams weighed less at birth than the pups of control dams, although litter size was unaltered. Pups from young malnourished dams tended to weigh less than those from adult malnourished dams. The incidence of stillbirths was higher in malnourished rats, the highest values occurring in the adult group. These results suggest that alimentary protein deficiency during pregnancy in young rats reduces maternal weight gain, presumably reducing nutrient storage. This may cause fetal/maternal competition for nutrients leading to retardation of both maternal and fetal growth. Growth impairment may be an adaptative process, assuring fetal survival.
Index Keywords: aging; animal experiment; article; nonhuman; pregnancy; protein calorie malnutrition; rat; reproduction; Aging; Animals; Biometry; Birth Weight; Body Weight; Diet; Disease Models, Animal; Female; Fetal Death; Litter Size; Male; Pregnancy; Pregnancy Complications; Protein-Energy Malnutrition; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Reproduction; Animalia

Authors: Pimenta W.P., Saad M.J., Paccola G.M., Piccinato C.E., Foss M.C.
Title: Effect of oral glucose on peripheral muscle fuel metabolism in fasted men.
Source title: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research
Affiliations: Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.
Authors with affiliations: Pimenta, W.P., Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.; Saad, M.J., Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.; Paccola, G.M., Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.; Piccinato, C.E., Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.; Foss, M.C., Departamento de Clínica Médica, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, Universidade de São Paulo, Brasil.
Abstract: 1. The metabolic adaptations of peripheral muscle during a 5-day "modified" fast (daily oral intake of 200 g of glucose) were studied in 12 normal males. The volunteers were studied initially after receiving a balanced 2,400-kcal diet for at least 3 days (S1) and then after 5 days of modified fast (S2). The forearm muscle exchange of energy substrate (glucose) and the carbohydrate and lipid oxidation rates in muscle were measured during the postabsorptive state (S1) and after an oral glucose challenge (S2). 2. Glucose intolerance was not observed in either situation. Arterial glucose levels increased from a basal value of 83 mg/100 ml to 171 mg/100 ml in S1 and to 187 mg/100 ml in S2 at 30 and 60 min, respectively, and returned to basal values at 180 min in both studies. Increased forearm glucose uptake was observed in S2 compared to S1 (121.7 +/- 17.1 vs 92.6 +/- 12.0 mg 100 ml forearm-1 3 h-1), with decreased glucose oxidation (23.8 +/- 3.7 vs 30.4 +/- 4.7 mg 100 ml forearm-1 3 h-1) and increased glucose storage (98.0 +/- 16.6 vs 62.2 +/- 10.8 mg 100 ml forearm-1 3 h-1) as muscle glycogen. 3. Basal serum free fatty acid (FFA) levels were significantly more elevated in S2 than S1 (1030 +/- 95 vs 657 +/- 59 mumol/l; P less than 0.05) but were markedly reduced by glucose ingestion in both studies (352 +/- 33 (S2) vs 364 +/- 30 (S1) mumol/l at 120 min). Basal FFA oxidation was similar in both studies (0.091 +/- 0.015 (S1) vs 0.105 +/- 0.019 (S2) mg 100 ml forearm-1 min-1) and decreased significantly 3 h after glucose ingestion only in S1 (0.030 +/- 0.010 (S1) vs 0.078 +/- 0.020 (S2) mg 100 ml forearm-1 min-1; P less than 0.05). 4. The insulin response to oral glucose was similar in both studies (11,060 +/- 899 (S1) vs 11,078 +/- 918 (S2) microU ml-1 3 h-1), but the peak concentration occurred later (60 min (S2) vs 30 min (S1] and basal levels were significantly lower in S2 compared to S1 (9.2 +/- 1.7 vs 11.1 +/- 1.5 microU/ml; P less than 0.05). 5. These data show that the metabolic adaptations of normal subjects to a 5-day "modified" fast (daily oral intake of 200 g glucose) were increased muscle uptake of glucose, with reduced glucose oxidation and increased glucose storage in the form of muscle glycogen.
Index Keywords: glucose; article; diet restriction; forearm; gluconeogenesis; human; male; metabolism; muscle; Fasting; Forearm; Gluconeogenesis; Glucose; Human; Male; Muscles; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Authors: Korinek Kenneth, Hendry David, Howard John
Title: Alabama electric cooperative compressed air energy storage project
Source title: International Exhibition & Conference for the Power Generation Industries - Power-Gen
Affiliations: Burns & McDonnel Engineeing Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Korinek, Kenneth, Burns & McDonnel Engineeing Co, United States; Hendry, David, Burns & McDonnel Engineeing Co, United States; Howard, John, Burns & McDonnel Engineeing Co, United States
Abstract: Alabama Electric Cooperative (AEC), located in Andalusia, Alabama, is proceeding with the first Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) facility to be constructed in the United States. CAES is a process that allows storage of energy produced during off-peak periods for use during peak generation periods. Air is compressed and stored at high pressure, and then used in the combustion process of a hot gas expander. This paper describes the AEC project and the application of CAES in the United States. The AES CAES plant will consist of a single 110-MW unit with site provisions for a second unit. Using electricity generated during off-peak times, it will compress and store air in a salt cavern to generate electricity during periods of peak load demand. The high pressure air (1000 psig) will be used in the combustion process of a hot gas expander. A generator driven by the expander produces electrical power. The generator also serves as a motor to drive compressors that fill the air storage cavern.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air - Applications; Electric Power Generation - Alabama; Alabama Electric Cooperative (AEC); Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Power Plants

Authors: Feitosa E.A.N., Medeiros A.L.R., Rohatgi J.S., Kruppel R.
Title: Pneumatic water pumping systems driven by wind turbines. A comparative study
Authors with affiliations: Feitosa, E.A.N.; Medeiros, A.L.R.; Rohatgi, J.S.; Kruppel, R.
Abstract: Nearly a decade of experience with AIR-LIFT and BARC pumps in Brazil has shown that in terms of capital and operational costs and working efficiency, pneumatic water pumping systems driven by wind turbines offer a real alternative choice. It is emphasized that the characteristics of the water source (e.g. well) must always be carefully analysed when considering the application of the set wind turbine AIR-LIFT pump. In this way, precipitate and misleading conclusions related to efficiency can be avoided. Following the success of the above mentioned systems, a new development of a wind turbine with 15m diameter coupled to a BARC pump is in progress. This unique system will use an energy storage device (compressed air storage tank) and will be a first step towards large irrigation applications.
Index Keywords: Compressors - Applications; Control Systems; Friction; Pumps - Pneumatic Drive; Thermodynamics; Air-Lift Pump; BARC Pump; Directional Valve; Fluid Friction; Irrigation Channel; Volumetric Efficiency; Wind Turbines

Title: CAES, old and new
Source title: International Exhibition & Conference for the Power Generation Industries - Power-Gen
Affiliations: Gibbs & Hill, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Totten, Peter A., Gibbs & Hill, Inc, United States
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) power plants can provide an important and economical source of peaking and intermediate energy for utilities. The fundamental principal behind this technology is the storage of relatively inexpensive off-peak energy from base load plants, and the subsequent use of this energy when it is needed at on-peak time periods when electricity is relatively more expensive. The energy is stored by compressing air into underground storage reservoirs, and then withdrawing the air, heating it, and expanding it through an expansion turbine-generator when needed. Although new to the United States, a 290 MW CAES facility has been operating in Huntorf, Federal Republic of Germany since 1978. Alabama Electric Cooperative has contracted with the Joint Venture of Gibbs & Hill, Inc. and Harbert International, Inc. for the design and construction of the first CAES plant to be built in the United States. The 110 MW plant, to be located in McIntosh, Alabama, approximately 40 miles north of Mobile, is scheduled for operation in 1991. This paper will discuss the concept of CAES plants in general, as well as its application to the Huntorf, Soyland, and McIntosh plants. For the McIntosh facility, the paper will address specific design details as well as the evolution of the design since the detailed engineering commenced. In addition, it will discuss the status of construction, including the solution mining of the 19,000,000 cubic foot underground storage cavern being developed to contain the air at pressures up to 1130 psig. The paper will also describe various obstacles that have arisen during the engineering of the plant, and the methods used to overcome them.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air - Applications; Electric Power Generation; Alabama Electric Cooperative (AEC); Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES); Power Plants

Authors: Creegan Joseph B., Monforte Frank A.
Title: Modeling nonconvexities arising in a gas distribution planning problem with special ordered sets
Source title: Pipeline Simulation Interest Group. PSIG Annual Meeting 1989
Affiliations: Ketron Management Science, Inc., Arlington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Creegan, Joseph B., Ketron Management Science, Inc., Arlington, United States; Monforte, Frank A., Ketron Management Science, Inc., Arlington, United States
Abstract: With the deregulation of the California Natural Gas Industry in 1988, California gas utilities face new market pressures to remain a competitive energy source. At Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas), which is the largest distributor of natural gas in the Nation serving over 4 million customers, the Gas Balance model was developed to provide the necessary planning assistance. This model has a Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) formulation which is critical to the model's ability to project economically efficient gas operations. The SoCalGas gas distribution problem is to determine a least cost mix of supply purchases, distribution alternatives, and storage operations to meet system demand. Constraints imposed on the supply and storage operations, in addition to demand requirements and supply availabilities, are the physical limitations of the transmission and storage system.
Index Keywords: Economics; Mathematical Techniques--Algorithms; Nonconvexities; Storage Injection Curve; Submatrix; Gas Pipelines

Authors: Giacomelli E., Bernardini F., Pini A., Andree H.
Title: Application of gas turbines for large reciprocating compressor drive
Affiliations: Nuovo Pignone SpA, Florence, Italy

Abstract: The use of variable-speed drive systems such as gas turbines enhances the functional flexibility of reciprocating compressors. The experience gained till now makes it possible to forecast an increasing application of gas turbine-compressor arrangements thanks to the energy-saving advantages and the high reliability obtained with special design procedures and modern full-load test facilities.

Title: Investigation of electric car energy consumption using mathematical modeling
Authors with affiliations: Lobtsov, A.I.; Salakhov, M.S.
Abstract: In order to evaluate the influence of drive characteristics of electric car energy consumption we present an investigation of energy expenditure using a mathematical model. In modelling the car we use an electric drive diagram with a traction motor (TM) utilizing a separate excitation. Using this diagram, we constructed and calculated instantaneous electric circuit substitution diagrams for pulse loading of the traction accumulator battery (TAB) and for a smooth current loading regime. The investigations were carried out using an electric car with a total weight of 3.0 tonnes.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Motors, DC--Traction; Drive Characteristics; Electric Car; Energy Consumption; Mathematical Modeling; Storage Battery Vehicles

Title: Influence of the rated windspeed of a wind powered generator on consumer economics
Affiliations: Shizuoka Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawamoto, T., Shizuoka Univ, Japan; Sakakibara, T., Shizuoka Univ, Japan
Abstract: When a consumer introduces wind powered generator (WPG) systems in order to reduce charges for electricity, various system parameters should be determined. For the optimum system design, the influence of the rated windspeed of WPG, which is one of the most important parameters, is analyzed and an optimum value for it is obtained based on computer simulations. Generally, the system with the lower rated windspeed leads to decreased charges for electricity, but to increased WPG system cost. Taking these factors into account, the optimum rated windspeed was obtained and it was shown that the value of this decreases as the wind penetration increases.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electric Generators; Electric Power Systems; Energy Storage; Public Utilities; Consumer Economics; Rated Windspeed; Wind Powered Generator Systems; Wind Power; Economics; Power Generation; Wind Turbines

Title: Some aspects of wind diesel systems with reference to chalmers experimental wind diesel system
Affiliations: Chalmers Univ of Technology, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Linders, Jan, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Sweden
Abstract: This paper surveys the principal parameters involved in the design and operation of a wind-diesel system, indicating the options available for control, electrical power conversion including the use of power electronics, and energy storage systems. Each aspect is briefly described with its advantages and disadvantages, and reference is made where appropriate to the experimental wind diesel system being studied at Chalmers University of Technology.

Abstract: The design and experimental manufacture of a zinc-chlorine battery module having a discharge capacity of 60 kW × 8 hr are described. The battery characteristic test, the reliability and safety confirmation test, and the response test to various charge-discharge patterns are discussed. The module uses an organic solvent for storage of chlorine and is an improved version of the 10-kW-class battery equipped with an absorption tower for chlorine dissolution.

Title: Construction of insertion devices for elliptically polarized synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Shioya, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sasaki, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kitamura, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: Two new insertion devices for the generation of elliptically polarized synchrotron radiation have been constructed to be installed in two electron storage rings, the Accumulation Ring for the TRISTAN project and the Photon Factory ring at KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics. These new light sources are designed to produce (1) intense radiation with a degree of circular polarization (Pc) between 0.5 and 0.9 in hard x-ray region, and (2) quasimonochromatic radiation with Pc>0.7 in vacuum ultraviolet region.

Authors: Schilling D., Dransfeld K., Bihler E., Holdik K., Eisenmenger W.
Title: Polarization profiles of polyvinylidene fluoride films polarized by a focused electron beam
Affiliations: Fakultät für Physik, Universität Konstanz, Postfach 5560, 7750 Konstanz, Germany; 1. Physikalisches Institut der Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring, 57, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schilling, D., Fakultät für Physik, Universität Konstanz, Postfach 5560, 7750 Konstanz, Germany; Dransfeld, K., Fakultät für Physik, Universität Konstanz, Postfach 5560, 7750 Konstanz, Germany; Bihler, E., 1. Physikalisches Institut der Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring, 57, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany; Holdik, K., 1. Physikalisches Institut der Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring, 57, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany; Eisenmenger, W., 1. Physikalisches Institut der Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring, 57, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Abstract: The depth profiles of the polarization in films of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as well as in vinylidene-fluoride-trifluoroethylene (VDF-TrFE) copolymer films polarized by a focused electron beam were investigated using the piezoelectrically generated pressure step method. The dominant polarization exhibits a broad maximum inside the film. The position of this maximum depends not only on the energy of the incident electrons but also on the material parameters of the sample. Close to the surface exposed to the electron beam we have in addition observed a small secondary maximum of opposite polarization (amounting to about 1 mC/m2). A qualitative model is presented for the poling of films of PVDF and its copolymers with TrFE by focused electron beam accounting for most of the observed features. The application of electron beams for the poling of ferroelectric films allows the production of piezoelectric bimorphs. By using a well-focused electron beam also ferroelectric domains of very small lateral dimensions can be created which could become important for ferroelectric data storage.
