Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Hamburg, Hamburg, Germany; Zimmer, M., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany; Zorn, G.T., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Abstract: The charmed quark charge asymmetry has been measured at the average centre of mass energy of 35 GeV with the JADE detector at the e+e- storage ring PETRA. Charmed quarks were identified by D*± tagging using the ΔM technique. D*± mesons were reconstructed through their decay into D0 mesons resulting in (Kπ) π and (K π π π) π final states. The measured charge asymmetry A=-0.149±0.067 is in agreement with the expectation from the electroweak interference effect in quantum flavour dynamics (QFD). © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: MacDowell A.A., Hashizume T., Citrin P.H.
Title: A soft/hard x-ray beamline for surface EXAFS studies in the energy range 0.8-15 keV
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacDowell, A.A., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Hashizume, T., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Citrin, P.H., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: A new ultrahigh-vacuum x-ray beamline for surface EXAFS experiments has been constructed at the 2.5-GeV storage ring at Brookhaven National Laboratory, USA. Its design minimizes or eliminates a variety of problems inherent in other beamlines, providing state-of-the-art intensity, brightness, resolution, and beam stability over an extremely wide range of energy. Performance is discussed with initial results obtained after the recent x-ray ring shutdown.

Authors: Albers P.W., Sicking G.H., Ross D.K.
Title: The use of neutron inelastic scattering and hydrogen isotope exchange to investigate the nature of sites occupied by hydrogen in TiMn1.5
Affiliations: Degussa AG, Hanau, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Albers, P.W., Degussa AG, Hanau, Germany; Sicking, G.H., Degussa AG, Hanau, Germany; Ross, D.K., Degussa AG, Hanau, Germany
Abstract: Inelastic neutron scattering and isotope separation factor measurements are reported for the potential hydrogen storage system Ti0.4Mn 0.6Hn. Inelastic spectra were measured for six hydrogen concentrations ranging from 0.001 to 1.0 hydrogens/metal atom, the first five in the alpha and alpha + beta phases and the last in the beta phase. The spectra consisted of two groups of peaks, the first from 70 meV to 110 meV and the second from 110 to 180 meV. The intensity of the former was independent of the hydrogen content and could be associated with a precursor region in the isotherm while that of the latter rose linearly with hydrogen content. Peak shape analysis of the high energy peaks show them to be consistent with occupation of first Ti3Mn and then Ti2Mn2 sites and with changes between the alpha - and beta -phases. The identification of the precursor sites is not easy if based entirely on the IINS spectra as both-OH and near surface interstitial sites could be involved. However, the measurement of the H/T isotope separation factor unambiguously points to the existence of TiOH because only this can explain the dramatic fall of alpha near n=0.

Authors: Vinokurov N.A., Drobyazko I.B., Kulipanov G.N., Litvinenko V.N., Pinayev I.V.
Title: Lasing in visible and ultraviolet regions in an optical klystron installed on the VEPP-3 storage ring (invited)
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vinokurov, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Drobyazko, I.B., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kulipanov, G.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Litvinenko, V.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pinayev, I.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Lavrentyev Prospect II, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Since 1979, experiments on the storage ring VEPP-3 with an optical klystron (OK) have been performed at the INP Academy of Sciences of the USSR. In 1979, 1981, and 1983, three different OK magnetic systems based on SmCo permanent magnets undulators were installed at the VEPP-3 straight section at 6300-A wavelength. The following gains per pass have been obtained: 0.5% in 1980, 1% in 1982, and 2%-2.5% in 1984. In late 1985, we decided to improve the storage ring VEPP-3 and develop a dc bypass, a special straight section dedicated for OK operation. The bypass allowed us to install an OK magnetic system of 7.8 m length and significantly increase the gain per pass in March of 1988. The bypass was installed at the storage ring VEPP-3 on 3 June 1988. We obtained lasing in the red and yellow light spectral range from 5800 to 6900 A with 5%-10% gain per pass. After changing mirrors for new ones with minimum losses at 4150 A, lasing in the violet and near UV spectral range with 3%-6% gain per pass from 4500 to 3750 A was obtained on 8 July. All work is being carried out at an energy of 350 MeV. Threshold currents for lasing are 1-10 mA depending on the optical cavity mirror conditions. The maximum current is 80 mA at present. A set of measurements on studying lasing in various conditions is underway.

Authors: Vass I., Chapman D.J., Barber J.
Title: Thermoluminescence properties of the isolated photosystem two reaction centre
Affiliations: Institute of Plant Physiology, Biological Research Center, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 521, Szeged, H-6701, Hungary; AFCR Photosynthesis Research Group, Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Imperial College, London, SW7 2BB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Vass, I., Institute of Plant Physiology, Biological Research Center, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 521, Szeged, H-6701, Hungary; Chapman, D.J., AFCR Photosynthesis Research Group, Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Imperial College, London, SW7 2BB, United Kingdom; Barber, J., AFCR Photosynthesis Research Group, Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Imperial College, London, SW7 2BB, United Kingdom
Abstract: Formation of thermoluminescence signals is characteristics of energy- and charge storage in Photosystem II. In isolated D1/D2/cytochrome b-559 Photosystem II reaction centre preparation four thermoluminescence components were found. These appear at -180 (Z band), between -80 and -50 (Zv band), at -30 and at +35°C. The Z band arises from pigment molecules but not correlated with photosynthetic activity. The Zv and -30°C bands arise from the recombination of charge pairs stabilized in the Photosystem II reaction centre complex. The +35°C band probably corresponds to the artefact glow peak resulting from a pigment-protein-detergent interaction in subchloroplast preparations (Rózsa Zs, Droppa M and Horváth G (1989) Biochim Biophys Acta 973, 350-353). © 1989 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: charge recombination; D1/D2/cytochrome b-599; Photosystem II; thermoluminescence

Authors: Tatchyn R., Csonka P., Toor A.
Title: Perspectives on micropole undulators in synchrotron radiation technology
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Csonka, P., Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States, Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Toor, A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: Micropole undulators promise to advance synchrotron radiation (SR) technology in two distinct ways. The first is in the development of economical, low-energy storage rings, or linacs, as soft x-ray sources, and the second is in the opening up of gamma-ray spectral ranges on high-energy storage rings. In this paper the promise and current status of micropole undulator (MPU) technology are discussed, and a review of some practical obstacles to the implementation of MPU's on present-day storage rings is given. Some successful results of recent performance measurements of micropole undulators on the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory linac are briefly summarized.

Authors: Peatman W., Carbone C., Gudat W., Heinen W., Kuske P., Pflüger J., Schäfers F., Schroeter T.
Title: The BESSY wiggler/undulator-TGM-5 beamline (invited)
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; KFA Jülich GmbH, IFF, Postfach 1913, D-5170 Jülich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Peatman, W., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Carbone, C., KFA Jülich GmbH, IFF, Postfach 1913, D-5170 Jülich, Germany; Gudat, W., KFA Jülich GmbH, IFF, Postfach 1913, D-5170 Jülich, Germany; Heinen, W., KFA Jülich GmbH, IFF, Postfach 1913, D-5170 Jülich, Germany; Kuske, P., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Pflüger, J., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Schäfers, F., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Schroeter, T., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: In actual performance, the 35 pole wiggler/undulator (W/U) at BESSY has been shown to deliver 50 to 250 times more flux than a TGM with 10 mrad of dipole radiation under otherwise comparable conditions. The beamline, laid out for photon energies from 15 to 400 eV, has been calibrated and the resolution measured at several energies. Interactions of the W/U with the storage ring have been studied and, in part, corrected for: the working point does not change in either direction (<10%) as the gap is varied and the electron beam position in the ring remains constant to within 10 μm and the angle of emission of the SR from the ring to within 5 μrad for K≤2.7. The reduction of the lifetime of the electron beam in the ring and the change in the vertical size of the beam as a function of the gap are typical of the problems associated with the interaction of such a device on a high brightness ring. The beamline has been in normal user operation for over a year.

Authors: Isoyama G., Yamamoto S., Shioya T., Ohkuma H., Sasaki S., Mitsuhashi T., Yamakawa T., Kitamura H.
Title: Construction of a multiundulator, Revolver No. 19, at the Photon Factory
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Isoyama, G., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamamoto, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Shioya, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Ohkuma, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sasaki, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Mitsuhashi, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamakawa, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kitamura, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: A multiundulator, Revolver No. 19, was constructed and installed at the straight section (B 18-B19) of the 2.5-GeV Photon Factory storage ring. The mechanical structure of Revolver No. 19 consists of a main frame and two rotatable beams with four base plates, on which undulator magnets with four different lengths of period are mounted. A pair of undulator magnets with a desired period length can be selected by revolving the rotatable beams. The energy range of the radiation covered by fundamental peaks from the undulator magnets is from 7.8 to 1150 eV.

Authors: Karpenko V., Kinney J.H., Kulkarni S., Neufeld K., Poppe C., Tirsell K.G., Wong J., Cerino J., Troxel T., Yang J., Hoyer E., Green M., Humphries D., Marks S., Plate D.
Title: Beamline 10: A multipole wiggler beamline at SSRL (invited)
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA, United States; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Karpenko, V., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Kinney, J.H., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Kulkarni, S., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Neufeld, K., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Poppe, C., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Tirsell, K.G., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Wong, J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Cerino, J., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA, United States; Troxel, T., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA, United States; Yang, J., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA, United States; Hoyer, E., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States; Green, M., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States; Humphries, D., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States; Marks, S., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States; Plate, D., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: A beamline has been constructed at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL) whose radiation source is a multipole permanent magnet wiggler installed in a straight section of the SPEAR 3-3.5 GeV electron storage ring. The wiggler is a hybrid design that utilizes Nd-Fe alloy magnet material combined with Vanadium Permendur poles. It is approximately 2 m long and has 15 full wiggler periods. Its field is regulated by varying its gap height. It has a peak operating field, limited by the electron beam vacuum chamber vertical aperture, of 1.4 T. The beamline consists of vacuum, safety, and optical components capable of transporting photons to one hard x-ray (3-30 keV) end station, with provisions for implementing up to two additional branch lines. The existing hard x-ray branch can be focused by a Pt-coated toroidal mirror with a cutoff energy of approximately 22 keV. The experimental end station is serviced by a Hower-Brown type double crystal monochromator. The wiggler and beamline construction was completed in the fall of 1987 and was operated for a brief period for characterization and experimental use. We present design details and results of the initial characterization studies.

Authors: Navarro E., Iglesias J.I.P., Larrañaga A.
Title: Interannual variation in the reproductive cycle and biochemical composition of the cockle Cerastoderma edule from Mundaca Estuary (Biscay, North Spain)
Affiliations: Departamento de Biología Animal y Genética, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea, Apartado 644, Bilbao, E-48080, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Navarro, E., Departamento de Biología Animal y Genética, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea, Apartado 644, Bilbao, E-48080, Spain; Iglesias, J.I.P., Departamento de Biología Animal y Genética, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea, Apartado 644, Bilbao, E-48080, Spain; Larrañaga, A., Departamento de Biología Animal y Genética, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea, Apartado 644, Bilbao, E-48080, Spain
Abstract: Seasonal determinants of body weight, biochemical composition and reproductive condition in the cockle Cerastoderma edule L. from the Mundaca Estuary, Spain, were performed from December 1983 to July 1985. Interannual differences in timing of gametogenesis and spawning between 1984 and 1985 were correlated with temporal variations in the cycles of storage and utilisation of carbohydrate reserves. Young individuals exhibited larger annual fluctuations in soft-body weight, displaying higher growth rates in spring and greater diminishment of energy reserves during autumn and winter than older individuals. Carbohydrate content displayed a similar tendency, levels being lower in young individuals throughout the year. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Charge transfer in ZnS-type electroluminescence
Affiliations: Laboratoire d'Optique de la Matière Condensée, Université P. et M. Curie, Tour 13, 4 place Jussieu, 75252 Paris Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Bringuier, E., Laboratoire d'Optique de la Matière Condensée, Université P. et M. Curie, Tour 13, 4 place Jussieu, 75252 Paris Cedex, France
Abstract: In this paper, a simple model for the charge transfer in thin-film, ac-driven electroluminescent structures of doped ZnS type is proposed. We first review the minimal assumptions needed to account for the carrier emission under high-field conditions and its subsequent feedback on the field strength; it opens the way to a quantitative description of the field variation with time and the conduction current under arbitrary low-frequency drive conditions and without using any adjustable parameter. The charge-voltage relationships are also examined in detail. Conduction in the phosphor layer is assumed to originate from deep levels (traps) in the phosphor forbidden band gap, located at the insulator-phosphor interface. These levels act for charge storage, too. When a discrete trap level is considered, field clamping in the active layer is obtained; when a smooth interface-state energy density is assumed, deviations from the field clamping are possible and simply related to the interface parameters. Most of the work is analytical and the model is shown to exhibit the main qualitative features of nonmemory devices.

Authors: Hosokawa T., Kitayama T., Hayasaka T., Ido S., Uno Y., Shibayama A., Nakata J., Nishimura K., Nakajima M.
Title: NTT superconducting storage ring - Super-ALIS
Affiliations: NTT LSI Laboratories, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, 3-1, Morinosato Wakamiya, Atsugi-Shi, Kanagawa Pref., 243-01, Japan

Abstract: A superconducting electron storage ring fully dedicated to x-ray lithography has been developed. It has a racetrack shape, consisting of two superconducting bending magnets, other normal conducting multipole magnets, rf system, vacuum system, and beam monitoring systems. The storage ring circumference is 16.8 m. The critical wavelength (λc) is 17.3 Å. The beam size (σ) at every synchrotron radiation source point is less than 1 mm. This machine employs the energy-boost-in-the-ring scheme; electrons are injected at around 15 MeV and then accelerated to 600 MeV in the ring. The injector is a newly developed linear accelerator with an energy compression system. Higher-energy injection is also available.

Authors: Bernstorff S., Braun W., Mast M., Peatman W., Schroeter T.
Title: A flexible high-energy toroidal grating monochromator at Bessy
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bernstorff, S., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Braun, W., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Mast, M., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Peatman, W., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Schroeter, T., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: A toroidal grating monochromator, the HE-TGM-2, designed for medium high resolution and high transmission in the spectral range 100-730 eV, has been installed and tested at the Berlin electron storage ring BESSY. Having a conventional configuration, namely a prefocusing mirror and an entrance slit, the resolution of the HE-TGM-2 is essentially independent of the source size and position of the stored electron beam. Gas phase photoionization spectra of free atoms and molecules as well as photoemission experiments on solid surfaces have been used to characterize this monochromator.

Authors: Brinkman A.C., Aarts H.J.M., Branduardi-Raymont G., Hailey C.J., Jansen F.A., Kahn S.M., de Korte P.A.J., Zehnder A.
Title: Spectroscopic investigations with a reflection grating spectrometer
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Utrecht, Netherlands; SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Leiden, Netherlands; Mullard Space Science Laboratory, University College London, Dorking, United Kingdom; University of California, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; University of California, Berkeley, United States; Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Brinkman, A.C., SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Utrecht, Netherlands; Aarts, H.J.M., SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Leiden, Netherlands; Branduardi-Raymont, G., Mullard Space Science Laboratory, University College London, Dorking, United Kingdom; Hailey, C.J., University of California, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; Jansen, F.A., SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Leiden, Netherlands; Kahn, S.M., University of California, Berkeley, United States; de Korte, P.A.J., SRON-Laboratory for Space Research, Utrecht, Netherlands; Zehnder, A., Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: The Reflection Grating Spectrometer experiment (RGS) on the X-ray Multi-Mirror Mission spacecraft (XMM) of the European Space Agency (ESA) consists of two identical instruments behind two of the three high throughput X-ray telescopes. The instruments will achieve high energy resolution and high efficiency in the combined first and second order of diffraction in the wavelength range between 5 and 35 Å. The design incorporates an array of reflection gratings placed in the converging beam at the exit from the X-ray telescope. The grating stack picks off roughly half of the X-ray light and diffracts it to the array of charge-coupled device (CCD) detectors offset from the telescope focal plane. The remaining light passes undeflected through the grating stack where it can be utilised by instruments located in the focal plane. Both the gratings and the detector are placed on the Rowland circle. The reflection gratings diffract first, second and third order at high to moderate efficiency. The separation of the spectral orders is accomplished using the energy resolution of the CCD detectors. A set of ten CCD-chips (nine for spectroscopy, one for wavelength calibration) are arranged in a strip oriented tangentially to the Rowland circle. Since the optical design is nearly stigmatic, the spectrum of an on-axis point source will appear as a line image along the detector array. In order to reduce noise and dark current an operational temperature of -80°C is adopted for the CCD’s. The cooling is provided through a passive radiator. The chips are read out sequentially with a common electronics chain. Each chip is configured in an “image and store” mode in which the image is first acquired over half the chip and transferred to the other half for storage prior to read out. © 1989 SPIE.

Title: Silicon photodiodes with stable, near -theoretical quantum efficiency in the soft x-ray region
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: United Detector Technology, Hawthorne, CA, 90250, United States; National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Korde, R., United Detector Technology, Hawthorne, CA, 90250, United States; Canfield, L.R., National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD, 20899, United States
Abstract: Silicon photodiodes having practically no carrier recombination at the Si-Si02 interface or in the front diffused region have been developed by defect-free n-type impurity diffusion into p-type silicon. These photodiodes exhibit very high quantum efficiencies in the 10 eV to 150 eV photon energy region, typically 37 electrons per photon at 150 eV, which is about 300 times the quantum efficiency of the more commonly used photoemissive type soft X-ray detectors. The quantum efficiency of the developed diodes has been found to be stable to a few percent after exposure to photons in the region of 5eV to 200eV, with fluences in excess of 1014/cm2. No significant change in the quantum efficiency was observed after storage in air for several months. © 1989, SPIE.

Authors: Heard D., Roberts G.G., Goringe M.J., Griffiths J.
Title: Optical applications of IR-absorbing Langmuir-Blodgett films
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, United Kingdom; Department of Metallurgy and Science of Materials, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, United Kingdom; Department of Colour Chemistry and Dyeing, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Heard, D., Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, United Kingdom; Roberts, G.G., Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, United Kingdom; Goringe, M.J., Department of Metallurgy and Science of Materials, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, United Kingdom; Griffiths, J., Department of Colour Chemistry and Dyeing, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) films have been produced using a novel near-IR- absorbing dye based on 1,4-naphthoquinone. Wavelength compatibility with semiconductor diode lasers makes it particularly suitable for optical storage applications. Ablative data marks have been recorded using 830 nm light with a pulse energy of 3.6 nJ. The sensitivity is dependent on heat flow within the film and substrate, and can be increased using LB film buffer layers. © 1989.

Skjevling, G., University of Oslo, N-0316 Oslo 3, Norway; Stapnes, S., University of Oslo, N-0316 Oslo 3, Norway; Stugu, B., University of Oslo, N-0316 Oslo 3, Norway
Abstract: In an experiment performed at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings as a part of an energy scan to detect the ηc formation in pp annihilation, we studied the reaction pp→φφ→K+K-K+K-. The total cross section has been determined to be 25.0± 7.4±3.8 nb. © 1989.

Authors: Fujihira M., Kamei T., Sakomura M., Tatsu Y., Kato Y.
Title: Novel molecular optical memory of luminescent Langmuir-Blodgett films
Affiliations: Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujihira, M., Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Kamei, T., Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Sakomura, M., Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Tatsu, Y., Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan; Kato, Y., Department of Biomolecular Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan
Abstract: The photochemical oxidation of pure and mixed Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) films of 6-(1-(6(8)-decyl)pyrene)hexanoic acid (DPHA) and 10-(1-(6(8)-hexyl)-pyrene)decanoic acid (HPDA) in the presence of molecular oxygen was studied. The much higher rate of decrease in the fluorescence intensity than that in the UV-visible absorbance due to pyrene moieties can be ascribed to the energy transfer quenching of the photoexcited pyrene moieties by the photo-oxidative products. Energy transfer quenching of the Förster type was confirmed by examining the dependence of the fluorescence quenching on the spacer thickness between the monolayers of the pyrene moieties and the photoproducts in the heterogeneous LB films. Application of the amplified decrease in the excimer emission in terms of the quenching by photoproducts to a very sensitive photoresponsive memory was also suggested. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Data storage, Optical; Fluorescence; Molecules; Langmuir-Blodgett Films; Molecular Optical Memory; Fatty acids

Title: Optimal storing, transport and processing for a forest-fuel supplier
Affiliations: Department of Operational Efficiency, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-77073 Garpenberg, Sweden, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Eriksson, L.O., Department of Operational Efficiency, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-77073 Garpenberg, Sweden, Sweden; Björheden, R., Department of Operational Efficiency, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-77073 Garpenberg, Sweden, Sweden
Abstract: The supplier of forest fuel has a large number of interrelated activities to coordinate on the way from raw material source to consumer. Transports, storing and intermediate processing must be decided on for a number of different raw materials. In this paper, an analysis is performed on the energy supply system of Jämtlandsbränslen, a subsidiary of the Swedish Cellulose Company. Included are several forest supply regions, one central processing site and one consumer. Optimal solutions are derived for a problem with an infinite sequence of years, where each year is divided into six periods. The problem is solved as an ordinary linear programming problem. Results are given on optimal production flows, storing and procurement. The usefulness of the applied analytical approach for deriving rules for operational planning is discussed. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Fuels--Storage; Logging--Sweden; Mathematical Programming, Linear; Operations Research; Forest Fuel Supplier; Log Allocation Models; Network Algorithms; Wood

Title: Change in the structure during amorphization and crystallization of Ta2O5 under mechanical stressing. A comparative study with Nb2O5
Affiliations: Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Hiyoshi, Yokohama, 233, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ikeya, T., Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Hiyoshi, Yokohama, 233, Japan; Senna, M., Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, Hiyoshi, Yokohama, 233, Japan
Abstract: A non-crystalline state was produced by vibro-milling the monoclinic phase of Ta2O5. The structural units of mechanically amorphized Ta2O5 were more similar to the rhombic phase than the initial monoclinic phase. The short range order remained with a distorted hexagonal bipyramid as a unit structure. Further grinding resulted in the crystallization into the rhombic phase. The change in the structural units from monoclinic to rhombic phase via a non-crystalline state was almost identical with that observed in Nb2O5. However, the crystallization of mechanically amorphized Ta2O5 was more difficult than Nb2O5. This is attributed to the higher lattice energy, which does not allow significant energy storage. The difference in the role of crystallographic shear between Ta2O5 and Nb2O5 on the mechanism of structural change is discussed. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Oxides--Structure; Spectroscopy, Infrared--Applications; Spectroscopy, Raman--Applications; Stresses--Analysis; Mechanical Amorphization; Tantalum Oxide; Vibromilling; Tantalum Compounds

Authors: Huo Situ, Zhi Tao Wang, Ai-Lien Jung
Title: Mechanism of transformations in phase-change optical recording media
Affiliations: Amorphous Research Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (BUAA), Beijing, 100083, China
Authors with affiliations: Huo Situ, Amorphous Research Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (BUAA), Beijing, 100083, China; Zhi Tao Wang, Amorphous Research Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (BUAA), Beijing, 100083, China; Ai-Lien Jung, Amorphous Research Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (BUAA), Beijing, 100083, China
Abstract: Multielement alloys composed of two binary compounds such as SbTe, SbSe, InTe, InSe and MTeSe compounds, useful for optical recording media, have been prepared. The kinetics of phase change in these media are discussed. The activation energy of crystallization, ΔE, and the transformation index n are calculated. The data show that the film with stoichiometric composition not only has the best stability, but also has the largest transformation index. In addition, the times required for the media to change from the glassy state to the crystalline state by optical crystallization is much less than that of the pure thermal crystallization. A new model for the transformations induced by laser pulses based on the electronic structural changes of the alloys is proposed. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical--Materials; Optical Disk Materials; Optical Transformation; Phase Change Kinetics; Phase-Change Optical Recording Media; Glass, Metallic

Title: Effect of thermal perturbations from a used-fuel disposal vault on rock joints in the far field
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Affiliations: Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Heinrich, W.F., Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Canada
Abstract: Joints in rock are potential transport paths for radionuclides from a used-fuel disposal vault to the biosphere. The effect of radiogenic heat from such a vault on the stress field and, hence, on joints in the host rock is examined. Temperature changes in the host rock are determined for a vault with a radius of 1000 m, at a depth of 1000 m, and with a thermal loading of 10 W/m2. The time of maximum temperature in the vault, 5000 years, and the time of maximum thermal energy storage in the rock mass, 25 000 years, were singled out for subsequent stress analysis.
Index Keywords: Failure Analysis; Radioactive Wastes - Geological Repositories; Stresses - Thermal; Rock Joints; Rock

Title: Electrical and structural effects on ionizing radiation in IGFETS
Affiliations: Microelectronics Center of North Carolina, P. O. Box 12889, Research Triangle Park, 27709, NC, United States; Department Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, P. O. Box 7911, Raleigh, 27695, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reisman, A., Microelectronics Center of North Carolina, P. O. Box 12889, Research Triangle Park, 27709, NC, United States, Department Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, P. O. Box 7911, Raleigh, 27695, NC, United States
Abstract: In terms of initial device yield, and long term reliability, process induced radiation damage represents an area of considerable concern. The processes that need to be examined include Ion Implantation, X-ray, E-Beam and Ion Beam lithography, Electron Beam metal evaporation, Sputtering, Reactive Ion Etching, and even SEM examination. The paper discusses the effects of synchrotron X-radiation in the energy range 300-100 eV, as well as Al Ka exposures which simulate the effective wavelength of storage rings planned for X-ray lithography. It will describe such effects in the context of preliminary studies dealing with varying rad exposure level at constant gate insulator thickness, as well as the behavior at several rad exposure levels as a function of gate insulator thickness. Data will be presented indicating that despite prevailing beliefs, damage in the synchrotron range follows a linear relationship over the thickness range from less than 10 nm to 50 nm, indicating strongly that damage resides near the interface and is constant with increasing insulator thickness. It will be shown that such behavior is consistent with a simple model. Even if such damage can be annealed completely using normal techniques, which is questionable, there are wide-ranging implications concerning the rad hardness of scaled devices. © 1989 The Metallurgical of Society of AIME.
Author Keywords: process damage; radiation damage; X-ray induced insulator damage

Title: Increasing the transmitting capacity of a high-current gas-filled discharger
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kapishnikov, N.K., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: Test results are given for a single-channel trigatron spark discharger with a compressed gas as its working medium that switches a capacitive storage device with a working voltage of up to 5 kV and a stored energy of 85-90 kJ. Elconite (25% Cu + 75% W) inserts in the central parts of the copper electrodes and an elconite trigger electrode provide a life of over 100 actuations without variation of the discharger parameters.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Switching; Composite Materials - Erosion; Copper and Alloys - Wear Resisting; Electric Spark Gaps - Performance; Electrodes - Service Life; Elconite; Electrode Erosion; Single-Channel Dischargers; Transmitting Capacity; Trigatron Spark Dischargers; Trigger Electrodes; Electric Switches

Title: Stationary battery storage systems
Affiliations: BBT Control Systems, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Wetzel, Peter R., BBT Control Systems, South Africa
Abstract: From the beginning of the industrial use of electricity the storage of electrical energy was of the foremost interest for many applications. In general two approaches were chosen: Firstly, there was the direct storage of energy in batteries (accumulators), a development that started with experiments conducted by L. Galvani in 1786, followed by Volta's element in 1800, leading to the present-day lead acid accumulator and natrium sulphur battery. Secondly, there was indirect storage, whereby the electrical energy is converted into other forms of energy for storage. Examples are storage systems for potential energy thermal energy or compressed air stored in caverns. A further differentiation of electrical storage devices is whether they are used in mobile or in stationary systems. The mobile applications can further be divided into small accumulators as used in calculators, watches or portable radios, or accumulators of medium capacity as used mainly in road vehicles or shunting locomotives. In this article, the author looks at the stationary applications of high energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: Control, Electric Variables - Voltage; Energy Storage; High Energy Storage Systems; Peak Load Supply; Secondary Energy Storage; Stationary Applications; Stationary Battery Storage Systems; Voltage Regulation; Electric Batteries

Title: Use of renewable energy resources for industrial steam generation
Source title: Australian refrigeration, Air conditioning and heating
Affiliations: Maxitherm Boilers
Authors with affiliations: Sandilands, A.W.J., Maxitherm Boilers
Abstract: An examination is made of the economic advantages of using waste rather than premium fuels for steam generation. While only the sugar industry uses significant amounts of renewable energy resources, other industries could benefit from this approach. For steam generation, the figures presented clearly indicate the significant economic advantages to be gained in using waste fuels in place of the premium fuels such as oil and gas. The additional costs associated with the installation can be quickly recovered in the difference of the costs of the fuels. The problems of handling and the storage requirements of the waste fuels although not insignificant are certainly not insurmountable and should not preclude the use of these fuels in favour of a more 'convenient' premium fuel without a full evaluation of all costs. Watertube boilers and combustion equipment are available which will burn waste fuels cleanly and efficiently.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Wastes; Energy Resources; Fuels--Combustion; Waste Utilization; Calorific Value; Moisture Content; Renewable Energy Resources; Steam

Authors: Huang P., Goudy A.J., Koh J.T.
Title: Hydrogen absorption-desorption kinetics of MmNi5 and related compounds
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huang, P., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States; Goudy, A.J., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States; Koh, J.T., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States
Abstract: A study was made to determine the effects of aluminum and iron substitution on the reaction kinetics of MmNi5 (Mm = mischmetal). Each sample used in this study i.e. MmNi5, MmNi4.5 A10.5 and MmNi4.85Fe0.15, was mixed with a heat buffer so that nearly isothermal conditions could be maintained. Experiments were also designed so that the ratio of the equilibrium plateau pressure to the opposing pressure was the same for each sample. This was done to ensure that the thermodynamic driving force acting on each sample was the same. In addition, a sufficiently large number of absorption-desorption cycles were initially done on each sample for reproducible results to be obtained. The relative reaction rates among the various samples studied were found to change with the temperatures and pressure ratios that were chosen. Thus it is very important that any comparison of the reaction kinetics of metal hydrides should also include information about the temperature intervals used and the activation energies of each sample, as well as quantitative expressions showing how the reaction rates change with the imposed pressure ratio. At 25 °C and a pressure ratio of 2, reaction rates were found to be in the following order: MmNi5 > MmNi4.5Al0.5 ≈ LaNi5 > MmNi4.85Fe0.15. Thus it was concluded that aluminum and iron substitution has a deleterious effect on the reaction kinetics of MmNi5 hydride. Of the materials studied, MmNi4.5Al0.5 seems to be the most practical material for hydrogen storage. This is because it has thermodynamic and kinetic properties similar to those of LaNi5 but at a cheaper price. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Reaction Kinetics; Hydrogen Inorganic Compounds; Hydrogen--Storage; Hydrogen Absorption-Desorption; Metal Hydrides; Mischmetal Nickel Compounds; Nickel Compounds

Authors: Cady E.B., Elshove H., Jones D.A., Moll A.
Title: The metabolic causes of slow relaxation in fatigued human skeletal muscle.
Affiliations: Department of Medicine, University College London, Rayne Institute, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cady, E.B., Department of Medicine, University College London, Rayne Institute, United Kingdom; Elshove, H., Department of Medicine, University College London, Rayne Institute, United Kingdom; Jones, D.A., Department of Medicine, University College London, Rayne Institute, United Kingdom; Moll, A., Department of Medicine, University College London, Rayne Institute, United Kingdom
Abstract: 1. The relationship between slowing of relaxation and changes of intracellular pH and phosphorous metabolites has been examined in human skeletal muscle during the development of fatigue and subsequent recovery. Results obtained with normal subjects have been compared with those from a subject with myophosphorylase deficiency (MPD) who produced no H+ from glycolysis during exercise and therefore afforded the opportunity of assessing the role of H+ in the slowing of relaxation. 2. Subjects fatigued the first dorsal interosseous muscle in a stepwise fashion under ischaemic conditions, with intervals between the fatiguing contractions during which the relaxation rate was measured from brief tetanic contractions and the muscle phosphorous metabolites and pH were measured by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. 3. After 21 s maximal voluntary contraction under ischaemic conditions, relaxation in the MPD subject slowed to approximately 50% of the rate in the fresh muscle at a time when the intramuscular pH had not changed. This demonstrates that there is a mechanism causing slowing of relaxation that is independent of H+ accumulation. 4. The normal subjects showed a slow recovery of relaxation compared to the MPD subject when the circulation was restored. The main difference in the intracellular metabolite concentrations between MPD and normal subjects at this time was that, for the latter, the pH remained low (around 6.5) for at least 60 s after the circulation was restored. The results suggest that the slow recovery is a consequence of continuing acidosis, i.e. the existence of a pH‐dependent mechanism of slowing. 5. The existence of a pH‐dependent mechanism was further indicated by the fact that for the normal subjects, for a similar intracellular concentration of phosphocreatine, relaxation of the recovering muscle was approximately half that of the fatiguing muscle. This was at a time when the pH of the recovering muscle was 0.3‐0.4 units less than in the partially fatigued muscle. 6. The results show that in normal muscle there are at least two processes that lead to slow relaxation in fatigued muscle: one due to H+ accumulation, the other being independent of H+. © 1989 The Physiological Society
Index Keywords: adenosine diphosphate; adenosine triphosphate; creatine phosphate; cell ph; clinical article; controlled study; exercise; female; glycogen storage disease type 5; glycolysis; human; human cell; human experiment; ischemia; male; metabolism; muscle disease; muscle fatigue; normal human; priority journal; skeletal muscle; Adenosine Triphosphate; Adult; Energy Metabolism; Fatigue; Female; Human; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Intracellular Fluid; Magnetic Resonance Imaging; Male; Muscle Contraction; Muscle Relaxation; Phosphocreatine; Phosphorus; Phosphorylases; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Authors: Vulovic N., Primprac M., Stupar M., Ford J.L.
Title: Some studies into the properties of indomethacin suspensions intended for ophthalmic use
Affiliations: Schooi of Pharmacy, BeogradYugoslavia; Centre for Pharmaceutical Sciences, School of Health Sciences, Liverpool Polytechnic, LiverpoolU.K.
Authors with affiliations: Vulovic, N., Schooi of Pharmacy, BeogradYugoslavia; Primprac, M., Schooi of Pharmacy, BeogradYugoslavia; Stupar, M., Schooi of Pharmacy, BeogradYugoslavia; Ford, J.L., Centre for Pharmaceutical Sciences, School of Health Sciences, Liverpool Polytechnic, LiverpoolU.K.
Abstract: The formulation of eye drops containing indomethacin creates a number of problems since indomethacin is unstable in alkaline media but poorly soluble in acidic media. This paper outlines the formulation of a suitable suspension buffered to pH 5.6 and containing either hydroxypropylmethylcellulose (HPMC) or polyvinylalcohol (PVA) as viscolizers. Accelerated stability demonstrated satisfactory stability during storage under ambient conditions with a T10% (time for 10% to degrade) of - 280 days and an activation energy of 25.4 kcal/mol. Particle size measurements (Coulter Counter) indicated that no significant alterations occurred in the particle size distribution of indomethacin in the presence of PVA or HPMC following heating at 100° C with a bactericide for 30 min and following 2 months subsequent storage. The same behaviour for indomethacin particles was not observed in the absence of PVA or HPMC. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Indomethacin; Ophthalmic suspension; Particle size; Stability

Title: Luminescence excitation of barium fluorohalides by using synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Authors with affiliations: Mikhailin, V.V., Moscow State University, Moscow, 117234, Russian Federation; Terekhin, M.A., I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: Luminescence excitation spectra of barium fluorohalides are studied using synchrotron radiation of the Siberia-1 electron storage ring in the energy range from 4 to 35 eV. The energy position of edge and core excitation formation as well as that of the electronic excitation multiplication threshold have been established. © 1989.

Repkov, V.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Roenko, V.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Skrinsky, A.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sukhanov, S.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tokarev, Yu.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Trakhtenberg, E.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: In the last decade researches dealing with the creation of technology for X-ray lithography and for appropriate production equipment have been performed in many countries. The basic aim of these works is to provide a mass production of inexpensive devices with submicron structures (0.7-0.1 μm). Bringing X-ray lithographic technology into commercial practice necessitates to design and build a dedicated SR source for the electronic industry. The use of superconducting bending magnets with 40-70 kG field strength enables the storage ring circumference to be reduced by a factor of 2-5 and the injection energy by a factor of 3-4 as compared to the conventional designs of storage rings. In the present paper we consider a storage ring which was designed for a maximum energy of 600 MeV, with 60 kG field strength in its bending magnets and 10 m circumference. The critical SR wavelength is 8.6 Å. The electrons are injected into the storage ring at 50-60 MeV and the maximum stored current is assumed to be equal to 0.3 A. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Superconducting Magnets; Siberia Storage Ring; Synchrotron Radiation; Accelerators

Title: High-voltage trigatron-type rail discharger
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kapishnikov, N.K., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: A 10-channel trigatron-type rail discharger is described with gas filling at a pressure of 0.3-1 MPa. The discharger switches a capacitive storage device with an internal impedance of 0.6-2.5 Ω and a working voltage of 5-50 kV. The numbers of discharge channels for various gas mixtures and trigger conditions are measured. The current distribution over the discharge channels is evaluated. It is shown that 70-85% of the total number of discharge channels can be effective. The discharger life is several tens of thousands of actuations for a switched energy of units of kilojoules.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Discharges - Photography; Electrodes; Electronic Circuits, Trigger; Gases, Inert - Electric Breakdown; Current Distribution; Discharger Life; Discharger Reliability; Multichannel Dischargers; Rail Dischargers; Trigatron Dischargers; Electric Switches

Authors: Nishimura M., Bando Y., Kuraishi M., Hahne E.W.P.
Title: Direct storage of solar thermal energy using a semitransparent PCM - an indoor experiment under constant incidence of radiation
Affiliations: Gifu Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishimura, M., Gifu Univ, Japan; Bando, Y., Gifu Univ, Japan; Kuraishi, M., Gifu Univ, Japan; Hahne, E.W.P., Gifu Univ, Japan
Abstract: The effects of the optical thickness of a plane layer of a semitransparent PCM (phase-change material) on the temperature distribution and efficiency of a passive system directly heated and melted by the sun were investigated. The results agreed fairly well with theoretical predictions based on an analysis using the concept of the overall specific heat. Both the temperature distribution and the efficiency of thermal storage were strongly affected by the optical thickness of the PCM. Back-melting in a PCM with a small optical thickness increased the efficiency of thermal storage.
Index Keywords: Paraffin Waxes; Temperature Distribution; Phase-Change Material (PCM); Solar Thermal Energy; Thermal Storage; Solar Energy

Authors: Aksinenko V.D., Dement'ev E.A., Kaminskii N.I., Matyushin V.T., Matyushin A.T., Ryakhovskii V.N.
Title: High-voltage nanosecond pulse generator for streamer chamber
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Aksinenko, V.D., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Dement'ev, E.A., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Kaminskii, N.I., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Matyushin, V.T., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Matyushin, A.T., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Ryakhovskii, V.N., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors describe a high-voltage nanosecond pulse generator for the JINR 2-meter streamer chamber. Pulse charging of the shaping line of the generator is accomplished by a voltage-pulse generator with a heteropolar stage charging based on FM-100-15U3 capacitors. In operation with the streamer chamber, the generator has so far provided ≈235,000 actuations, of which 155,000 were produced with the streamer chamber in working sessions on the JINR synchrophasotron (≈900 h without maintenance). The generator parameters remained within the specified limits: a pulse amplitude of ≈500 kV for an amplitude instability of ≤1%, a half-height pulse duration of ≈12 nsec, and a delay of ≤300 nsec for a delay instability of 1.5-1.8%.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron - Electronic Equipment; Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Discharges; Electronic Circuits, Trigger; Pulse Generators - Performance; Delay Instability; Heteropolar Charging; Nanosecond Pulse Generators; Self-Breakdown Voltage; Streamer Chambers; Synchrophasotrons; Spark Chambers

Title: Controlled high-voltage converter for pulsed x-ray sources
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Leningrad Scientific-Industrial, Organization 'Burevestnik', Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Lozovoi, L.N., Leningrad Scientific-Industrial, Organization 'Burevestnik', Russian Federation; Sindalovskii, E.I., Leningrad Scientific-Industrial, Organization 'Burevestnik', Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors describe a controlled high-voltage converter for charging of the storage capacitors of MIRA-2D and similar pulsed x-ray sources. The converter has two channels for charging control: the power channel provides a wide control range (3-20 Hz) and the data channel permits fine tuning of the frequency of x-ray pulses. A built-in or external master generator and an external exposure timer can be used.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Transformers, Pulse; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Signal; Pulse Generators; X-Ray Apparatus - Electronic Equipment; Electric Rectifiers; Power Amplifiers; Power Transformers; Pulsed X-Ray Sources; Push-Pull Inverters; Storage Capacitor Charging; Electric Converters

Title: Gas storage in Denmark
Affiliations: Dansk Olie og Naturgas A/S, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Dreyer, Erik, Dansk Olie og Naturgas A/S, Denmark
Abstract: Natural gas is a relatively new form of energy in Denmark, in contrast to most other European countries. Because of the one-sided supply situation it has been important to Dansk Naturgas to have a highly reliable gas storage facility. It is expected that the coming winters, especially if they are cold, will require a more regular production from storage, giving the data and practical experience needed for assessing the capabilities of the storage facilities and giving a better basis for planning how to operate the facilities. This article also discusses how leached caverns ensure reliable source of supply.
Index Keywords: Leached Caverns; Gas Storage

Title: Trigger characteristics of gas-filled cascade discharges
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Evlampiev, S.B., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Korshunov, G.S., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors present the results of a study of the trigger characteristics of gas-filled cascade dischargers with two working gaps, one of which is controlled. The actuation delays and their spread are determined as functions of various factors for both the controlled and uncontrolled gaps. The switching accuracy of six parallel-operating dischargers filled with a gas mixture consisting of 10% SF6 and 90% N2 was ±(1.5-2.3) nsec for a ratio of charging voltage to self-breakdown voltage of 0.9-0.8.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Discharges; Electric Spark Gaps - Control; Gases - Electric Breakdown; Pulse Generators; Actuation Delay; Arkadev-Marks Pulse Generators; Cascade Discharges; Parallel Triggering; Switching Accuracy; Trigger Characteristics; Electric Switches

Title: R&D in the fast lane
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, Colorado Springs, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siuru, Bill, Mechanical Engineering, Colorado Springs, United States
Abstract: BMW is noted for both its luxurious, high-performance sports sedans and its innovative use of leading-edge technology. The company's scientists and engineers are now working to make personal transportation less dependent on fossil fuels, less destructive to the environment, and safer. Its research is focused on both electric vehicles (EVs) for urban use and hydrogen-powered cars for long-distance, high-speed travel.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen - Energy Utilization; Storage Battery Vehicles; Alternative Power; Hydrogen-Powered Car; Vision Enhancer System; Automobiles

Authors: Arvanitis D., Rabus H., Domke M., Puschmann A., Comelli G., Petersen H., Tröger L., Lederer T., Kaindl G., Baberschke K.
Title: High resolution photoabsorption spectroscopy at the carbon K-Edge
Source title: Applied Physics A Solids and Surfaces
Affiliations: Institut für Atom- und Festkörperphysik, FU Berlin, Arnimallee 14, Berlin 33, D-1000, Germany; Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, Trieste, I-34012, Italy; BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, Berlin 33, D-1000, Germany

Abstract: Using plane grating, ellipsoidal mirror, grazing incidence monochromators at the storage ring BESSY, a resolution of ≦ 150meV was achieved for a photon energy of 285 eV. This high energy resolution considerably extends the range of possible studies using core level Spectroscopy. Some of the new opportunities are illustrated at the C K edge by resolving the vibrational fine structure of condensed C2H4 multilayers in the (1s-1, π*) state by means of photoabsorption spectroscopy. For the sake of comparison with other high resolution instruments, the vibrational fine structure of condensed N2 multilayers at the N K edge (∼ 400eV) was also measured, yielding a resolving power of 3000. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Monochromators; X-Rays; High Resolution Photoabsorption Spectroscopy; Vibrational Fine Structure; Carbon

Title: Viscoelastic properties of sodium montmorillonite (Gelwhite H) suspensions
Source title: Journal of Colloid And Interface Science
Affiliations: ICI Agrochemicals, Jealott's Hill Research Station, Bracknell, Berkshire RG12 6EY, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sohm, R., ICI Agrochemicals, Jealott's Hill Research Station, Bracknell, Berkshire RG12 6EY, England, United Kingdom; Tadros, Th.F., ICI Agrochemicals, Jealott's Hill Research Station, Bracknell, Berkshire RG12 6EY, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The swelling of a commercial sodium montmorillonite clay suspension, namely Gelwhite H, has been investigated at pH 8.8-8.9 at various clay concentrations. Swelling was investigated using rheological measurements by following the storage modulus G′(t) as a function of time t. The exponential increase of G′(t) with t was used to calculate the modulus at infinite time G′t → ∞ as well as the gelation time tg. The results showed a rapid increase in G′t → ∞ with an increase in clay concentration from 30 to 60 g liter-. However, within experimental error, tg was constant and independent of clay concentration. A plot of G* (complex modulus), G′, and G′' (loss modulus) (at.1 Hz) versus Gelwhite H concentration (pH 8.8-8.9) showed a rapid increase in G* and G′ (which were identical) above a clay concentration of 30 g liter-1. G′' remained very low and showed a slight increase with an increase in clay concentration. Similar trends were obtained in the variation of shear modulus G∞ and the extrapolated yield stress τB. This means that the "gel point" for this clay sample is about 30 g liter-1, above which the elasticity increases very rapidly with a further increase in clay concentration. The cohesive energy, Ec, in the gel structure was obtained by measuring the viscoelastic parameters as a function of applied strain amplitude (at constant frequency). The results showed that G′(t), Ec, and the critical stress σc increase rapidly with an increase in Gelwhite H concentration. The results could be fitted to a power law with an exponent n in the concentration. This exponent was in the region 3.1-3.7 and was lower than that obtained previously with another commercial bentonite sample. The results confirmed the previously held view that gel formation in these commercial samples is most likely due to a face-to-edge association mechanism. This mechanism is favorable at intermediate to high electrolyte concentrations (usually present in commercial clay suspensions) whereby the double layers are compressed, thus obtaining close approach of the edges to the faces. Plots of G*, G′, G′', G, and τb versus pH showed a primary maximum at pH 7, indicating maximum interaction at this pH. At this pH, the edges are most likely positively charged and hence edge-to-face association is possible. The reduction at pH >7 is due to the reduction of positive charges on the edges. However, the reduction at pH <7 may also be due to the reduction in the number of units available for the build up of the double-T junctions. © 1989.

Title: Ruthenium, rhodium and palladium complexes of pyridines
Affiliations: Institute of Chemistry, Pedagogical University, Czestochowa, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Sliwa, W., Institute of Chemistry, Pedagogical University, Czestochowa, Poland
Abstract: The syntheses, chemical reactivity, physicochemical properties and applications in solar energy conversion and storage of ruthenium, rhodium and palladium complexes of pyridines are described. © 1989 Chapman and Hall Ltd.

Title: Performance comparisons of diode-pumped neodymium laser materials
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Aerospace Corporation, Electronics Research Laboratory, P.O. Box 92957, Los Angeles, CA  90009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fields, R.A., Aerospace Corporation, Electronics Research Laboratory, P.O. Box 92957, Los Angeles, CA  90009, United States; Fincher, C.L., Aerospace Corporation, Electronics Research Laboratory, P.O. Box 92957, Los Angeles, CA  90009, United States
Abstract: The performance of several Nd3+ doped laser materials were compared in a 1 watt diodeend-pumped configuration. The host materials included in this study were YVO4, YAG, BEL, Cr:GSGG, and LNA. Measurements were limited to laser performance on the 4F3/2 -> 4I11/2 transition. The predictive quality of traditional modelling was examined by generating detailed theoretical performance curves for all the materials. The best theoretical fit to the data was obtained by using cross section values determined by the Birnbaum laser method and quantum efficiencies (QE) greater than 94% for all the materials except BEL and Cr:GSGG. The low QE for Cr:GSGG can be traced to excited state absorption into the Cr3+ bands. Uncertainty in the fit relates to the tradeoff between QE and loss. A performance comparison between coated and uncoated YAG suggests that surface losses contribute more than expected. The data and the model indicate that all materials studied here (except for Cr:GSGG) should display approximately a 55? or greater slope efficiency (optical-to-optical) above 1 watt of pump power if fabricated with a monolithic high reflector and antireflective coating at the appropriate faces. Based on projections from the model and data from the literature LNA has the potential to be a high efficiency and energy storage laser. Utilizing a new 2 watt 20 stripe diode laser array, 1.22 watts at an optical efficiency of 61? was obtained at 1064 nm in the TEM00 from a Nd:YVO4 crystal. © 1989 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Antireflection coatings; Digital storage; Excited states; Neodymium; Neodymium lasers; Nonlinear optics; Yttrium aluminum garnet; Anti reflective coatings; Cross-section values; Excited state absorption; Neodymium laser materials; Optical efficiency; Performance comparison; Slope efficiencies; Theoretical performance; Pumping (laser)

Authors: Baker G.J., Brocklehurst B., Hayes M., Hopkirk A., Holland D.M.P., Munro I.H., Shaw D.A.
Title: Ion-recombination luminescence in alkanes excited by synchrotron radiation in the range 10-40 eV
Affiliations: Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Chemistry Department, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, S3 7HF, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baker, G.J., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Brocklehurst, B., Chemistry Department, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, S3 7HF, United Kingdom; Hayes, M., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Hopkirk, A., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Holland, D.M.P., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Munro, I.H., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Shaw, D.A., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Time-resolved single-photon counting has been used to study ion-recombination luminescence in squalane solutions of paraterphenyl. The synchrotron storage ring at Daresbury provided excitation pulses in the photon energy range 10-40 eV. Changes in luminescence pulse shape and in the effect of applied magnetic field were observed. The results are related to the behaviour of multi-ion pair spurs produced by fast electrons or beta-particles. © 1989.

Authors: Ma H., Newman H., Zhu R.Y., Hamm R.
Title: Calibration of electromagnetic calorimeters in high energy experiments with a Radio Frequency Quadrupole accelerator
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; AccSys Technology, Inc., Pleasanton, CA 94566, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ma, H., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Newman, H., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Zhu, R.Y., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Hamm, R., AccSys Technology, Inc., Pleasanton, CA 94566, United States
Abstract: A fast, effective calibration technique has been developed for future Superconducting Supercollider (SSC) calorimeters based upon the radiative capture of protons from a pulsed Radio Frequency Quadrupole (RFQ) accelerator in a fluoride target. The intense flux of low energy photons acts as a clean "pulse generator" calibration signal equivalent to 20 GeV or more. This calibration technique has been demonstrated with a bismuth germanate (BGO) detector array, as well as with several barium fluoride detector crystals, to provide a calibration accuracy of 0.5% within two minutes. The SSC calibration has resulted from the development of this novel technique by Caltech over the past five years for the L3 BGO electromagnetic calorimeter, which uses a lithium target for the production of 17.6 MeV low energy photons for the calibration source. Proven techniques have been developed to provide an in situ calibration for all 11 000 BGO detector crystals, with an accuracy of 0.8% obtainable in 1-2 h. The result of the experimental test by using the AccSys RFQ accelerator is reported, as is the preliminary concept of a small storage ring that can be used to compress the output beam pulse from the RFQ accelerator into a target beam pulse of 100 ns or less. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Physics--High Energy; Barium Fluoride; Radio Frequency Quadrupole; Superconducting Supercollider; Calorimeters
