Zschorsch, P., Deutsches Electronen Synchrotron DESY, D-2000 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The Crystal Ball detector at the Doris II storage ring at DESY has been used to study the electron energy spectrum of the decay τ→evv̄. In the standard model the Lorentz structure of the decay matrix element is of the well known V-A type, resulting in a Michel parameter of p=0.75. Our spectrum is found to be consistent with this value. A fit yields the value of 0.64±0.07. © 1989.

Title: Research opportunities in atomic physics at the Advanced Light Source
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schlachter, A.S., Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Robinson, A.L., Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, 1 Cyclotron Road, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Light Source (ALS) now under construction at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory is being planned as a national user facility for the production of high-brightness and partially coherent X-ray and ultraviolet synchrotron radiation. The ALS is based on a low-emittance electron storage ring optimized for operation at 1.5 GeV with insertion devices in 11 long straight sections and up to 48 bending-magnet ports. High-brightness photon beams from less than 10 eV to more than 1 keV will be produced by undulators, thereby providing many research opportunities in atomic and molecular physics and chemistry. Wigglers and bending magnets will provide high-flux broad-band radiation at energies to 10 keV. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Light Sources; Advanced Light Source; Radiation Sources; Synchrotron Radiation; Physics

Title: Preparations for research with the Indiana Cooler
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Indiana University, Swain Hall West, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, H.O., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Swain Hall West, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: A storage ring with electron cooling for medium-energy light ions has been completed at the Indiana University Cyclotron Facility. At the present time, the machine is being commissioned for experiments in nuclear, atomic and accelerator physics. We review the current status of the storage ring, the research program and the preparations for the first round of experiments. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Ion Beams; Physics--Nuclear; Protons; Electron Cooling; Indiana Cooler; Accelerators

Title: Cascade analysis for energy and process integration of batch processes. Part 3. A case study
Affiliations: Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kemp, I.C., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom; Deakin, A.W., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper shows in detail how the Cascade techniques were applied to a process integration study of a speciality chemicals plant. Energy targeting, heat storage, network design, and identification and classification of rescheduling opportunities are all featured. Conclusions are drawn on the practical application of the Cascade analysis to process plants, buildings and total sites.
Index Keywords: Chemical Plants--Heat Exchangers; Mathematical Models; Batch Processes; Cascade Analysis; Heat Cascades; Speciality Chemicals Plants; Heat Exchangers

Title: Success for the NUHOMS dry store
Affiliations: Nutech, United States
Authors with affiliations: McConaghy, William, Nutech, United States; Kunita, Robert, Nutech, United States
Abstract: In March 1984, Carolina Power and Light (CP&L) entered into a cooperative agreement with the US Department of Energy (DoE) to conduct a demonstration programme for the Nutech Horizontal Modular Storage (NUHOMS) system at its H. B. Robinson site. In 1989 the first fuel assemblies were loaded into the NUHOMS horizontal dry store at Carolina Power and Light's Robinson site. The system has also been chosen by Duke Power and Baltimore Gas & Electric. The NUHOMS system is designed to provide long term dry storage for fuel assemblies. The fuel assemblies are confined in a helium atmosphere within a stainless steel canister. When placed in storage, the canister is protected and shielded by the reinforced concrete storage module. The module provides the necessary shielding while decay heat is removed by passive ventilation, and by radiation and conduction through the walls and roof.
Index Keywords: Helium; Nuclear Fuels - Storage; Nuclear Reactors - Spent Fuels; Thermocouples; Fuel Assembly; Nutech Horizontal Modular Storage (NUHOMS) System; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Cascade analysis for energy and process integration of batch processes. Part 2. Network design and process scheduling
Affiliations: Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kemp, I.C., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom; Deakin, A.W., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Abstract: Design of a heat exchanger network can be carried out by methods analogous to those for continuous processes. These require the use of the targets developed from the cascade analysis. A maximum heat exchange (MHX) network can be developed, as can networks using heat storage. Use of the time average model (TAM) and the overall pinch does not provide a systematic route to the most cost-effective batch networks, which are generally based on the MHX network. Rescheduling a process can allow heat recovery to be carried out by direct heat exchange rather than heat storage. A classification of rescheduling opportunities is introduced, distinguishing between those which are easy to apply and those which require major changes to the plant. Methods for identifying rescheduling opportunities, based on the heat storage targets obtained in the Cascade analysis, are outlined.
Index Keywords: Chemical Plants--Heat Exchangers; Mathematical Models; Cascade Targeting Analysis; Heat Storage Targets; Time Average Model; Time Slice Model; Heat Exchangers

Title: The spatial and temporal characteristics of the conducting PRIZ spatial light modulator
Affiliations: Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gardner, P.J., Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States; Luke, T.E., Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States
Abstract: The characteristics of the conducting PRIZ using single-pulse writing are found to differ from those using mulitple-pulse writing. For single-pulse writing the information storage times are long and independent of write-beam energy density up to the damage threshold. However, the spatial resolution of the devices is a function of the write-pulse energy density and saturates at about 100 μJ/cm2. In the case of multiple-pulse writing of a static image, the optical output is a function of the write-pulse energy repetition rate, the spatial frequency of the image, and the write-beam energy density per pulse. When the single-pulse energy density equals or exceeds that required for maximum spatial resolution, a second pulse of equal energy density reduces the optical output by about seventy-five percent. This reduction is similar to dynamic image selection. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Image Transformer; Photorefractive Material; Spatial Light Modulator; Transverse Linear Electro-Optic Effect; Electrooptical Devices; Electrooptical Effects; Light

Title: Compact electron-storage ring for use as a synchrotron-radiation light source for JAERI
Affiliations: Industry Systems Group
Authors with affiliations: Harada, Shunji, Industry Systems Group; Ota, Kanji, Industry Systems Group
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation is emitted tangential to the direction of travel by high-energy electrons when their path is bent by a magnetic field. The special characteristics of synchrotron radiation are outlined. Synchrotron-radiation light sources promise to be useful in developing new materials and processes, and new measurement techniques for use in the life sciences, industry, and basic research. Anticipated application fields include X-ray lithography for (ULSI) production, photoelectric surface-chemical analysis, crystallographic analysis, atomic-structure studies using extended X-ray absorption fine-structure (EXAFS) analysis, X-ray fluorescence analysis for material evaluation, and medical diagnostic uses such as computer tomography. The Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI) recently commissioned the construction of a
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Electron Ring--Japan; Light Sources; EXAFS; For (ULSI) Production; Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI); Synchrotron-Radiation Light Source; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: Control and supervision of melting process for electric arc furnaces and ladle furnaces
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Whilst considerable efforts have been made on the primary equipment associated with EAFs to increase throughput and productivity, equally important is the optimisation of operational procedures through monitoring and control. For process control in steelworks, Ceda has developed and supplied electronic systems since 1985. In particular, for arc and ladle furnaces the company has designed a system which is structured on two hierarchical levels. Level 1 which consists of a PLC for interface with the process, control of the regulation loops, typical interlocking functions and command signals; and Level 2 which consists of a PC with a 14in colour semigraphic screen and printer. The system is connected via a serial line with the PLC of Level 1, and performs the functions of data retrieval and storage, calculations relative to the mathematical models, printing of reports and alarms, and communication with the operator through the video unit.
Index Keywords: Furnaces, Electric--Process Control; Furnaces, Melting--Electric; Ladles--Design; Metal Melting--Mathematical Models; Electric Arc Furnaces; Ferroalloy Additions; Ladle Furnaces; Melting Energy Calculation; Melting Process Control; Melting Report Print-Out; Steelmaking

Title: Photon storage ring
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Technology Department, Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, 2-1-1 Yato-Cho, Tokyo, 188, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamada, H., Synchrotron Radiation Technology Department, Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, 2-1-1 Yato-Cho, Tokyo, 188, Japan
Abstract: The proposed photon storage ring (PhSR) is composed of an electron storage ring (ESR) and a group of mirrors surrounding the electron orbit. The ESR in this case is of a type having no straight sections. In this system, synchrotron radiations are reflected back by the mirror to intersect the electron orbit again, and are consequently accumulated within the mirror. The PhSR functions like an undulator having an infinite number of periods, and thus specific wavelengths are enhanced. The wavelength is selected by the mirror radius regardless of the electron energy as long as the electron orbit curvature is kept unchanged. The generated synchrotron radiations are fully extracted through a simple opening on the mirror surface. A strong magnetic field can be introduced without any deterioration of the interference effect, which allows the radiation yield to be increased. A conceptual design of such a PhSR is described in this article. © 1989 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.
Author Keywords: Free-electron laser; Synchroton; Undulator
Index Keywords: Electron Optics; Lasers, Free Electron; Mirrors; Photons; Electron Storage Rings; Photon Storage Rings; Accelerators

Title: Cascade analysis for energy and process integration of batch processes. Part 1. Calculation of energy targets
Affiliations: Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kemp, I.C., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom; Deakin, A.W., Harwell Lab, United Kingdom
Abstract: Analysis methods based on modifications of techniques used on continuous processes use average heat flows over the period of the batch. It is shown that these can give over-optimistic energy targets which are not practically achievable. A time-dependent analysis, the Cascade analysis, is then presented. The process is broken down into time intervals analogous to the temperature intervals used in conventional pinch technology methods. Time-temperature cascade tables are developed which show how much heat can be recovered by direct heat exchange between streams, and how much heat can be transferred between different time intervals by heat storage systems. A three-dimensional cascade plot is introduced to aid visualisation of heat flows. The effects of using different types of heat storage are discussed briefly. Algorithms for generation of the cascades are also presented. Targets are obtained for maximum heat recovery maximum direct heat exchange and heat storage.
Index Keywords: Chemical Plants--Heat Exchangers; Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Algorithms; Batch Processes; Cascade Analysis; Pinch Technology; Time Average Model; Heat Exchangers

Abstract: The MAC detector at PEP recorded data for an integrated luminosity of 335 pb-1 between 1980 and 1986. The design of this low-cost MAgnetic Calorimeter was optimized for electron and muon identification, as well as for the measurement of hadronic energy flow. Muon identification is available over 96% of the solid angle, and MAC was the first detector to make large-scale use of gas-sampling calorimetry. Electromagnetic calorimetry in the central section employs alternating layers of lead and proportional wire chambers (PWCs), and hadron and the remaining electromagnetic calorimetry is accomplished with iron plate and PWC layers. A relatively small central drift chamber in an axial magnetic field provides pattern recognition and modest momentum determination. An outer blanket of drift tubes completes the muon identification system. During the latter two years of operation an innovative "soda straw" vertex chamber made more precise lifetime measurements possible. With an evolving trigger system and highly automated data acquisition system, this modest detector has exceeded most of its designers' expectations and has produced a gratifying spectrum of physics results. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Linear--Storage Rings; Calorimeters; Electron-Positron Colliders; MAC (MAgnetic Calorimeter) Detector; Radiation Detectors

Authors: Goetzinger J.W., Ripley D.L., French C.
Title: Jet fuel thermal stability problems related to incompatibility
Source title: American Chemical Society, Division of Petroleum Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goetzinger, J.W., Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States; Ripley, D.L., Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States; French, C., Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States
Abstract: Military specifications for aviation turbine fuel require that jet fuels pass a thermal stability test to be acceptable. Thermal stability of jet fuels is determined by ASTM Method D 3241, using the Jet Fuel Thermal Oxidation Tester (JFTOT). The Defense Fuel Supply Center (DFSC) experienced thermal stability problems with JP-4 jet fuel at one of its fuel terminals, and the National Institute for Petroleum and Energy Research (NIPER) was requested to assist in determining the cause of the problems. The thermal stability problems were typically characterized by situations in which various suppliers' fuels passed all tests, including thermal stability, prior to shipment, but blended fuels in some storage tanks failed the thermal stability test. In many cases, the failures were evidenced primarily by high pressure drop across the test filter; however, in some cases heavy tube deposits were also obtained. Various other instances of similar problems have been reported but not documented. This paper describes the results of blending studies to identify the problem fuels and their characteristics. The results indicate that the incompatibility between fuels which gives rise to off-spec JFTOT test results is a transient phenomenon which apparently only occurs with occasional shipments of fuel and not with all fuel from certain suppliers.
Index Keywords: Fuels--Stability; Blended Fuels; Jet Fuels; Thermal Stability; Aircraft Fuels

Title: Optimal design of reinforced-plastic chord flywheels under reliability limitations
Affiliations: Riga Polytechnic Institute, Russia
Authors with affiliations: Gurvich, M.R., Riga Polytechnic Institute, Russia
Abstract: The proposed method makes it possible to accomplish optimal design of a CF according to the condition of providing a maximum energy-storing capacity with consideration of the random character of the strength and deformation properties of the plastic being used and the geometry of the composition of the system. In this case, the problem of optimal design reduces to a nonlinear programming problem, where the random values of the objective function and limitations are calculated on the basis of the Monte Carlo method. The requirement of fulfilling the prescribed level of reliability of the CF is the condition of optimal design, which makes it possible to take into account the variation of the load-bearing capacity of the structure, variation of the energy-storing capacity, and conditions of the planned purpose. The effect of the structural parameters was analyzed for the example of the optimal design of a FGRP CF and the interrelation and difference of the stochastic and deterministic solutions was shown. The investigations can be useful in the practice of using effective reinforced plastics in the production of mechanical energy storages. © 1989 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials - Optimization; Composite Structures - Reliability; Failure Analysis - Computer Aided Analysis; Mathematical Statistics - Monte Carlo Methods; Plastics, Reinforced - Glass Fiber; Breaking Speed; Chord Flywheels; Energy-Storing Capacity; Optimal Design; Reinforced-Plastic Chord Flywheels; Reliability Limitations; Flywheels

Authors: Chow C.-J., Ochiai Y., Watabe S., Hashimoto K.
Title: Reduced Stability and Accelerated Autoxidation of Tuna Myoglobin in Association with Freezing and Thawing
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Affiliations: National Kaoshiung Institute of Marine Technology, Kaoshiung 800, Taiwan; Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Chow, C.-J., National Kaoshiung Institute of Marine Technology, Kaoshiung 800, Taiwan; Ochiai, Y., Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Watabe, S., Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan; Hashimoto, K., Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Bunkyo, Tokyo 113, Japan
Abstract: The mechanisms involved in accelerated discoloration of frozen tuna meat after thawing were investigated. Bluefin tuna myoglobin (Mb) was dissolved in 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 5.5-7.4) with or without 0.2 M NaCl and quickly frozen in dry ice-acetone, followed by a 2-h storage at -80 °C and subsequent thawing at 20 °C. The “frozen/thawed” Mb solution thus prepared, along with unfrozen (intact) Mb, was examined for the free energy for unfolding, helical content, and autoxidation rate. In 50 mM phosphate buffers, the free energy for unfolding (AGD) was generally lower in frozen/thawed Mb than in unfrozen Mb, with the highest value (7.3 kcal/mol) at pH 6.5. Similar tendency was observed in 50 mM phosphate buffers containing 0.2 M NaCl, although ΔGDH2° values were generally lower. Helical contents of frozen/thawed Mb were practically the same as those of unfrozen Mb, regardless of pH. Frozen/thawed Mb showed a higher autoxidation rate than unfrozen Mb. It was concluded that, during freezing and thawing, Mb suffered some conformational changes in the nonhelical region, resulting in a higher susceptibility to both unfolding and autoxidation. © 1989, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mancini D.C., Sullivan M., Taylor J.W., Bormett R., Jayaraman T.V., West R.J.
Title: X-ray chemical reactions of novolac diazonaphthoquinone resists
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Materials Science Program and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI  53706, United States; Microelectronics Research and Development, Olin Hunt Specialty Products, Inc., East Providence, RI  02914, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mancini, D.C., Materials Science Program and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI  53706, United States; Sullivan, M., Materials Science Program and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI  53706, United States; Taylor, J.W., Materials Science Program and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI  53706, United States; Bormett, R., Materials Science Program and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI  53706, United States; Jayaraman, T.V., Microelectronics Research and Development, Olin Hunt Specialty Products, Inc., East Providence, RI  02914, United States; West, R.J., Microelectronics Research and Development, Olin Hunt Specialty Products, Inc., East Providence, RI  02914, United States
Abstract: Model cresol novolac resins and photoactive compounds (PAC) based on polyhydroxybenzophenones were prepared according to known procedures. The components and resists formulated from them were exposed to X-rays from Aladdin, the electron storage ring at the University of Wisconsin. The loss of azide functionality and the conversion of PAC to acid or ester was monitored by FTIR difference spectrometry. The energy dependence of the sensitivity of conversion of diazonaphthoquinone to ketene was followed by monitoring the loss of diazide when exposed to synchrotron radiation. The effect of PAC functionality on the sensitivity and chemical pathways was studied. The relationship of structure and photon energy to lithographic performance are explored. We discuss the applicability of synchrotron radiation as an exposure source and FTIR as an analytical tool for the study of X-ray resist mechanisms. © 1989 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Phenolic resins; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Analytical tool; Chemical pathways; Diazonaphthoquinone; Electron storage ring; Energy dependence; Exposure sources; Photoactive compounds; University of Wisconsin; X rays

Zaccardelli, C., University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States; Von Zanthier, C., University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, United States
Abstract: The Mark II detector has been upgraded in preparation for its role as the first detector to take data at the Stanford Linear Collider. The new detector components include the central drift chamber, the time-of-flight system, the coil, the endcap electromagnetic calorimeters and the beam energy and luminosity measuring devices. There have also been improvements in detector hermeticity. All of the major components were installed for a test run at the PEP storage ring (√s = 29 GeV) in 1985. This paper describes the upgraded detector, including its trigger and data acquisition systems, and gives performance figures for its components. Future improvements are also discussed. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Calorimeters; Physics--High Energy; Spectrometers; Drift Chamber; Linear Collider; Luminosity Monitors; Muons; Time of Flight Systems; Vertex Detectors; Particle Detectors

Title: Long-term nuclear waste management: Present status and alternatives
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institut de Physique Nucléaire, BP no. 1, 91406 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Schapira, J.P., Institut de Physique Nucléaire, BP no. 1, 91406 Orsay, France
Abstract: Long-term nuclear waste management deals with the final and irreversible stage of waste disposal, on surface and in deep geological formations (according to the waste type), when institutional surveillance is over. There are presently two main options available to deal with the wastes generated by spent nuclear fuel unloaded from reactors and containing most of the radiotoxicity produced all along the nuclear fuel cycle. Since the end of Word War II, spent-fuel reprocessing technology has gone through three different stages, ending up with considerable technical achievements and large investments (construction of large facilities, UP3 in France and THORP in the UK). However, having to face spent-fuel risings and lack of reprocessing capacities, since the mid-seventies some countries are considering the possibility of direct spent-fuel disposal without reprocessing. These two options are discussed in terms of long-term waste management. Because of the types of waste conditioning and packaging adopted with present reprocessing technology, in that case long-term safety, after a few centuries, relies completely on the geological barriers. On the other hand, long-term safety with the second option is based essentially on the retention properties of uranium oxide with respect to actinides. Finally, alternatives such as chemical partitioning of minor actinides followed by their transmutation, either in reactors or using high-energy particle accelerators, are under discussion. Apart from the standard reprocessing (after a cooling period of 3-5 years), all the other options called for a long period (50 years) of interim storage, preventing the adoption of irreversible, costly and not well proved waste management solutions, and leaving time to develop and assess these alternative methods. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Industrial Wastes--Radioactive Materials; Nuclear Fuels--Reprocessing; Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Nuclear Waste Management; Radiotoxicity; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Bukovec N., Bukovec P., Arbanas V.
Title: Tg and dsc investigation of CaCl2 · 6H2O, a phase change material for energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, E. Kardelj University, 61000 Ljubljana
Authors with affiliations: Bukovec, N., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, E. Kardelj University, 61000 Ljubljana; Bukovec, P., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, E. Kardelj University, 61000 Ljubljana; Arbanas, V., Department of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, E. Kardelj University, 61000 Ljubljana
Abstract: A number of CaCl2·6H2O samples with various amounts of NaCl, KCl, SrCl2 and BaSO4 have been prepared and studied by TG and DSC. There are two effects of inorganic salts on the dehydration curves of CaCl2·6H2O. The appropriate amount of additive can improve the stability of intermediate hydrate and change the stoichiometry of the dehydration process. © 1989.

Authors: Bogdanovich B.Yu., Senyukov V.A., Shal'nov A.V.
Title: Tests on a LEA with HF generator energy storage
Affiliations: Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Bogdanovich, B.Yu., Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Russian Federation; Senyukov, V.A., Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Russian Federation; Shal'nov, A.V., Moscow Engineering Physics Institute, Russian Federation
Abstract: Test are reported on a linear electron accelerator LEA whose high-frequency power supply stores energy, which raises the pulse power at the input to the accelerating section without raising the mean power consumed. The accumulation is provided by two high-quality cavities. The current load affects the beam characteristics, and the measurements are compared with calculations. © 1990 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Authors: Burnell J.G., McNabb A., Weir G.J., Young R.
Title: Two-phase boundary layer formation in a semi-infinite porous slab
Affiliations: Applied Mathematics Division, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 1335, Wellington, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Burnell, J.G., Applied Mathematics Division, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 1335, Wellington, New Zealand; McNabb, A., Applied Mathematics Division, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 1335, Wellington, New Zealand; Weir, G.J., Applied Mathematics Division, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 1335, Wellington, New Zealand; Young, R., Applied Mathematics Division, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 1335, Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: Similarity profiles of pressure and saturation are analysed which result from one-dimensional planar withdrawal of fluid from a porous region initially containing a two phase mixture of steam and water. Approximate expressions are derived for the evolution of pressure and saturation profiles, and boundary-layer changes in saturation are identified. The existence of a similarity variable implies that the saturation conditions for the reservoir tend with time either to having both phases flowing; or to a single phase vapour. In particular, the nonlinear nature of the governing equations implies that infinitesimal changes in pressure can produce finite changes in saturation. The two mechanisms responsible for saturation changing with time involve local changes in energy storage in rock and fluid; together with spatial variations in flowing enthalpy. The latter mechanism occurred relatively slowly in the examples treated, and was responsible for boundary-layer formation when one phase was initially immobile. Dimensional analysis reveals that when a boundary layer develops, the underlying equations involve essentially only one dimensionless parameter which is typically small, being associated with the ratio of the energy density of the mobile phase relative to the total energy density. © 1989 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: fluid withdrawal; porous; pressure; saturation; similarity variable; steam; theory; Two-phase boundary layer; water

Authors: Kordesch K., Oliveira J.C.T., Gruber Ch., Winkler G.
Title: Water removal studies on high power hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells with alkaline electrolytes
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Technical Univ Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Kordesch, K., Technical Univ Graz, Austria; Oliveira, J.C.T., Technical Univ Graz, Austria; Gruber, Ch., Technical Univ Graz, Austria; Winkler, G., Technical Univ Graz, Austria
Abstract: The paper reports results obtained in a five-year energy storage and energy conversion project of the Austrian Fonds for Support of Scientific Research. Additional fuel cell studies were performed in connection with and subsequent to an investigation of water transpiration properties of PTFE-bonded carbon electrodes. Alkaline fuel cells working at temperatures in the range of 140-150°C performed with very high efficiencies. The ultimate purpose of the work is the verification of bipolar fuel cell designs, containing massproducable all-carbon electrodes, which can be used in alkaline or acidic cells with liquid or immobilized (matrix) electrolytes.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Electrodes, Electrochemical--Applications; Electrolytes--Applications; Fuel Cells--Space Applications; Alkaline Fuel Cells; High Power Hydrogen-Oxygen Fuel Cells; Spacecraft

Title: Challenges for future space power systems
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandhorst Jr., Henry W., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: While forecasts of space power needs are problematic, an assessment of future needs based on terrestrial experience has been made. These needs fall into three broad categories - survival, self sufficiency, and industrialization. The cost of delivering payloads to orbital locations from LEO to Mars has been determined and future launch cost reductions projected. From these factors, then, projections of the performances necessary for future solar and nuclear space power options has been made. These goals are largely dependent upon orbital location and energy storage needs.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Satellites--Power Supply; LEO Launch Costs; Space Power; Spacecraft

Title: Hydrogen/oxygen SPE electrochemical devices for zero-g applications
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: United Technologies Corp
Authors with affiliations: Leonida, Andrei, United Technologies Corp
Abstract: Hydrogen-oxygen-water electrochemical system could be used to integrate life support, propulsion and energy storage functions for future space programs. This paper discusses the performance of two passive fluid management electrochemical cells. One is an electrolyzer which has separate water and product gas compartments and generates liquid free gases. The second is a fuel cell device which effects the water separation and removal internally without moving parts. Passive fluid management makes the designs of interest for 'zero-g' applications. A unitized design combining the electrolyzer and fuel cell capabilities in a single cell for energy conversion and storage is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Direct Energy Conversion--Space Applications; Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Fuel Cells--Space Applications; Space Flight--Weightlessness; Electrolyzers; Hydrogen-Oxygen-Water Electrochemical System; Regenerative Fuel Cell Systems; Zero Gravity Fluid Management; Spacecraft

Authors: Millet P., Alleau T., Mathonnet P., Pineri M., Durand R.
Title: Solid polymer electrolyte water electrolysis as a mean of energy storage for space applications
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France
Authors with affiliations: Millet, P., Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France; Alleau, T., Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France; Mathonnet, P., Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France; Pineri, M., Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France; Durand, R., Cent d'Etudes Nucleaires, France
Abstract: Solid Polymer Electrolyte water electrolysis technology has been considered and selected as the best candidate for the construction of the electrolysis unit of a Regenerable Fuel Cell System. Results concerning the preparation of Membrane-Electrode assemblies are presented. Life-tests performed on lab-scale samples have shown that the electrochemical performances can be maintained over 15,000 hours of continuous electrolysis without any problem. A filter-press type electrolzer has been designed and constructed. Electrochemical performances obtained so far are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Electrolysis; Electrolytes, Solid; Fuel Cells--Space Applications; Electrochemical Cell Reactions; Membrane-Electrode Assemblies; Regenerative Fuel Cell Systems; Solid Polymer Electrolyte; SPE; Water Electrolysis; Spacecraft

Title: Power conditioning for active array sar antennas
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Dornier GmbH, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schaeper, W., Dornier GmbH, Germany
Abstract: Active array SAR antennas require a complex power conditioning and distribution subsystem to supply the numerous decentralized loads. The paper presents a trade-off between different overall concepts rather than circuit details. A hierarchically structured system employing AC distribution turns out to be favourable. Active antennas are failure-tolerant to a certain extent. Therefore, special attention is paid to particular reliability aspects. Finally breadboard hardware implemented is presented including a discussion of further improvement of pulse energy storage.
Index Keywords: Antennas--Arrays; Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Distribution; Electronic Circuits, Power Supply; Active Array Sar Antennas; Capacitive Energy Storage; Electric Power Conditioning; Pulse Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Modular power subsystem
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mackowski, Michael J., McDonnell Douglas Corp, United States
Abstract: A modular spacecraft electrical power processing and energy storage system with a load capability of over one kilowatt has been designed, built, and tested, and is now in use on several low Earth orbit satellites. The modular power subsystem (MPS) conditions energy received from an appropriately-sized solar array for distribution to other spacecraft modules, to the payloads, and for recharging nickel-cadmium batteries. A peak power tracking circuit in the power conversion electronics is used to maximize the energy drawn from the solar array. Presently, power requirements of from 250 to 1200 watts can be satisfied by the MPS and techniques for combining the outputs of several MPS modules are under development.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage--Space Applications; Electric Power Distribution--Space Applications; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Solar Cells--Arrays; Modular Power Subsystem; Multimission Modular Spacecraft; Peak Power Tracking; Power Conditioning; Spacecraft

Title: 25 kWe spaceborne solar dynamic generator
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Aerospatiale, France
Authors with affiliations: Andrieux, F., Aerospatiale, France; Pelenc, L., Aerospatiale, France
Abstract: Solar dynamic (SD) generators associated with a Brayton cycle are competitive in supplying future satellites or space station with electrical power over 25 kW. The global efficiency of solar dynamic generators (20%) allows reductions of captation surface area and thereby of the orbit-keeping propellant. The thermal storage is much lighter than the electrochemical one. Such a generator's technological feasibility depends on heat source feasibility i.e. receiver, reflector and storage feasibility. This article discusses the different constituents of SD systems (concentrator, receiver, storage, thermodynamic cycle, alternator, radiator) and then defines its design, performance, and the critical items. Finally, the most critical aspects, which are the Receiver and the Thermal Storage concept are dealt with in detail.
Index Keywords: Electric Converters; Electric Power Generation--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Solar Cells--Space Applications; Solar Energy--Space Applications; Brayton Cycle; Space Station; Spaceborne Solar Dynamic Generators; Thermal Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Progress toward disposal of LLRW in Canada
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Affiliations: Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Charlesworth, D.H., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd
Abstract: Low-level radioactive wastes are managed in Canada currently by interim storage methods operated by the major generators of the wastes. The potential benefits of permanent disposal have led Atomic Energy of Canada Limited to undertake a development and demonstration program to make the transition from storage to disposal at its Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories. The first stages of the demonstration are based on an enhanced version of shallow land burial for the least hazardous wastes, and a unique design of a belowground concrete vault. The program includes the development and testing of the auxiliary equipment, processes and procedures necessary to support the disposal system, as well as the performance assessment methods and information needed to assure its safety.
Index Keywords: Industrial Wastes--Radioactive Materials; Intrusion Resistant Underground Structure; Low Level Wastes; Radioactive Wastes

Authors: Koval'chuk B.M., Kokshenev V.A., Novikov A.A., Yakovlev V.P.
Title: 1-MV section for high-current pulse generators
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Koval'chuk, B.M., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Kokshenev, V.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Novikov, A.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Yakovlev, V.P., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: The authors describe the development and testing of a high-current storage-capacitor section with an Arkad'ev-Marks circuit that has stable switching over a wide range and a stable actuation time. A generator of three parallel-connected sections has an energy capacity of 0.2 MJ, an output voltage of up to 1 MV, an inductance of 0.85 μH, a maximum current of 0.6 MA, and a specific energy capacity of 16.5 kJ/m3.

Authors: Baron Francis, Philippi Ralf, Tillmetz Werner
Title: European regenerative fuel cell technology for space use
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: ESTEC, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Baron, Francis, ESTEC, Netherlands; Philippi, Ralf, ESTEC, Netherlands; Tillmetz, Werner, ESTEC, Netherlands
Abstract: Two studies were performed of European regenerative fuel cell systems for energy storage and supply in space. The technologies considered are immobile alkaline electrolyte (KOH) systems; proton exchange membrane (PEM) systems; mixed systems with KOH imm. fc and PEM electr; and mobile alkaline electrolyte (KOH) systems. A comparison of the different systems concerning their application in space is given. Emphasis is placed on the performance efficiency and mass of the systems. The comparision demonstrates advantages of the immobile KOH systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Fuel Cells--Space Applications; Electrochemical Performance; Immobile Electrolyte; Mobile Electrolyte; Regenerative Fuel Cell Systems; Spacecraft

Title: Development of a high temperature storage unit for integration with solar dynamic systems
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Staehle, H.J., Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Germany; Lindner, F., Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Germany
Abstract: LiF with a Tm of 1121 K and a ΔHm of 1044 kJ/kg is one of the most suitable thermal energy storage materials for solar dynamic power systems. The high corrosivity in molten state may lead to container failure in long term use. In order to avoid destruction of canisters, a graphite container was developped as graphite is not wetted by liquid LiF and thus does not suffer any corrosion. In order to match the mechanical forces caused by the volume increase of ca. 22% during melting, a channel-like internal structure was tested. The melt formed first can expand into these channels and no pressure is built up. When the phase change material is completely molten, the liquid is through to be driven out of the channels at μg-conditions because of the surface tension of the melt.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Generation--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Lithium Compounds; Solar Energy--Space Applications; Brayton Cycle; Graphite Containers; Lithium Fluoride; Phase Change Materials; Solar Dynamic Power Generation; Thermal Energy Storage Materials; Spacecraft

Title: Space station freedom energy storage system design and development
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Ford Aerospace, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haas, R.J., Ford Aerospace, United States; Koehler, C.W., Ford Aerospace, United States
Abstract: The NASA Space Station Freedom 75 kW energy storage system will utilize nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H2) batteries to provide electrical power during eclipse and peak load operation. The 81-Ah battery cells are designed for a five year life in low-earth-orbit (LEO with a 35 percent depth-of-discharge (DOD)). The batteries consist of 30 individual pressure vessel (IPV) cells enclosed in an orbital replaceable unit (ORU). The basic cell, battery and ORU design, development and production are described. The key system design issues include the mechanical and thermal interfaces for both the battery and the ORU assembly. Verification plans for the mission critical components such as the nickel electrode and Inconel 718 pressure vessel are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Space Applications; Electric Energy Storage--Space Applications; Electric Power Generation--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Leo Satellites; Nickel-Hydrogen Batteries; Orbital Replaceable Unit; Space Station; Satellites

Authors: Denner W.J., Fritzsche A.A., Jany P.
Title: Optimized sensible heat storage systems for application to solar dynamic power generation
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Dornier GmbH, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Denner, W.J., Dornier GmbH, Germany; Fritzsche, A.A., Dornier GmbH, Germany; Jany, P., Dornier GmbH, Germany
Abstract: The transient behavior of a sensible heat storage system has been investigated numerically. With a counterflow scheme and a matrix of BeO-spheres, a thermal efficiency of 98.5% and almost constant fluid outlet temperature during 85% of discharge time has been obtained proving the potential of this storage alternative for application to solar dynamic power generation in space. Some preliminary results of the overall SD-system simulation, comprising the storage induced transient behavior of turbines, radiators etc. indicate that the electrical power output can be kept constant within a few percent.
Index Keywords: Electric Energy Storage; Electric Power Generation--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Solar Energy--Space Applications; Brayton Cycle; Numerical System Simulation; Sensible Heat Storage System; Solar Dynamic Power Generation; Spacecraft

Title: Proceedings of the European Space Power Conference Proceedings of the European Space Power Conference
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 129 papers dealing with space power technology. Topics covered include: power systems and subsystems; batteries and fuel cells; power electronics; and photovoltaic generators. All papers are abstracted and indexed individually.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Space Applications; Electric Converters--Space Applications; Electric Power Systems--Space Applications; Satellites--Power Supply; Solar Energy--Space Applications; Direct Energy Conversion; Eirev; Electric Energy Storage; Fuel Cells; Photovoltaic Generators; Solar Cells; Spacecraft

Title: Compilation of international progress in 1988 on high-Tc material studies relevant to power application
Affiliations: NV KEMA, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Barten, H., NV KEMA, Netherlands; Leferink, R.G.I., NV KEMA, Netherlands
Abstract: The continuous and intensive research on superconductors has led to much progress in 1988. For instance, new classes of superconductors based on Tl-Ca-Ba-Cu-O and Bi-Ca-Sr-Cu-O have been found. As a result, the maximum verified critical temperature reached 125 K, and the problem of chemical instability (oxygen stoichiometry) were reduced at the same time. The discovery of a copperless superconductor - Ba0.6K0.6BiO3, with a Tc of 30 K - unsettled several new theoretic models of superconductivity once again. Furthermore, it was found that the well-known Meissner effect is not limited to levitation of the superconductor above a magnet but also alongside and beneath it. Major advances have been made in the filament, tape and thin-film technologies, so that critical current values, required for application, can now be approached. There is thus growing optimism that conductors suitable for use at the temperature of liquid nitrogen will be developed.
Index Keywords: Electric Generators; Electric Motors; Electrical Engineering--Research; Energy Storage; Superconducting Devices; Copper Oxide Based Superconductors; Copperless Superconductors; High Temperature Superconductors; Liquid Nitrogen Temperature; Meissner Effect; Thin Film Technology; Superconducting Materials

Title: Impact of high-Tc superconductors - a world-wide review
Affiliations: NV KEMA, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Steennis, E.F., NV KEMA, Netherlands
Abstract: A review is presented of international opinions on the impact of high-Tc superconductors in electrical-power engineering. It is assumed that the operation temperature will be 77 K, and that critical parameters other than the critical temperature will be met by wires and tapes, even though this is not yet the case. The devices considered are: generators, electromotors, transformers, energy-storage devices, power-transmission equipment, current limiters and switches, power-regulation devices, magnets and transportation (maglev). Several arguments are identified and compared for their desirability and for the technical-economical barriers that their realization will meet. Economic break-even points are indicated for some cases. It is stressed, however, that fixed local factors and choices of the dimensions of the components highly influence the considerations. This explains the variations in a number of conclusions, as drawn by different sources.
Index Keywords: Electric Generators; Electric Motors; Superconducting Devices; Superconductivity--Applications; Current Limiters; Energy Storage Devices; High Temperature Superconductors; Maglev; Power Engineering; Power Transmission Equipment; Superconducting Materials

Title: Dietary patterns and nutrition in pregnancy in Jamaica
Affiliations: Tropical Metabolism Research Unit, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of the West Indies, Mona, Kingston 7, Jamaica
Authors with affiliations: Landman, J.P., Tropical Metabolism Research Unit, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of the West Indies, Mona, Kingston 7, Jamaica; Hall, J.S.E., Tropical Metabolism Research Unit, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of the West Indies, Mona, Kingston 7, Jamaica
Abstract: During a study of nutrition in pregnancy, the diets of 108 Jamaican pregnant women were assessed by single 24-hour recalls. The women were 16-45 years old, of mixed parity (0-9), attended private (23 per cent) and public (77 per cent) antenatal clinics and differed in stage of pregnancy at interview. Mean energy intake (2110 ± 739 kcal/d) was low, 83 per cent of the average Recommended Dietary Allowance for the Caribbean (CFNI 1976). Most (76 per cent) women had low energy and dietary iron (75 per cent) intakes. Fewer women had low riboflavin (42 per cent) or protein intakes (29 per cent). Maternal age, parity, obstetric performance, and unusual cravings influenced maternal nutrition to some extent. Dietary assessments overestimated the risk of maternal malnutrition. © 1989 Oxford University Press.

Title: Condition of larval anchovy (Engraulis mordax) in the Southern California Bight, as measured through lipid analysis
Affiliations: Marine Biology Research Division, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, A-002, University of California at San Diego, La Jolla, 92093-0227, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Håkanson, J.L., Marine Biology Research Division, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, A-002, University of California at San Diego, La Jolla, 92093-0227, California, United States
Abstract: Northern anchovy larvae, Engraulis mordax, were collected on five cruises covering the Southern California Bight, one cruise in April 1984, four cruises in January, February and May 1986. The amounts of triacylglycerol, cholesterol and polar lipid were measured in individual anchovy larvae as indicators of their nutritional condition. There was a significant difference in each of the size-specific lipid components between the stations for four of the five cruises. This indicates that all the ocean habitats within a cruise were not equal in promoting growth (and presumably survival) in the anchovy larvae. There were also differences between cruises, where the percentage of the larvae judged to be in poor condition varied from 8 to 27%. Canonical correlation analyses revealed a significant relationship in most cases between the larval fish parameters and the physical and biological data collected from each occupied station. Cholesterol and triacylglycerol were the most important larval components, and the short-term energy storage component in the copepod Calanus pacificus was the most important station component. The data, however, are not sufficient to identify and characterize stations in the field which produce anchovy larvae in good condition. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Leonelli J., Holland P.L., van der Laan J.E.
Title: Multiwavelength and triple CO2 lidars for trace gas detection
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: SRI International, Electro-Optics Systems Laboratory, 333 Ravenswood Avenue, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leonelli, J., SRI International, Electro-Optics Systems Laboratory, 333 Ravenswood Avenue, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States; Holland, P.L., SRI International, Electro-Optics Systems Laboratory, 333 Ravenswood Avenue, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States; van der Laan, J.E., SRI International, Electro-Optics Systems Laboratory, 333 Ravenswood Avenue, Menlo Park, CA, 94025, United States
Abstract: SRI International has developed two infrared differential absorption lidar (IR DIAL) systems to detect infrared-absorbing trace gases and environmental monitoring applications. The multiwavelength DIAL system operates at 10.6 μm and performs both path-integrated (column-content) and range-resolved measurements. This van-mounted system contains four grating-tuned Tachisto 555-G (custom) TEA CO2 lasers, with a nominal 1 J of transmitted energy at 10P(20). The lasers are typically fired with a 100 μs spacing to freeze the atmosphere. The IR receiver uses a 16-in. f/2.5 telescope and a liquid-nitrogen-cooled HgCdTe quadrant detector. The scanner allows pointing over a full hemisphere. The lidar data system features two DEC PDP-11/73 microcomputers and a computer automated measurement and control (CAMAC) data acquisition system for real-time data collection, signal averaging, data analysis, color graphics display, and storage on magnetic tape. The multiwavelength DIAL system has demonstrated path-integrated measurements to a range of 9 km and range-resolved measurements to 4 km. The triple CO2 DIAL system operates at 3.4 μm and utilizes three mini-TEA CO2 lasers and nonlinear crystals in a novel frequency-mixing technique to detect and discriminate selective hydrocarbons. © 1989 SPIE.

Authors: Leavitt J.A., McIntyre L.C., Ashbaugh M.D., Jr., Dezfouly-Arjomandy B., Oder J.G.
Title: Characterization of optical coatings with backscattering spectrometry
Affiliations: University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leavitt, J.A., University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; McIntyre, L.C., University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Ashbaugh, M.D., Jr., University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Dezfouly-Arjomandy, B., University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States; Oder, J.G., University of Arizona, Physics Department, Tucson, AZ, 85721, United States
Abstract: We present three examples to illustrate the use of backscattering spectrometry to determine film stoichiometry, areal density, and impurity levels in optical coatings. Helium-ion beams with energies in the 1.5–5.0-MeV range were used to analyze (1) a magnesium fluoride coating, (2) a tungsten/silicon multilayer soft x-ray mirror, and (3) a trilayer optical data storage film. © 1989 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Gottstein G., Lee T., Schmidt U.
Title: Deformation temperature and recrystallization
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgy, Mechanics and Materials Science, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1226, United States; Institut für Allgemeine Metallkunde and Metallphysik, RWTH Aachen, Aachen, Germany

Abstract: The influence of the deformation temperature on recrystallization of copper single crystals and polycrystals was investigated by measurement of flow stress, hardness and microstructure development. It was found that an increase in deformation temperature actually promotes recrystallization when deformation is carried out to an equivalent stress. The results are compared with stored energy measurement and it is concluded that the observed effect is due to recovery-controlled dislocation storage and nucleation of recrystallization. Implications for the understanding of dynamic recrystallization are discussed. © 1989.

Authors: Bershadsky E., Josephy Y., Ron M.
Title: Permeability and thermal conductivity of porous metallic matrix hydride compacts
Affiliations: Department of Materials Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, HaifaIsrael, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bershadsky, E., Department of Materials Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, HaifaIsrael, Israel; Josephy, Y., Department of Materials Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, HaifaIsrael, Israel; Ron, M., Department of Materials Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, HaifaIsrael, Israel
Abstract: PMH compacts with various contents of aluminium matrix were prepared by a method including a final step of sintering under high hydrogen pressure. The gas permeability was determined as a function of the weight fraction of the aluminium matrix, f{hook}. A correlation between the microstructure, morphology and porosity of the PMH compacts and the coefficient of permeability α′ was found. A tri-dimensional aluminium matrix was found to form in compacts having fractional aluminium contents in the range 0.15-0.22, and to be followed by a steep decrease of α′. On the other hand, the effective thermal conductivity keff of the PMH compacts is known to increase with the increasing aluminium content. Major requirements from PMH compacts are high hydrogen and thermal yields, which are contingent upon high heat and mass transfer rates prevailing simultaneously. As the heat and mass transfer rates depend on keff and α′ respectively, it is concluded that these quantities must be optimized in a range where keff as well α′ are sufficiently high. The permeability results were interpreted also in terms of dimensionless parameters, such as the friction factor Cf and Reynolds' number Re. From the results it is seen that the transition from the D'Arcy region to the high-velocity region is quite smooth and graduai as expected of porous materials. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Lanthanum Nickel Alloys--Thermal Conductivity; Mass Transfer; Powder Metallurgy--Lanthanum Nickel Alloys; Friction Factor; Hydrides; Hydrogen Storage; Permeability; Porous Metallic Matrix Hydride Compacts; Reynolds Number; Lanthanum Compounds

Title: Characteristics of hydrogen absorption by organic compound-modified magnesium and MgNi systems
Affiliations: Department of Industriel Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2557 Tokiwadai, Ube, 755, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Imamura, H., Department of Industriel Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Yamaguchi University, 2557 Tokiwadai, Ube, 755, Japan
Abstract: Tetrahydrofuran(THF)-solvated magnesium (MgTHF) and nickel-dispersing magnesium (MgNiTHF) particles prepared by vaporizing metal atoms into THF matrices at 77 K were studied in order to determine the hydrogen absorption characteristics of organic-compound-modified magnesium systems. The particles were exceptionally active for hydride formation under extremely mild conditions. The initial activity of MgNiTHF was higher by a factor of between 2 and 10 than that of MgTHF. We observed better yields of MgH2 at hydrogen pressures and temperatures substantially lower than those reported previously. For MgNiTHF the active compounds were those in which the nickel metallic surface area and the degree of nickel dispersion were high. For MgTHF and MgNiTHF, the hydriding reaction was explained by a rate-limiting surface reaction in the initial stage, followed by diffusion-rate-limited hydriding. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Magnesium Nickel Alloys--Gases; Hydrogen Absorption; Hydrogen Storage; Tetrahydrofuran Solvation; Magnesium and Alloys

Authors: Efron A., Lifshitz Y., Lewkowicz I., Mintz M.H.
Title: The kinetics and mechanism of titanium hydride formation
Affiliations: Soreq Nuclear Research Center, Yavne, 70600, Israel; Nuclear Research Center - Negev, P.O. Box 9001, Beer ShevaIsrael
Authors with affiliations: Efron, A., Soreq Nuclear Research Center, Yavne, 70600, Israel; Lifshitz, Y., Soreq Nuclear Research Center, Yavne, 70600, Israel; Lewkowicz, I., Soreq Nuclear Research Center, Yavne, 70600, Israel; Mintz, M.H., Nuclear Research Center - Negev, P.O. Box 9001, Beer ShevaIsrael
Abstract: The kinetics and mechanism of titanium hydride formation were studied by measurements of overall reaction rates combined with metallographic examinations of partially hydrided samples. The main part of the reaction involves the formation of a continuous protective hydride layer which progresses into the sample. Paralinear rate equations fit the kinetic behaviour over a pressure range of 30-450 Torr H2 and temperatures of 100-250 °C. The reaction rate is controlled by the diffusion of hydrogen through the protective thickening product layer which finally reaches an apparently constant thickness for diffusion as a result of cracking on the outer surface. This maximum thickness is temperature dependent and increases abruptly above approximately 150 °C. A corresponding apparent deviation from Arrhenius dependence is observed in the linear rate constants. Morphological aspects of hydride development are described. The effect of the metal microstructure on the hydriding kinetics is discussed. © 1989.

Title: Novel laser writing mechanism in void rich columnar thin films for optical storage applications
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Science, Applied Optics Laboratory, Instrumentation and Services Unit, Bangalore, 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, L.K., Indian Institute of Science, Applied Optics Laboratory, Instrumentation and Services Unit, Bangalore, 560012, India
Abstract: A novel optical darkening effect has been observed due to transient laser irradiation, in semitransparent thin films of PbTe containing void rich columnar microstructure. Oblique deposition technique is used to generate the columnar microstructure in these films. A free running Nd:YAG laser is used to irradiate the films. The darkening effect is analysed using optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. This darkening effect is found to be distinctly different from the well known photodarkening phenomena in amorphous materials and gives rise to high optical contrast a relatively low laser writing energy of 2 to 3 nJ/μm2. A novel interactive mechanism, based on a new morphological transformation in the intravoid region of the columnar microstructure is proposed to explain the observed darkening effect. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Optical Materials--Thin Films; Columnar Microstructure; Columnar Thin Films; Laser Writing; Optical Darkening; Photodarkening; Semitransparent Thin Films; Data Storage, Optical

Title: Analysis of internal target effects in light ion storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institut für Strahlen-, Kernphysik der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 14-16, D-5300 Bonn 1, Germany

Abstract: This paper considers the rate of beam phase space growth and beam losses caused by thin internal targets in light ion storage rings without beam cooling. The analysis of transverse emittance growth and beam losses by small angle Coulomb scattering is recapitulated. The formalism is extended to analyze the effects of transverse and longitudinal emittance growth by energy loss fluctuations. All target effects can be parametrized by two quantities, the mean square values θrms2 and δrms2 of the small angle scattering and relative momentum straggling per target traversal. This paper presents simple expressions for the transverse and longitudinal emittance growth, the beam survival probability and the quantities θrms2 and δrms2. © 1989.

Authors: Koh J.T., Goudy A.J., Huang P., Zhou G.
Title: A comparison of the hydriding and dehydriding kinetics of LaNI5 hydride
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koh, J.T., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States; Goudy, A.J., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States; Huang, P., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States; Zhou, G., Department of Chemistry, West Chester University, West Chester, PA 19383, United States
Abstract: A comparison of the hydriding and dehydriding reactions of LaNi5 hydride, in the two-phase region, has been made under essentially identical conditions. In both the absorption and desorption processes, the sample was maintained at approximately isothermal conditions by mixing it with a heat buffer. In addition, the hydrogen pressure in the system was adjusted such that the ratio of the equilibrium plateau pressure to the opposing pressure was the same for both the hydriding and dehydriding processes. Pressure ratios of 2, 3, 4 and 5 were used in each case. Since these factors, as well as the number of times that the sample had been subjected to hydriding-dehydriding cycles, were kept constant, it was possible to make valid comparisons of the intrinsic rates of hydriding and dehydriding. The rates of hydriding and dehydriding were found to differ substantially under the conditions used. In the case of hydriding, the reaction rate started out slowly, increased to a maximum, then decayed exponentially. In the case of dehydriding, the reaction rate decreased exponentially throughout. This suggests that in the early stages, absorption proceeds by a nucleation and growth process in which β-phase nuclei form on the surface. Once the nuclei have grown to the extent where overlapping occurs, the β phase forms a contracting envelope around the α phase and grows inwardly with a corresponding decrease in the α-β interface area. Dehydriding, however, can best be described throughout the entire reaction by a shrinking core model in which α-phase forms on the surface and grows inwardly. In both processes, the reaction rate seems to be controlled by phase transformation at the α-β interface. Activation energies were found to be 27 and 37 kJ mol-1 for the absorption and desorption process respectively, at a pressure ratio of 2. Also, since the first order rate constants for absorption and desorption were found to vary linearly with the logarithm of the pressure ratio, it is suggested that pressure ratios should always be specified when reporting kinetic data. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Lanthanum Nickel Alloys--Absorption; Activation Energy; Arrhenius Plots; Dehydriding Kinetics; Hydrides; Hydriding Kinetics; Pressure Ratio; Lanthanum Compounds

Abstract: A method to increase the energy content of metallic conductors is described. The conductor is enclosed by a high-melting-point material such as carbon. The suggested configuration does not allow the conductor material to evaporate during the heating process (e.g. applying very high pulsed magnetic fields or very high electric currents), thus avoiding a significant decrease in the electric conductivity. © 1989 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: Laser and laser related characteristics of Nd:Bel
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Allied-Signal Inc., Corporate Technology, P.0.Box 1021R, Morristown, NJ, 07960, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rapoport, W.R., Allied-Signal Inc., Corporate Technology, P.0.Box 1021R, Morristown, NJ, 07960, United States; Chin, T., Allied-Signal Inc., Corporate Technology, P.0.Box 1021R, Morristown, NJ, 07960, United States
Abstract: A variety of different axis cuts of Nd:BEL were investigated in both rod and straight through slab form. Using two cw diode pumped Nd:BEL lasers operating at 1.070 and 1.079 μm, the small signal gain was measured. This measurement was done for X, Y, Z, and athermal rods for both polarizations. The same procedure was done for Nd:YAG and Nd:Cr:GSGG for comparison tests. Using spectroscopic data for all materials, the stored energy was calculated as well as the pumping efficiency. Efficient, high quality beam, operation of the laser also requires prior knowledge of the thermal distortions induced by the flashlamp pumping. This information was obtained by operating the pump chamber in one arm of a Mach-Zehnder interferometer at flashlamp powers up to 600 watts at 20 Hz. This procedure can show a large degree of non-isotropic lensing and wedging. In order to help deconvolve the pump induced wedge terms, the rods were also rotated 90. These measurements were made for both polarizations showing strong polarization dependent thermal distortion for Nd:BEL. Moire' deflectometry was also used to characterize the lensing. These results will be compared to the pumped interferometry. Knowledge of the thermal distortion profiles can lead to the design of straight through slabs with low thermal lensing terms. Long Pulse and Q-switched laser tests were conducted for the different axis rods and compared to Nd:YAG and Nd:Cr:GSGG in the identical optical arrangement. These results confirm the higher storage of Nd:BEL compared to Nd:YAG. © 1989, SPIE.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Neodymium lasers; Polarization; Q switched lasers; Yttrium aluminum garnet; Comparison test; Optical arrangement; Prior knowledge; Pumping efficiency; Small signal gain; Spectroscopic data; Thermal distortions; Thermal lensing; Pumping (laser)

Authors: Havaux M., Lorrain L., Leblanc R.M.
Title: In vivo measurement of spectroscopic and photochemical properties of intact leaves using the 'mirage effect'
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, CP 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Havaux, M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, CP 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec G9A 5H7, Canada; Lorrain, L., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, CP 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, boul. des Forges, CP 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: This paper describes a new, highly sensitive, method for in vivo studies of photosynthesis based on the 'mirage effect' in which thermal energy dissipation from intact leaves, illuminated with intensity-modulated light, is sensed through the periodic deflection of a laser beam propagating along the leaf surface. The photothermal deflection technique allows one to rapidly estimate the gross efficiency of photochemical energy storage by comparing the heat emission signal with and without an additional strong, photosynthetically saturating, non-modulated light. In pea leaves, the maximal storage efficiency at low light intensities was shown to approach 55%. The general utility of this simple photothermal method is illustrated by examining the variation of the deflection signal under different conditions. The spectral resolution of this new method is shown to be much higher than that of the photoacoustic method. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Intact leaf; Mirage effect; Photoacoustic technique; Photosynthesis; Photothermal deflection technique

Title: Traps and rings: Is small beautiful?
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Church, D.A., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Jian, J., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Kravis, S.D., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Shigu, T., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Qi, W., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Xiang-Tai, W., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: In recent years ion traps of various types have served in studies of collision interactions and spectroscopy of low energy multicharged ions. With large storage rings for multicharged heavy ions, dedicated to atomic physics research, now planned or coming into operation, it is useful to consider the role of ion traps in future experimental work. The capabilities and current limitations of multicharged ion research using traps are discussed, and a comparison with storage rings for the purposes of ion spectroscopy is made. Recent experimental investigations to develop techniques for the study of multicharged ions in traps using laser or synchrotron radiation are discussed, including a UHV pulsed gas source and an atom beam as ionization targets. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Ion Beams; Physics--Atomic; Ion Traps; Multicharged Ions; Synchrotron Radiation; Accelerators

Title: From splines to fractals
Source title: Proceedings of the 16th Annual Conference on Computer Graphics and Interactive Techniques, SIGGRAPH 1989
Affiliations: Cambridge Research Lab, Digital Equipment Corp., One Kendall Square, Cambridge, MA  02139, United States; Schlumberger Laboratory for Computer Science, P.O. Box 200015, Austin, TX  78720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Szeliski, R., Cambridge Research Lab, Digital Equipment Corp., One Kendall Square, Cambridge, MA  02139, United States; Terzopoulos, D., Schlumberger Laboratory for Computer Science, P.O. Box 200015, Austin, TX  78720, United States
Abstract: Deterministic splines and stochastic fractals are complementary techniques for generating free-form shapes. Splines are easily constrained and well suited to modeling smooth, man-made objects. Fractals, while difficult to constrain, are suitable for generating various irregular shapes found in nature. This paper develops constrained fractals, a hybrid of splines and fractals which intimately combines their complementary features. This novel shape synthesis technique stems from a formal connection between fractals and generalized energy-minimizing splines which may be derived through Fourier analysis. A physical interpretation of constrained fractal generation is to drive a spline subject to constraints with modulated white noise, letting the spline diffuse the noise into the desired fractal spectrum as it settles into equilibrium. We use constrained fractals to synthesize realistic terrain models from sparse elevation data.
Author Keywords: Constraints; Deformable models; Digital terrain models; Fractals; Physically based modeling; Scattered data interpolation; Splines

Abstract: The oxidation of iron/II/ ions has been studied by dissolving γ-irradiated NaCl crystals in aqueous Fricke solution. The yield of iron/III/ ions was determined as a function of the amount of NaCl added, storage time, dose, concentration of iron/II/ ions and pH of the Fricke solution. The energy transfer parameter, ε, which is the ratio of G/Fe3+/ obtained by the addition of irradiated NaCl to that by direct radiolysis was evaluated. © 1989 Akadémiai Kiadó.

Abstract: Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) evaluates EV propulsion systems and components for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Electric & Hybrid Vehicle (EHV) Programme. In this study, experimental data were used to evaluate the relative performances of the benchmark Chrysler/GE ETV-1 DC and the Ford/GE First Generation Single-Shaft AC (ETX-I) propulsion systems.

Authors: Eiland B.R., Monroe G.E., Hellwig R.E.
Title: Status of production, harvesting, handling and storing of biomass crops
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Okeelanta Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eiland, B.R., Okeelanta Corp, United States; Monroe, G.E., Okeelanta Corp, United States; Hellwig, R.E., Okeelanta Corp, United States
Abstract: Research activities on the production, harvesting and storing of biomass crops for energy utilization are reviewed. Crops include sugar producing plants, nonsugar bearing grasses and weeds, root crops, and some specialty crop species. While progress has been made in producing biomass crops, areas for additional or continued research are identified. These areas include (1) development of basic information on plant genes which control sugar, starch, and nonsoluble fiber formation, (2) development of production and harvesting systems for promising 'new' crops, (3) screening of new crop species with emphasis on seed production as a diesel fuel or lubricant substitute, (4) utilization of cull fruits and vegetables and processing wastes as ethanol or methane feedstocks, and (5) assessment of production costs including fertilizer inputs on fiber crops for use as furnace fuel.
