Title: Simulation of the transient refrigeration load in a cold storage for apples and pears
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adre, Norberto, Cornell Univ, United States; Hellickson, Martin L., Cornell Univ, United States
Abstract: Increased consumer demand for fresh fruit throughout the year has created a need for long term storage. As storage periods of fresh commodities increase, especially through the use of controlled atmosphere environments, production costs increase. A BASICA computer program, RLSIM, was developed to predict the transient refrigeration load throughout the storage season in apple and pear cold storage warehouses. RLSIM accurately predicted the seasonal and component refrigeration system energy demand during the 1985-865 cold storage season. Results indicated that the largest single energy use component is continuous operation of the evaporator fans. Simulation of a six hours on and six hours off fan cycling scheme indicated a reduction of 23.75% could be achieved in overall refrigeration system energy use in the cold storage warehouse used.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Energy Utilization--Computer Simulation; Refrigeration--Computer Simulation; Apples; Cold Storage; Pears; Software Package RLSIM; Transient Refrigeration Load; Agricultural Products

Title: Cold air distribution makes cool storage the best choice
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dorgan, Charles E., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, United States
Abstract: Cold air distribution is a technology that makes cool storage competitive with the first cost of conventional air conditioning. It further reduces the electrical demand related to air conditioning. Since cold air distribution has both first and operating cost benefits, it should be analyzed for all new facilities and wherever existing facilities are upgraded or cooling capacity is increased. Cold air distribution in its current form has only become widely used the last three years. In some U.S. locations and in London, it has become one of, if not the, preferred system in multi-story and large facilities. Benefits include lower first cost, lower operating cost, better comfort, lower electric demand, increased air-conditioning demand factor, and good retrofit option.
Index Keywords: Air; Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids; Temperature Distribution; Cold Air Distribution; Cool Storage; Thermal Energy; Buildings

Title: Chilled air approaches the office building market
Affiliations: Henry Adams Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pearson, Frederick J., Henry Adams Inc, United States
Abstract: Design and construction options available through the combination of ice-storage/low-temperature air (also called 'cold air' and 'chilled air') distribution systems could rapidly make off-peak generation with ice storage the dominant method of providing cooling energy in new office buildings. Potential benefits offered by this combination, when compared with frequently used 'conventional' systems, include improved indoor air quality, lower operating cost, reduced electric power requirements, lower construction costs, improved occupant comfort and increased revenue potential. Each of these benefits is discussed in the article.
Index Keywords: Air; Energy Storage; Flow of Fluids; Cold Air Distribution; Office Buildings

Title: Wind power on cape clear
Authors with affiliations: Kennedy, T.
Abstract: Since 1983 the European Commission has put about £20 million into 98 different wind energy projects. The latest development on a 150 acre island off the coast of Cork is expected to demonstrate that high grade power can be generated at reasonable cost on a small scale. To meet the requirements it was decided to have two wind energy converters, a battery storage bank and a back up diesel. On a windy day the mills alone can generate enough power to supply the island grid. When the wind drops the diesel takes over and the batteries bridge any gap. The advance involved in this system is that it allows the diesel to close down when not required.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation--Ireland; Wind Turbines; Ireland Wind Power Test Site; Wind Power

Title: Thermal storage retrofit
Affiliations: Paul Mueller Co
Authors with affiliations: Knebel, David E., Paul Mueller Co; Houston, Steve, Paul Mueller Co
Abstract: The Worthington Hotel opened in 1980 to provide luxury accommodations to Fort Worth visitors. The hotel has 525,000 sq ft of air-conditioned space. The original cooling system consisted of three 400 hp open screw compressor heat-pump chiller packages, and seven direct expansion 50,000 lb ice on pipe thermal storage tanks. This article discusses how more than 850 kW is saved during peak electrical demand based on a thermal energy storage system retrofitted to the hotel. Subjects covered include the retrofit stages that the system went through, system components, electric energy utilization, building electrical demand, system design, and others.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Utilization; Energy Conservation; Energy Storage--Retrofitting; Thermal Energy; Hotels

Title: Cool storazge: A technology update
Affiliations: EPRI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wendland, Ronald D., EPRI, United States
Abstract: The electric utility industry regards cool storage as a major load management opportunity to defer capacity additions, improve load factors and conserve scarce fuels. Therefore, cool storage research and technical transfer is a high priority program at the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) designed to supplement the extensive HVAC community efforts in cool storage. This article discusses various aspects of this research effort, including system controls, indoor air quality, comfort criteria, chilled water storage, and others.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Air Conditioning; Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Cool Storage; Energy Storage

Authors: van Melle J.C.C., van Nieuwenhuizen G.J., Meijer R.J., Box P.F., Decowski P., Kamermans R.
Title: Pulse shape analysis of CsI(Tl)-PD signals induced by 6-20 MeV α-particles and protons
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van Melle, J.C.C., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; van Nieuwenhuizen, G.J., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Meijer, R.J., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Box, P.F., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Decowski, P., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands; Kamermans, R., Fysisch Laboratorium, Rijksuniversiteit Utrecht, PO Box 80000, 3508 TA Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: The preamplifier response of a CsI(Tl)-photodiode light-particle detector is studied as a function of α-particle and proton energy. Preamplifier pulse shapes were recorded with a digital storage scope and analyzed afterwards. These measurements show that it is possible to determine the identity and energy of a particle by a computer analysis of the preamplifier pulse. Also the timing of a particle can be quite accurately obtained. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Charged Particles--Spectrum Analysis; Scintillation Counters; Semiconductor Diodes, Photodiode; Alpha Particles; Cesium Iodide; Preamplifer Response; Pulse Shape Analysis; Particle Detectors

Authors: Ageev S.G., Ivanov I.I., Sarkisova M.F., Shestopal E.N., Shishkin A.K.
Title: Selection of the layout of the powerhouse of a pumped-storage station in a drop shaft
Authors with affiliations: Ageev, S.G.; Ivanov, I.I.; Sarkisova, M.F.; Shestopal, E.N.; Shishkin, A.K.
Abstract: 1. The layout of the powerhouse of a PSS in drop shafts with a nonstandard waterway of the pump-turbine with a specific speed of 220 for heads up to 100 m are comparable in their hydraulic, energy, and dynamic characteristics to a standardized waterway, which enables recommending it for use in designs of medium-head PSSs. 2. The use of drop shafts when constructing a PSS on soft ground provides substantial technical-economic advantages of such a variant of the layout of the hydro development. © 1989 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: Dropshafts; Powerhouse; Pumped Storage; Flow of Fluids - Tubes; Foundations - Soil Structure Interaction; Hydraulic Structures - Models; Hydraulic Turbines - Hydrodynamics; Penstocks - Concrete; Drop Shafts; Head Losses; Powerhouses; Pump-Turbine Units; Spiral Casings; Undercutting; Hydroelectric Power Plants

Authors: Canaani O., Schuster G., Ohad I.
Title: Photoinhibition in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii: Effect on state transition, intersystem energy distribution and Photosystem I cyclic electron flow
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Department of Biological Chemistry, Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Canaani, O., Department of Biochemistry, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Schuster, G., Department of Biological Chemistry, Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Ohad, I., Department of Biological Chemistry, Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Abstract: The energy distribution, state transitions and photosynthetic electron flow during photoinhibition of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii cells have been studied in vivo using photoacoustics and modulated fluorescence techniques. In cells exposed to 2500 W/m2 light at 21 °C for 90 min, 90% of the oxygen evolution activity was lost while photochemical energy storage as expressed by the parameter photochemical loss (P.L.) at 710-720 nm was not impaired. The energy storage vs. modulation frequency profile indicated an endothermic step with a rate constant of 2.1 ms. The extent of the P.L. was not affected by DCMU but was greatly reduced by DBMIB. The regulatory mechanism of the state 1 to state 2 transition process was inactivated and the apparent light absorption cross section of photosystem II increased during the first 20 min of photoinhibition followed by a significant decrease relative to that of photosystem I. These results are consistent with the inactivation of the LHC II kinase and the presence of an active cyclic electron flow around photosystem I in photoinhibited cells. © 1989 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Chlamydomonas reinhardtii; photoacoustics; photoinhibition; PS I cyclic electron flow; state transitions

Title: Natural charge densities for the evaluation of MC-SCF energy derivatives without density matrix transformation
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pulay, P., Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Bofill, J.M., Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: A technique is described which allows the construction of the reduced two-electron density matrix "on the fly" in MC-SCF derivative calculations. The method eliminates the problems associated with the storage and access of a large density matrix file, and incurs only a small computational overhead for active spaces of moderate dimension (up to 12). © 1989.

Title: Study of the performance of the solar heating system of a multifamily building
Affiliations: Centre de Recherches sur les Très Basses Températures, CNRS, BP 166 X, 38042 Grenoble Cédex, France
Authors with affiliations: Flouquet, F.O., Centre de Recherches sur les Très Basses Températures, CNRS, BP 166 X, 38042 Grenoble Cédex, France; Kernevez, N., Centre de Recherches sur les Très Basses Températures, CNRS, BP 166 X, 38042 Grenoble Cédex, France
Abstract: The computer program TRNSYS was used to simulate the heating system of the Bourgoin-Jallieu experimental solar building and added quantitative results to the survey of several years of monitoring. The building, situated near Lyon, France, consists of two identical three-storey blocks; the south face is a curtain wall with water solar collectors (the parameters of the solar system can be varied). The floors are equipped with coils of water imbedded in the concrete. The heating system was simulated by a model which took into account the independent electric auxiliary heating and the thermal capacitance of the floor and of the walls. It gave good information about the energy balance according to the experiments. The overall performance of the system has been investigated by the Chang model and the concept of decay constant was analyzed. It was shown to be relevant only for intermediate solar radiation, to be a function of the utilizability and to be inversely proportional to the load of the building. It was also shown that the most interesting solution is to use the largest storage allowed by the tanks, although the direct use of the concrete mass of the floor could achieve nearly equivalent energy performance at a lower cost. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Apartment Houses; Buildings; Computer Simulation; Solar Energy--France; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Chang Model; Software Package TRNSYS; Solar Heating Systems; Heating

Title: Evidence for off-axis leakage radiance in high-altitude IR rocketborne measurements
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Air Force Geophysics Laboratory, Hanscom AFB, Bedford, MA, 01731, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.R., Air Force Geophysics Laboratory, Hanscom AFB, Bedford, MA, 01731, United States
Abstract: Analysis of IR data obtained from several rocketborne sensors in a limb-viewing geometry clearly show off-axis leakage to be the dominant source of radiance at tangent heights above approximately 100 km in all but the strongest of atmospheric emission bands: CO22(15) and NO (5.3). Telescope leakage model calculations using BRDF values of ~2-4 × 10−3at 10 are in adequate general agreement with much of these flight data and indicate inflight rejection performance 20-40 times worse than model predictions based on pre-flight laboratory measurements. Laboratory measurements on a number of IR telescopes after many months of vacuum storage indicate an average degradation factor of approximately 35 in excellent general agreement with these rocketborne measurements. However, both laboratory and flight measurements indicate degradation factors which are a function of the off-axis angle with a performance at small angles (< 2°) which can be significantly poorer than these average factors, and can result in a major portion of the leakage energy originating from the lower atmosphere. In at least one case, the off-axis rejection performance at small angles was found to be poor enough for non-rejected radiation from the lower atmosphere to become the dominant source of leakage energy in several IR bands. In this example, the clear presence of anomalous atmospheric spectral features in the data for high tangent heights can only be interpreted in this context. Modelling of the spectra from these experiments throughout the IR region requires proper inclusion of the effects of the atmosphere (both in emission and absorption). Results to date indicate that high-resolution line-by-line calculations may be required to fully explain the detailed structure of the spectra from these measurements. © SPIE.
Index Keywords: Research laboratories; Stray light; Telescopes; Atmospheric emission; Degradation factor; Flight measurements; Laboratory measurements; Limb-viewing geometry; Line-by-line calculations; Lower atmosphere; Rejection performance; Digital storage

Title: Pegasys - a proposed internal target spectrometer facility for the PEP storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, PO Box 808, L-405, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Van Bibber, K., Department of Physics, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, PO Box 808, L-405, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States
Abstract: A proposal for an internal gas-jet target and forward spectrometer for the PEP storage ring is described. The beam structure, allowable luminosity (ℓ = 1033cm-2s-1 for H2, D2 decreasing as Z-1.75 for nuclear targets) and energy (Ee ≦ 15 GeV) make the ring ideal for multiparticle coincidence studies in the scaling regime, where perturbative QCD may be an apt description of some exclusive and semi-inclusive reactions. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Physics--Nuclear; Spectrometers; PEGASYS (PEP Gas Jet Spectrometer System); PEP Storage Ring; Synchrotron Radiation; Accelerators

Authors: Friesel D.L., Ellison T.J., Schwandt P.
Title: Status report on the IUCF cooler-storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Indiana University Cyclotron, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States
Authors with affiliations: Friesel, D.L., Indiana University Cyclotron, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States; Ellison, T.J., Indiana University Cyclotron, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States; Schwandt, P., Indiana University Cyclotron, Bloomington, IN 47408, United States
Abstract: Commissioning activities on the IUCF Cooler, a storage ring with internal targets and electron cooling, were begun in November, 1987. By June 1988, proton beam accumulation, storage, acceleration, and cooling (both in the absence and in the presence of internal targets) had been demonstrated. Commissioning studies in the summer of 1988 were devoted to measuring the lattice parameters and exploring the operating characteristics of the cooler and optimizing its performance for use as an intermediate-energy nuclear physics research instrument. Both stripping injection of 90 MeV H+2 ions and direct, fast kicker injection of 148 and 179 MeV polarized proton beams from the IUCF cyclotrons were demonstrated. The initial performance characteristics of the ring for beams stored, accelerated, and cooled in this new facility are discussed here. Results from preliminary measurements of the equilibrium properties of stored, cooled beams in the presence of thin internal targets (014atoms/cm2) are also reported. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Ion Beams; Protons; Electron Cooled Storage Rings; Polarized Proton Beams; Accelerators, Cyclotron

Authors: Montemezzan G., Ingole M., Looser H., Gunter P.
Title: Multiple photorefractive gratings in ce-doped linbO3 and knbO3 crystals
Affiliations: Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Montemezzan, G., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland; Ingole, M., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland; Looser, H., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland; Gunter, P., Institute of Quantum Electronics, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: The dynamics of the build-up and the dark decay of photorefractive gratings written in LiNbO3:Ce (1%) at room temperature and in undoped KNbO3 crystals heated above 70°C has been investigated. Positive and negative charge carriers seem to contribute to the photorefractive effect with different rise and decay times. In potassium niobate activation energies for both charge carriers are given. A fixing method is described, which leads to a large increase of the holographic storage times in KNbO3. © 1989, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Physiological energetics of the intertidal sea anemone Anthopleura elegantissima - III. Biochemical composition of body tissues, substrate-specific absorption, and carbon and nitrogen budgets
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Maine, Orono, 04469, ME, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zamer, W.E., Department of Zoology, University of Maine, Orono, 04469, ME, United States; Shick, J.M., Department of Zoology, University of Maine, Orono, 04469, ME, United States
Abstract: Lipid is the major energy storage molecule, and protein is highly conserved when food availability is low in high- and low-intertidal individuals of Anthopleura elegantissima. Under laboratory conditions zooxanthellae were lost from anemones, and tissue carbohydrate was mobilized to support metabolic demands. Routine catabolic requirements for carbohydrate are probably met by translocated photosynthate. Substrate-specific absorption efficiencies were greater than 95% for protein and lipid, but considerably lower (10 to 60%) for carbohydrate. This pattern of absorption is directly related to very low levels of dietary carbohydrate compared to the other substrates. High-intertidal anemones absorbed more lipid than low-intertidal anemones. Integrated budgets for organic nitrogen, the first reported for any cnidarian, indicate that low-intertidal anemones require larger daily rations than high-intertidal anemones to meet their higher metabolic demands for protein. These results are considered in relation to potential importance of zooxanthellae in nutrient cycling. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Anthopleura elegantissima; Biochemical composition; Nitrogen budgets; Respiratory substrates; Zooxanthellae
Index Keywords: carbon budget; energetics; nitrogen budget; sea anemone

Title: 9th International Electric Vehicle Symposium (EVS-9)
Abstract: Proceedings incorporates eight papers dealing with recent developments of modern electric vehicles. Topics considered include: lead-acid batteries, electric propulsion, electric delivery vans developed in Finland, sodium-sulfur batteries, electric road vehicles, aluminum-air batteries, transit bus systems, and the role played by the US Dept of Energy in R&D activities concerned with electric vehicles.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Electric Batteries, Secondary; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Rapid Transit; Storage Battery Vehicles; Aluminum-Air Batteries; Delivery Vans; EIREV; Electric Vehicles; Lead-Acid Batteries; Sodium-Sulfur Batteries; Vehicles

Title: US Department of Energy's electric vehicle product improvement programme
Affiliations: DOE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barber, K.F., DOE, United States; Takagishi, S.K., DOE, United States
Abstract: In 1982 the US Department of Energy, in conjunction with a group of active electric vehicle site operators, initiated a cost-shared program to test and evaluate new and improved technologies in an effort to resolve some of the technical and operational problems that were being experienced by the vehicle users. Over 20 new technologies were tested including battery systems, drivetrain components, battery support systems, auxiliary power systems, and improved vehicles. Numerous problems have been identified and resolved since. The improvements have been reflected by a decrease in vehicle maintenance and an overall increase in vehicle reliability in the fleets that made full utilization of the available new technologies. However, many of the vehicles are now approaching 8 years of service and their value as a field test fleet is coming to an end. More advanced technology vehicles are becoming available and need to be evaluated in a field environment.
Index Keywords: Storage Battery Vehicles; Auxiliary Power Systems; Battery Support Systems; Drivetrain Components; Electric Vehicle; Field Test Fleet; US Department of Energy; Vehicles

Authors: Sok Ban He, Lyashenko V.I., Sodomyn E., Tudor T., Vu Chan An, Shcherbakov Yu.A.
Title: Increasing the efficiency of a nitrogen laser
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Sok, Ban He, Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Lyashenko, V.I., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Sodomyn, E., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Tudor, T., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Vu, Chan An, Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Shcherbakov, Yu.A., Joint Inst for Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Abstract: A nitrogen laser with improved performance that provides ultraviolet radiation with a wavelength of 337.1 nm is described. To increase efficiency, the supply system is optimized; a continuous flow of gas is introduced into the laser chamber. Laser operation with various supply voltages and gas pressures in the discharge chamber is studied. The pulse power is 2 MW and the pulse duration at half maximum is 5 nsec. The specific energy is 0.3 mJ/cm3 in a laser active volume of 32.4 cm3 for a gas flow rate of 80 ml/min. Measures are taken to stabilize operation of the dye used to convert the ultraviolet radiation to visible. The efficiency and stability of the laser are increased.
Index Keywords: Capacitors, Ceramic - Energy Storage; Electric Power Supplies to Apparatus; Laser Optics; Lasers - Efficiency; Aluminum Mirrors; Forced Dye Circulation; Gas Flow-Through; Nitrogen Lasers; Noninductive Capacitors; Rhodamine Solutions; Lasers, Dye

Title: Storage batteries for terrestrial solar applications. Selection and design
Source title: Journal of the Electrochemical Society of India
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Science, India
Authors with affiliations: Sathyanarayana, S., Indian Inst of Science, India
Abstract: A discussion is presented of criteria for storage batteries. Their general characteristics are also presented. The type of storage batteries needed for terrestrial solar power stations are also discussed. Electrochemical design principles are outlined.
Index Keywords: Electrolytes; Energy Resources - India; Solar Cells; Solar Energy; Solar Power Plants - India; Charge Efficiency; Flooded Electrolyte Batteries; Solar Electric Generators; Solar Power Stations; Storage Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: Altseimer John H., Edeskuty Frederick J.
Title: Geothermal process heat applications for Guatemala
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: Altseimer, John H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, United States; Edeskuty, Frederick J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, United States
Abstract: This paper describes how process heat from Guatemala's geothermal energy resources might be developed to reduce Guatemala's costly importation of oil, create new employment by encouraging new industry, and reduce fuel costs for existing industry. Two sites, Amatitlan and Zunil, are being developed geothermally. Amatitlan is in the better industrial area but Zunil's geothermal development is more advanced. The industry around Zunil is almost exclusively agricultural and the development of an agricultural processing plant (freezing, dehydration, and cold storage) using geothermal heat is recommended as a private-sector investment. Similar developments throughout the volcanic zones of Guatemala are possible. Later, when the field at Amatitlan has been further developed, an industrial park can be planned. To help promote the geothermal agricultural processing concept, Los Alamos has been constructing a small demonstration plant at Zunil and its status is described.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Products--Processing; Geothermal Energy--Energy Utilization; Agricultural Processing Plant; Guatemala; Private-Sector; Industrial Heating

Authors: Popel O.S., Shpil'rain E.E., Kalashyan M.S.
Title: Choosing the parameters of a solar space heating system for an individual house
Affiliations: Inst of High Temperatures of the, USSR Acad of Sciences, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Popel, O.S., Inst of High Temperatures of the, USSR Acad of Sciences, Russian Federation; Shpil'rain, E.E., Inst of High Temperatures of the, USSR Acad of Sciences, Russian Federation; Kalashyan, M.S., Inst of High Temperatures of the, USSR Acad of Sciences, Russian Federation
Abstract: Solar heating systems for individual houses are a potential use for solar energy in the future. As yet only individual experimental units with solar heating plants have been set up in the Soviet Union. One of the first solar houses was built in 1981 in the settlement of Mertsavan in Armenia. The purpose of this article is to discuss problems of the selection and functioning of solar space heating systems in individual houses, also to make recommendations for improving these systems. The use of a short-term storage unit for the solar plant does not completely cover the heating requirements of the house for space heating throughout the heating season. The heat supply system is therefore provided with an automatic gas water heater (AGWH) as back-up, designed to ensure that the heating load for the house is fully covered during a long period without solar radiation.
Index Keywords: Houses--Space Heating; Solar Power Plants; Automatic Gas Water Heater; Mertsavan House; Short-Term Storage Unit; Temperature Gradient; Heating

Title: Thermal modeling of Petroleum, Oil, and Lubricants (POL) bulk storage tanks
Source title: Technical Report - US Army Engineer Waterways Experiment Station
Affiliations: US Army Corps of Engineers, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodge, Bernice K., US Army Corps of Engineers, United States
Abstract: A lumped-mass surface-temperature thermal model for POL bulk storage tanks is developed. The model uses 12 ordinary, coupled, first-order differential equations, obtained from energy balances, to describe the time-dependent variation of the surface temperatures (top and eight wall segments) of a partially filled POL tank. Convective heat transfer and direct and diffuse irradiation are modeled as energy transfers into and out of the 12 lumped masses. One-dimensional transient conduction is considered in the soil below the tank. The model is implemented in a computer simulation. Comparisons of the predicted tank surface temperatures with the limited data available show that the correct trends and salient features are predicted. In most instances, predicted temperatures are within a few degrees Celsius of measured. Preliminary model performance indicates that the technique incorporates much of the correct physics and is capable of being developed into a reliable predictive model. Recommendations are made for further development and validation.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Infrared Detectors; Mathematical Models; Military Engineering--Camouflage; Temperature Distribution; Fluid Filled Targets; Lubricant Tanks; Oil Tanks; Petroleum Tanks; Target Detection; Thermal Modeling; Tanks

Authors: Andrew M.G., Budney P.A., Heder J.L.
Title: Advanced lead-acid batteries for EV propulsion
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Andrew, M.G., Johnson Controls Inc, United States; Budney, P.A., Johnson Controls Inc, United States; Heder, J.L., Johnson Controls Inc, United States
Abstract: Work is reported on a four year contract, sponsored by the United States Department of Energy for the design and development of an advanced lead-acid battery system for electric delivery vehicles. The improved state of the art battery, developed under DoE sponsorship, utilized the patented electrolyte circulation system and progress continued towards the development of the forced convection electrolyte flow concept. These activities will culminate in the fabrication of a 39-kwh battery system for vehicle evaluation.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Electric Delivery Vehicles; Electrolyte Circulation System; Forced Convection Electrolyte; Lead-Acid Batteries; United States Department of Energy; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: McWhinnie John, Kelly Barry P., Sims Ronald I., Clegg Gordon
Title: Advanced tubular plate lead-acid battery system for EV applications
Affiliations: Chloride Industrial Batteries Ltd
Authors with affiliations: McWhinnie, John, Chloride Industrial Batteries Ltd; Kelly, Barry P., Chloride Industrial Batteries Ltd; Sims, Ronald I., Chloride Industrial Batteries Ltd; Clegg, Gordon, Chloride Industrial Batteries Ltd
Abstract: An electric vehicle battery has been developed for Ford Motor Company's DOE funded ETX-I powertrain programme. The latest tubular plate lead-acid technology has been incorporated into a design to meet the energy and power requirements to achieve a sixty mile vehicle range. The battery is fitted with a microprocessor based battery management system, which was developed to monitor the state-of-charge and control the charging operation to maximize battery performance and life. Also fitted is a centralized watering system for reliable and uniform topping up.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Centralized Watering System; Electric Vehicle Battery; ETX-I Powertrain; Lead-Acid Battery; Sixty Mile Vehicle Range; Tubular Plate; Storage Battery Vehicles

Title: Status and projected activities of the Monitored Retrievable Storage Review Commission
Source title: JNMM, Journal of the Institute of Nuclear Materials Management
Affiliations: Monitored Retrievable Storage Review, Commission, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parker, Frank L., Monitored Retrievable Storage Review, Commission, United States
Abstract: Federal monitored retrievable storage was first proposed as a retrievable surface storage facility by the Atomic Energy Commission as early as 1972. The Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act of 1987 established a Monitored Retrievable Storage Review Commission. The nature of this assignment, the commission's activities, and its plans for completing the assignment are described.
Index Keywords: Legislation; Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; Monitored Retrievable Storage; Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Major tracer-gas migration and stability characteristics are studied
Affiliations: Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, R.P., Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States; Vogh, J.W., Natl Inst for Petroleum & Energy, Research, United States
Abstract: Migration characteristics and stability of tracer gases used in underground-storage-gas identification are insufficiently understood. Much of a major recent study conducted by the National Institute for Petroleum & Energy Research for the Pipeline Research Committee examined stability and migration rates of selected tracer gases and evaluated numerical methods, based on standard compositional analyses, for the detection of gas migration. The following tracers were selected for stability and migration studies: ethylene, propylene, isobutene, 1-butene, carbon monoxide, sulfur hexafluoride, Freon-12 (dichlorodifluoromethane), Freon-13 (chlorotrifluoromethane), Freon-14 (tetrafluoromethane), and Freon-23 (trifluoromethane). The tracers in this study were stored at 100 atm at 60°C in a blend of typical natural-gas composition. The vessels also contained crushed Berea sandstone and water. Gas samples were drawn from the storage vessels and analyzed on a monthly basis to detect loss of tracer.
Index Keywords: Carbon Monoxide; Chromatographic Analysis--Gas; Freons; Olefins; Sulfur Compounds; Chlorotrifluoromethane; Dichlorodifluoromethane; Sulfur Hexafluoride; Tetrafluoromethane; Tracer Gases; Trifluoromethane; Gas Storage

Title: Nuclear industry and communication: a personal view
Authors with affiliations: Morvan, Pierre
Abstract: This article stresses the importance of communication between the nuclear industry and the public. Nuclear energy still suffers today from associations often made between it and nuclear armaments. Nuclear reactors are the most visible part of the fuel cycle, and are therefore the main target of anti-nuclear protestors. Critics of nuclear energy often confuse irradiated fuel with waste. It must be made clear to critics how storage of this waste is carried out at reprocessing plants, both in the long and medium term. The nuclear industry should also not be hesitant in proclaiming its belief that nuclear energy is justifiable politically, economically and ecologically. Security is of the utmost importance at all nuclear sites. The commitment to security must be based on mutual confidence between specialists and the public particularly those living in the vicinity of a nuclear plant. A precise scale by which nuclear incidents can be measured must be defined, indicating their degree of seriousness and consequently what should be done.
Index Keywords: Energy Policy; Nuclear Energy; Nuclear Engineering--Social Aspects; Communications; Policy Issues; Nuclear Industry

Title: Yucca Mountain, Nevada: Is it a safe place for isolation of high-level radioactive waste?
Source title: JNMM, Journal of the Institute of Nuclear Materials Management
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy Yucca Mountain Project, Las Vegas, NV, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gertz, C.P., U.S. Department of Energy Yucca Mountain Project, Las Vegas, NV, United States
Abstract: As mandated by Congress in the amended Nuclear Waste Policy Act, Yucca Mountain, Nevada is currently being studied by the U.S. Department of Energy to determine if it is a suitable location for the nation's first geologic repository for disposal of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fueal. While the site has attributes that suggeest it may be suitable, DOE must spend the next five to seven years and up to $2 billion to find out if the site would be able to isolate radioactive materials for 10,000 years. Site characterization studies are being conducted to determine the geologic, hydrologic and environmental characteristics of the Yucca Mountain site. The DOE is planning to start construction of an underground laboratory in 1989 and to implement an extensive surface-based study program. The next five to seven years of study will determine if Yucca Mountain can meet regulations for waste isolation and qualify for a Nuclear Regulatory Commissions license for repository construction and operation.As mandated by Congress in the amended Nuclear Waste Policy Act, Yucca Mountain, Nevada, is currently being studied by the U.S. Department of Energy to determine if it is suitable location for the nation's first geologic repository for disposal of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. Site characterization studies are being conducted to determine the geologic, hydrologic and environmental characteristics of the Yucca Mountain site. The DOE is planning to start construction of an underground laboratory in 1989 and to implement an extensive surface-based study program. The next five to seven years of study will determine if Yucca Mountain can meet regulations for waste isolation and quality for a Nuclear Regulatory Commission license for repository construction and operation.
Index Keywords: Legislation; Nuclear Reactors--Spent Fuels; High Level Radioactive Wastes; Yucca Mountain Site; Radioactive Wastes; cost; economic aspect; geology; radioactive waste storage; siting; underground storage; united states

Title: Spectrum-image: The next step in EELS digital acquisition and processing
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique, Solides associé au CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 510, F-91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Jeanguillaume, C., Laboratoire de Physique, Solides associé au CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 510, F-91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Colliex, C., Laboratoire de Physique, Solides associé au CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 510, F-91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: This paper defines a new concept in EELS digital acquisition and processing: the spectrum-image. This is a 3D array of nxnxs numbers, the first two axes of which correspond to the x - y position on the specimen as for any image, while the third is associated to a complete energy-loss spectrum. New images and spectra can be extracted as sections or projections of this matrix, and their respective aims and advantages will be sketched. Novel types of processing are also evoked. This approach is closely related to the parallel detection units for EELS spectroscopy now available: despite their great size, these spectrum- images can be handled with normal computing technology, and an example of data compression is introduced to illustrate how far problems in storage can be solved. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Image Processing; Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (EELS); Spectrum Images; Spectroscopy, Electron

Authors: Aloy M., Mermet R., Sanejouand J.
Title: Biomethanization of tannery waste: An industrial experiment
Source title: Journal of the American Leather Chemists Association
Affiliations: Cent Technique Cuir Chaussure, Maroquinerie, France
Authors with affiliations: Aloy, M., Cent Technique Cuir Chaussure, Maroquinerie, France; Mermet, R., Cent Technique Cuir Chaussure, Maroquinerie, France; Sanejouand, J., Cent Technique Cuir Chaussure, Maroquinerie, France
Abstract: The article describes an industrial unit for conjoint processing of tannery waste and spent liquors. This unit has a storage capacity of 135 m3. It was brought into service during October, 1985 and experiments continued to 31 January, 1987. During the optimum phase, each day 8 m3 of sludge and fleshing were loaded in the two digesters. The results of the experiment confirm the technical feasibility of the project and the high level of biogas produced per kg of volatile material fed into the digesters. Nevertheless, economic viability remains heavily influenced by the cost of energy and the cost of waste disposal.
Index Keywords: Biogas--Production; Methane--Production; Organic Compounds--Fermentation; Waste Disposal--Digestion; Wastewater--Biological Treatment; Biomethanization; Digesters; Methanic Fermentation; Tannery Spent Liquors; Tannery Waste; Tanning

Authors: Jeday M.R., Steranka P., Le Goff P.
Title: Miomechanical machines: 3. Evaluation of the total cost for the storage of electricity
Affiliations: CNRS, France
Authors with affiliations: Jeday, M.R., CNRS, France; Steranka, P., CNRS, France; Le Goff, P., CNRS, France
Abstract: Calculations are made of the cost for the storage of electricity, using the equipment and process described. Calculations are carried out on eight previously variants of the system, which differ in output power (7.5 or 150 MW), storage autonomy (2 or 20 hours), and thermal conditions (″self-heated″ or ″with provisions of thermal exergy″). The attractiveness of each variant is expressed in three ways: the investment cost per unit of output power (Francs/kW), the investment cost per unit of energy stored (Francs/kWh), and the crude payback time on the additional investment, taking into account the rates of electricity from the national grid. The results of the analysis show that the best variants are almost equal economically to those of other processes (hydraulic pumping, air compression, etc.).
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Calculations; Fluids--Mixing; Liquids--Separation; Investment Costs; Mixomechanical Machines; Payback Time; Sodium Thiocyanate; Electricity

Title: Mixomechanical machines: 2. Examples of applications to the storage of electricity
Affiliations: Lab des Sciences du Genie Chemique, France
Authors with affiliations: Steranka, Paul, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chemique, France; Le Goff, Pierre, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chemique, France
Abstract: The system for the storage of energy described consists of a MVR machine, three storage reservoirs, and an inverse MVR machine. In the first ″self-heated″ system the heat given up by condensation-mixing of the solvent in the solution is used directly for evaporating pure solvent in an adjacent chamber. Three cases are dealt with numerically in which the thermal pinch of the evaporator-condenser is 6°C, 2°C, or zero. In a second system with external heat and cold sources the evaporator is heated with waste water at 30°C and the condenser is cooled with water at 4°C. The degree of recovery of mechanical energy is of the order of 0.4 to 0.6 in the self-heated system.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Energy Storage; Evaporators; Solvents--Evaporation; Inverse MVR; Mixomechanical Machines; Off-Peak Electricity Storage; Thermal Pinch; Electricity

Title: Performance of a conduction cooled Nd:glass zigzag slab laser
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Applied Physics Dept., Stanford University, Stanford, CA  94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reed, M.K., Applied Physics Dept., Stanford University, Stanford, CA  94305, United States; Byer, R.L., Applied Physics Dept., Stanford University, Stanford, CA  94305, United States
Abstract: The zigzag optical path slab geometry is an established method for reducing thermal focusing and birefringence in solid state lasers. By using the slab geometry, solid state laser systems can be scaled to higher repetition rates without sacrificing beam quality. Ndiglass is a laser material available in large sizes and with high energy-storage capacity. The goal of our slab laser design is a high peak and average power Ndiglass laser with a polarized, low-divergence output that can be focused on to solid targets to produce x-ray emitting high-temperature plasmas. We have built a Ndiglass laser with a slab of dimensions (325 × 64 × 6) mm3 pumped by four xenon flashlamps. The optical pumping and water cooling are controlled to produce a uniform temperature distribution within the Ndiglass slab and minimise thermo-optic distortions. The slab is cooled by conduction through a thin helium gap and sapphire windows placed over the slab faces to protect the slab's total internal reflection surfaces from contamination. The laser is used as an oscillator and multipass amplifier and was designed to operate in a Q-switched mode at 10 joules per pulse and 10 pulses per second. This paper will report the results of our tests of this laser's peak and average power performance. © 1989 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Optical pumping; Refractive index; Sapphire; Stained glass; Conduction cooled; Energy storage capacity; High-temperature plasmas; Multipass amplifiers; Sapphire windows; Solid-state laser systems; Total internal reflections; Zig-zag slab lasers; Solid state lasers

Abstract: We have constructed and installed a pressurized straw vertex chamber in the Mark III experiment at the SLAC e+e- storage ring SPEAR. The chamber consists of 12 concentric layers of straws, arrayed at radii between 5.4 cm and 13.0 cm from the interaction point. There are a total of 640 straws, each 8 mm in diameter and 84 cm long. We obtain an overall spatial resolution of 49 μm for argon-ethane ( 50% 50%) at 3 atm absolute using a cosmic ray data sample. The effects of gases on various chamber materials have been investigated. Chamber lifetime studies have been performed. A prototype chamber was used to study the resolution obtained with various gases. © 1989.

Abstract: An image sensor with storage capability is presented. Abstract: The quark charge asymmetry, summed over flavours, has been measured at centre of mass energies of 35 GeV and 44 GeV using the JADE detector sited on the electron-positron storage ring PETRA. The asymmetry is found to be consistent with the expectations of the standard model at both energies and enables a measurement of the product of the axial-vector coupling constant of the electron with the axial-vector coupling constants of the quarks, assuming the moduli of these latter to be flavour independent. This gives, with reasonable assumptions concerning the effects of {Mathematical expression} mixing, aeaq=-1.09±0.18±0.23 where the first error is statistical and the second systematic. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Clarke A., Ellis-Evans J.C., Sanders M.W., J. Holmes L.
Title: Patterns of energy storage in Pseudoboeckella poppei (Crustacea, copepoda) from two contrasting lakes on Signy Island, Antarctica
Affiliations: British Antarctic Survey, NERC, High Cross, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 OET, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke, A., British Antarctic Survey, NERC, High Cross, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 OET, United Kingdom; Ellis-Evans, J.C., British Antarctic Survey, NERC, High Cross, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 OET, United Kingdom; Sanders, M.W., British Antarctic Survey, NERC, High Cross, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 OET, United Kingdom; J. Holmes, L., British Antarctic Survey, NERC, High Cross, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 OET, United Kingdom
Abstract: The copepod Pseudoboeckella poppei (Daday) (Calanoida, Centropagidae) was sampled from Sombre and Heywood Lakes on Signy Island, Antarctica (60° S, 45° W) between January 1984 and March 1985. Sombre Lake is clear and oligotrophic with little phytoplankton and a bottom sediment low in organic content. By contrast Heywood Lake is turbid and mesotrophic; a substantial phytoplankton develops in summer and the bottom sediments are comparatively rich in organics. Both lakes freeze over for much of the year, forcing the copepods to adopt a benthic feeding strategy over winter. Adult Pseudoboeckella feed on phytoplankton when this is available, but also on detritus, diatoms and short algal filaments stirred up from the sediment. In Heywood Lake, male copepods show a smooth seasonal trend in lipid content with lipid being synthesised in early summer and utilised in late summer and winter. The summer increase in lipid content is associated with an increase in dry weight. Female lipid contents show evidence of two peaks of egg production. In Sombre Lake both male and female copepods increase in size during summer and show a wider range of lipid contents than in Heywood Lake; it is likely that this is due to the poorer winter feeding conditions which necessitate the synthesis of a much larger store of reserves during the summer. In contrast to marine calanoid copepods, lipid stores are exclusively triacylglycerol with no trace of wax ester. © 1989 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Antarctic lakes; copepod; lipid; phytoplankton; triacylglycerol; wax ester

Authors: Ou S.-c.S., Liou K.N., Liou W.J.
Title: The seasonal cycle of the global zonally averaged energy balance
Affiliations: Department of Meteorology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ou, S.-c.S., Department of Meteorology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, United States; Liou, K.N., Department of Meteorology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, United States; Liou, W.J., Department of Meteorology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
Abstract: The annual and seasonal cycle of the global zonally averaged storage and transport of moist static energy (MSE), the surface eddy flux of MSE, and the radiation budget at the top of the atmosphere (TOA) and surface are investigated in this paper. We use the GFDL (Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory) zonal mean data to compute the storage rate, divergence, and poleward flux of MSE. Surface eddy fluxes are determined based on an empirical formula developed from available climatological data. Radiative fluxes at the TOA and surface are computed from a radiation model. A number of significant features are illustrated by the present analysis in regard to the global annual and seasonal energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. The storage/release rate of MSE is greater in spring and autumn than in summer and winter. The rate of poleward transport of MSE has a maximum at ~40°N and ~35°S with a value of ~3 × 1015 W. In terms of the radiation budget, the persistent ITCZ minimum and subtropical maxima of the IR flux distribution are reproduced well in the radiation parameterization program. The incoming solar flux maximum shifts from ~20°N in spring to ~40°N in summer due to the poleward increase in the fraction of daytime. Finally, an examination of the global surface energy balance reveals that the surface net fluxes derived from parameterizations for eddy and radiative fluxes agree well with values derived from observations. This agreement appears to imply that on the global mean, the physical parameterizations used in the present study are reliable in modeling the seasonal surface flux components. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: energy balance; seasonal cycle; surface flux component; zonally averaged

Title: Storage-capacitor supplies for pulsed electromagnets (review)
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York

Authors with affiliations: Furman, E.G., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: Pulse systems are analyzed that supply inductive loads from capacitive storage devices that employ the most economic operating conditions: unipolar voltage for the capacitive storage device and unipolar current for the inductive load. Particular attention is given to problems of current switching in pulse supply systems from one group of rectifiers to another. Control and stabilization of the shape and energy of the magnetic field with periodic operation are examined. The principal energy relations for design of pulse supply systems are given.

Authors with affiliations: Arzubov, N.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Isaev, G.P., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Ryabchikov, A.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: A periodic-pulse ion accelerator based on low-current vacuum-arc discharge is described. It is shown that stable conditions for ion-beam generation are achieved for a residual gas pressure in the accelerator chamber of <10-5 torr and a pulse repetition rate of >5 Hz. The accelerator can generate beams of ions of conducting materials at an accelerating potential of up to 50 kV, an ion charge of 1-4, a beam current of 0.1-1 A, a pulse duration of 10-103 μsec, a pulse repetition frequency of up to 103 Hz, and a beam diameter of 0.2-20 cm.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Discharges; Electric Transformers, Pulse; Electronic Circuits, Trigger; Ion Beams - Production; Cathode Composition Effects; Ion Accelerators; Periodic Pulse Triggering; Periodic-Pulse Ion Accelerators; Trigger Electrodes; Vacuum Arc Discharges; Accelerators, Linear

Title: Thyristor ultrasonic generator
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Savchenko, I.S.; Tolpegov, A.V.
Abstract: A thyristor generator with an average power of 1.6 kW and an efficiency of ≥85% is described that produces single-period sinusoidal pulses with a low off-duty factor. The frequency of current oscillations in the load is 66 kHz, and the load impedance is 5 Ω. The pulse off-duty factor can be controlled by variation of the control-pulse repetition frequency.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electronic Circuits, Flip Flop; Logic Circuits, NAND; Thyristors - Applications; Ultrasonic Devices; Diodes; Inductance Coils; Pulse Repetition Frequency; Thyristor Generators; Transistors; Ultrasonic Generators; Pulse Generators

Title: Incremental-memory module for spectrometric data
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zhukov, A.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Myagkikh, A.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: An incremental-memory unit for composition of differential energy spectra of nuclear radiation is described. The use of read-only memory as an incrementing device reduces the number of components and simplifies the readout procedure. The memory unit is organized into 2048 channels of 12 bits each. The device is directly connected to the bus of microprocessor systems similar to the KR580. The maximum incrementation time with static CMOS memory is 3 μsec. The unit can be used as a multichannel counter.
Index Keywords: Data Conversion, Analog to Digital; Data Storage, Digital - Fixed; Electronic Circuits, Flip Flop; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Signal; Spectrometers - Computer Applications; Address Counters; Differential Energy Spectra; Incremental-Memory Modules; Incrementation Time; Multichannel Counters; Spectrometric Data Processing; Data Processing

Title: Methods of ice production for air-conditioning installations
Affiliations: C.A. du Toit & Partners, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Janse van Rensburg, Nico, C.A. du Toit & Partners, South Africa
Abstract: Ice storage systems are gaining popularity in South Africa as a result of the necessity for energy storage and economy of use. There are a number of these ice storage systems already in operation in South Africa, with several others in the design and construction stage. The article describes methods of ice production for the air-conditioning industry.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Energy Storage; Ice Harvesting Systems; Ice Particle Systems; Ice Storage Systems; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Ice

Authors: Nishimura Makoto, Bando Yoshiyuki, Kuraishi Michio, Hahne Erich W.P.
Title: Direct solar thermal energy storage using a semitransparent phase change material
Affiliations: Gifu Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishimura, Makoto, Gifu Univ, Japan; Bando, Yoshiyuki, Gifu Univ, Japan; Kuraishi, Michio, Gifu Univ, Japan; Hahne, Erich W.P., Gifu Univ, Japan
Abstract: For a passive solar thermal energy storage system, in which a plane layer of a semitransparent PCM (phase change material) is directly heated and melted by the sun, the effect of the optical thickness of the PCM on the temperature distribution and the efficiency of thermal energy storage was investigated. Paraffin wax was used as the PCM and a black dye was added to vary its absorption coefficient. Samples composed of the PCM layer and an insulating layer with an adiabatic rear side were tested using a solar simulator with constant incident radiation. A theoretical analysis was carried out by applying the concept of overall specific heat. The numerical results agreed fairly well with the experimental results within the range of the present experimental conditions thus validating the theoretical analysis. It became clear that the optical thickness of the PCM has a strong influence on the temperature distribution and the efficiency of thermal energy storage. It was found that a PCM with small optical thickness has greater efficiency of thermal energy storage because of inner (back) melting.
Index Keywords: Solar Radiation--Spectrum Analysis; Phase Change Material; Solar Thermal Energy Storage; Spectral Distribution; Energy Storage

Title: Rotary discharge machines prove ideal for reclaiming bulk materials from stockpiles
Authors with affiliations: Venzin, Raymund
Abstract: To enable all raw materials, including those with poor flow characteristics to be efficiently removed from bunkers and stockpiles, LOUISE GmbH of Germany has developed the discharge concept where the shape of the walls enables the pressure of the material to act directly on the bunker shelf. By using a rotating wheel with low profile arms and a patented curvature, these rotary discharge machines remove material from the pressure zone, thereby considerably reducing the possibility of materials-bridging. Also, as only a slow rotary speed is required, the discharge distance from the shelf to the main collector or belt conveyor can be kept to a minimum and there is no further compaction of the stored material, as can often occur with a plough reclaimer. A typical installation using LOUISE block model rotary discharge machines is the Superior Midwest Energy Terminal for coal trans-shipment, located in Wisconsin, USA. Six such machines arranged in two groups of three are under a large coal stockpile. The stockpile is needed for high capacity ship loading and for coal storage during the winter months when shipping is not possible. Each group of three machines discharge a combined total of 10,000 tonnes per hour onto a 2.4 metre wide reclaim belt conveyor leading to a ship loader.
Index Keywords: Coal Handling; Machinery; Portal Model; Rotary Discharge Machines; Materials Handling

Title: Cementitious binder from aluminium industries wastes
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India), Part T: Technician's Journal
Authors with affiliations: Chauhan, R.K.
Abstract: India produces today approx. 1.5 million ton of 'red mud' as a waste from aluminium industries. Apart from storage problems it is causing adverse environmental impacts and pollution to surrounding areas. Presently, the major portion of this waste remains unutilized. Earlier experiments were carried out to make building bricks from this material, but due to high manufacturing costs the project was not commercially viable. There is a shortage of building materials, particularly that of cement, which can be partly met by the use of red mud cement. This paper summarizes the investigation of a binder from red mud, which can be effectively utilized in the building industry. From the above analysis it is concluded that cementitious binder from red mud can be economically prepared (without the expenses of additional energy) similar to lime pozzolana mixes for masonary mortars, plasters and nonstructural concrete, ie. concrete for mass foundation, terracing, subflooring, etc. Further work to optimize the conditions and testing and evaluation as per relevant Indian Standards is in progress.
Index Keywords: Cement--Raw Materials; Red Mud; Aluminum Plants

Authors: De Angelis V., Orazi B.M., Santarossa L., Molaro G.L., Villalta D., Santini G.F., Doretto P., Cappelletti P.
Title: Time-related shape control modifications during erythrocyte storage with additive solutions

Abstract: To obtain more detailed information on the reversibility of shape alterations in blood bank stored erythrocytes, we have studied shape recovery after chemical crenation and rheological properties in 8 PAGGS-sorbitol preserved erythrocyte concentrates during a five week storage period under blood bank conditions. Our results show that red cell capability to regain a normal discoid shape after chemical crenation decreases during storage but is not lost over a five week period. Moreover there is a significant but weak correlation between red cell ATP content and both shape recovery capability and viscosity. Our results confirm suspicious that red cell shape perturbations following blood bank storage are widely reversible. Two different mechanisms may be involved in reducing shape recovery capability during storage, namely an ATP-dependent mechanism and an energy-independent one. The energy dependent mechanism may be preserved by the previous addition of solutions which maintain higher energy levels during storage. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Additive solutions; ATP; Erythrocyte; Shape control; Storage
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; sorbitol; blood storage; cell shape; erythrocyte; human; priority journal; Adenine; Adenosine Triphosphate; Blood Preservation; Blood Viscosity; Cell Separation; Dinitrobenzenes; Erythrocyte Aging; Erythrocyte Deformability; Glucose; Guanosine; Human; Phosphates; Sodium Chloride; Solutions; Sorbitol; Tosylphenylalanyl Chloromethyl Ketone

Title: Prospects for electron cooling of antiprotons at low energies
Affiliations: Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wolf, A., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Poth, H., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Schwab, W., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Seligmann, B., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Wörtge, M., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Haseroth, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hill, C.E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Vallet, J.-L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The motivation of using electron cooling in low-energy antiproton storage rings and the expected cooling performance are discussed. Results obtained recently, during the first operation of electron cooling in LEAR at CERN with a 50 MeV proton beam, are summarized, concerning in particular the equilibrium beam properties, the recombination between cooling electrons and cooled protons, and the deceleartion of acceleration of protons by friction in the electron beam. Conclusions are drawn for the formation of antihydrogen with the cooled antiproton beam, and for the deceleration of antiprotons to energies close to or below 1 MeV. © 1988 J.C. Baltzer A.G. Scientific Publishing Company.

Abstract: The Crystal Ball Collaboration has measured the energy spectrum of electrons from semileptonic B meson decays at the e+e- storage ring DORIS II. Branching ratios and weak mixing angles of the Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix are determined using several models for the hadronic matrix elements. We obtain the branching ratio for semileptonic. B decays to charmed states BR(B→evXc)=(11.7±0.4±1.0)%. Our result for the corresponding Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix element is |Vcb|=0.052±0.006. The model dependence of both results is included in the error. We have not observed semileptonic B decays to non-charmed mesons. Analyzing the measured electron spectrum above 2.4 GeV, where no b→c decays contribute, we find BR(B→evXu)/BR(B→evXc)<6.5% at the 90% confidence level. This corresponds to an upper limit |Vub/Vcb|<0.21. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

This paper describes its design and presents preliminary data from its first use at the CESR storage ring to isolate 120 ps X-ray pulses. © 1989.

Authors: Hinterberger F., Mayer-Kuckuk T., Prasuhn D.
Title: Monte Carlo simulations of thin internal targets in intermediate energy proton storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institut für Strahlen-, Kernphysik der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 14-16, D-5300 Bonn 1, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hinterberger, F., Institut für Strahlen-, Kernphysik der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 14-16, D-5300 Bonn 1, Germany; Mayer-Kuckuk, T., Institut für Strahlen-, Kernphysik der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 14-16, D-5300 Bonn 1, Germany; Prasuhn, D., Institut für Strahlen-, Kernphysik der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 14-16, D-5300 Bonn 1, Germany
Abstract: The feasibility of using thin internal targets in a recirculator mode without beam cooling is studied in a Monte Carlo simulation. The limiting factor is the growth of beam emittance and energy spread by small angle Coulomb scattering and energy loss straggling. The corresponding probability density distributions are derived for proton energies ≳ 1 GeV and target thicknesses ≲ 10-6 radiation length. It is very important to take the low intensity single scattering tails of those distributions into account as the beam distortions result from on the order of 106 passes through the target. The beam emittance, energy spread and survival probability are calculated as a function of turn number. Numerical results are obtained for a typical case (1.5 GeV kinetic energy protons incident on a 10 μg/cm2 thick carbon target) using the design parameters of the cooler synchrotron COSY. The calculations are compared with simple analytical estimates. They demonstrate that thin self-supporting internal targets can be used for experiments in storage rings above 1 GeV. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Statistics--Monte Carlo Methods; Physics--Nuclear; Probability; Protons; Beam Cooling; Accelerators

Title: Semiclassical spin diffusion model compared to quantum calculation of depolarization in electron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, 91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Buon, J., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: The Chao formalism of the semiclassical spin diffusion model is compared to the Hand-Skuja quantum calculation of equilibrium polarization in electron storage rings. This spin diffusion model, considering electron energy jumps as well as angular recoils, exactly reproduces the main quadratic terms in the quantum result which are responsible for beam depolarization. This comparison justifies the use of this semiclassical model to first order in the spin motion and shows its limitations. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Mathematical Techniques; Chao Formalism; Depolarization; Electron Spin Motion; Hand Skuja Quantum Calculation; Spin Diffusion Model; Electrons

Title: A universal classification of optimal undulator types and parameters for arbitrary storage ring environments
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 94403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 94403, United States
Abstract: Prevailing insertion device technology utilizes transverse magnetostatic (TM) field configurations with fixed periods to induce periodic deviations in relativistic charged particle trajectories. Such devices are invariably tuned by varying the field strength in the region encompassing the trajectory. As a consequence, the highest first harmonic frequencies generated by such structures are limited by their period lengths, while the generation of lower first harmonics quickly leads to the production of excessive amounts of out-of-band radiation. In the spontaneous emission regime, this superfluous power varies directly with the length of the device. In view of this, recent access to straight sections in high energy storage rings exceeding lengths of 100 m has raised the undesirable prospect of unmanageable power levels limiting the utility of such facilities. In this article a general study of a set of major types and classes of transverse insertion devices operating on storage rings of arbitrary energy and current is made and the results are represented with a set of universal performance curves. The graphical tabulation enables easy identification of optimum undulator types and operating parameters for any storage ring environment; in particular, optimal devices which do not suffer from excessive power generation on high energy storage rings are defined. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Fields; Insertion Devices; Synchrotron Radiation; Transverse Undulators; Undulators; Accelerators

Title: Current status of ion implantation for VLSI applications
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Electric Corp., LSI R, D Laboratory, 4-1 Mizuhara, Itami, 664, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akasaka, Y., Mitsubishi Electric Corp., LSI R, D Laboratory, 4-1 Mizuhara, Itami, 664, Japan
Abstract: The implanted dose in practical VLSI applications ranges from 1011 to 1016/cm2 with a medium energy from 30 to 150 keV, which is used for junction formation and threshold voltage control in both MOS and bipolar devices. Recently, new applications have been studied especially in the very low and very high (MeV) energy and/or the very high dose range which enables one to synthesize the materials. In this review paper, the following current topics of implantation applications for VLSI are discussed: 1) Shallow junction formation with very low energetic B+ or BF+2 implant or preamorphotization with Si+ or Ge+ ions; 2) MeV implant for retrograde well, buried layer, threshold voltage control in ROM, and gettering in advanced device structures; 3) High dose oxygen implant for SIMOX; and 4) Angle implant for trench structures or drain engineering of advanced transistors. The problems in ion implantation equipment as well as in the technologies are also discussed from the viewpoint of an equipment user for semiconductor manufacturing. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital - Fixed; Integrated Circuits, VLSI; Semiconductor Devices, MOS; Simox Structure; Threshold Voltage Control; Semiconductor Materials

Abstract: A compact pulsed XeCl laser is described that has a pulse energy of ≈1 J, an average power of 60 W, a pulse repetition frequency of up to 100 Hz, a divergence in two mutually perpendicular directions of 10-4-10-5 rad, an efficiency of ≈1%, and a life of >105 pulses without change of gas mixture.

Abstract: Ageing of rocket propellants refers to deterioration of mechanical and ballistic properties during prolonged storage. This paper reviews the literature available on the ageing characteristics of CMDB propellants with a view to examine the applicability of methods recommended for DBP and CP. Stress has been laid on the prediction of useful life of CMDB propellants.

Title: PSA's battery powered vehicles
Affiliations: EV Research Cent, France
Authors with affiliations: Peyriere, C.P., EV Research Cent, France
Abstract: The PSA group has been working for a number of years on the electric vehicle. Among the small vehicles, are a small car with four seats, the Peugeot 205, and a van, the Citroen C15. These two vehicles have the same compact electric propulsion making it possible to achieve the same volumes as in thermic versions. Among the larger vehicles, are delivery vans - Citroen C25 and Peugeot J5 and J9 as well as a minibus from J9. These vehicles have a simple electric transmission that keeps manufacturing costs low.

Abstract: The design and the mass production of the proportional wire chambers for the barrel part of the uranium-gas sampling hadron calorimeter of the L3 detector at the CERN Large Electron-Positron storage ring (LEP) are described. The chambers meet the specific requirements arising from the limited space available to the calorimeter, the radioactivity of uranium, and the physics criteria of good energy and position resolution for incident hadrons. The mass production techniques employed ensured that all of the 371664 chamber cells have uniform response (with 5% accuracy) to ionizing particles. Over 8000 chambers of the same design, in 53 different sizes, were manufactured and tested at the ITEP (Moscow), at the University of Michigan (Ann Arbor) and at the IHEP (Beijing). © 1989.
Index Keywords: Particle Detectors; Spectrum Analysis; Hadrons; Large Electron-Positron Storage Ring; Proportional Wire Chambers; Calorimeters

Title: Sizing a storage type water heating system
Affiliations: Diversified Engineering Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abdi Hejazi, S., Diversified Engineering Inc, United States
Abstract: Sizing of the storage type hot water heater is based upon estimation of the maximum hourly hot water demand and duration of the peak load. Almost all designers assume 70 percent of the stored water is usable regardless of the fact that the usability factor depends on several parameters, e.g., the entering cold water temperature, heat recovery rate and heat loss from storage tank and piping. In this article, the storage type heater is analyzed in the transient state to investigate the actual performance of the heater under various load conditions with respect to time. An equation is derived for the enthalpy of the stored water as a function of time and system parameters. The equation can be applied for proper sizing of new storage type heaters and for evaluation of the performance characteristics of existing heaters.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Hot Water Supply Systems; Mathematical Models; Domestic Hot Water Generation; Storage Type Water Heating Systems; Water Heaters

Title: DSEP AC electric van first vehicle test results
Affiliations: Eaton Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kelledes, William, Eaton Corp, United States
Abstract: The first DSEP AC test vehicle, designated TB-1, has completed its prescribed performance tests with satisfactory results. Nearly all performance goals have been reached or exceeded. Though they may well be the most ambitious ever imposed on an EV, this has been accomplished with first generation hardware. The proving grounds tests comprised acceleration, braking, coast down, range, tractive force, gradeability, and rough road tests. The general drivability tests comprised braking effectiveness, shift quality, response to driver inputs, subjective handling and ride quality assessments, curb climbing, blocked start and rolling start tests.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Vehicles--Electric Drive; AC Electric Vans; Dual Shaft Electric Propulsion; TB-1 Electric Vehicle; Storage Battery Vehicles

Affiliations: Ford Motor Co, United States

Abstract: Improvements in the range and performance, and reductions in the cost, will help accelerate market acceptance of electric vehicles. Advancing the technology of the electric propulsion system is the key to improving these important electric vehicle characteristics. The Ford Motor Company is well along on a research and development program, supported by the US Department of Energy's Electric and Hybrid Vehicles Program, to develop a second generation advanced electric vehicle propulsion system suitable for use in a small commercial van.

Abstract: The design of the ASP detector is described and details of the construction and performance of the lead-glass tracking calorimeter are presented. ASP, a nonmagnetic particle detector, was used at the PEP e+e- storage ring at s = 29 GeV to study low-multiplicity final states consisting primarily of electrons and photons. The design utilized extruded lead-glass bars to obtain a compact electromagnetic calorimeter with good energy resolution, tracking and pattern recognition capabilities. © 1989.
