Title: Energy from Solar Ponds: Control of the Green Flagellate Dunaliella Using Osmotic Shock of Dilution
Affiliations: Human Environmental Sciences Division, School of Applied Science and Technology, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Solmat Systems Ltd., Yavne, 70 650, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Dor, I., Human Environmental Sciences Division, School of Applied Science and Technology, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Doron, B., Solmat Systems Ltd., Yavne, 70 650, Israel
Abstract: ■ The study was conducted in the vicinity of the Dead Sea, Israel, in connection with an experimental solar pond being tested as a source of low-grade heat for conversion into electricity. The hypersaline water of such a pond, acting as a solar collector, must be maximally transparent to allow for efficient transport of light energy to the pond's deep storage layer. This research evaluates the extent of interference caused to the solar pond system by a halo-tolerant, unicellular flagellate Dunaliella, predicts blooms of this alga according to its environmental requirements, and provides means for control of its growth, The method proposed for control is based on osmotic shock of dilution applied to the algal population by a periodic rapid inflow of fresh water. As a result of biochemical, physiological, and morphological changes, Dunaliella cells sink and are destroyed when they reach the deep hot water layer. © 1989, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Algae--Control; Ecosystems--Control; Salts--Solutions; Water--Solutions; Dilution; Dunaliella; Green Flagellate; Osmotic Shock; Solar Radiation

Title: Testing the GM Griffon and G Van
Affiliations: TVA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Driggans, R.L., TVA, United States; Whitehead, G.D., TVA, United States
Abstract: In 1981, TVA and EPRI started a project for the performance testing of EVs. In developing the EPRI/TVA EV Test plan, experience from previous EV evaluation efforts was taken into consideration and existing test procedures were incorporated so that test results could be compared with data from other sources. Testing is performed at the TVA EVTF in Chattanooga, Tennessee. Since the emphasis of this project is on 'real-world' vehicle performance, testing is carried out primarily on urban roads and on the one-mile oval track located at the EVTF. Tests include constant speed 56 km/h, SAE J227/a C Cycle, and 'real-world' urban route driving range, maximum acceleration, top speed, braking distance, and gradeability (10 and 18 per cent grades). In addition to the physical parameters being measured (distance, speed, and time), electrical quantities such as power, energy (DC and AC), and charge (amperehours) are also determined.
Index Keywords: Automobiles--Electric; Electric Motors; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Vehicles--Electric Drive; Bedford Commercial Vehicles; Electric Vehicles; G Van; General Motors; Griffon Electric Van; Vans; Storage Battery Vehicles

Title: Cogeneration in combination with electric heat pumps
Affiliations: TNO, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Collet, Peter J., TNO, Netherlands
Abstract: The results of a theoretical cost analysis show that a combination of cogeneration and electric heat pump installations can yield significant economic benefits in comparison with cogeneration-only installations. This concerns the application of these installations in combination with thermal storage and results in higher energy cost savings due to increased cogeneration operation during the high-tariff, on-peak hours of the electricity demand. The electric heat pump operates during the low-tariff, off-peak hours with residual waste heat of the cogeneration process providing a high temperature heat source. When considered for heating-only purposes, the economic benefits of a combination of cogeneration and electric heat pump installations will be marginal and dependent on the electricity-to-fuel price ratio being relatively low. However, the economic benefits rise significantly when the heat pump and the thermal storage reservoir also are required for providing air conditioning cooling service.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation--Costs; Heat Pump Systems--Electric Power; Heating--Heat Storage; Electric Heat Pumps; Thermal Storage; Cogeneration Plants

Title: Canadian electrochemical power sources R & D for traction applications
Affiliations: Univ of Ottawa, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Adams, W.A., Univ of Ottawa, Canada; Morgan, J.H., Univ of Ottawa, Canada
Abstract: Industrial, academic and government research and development activities in Canada relating to electrochemical power sources for electric propulsion are reviewed. The electrochemical power sources being studied are evaluated against requirements for applications in electric propulsion. The state of development and potential for commercialization is assessed. Systems discussed include Al/air, rechargeable ambient temperature lithium, Li-Al/FeS, Na/S, rechargeable lithium polymer electrolyte, alkaline and solid polymer electrolyte fuel cells.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Traction; Electrochemistry; Fuel Cells; Propulsion--Electric Energy; Electric Propulsion; Electric Vehicles; Electrochemical Power Sources; Lithium Fuel Cells; Solid Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cells; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Vissarionov V.I., Elistratov V.V., Mukhammadiev M.M.
Title: Energy and hydrodynamic studies of turbine operating regimes of large pumping stations
Authors with affiliations: Vissarionov, V.I.; Elistratov, V.V.; Mukhammadiev, M.M.
Abstract: 1. The possibility of operation of axial-flow pump units in a turbine regime was proved experimentally. 2. To provide efficient operation of the PSs in pump and turbine regimes it is expedient to carry out double regulation by means of the runner blades and gate vanes. 3. The maximum efficiency values of the model of the PSs with D1=350 mm are 81.5% in the turbine regime and 86.0% in the pump regime. 4. The zones of the optimal efficiency values of the characteristics of the pump and turbine regime do not coincide by 20-25% with respect to the reduced rotational speed. For matching the operation of the unit in the optimal zones of both regimes it is recommended to use a static frequency changer. 5. The blade frequency, frequency of revolution, and low-frequency oscillations excited by the vortex line behind the runner are the dominant frequencies of the pressure fluctuation process in turbine regimes with maximum energies. © 1989 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Title: The ultrastructure of chemolithoautotrophic Gallionella ferruginea and Thiobacillus ferrooxidans as revealed by chemical fixation and freeze-etching
Affiliations: Institut für Mikrobiologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Konstantin-Uhde-Strasse 5, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lütters, S., Institut für Mikrobiologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Konstantin-Uhde-Strasse 5, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany; Hanert, H.H., Institut für Mikrobiologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Konstantin-Uhde-Strasse 5, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany
Abstract: By using sodium thioglycolate to dissolve the high amount of excreted stalk material in axenic cultures of the chemolithoautotrophic iron bacterium Gallionella ferruginea, the ultrastructure of Gallionella cells from pure cell suspensions could be studied without any loss of viability or disturbance by dense ferric stalk fibers, and compared with Thiobacillus ferrooxidans, also grown chemolithoautotrophically with ferrous iron as energy source. Both organisms were chemically fixed or freeze-etched. Particular structural differences between these iron-bacteria could be ascertained. G. ferruginea possesses intracytoplasmic membranes and soluble d-ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate-carboxylase, whereas T. ferrooxidans contains carboxysomes but no intracytoplasmic membranes; Gallionella forms poly-β-hydroxybutyrate and glycogen as storage material; T. ferrooxidans produces only glycogen. Both organisms also differ from each other with respect to the freeze fracture behaviour of the cell envelope layers. Whereas the cells of T. ferrooxidans exhibit a characteristic double cleavage, exposing the plasmic fracture face and exoplasmic fracture face of the outer membrane and cytoplasmic membrane, the exceptionally thin multilayered cell envelope of G. ferruginea revealed a particularly intimate association between the layers, resulting in a visualisation of the supramolecular organisation of only the inner fracture face of the cytoplasmic membrane. The results are discussed predominantly in relation to the extremely distinct environments of both organisms. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Carboxysomes; Cell wall organization; Chemolithoautotrophy; Freeze-etching; Gallionella ferruginea; Intracytoplasmic membranes; Iron bacteria; Thiobacillus ferrooxidans; Ultrastructure

Authors: Nowak M.J., Speigel D., Hotta S., Heeger A.J., Pincus P.A.
Title: Charge storage on a conducting polymer in solution
Affiliations: Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nowak, M.J., Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Speigel, D., Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Hotta, S., Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Heeger, A.J., Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Pincus, P.A., Institute for Polymers, Organic Solids University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Abstract: Magnetic and optical studies of poly(3-hexylthienylene) doped in solution with NO+PF6- in both choloroform and in the more polar solvent methylene chloride indicate a relatively small difference in the energy of polarons versus biplarons, and imply that the weak effective electron-electron Coulomb repulsion can be controlled by varying the solvent and/or the polymer concentration. Even though bipolarons are found to have a lower creation energy than a pair of polarons, entropy favors polarons at dilute concentrations. As a result, we have observed unambiguous magnetic and optical signatures characteristic of polarons in P3HT in CH2Cl2 at the lowest doping levels. The relative fraction of polarons and bipolarons has been analyzed in the context of various proposed statistical models. A theoretical model is developed to include the effect (in such solutions) of ionic screening on the effective Coulomb interaction. This model is tested by adding salt to a dilute solution of doped polymer. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Properties; Optical Properties; Solutions; Bipolarons; Conjugated Polymers; Synthetic Metals; Polymers

Abstract: This paper gives an overview of soft x-ray monochromators for synchrotron radiation. Showing some typical examples for different energy regions and applications, general design criteria are explained, and specific problems, limitations and future developments using undulator radiation from third generation storage rings are addressed. Authors: Schmatz D.M., Baginsky W.F., Turner M.J.
Title: Evidence for and characterization of a mannitol cycle in Eimeria tenella
Affiliations: Department of Biochemical Parasitology, Merck Sharp and Dohme Research Laboratories, Rahway, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schmatz, D.M., Department of Biochemical Parasitology, Merck Sharp and Dohme Research Laboratories, Rahway, NJ, United States; Baginsky, W.F., Department of Biochemical Parasitology, Merck Sharp and Dohme Research Laboratories, Rahway, NJ, United States; Turner, M.J., Department of Biochemical Parasitology, Merck Sharp and Dohme Research Laboratories, Rahway, NJ, United States
Abstract: Recently, it was found that large quantities of mannitol are present in unsporulated oocysts of the protozoan parasite Eimeria tenella and that these levels diminish during maturation (sporulation) [1]. Investigations into the metabolic role of mannitol have led to the discovery that a mannitol cycle is present in this parasite. Prior to these studies the mannitol cycle was found exclusively in fungi. The parasite cycle is similar to that in the fungi although there are distinct differences in coenzyme requirements. The enzymes involved in the parasite pathway include mannitol-1-phosphate dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.17), mannitol-1-phosphatase (EC 3.1.3.22), mannitol dehydrogenase (EC 1.1.1.67), and hexokinase (EC 2.7.1.1). Kinetic studies were conducted to determine the Km and specific activities of these enzymes at both ambient temperature (where sporulation occurs) and the chicken's body temperature (41°C). The data suggest that mannitol is produced during oocyst formation in the chicken gut and accumulated as an energy reserve for sporulation. The apparent lack of mannitol kinase in the organism and the Km values for the dehydrogenases in the reverse direction all indicate that the cycle only proceeds in one direction. In addition to serving as an energy storage system the cycle may also function as an electron 'sink' for the parasite which must survive in the anaerobic environment of the gut. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Carbohydrate metabolism; Eimeria tenella; Hexokinase; Mannitol; Mannitol cycle; Mannitol dehydrogenase; Mannitol-1-phosphatase; Mannitol-1-phosphate dehydrogenase; Polyols

Title: Avoiding the integral storage bottleneck in LCAO calculations of electron correlation
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Supercomputer Institute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sæbø, S., Department of Chemistry, Supercomputer Institute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Almlöf, J., Department of Chemistry, Supercomputer Institute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: We propose a method for obtaining electron-repulsion integrals over a molecular-orbital basis without any explicit four-index transformation involving input/output. The approach is in the spirit of our direct SCF scheme in that it uses reevaluation of atomic integrals to allow for calculations that would otherwise be prohibited by storage limitations with conventional techniques. We present correlation energy calculations with up to 318 basis functions using the proposed approach. © 1989.

Title: Acoustic wavefield propagation using paraxial extrapolators
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd Conference on Hypercube Concurrent Computers and Applications: Architecture, Software, Computer Systems, and General Issues, C3P 1988
Affiliations: Seismological Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Graves, R.W., Seismological Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91125, United States; Clayton, R.W., Seismological Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91125, United States
Abstract: Modeling by paraxial extrapolators is applicable to wave propagation problems in which most of the energy is traveling within a restricted angular cone about a principle axis of the problem. Frequency domain finite-difference solutions are readily generated by using this technique. Input models can be described either by specifying velocities or appropriate media parameters on a two or three dimensional grid of points. For heterogeneous models, transmission and reflection coefficients are determined at structural boundaries within the media. The direct forward scattered waves sre modeled with a single pass of the extrapolator operator in the paraxial direction for each frequency. The first-order back scattered energy can then be modeled by extrapolation (in the opposite direction) of the reflected field determined on the first pass. Higher order scattering can be included by sweeping through the model with more passes. The chief advantages of the paraxial approach are 1) active storage is reduced by one dimension as compared to solutions which must track both upgoing and down-going waves simultaneously, thus even realistic three dimensional problems can fit on today's computers, 2) the decomposition in frequency allows the technique to be implemented on highly parallel machines such the hypercube, 3) attenuation can be modeled as an arbitrary function of frequency, and 4) only a small number of frequencies are needed to produce movie-like time slices. By using this method a wide range of seismological problems can be addressed, including strong motion analysis of waves in three-dimensional basins, the modeling of VSP reflection data, and the analysis of whole earth problems such as scattering at the core-mantle boundary or the effect of tectonic boundaries on long-period wave propagation. © ACM 1988.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Forward scattering; Frequency domain analysis; Geometry; Wave propagation; Finite-difference solution; Heterogeneous models; Higher-order scattering; Three-dimensional grids; Three-dimensional problems; Transmission and reflection coefficient; Wave propagation problems; Wavefield propagation; Data flow analysis

Title: Water-Rock Interaction WRI-6. Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium held at Malvern, U.K., on August 3-8, 1989.
Authors with affiliations: Miles, D.L.
Abstract: The main conference themes were mass transfer modelling and reaction kinetics, metamorphic and hydrothermal fluid reactions, the geochemistry of the solution/solid interface water/rock interaction (trace constituents), geochemical cycles, and geochemistry of energy and natural resources. Applications to water resource, water quality problems, water pollution, the oil and gas industry and radioactive waste storage are examined.

Title: The instrument INELAX for very high energy resolution and first direct measurements of phonon dispersion curves with X-Rays
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sektion Physik Universität, Miinchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Burkel, E., Sektion Physik Universität, Miinchen, Germany
Abstract: Very high energy resolution of x -rays can be achieved by extreme backreflection ( Bragg angle close to 90° ) from perfect crystals. This technique is used for the instrument INELAX, recently installed at the storage ring of HASYLAB, Hamburg. Inelastic scattering of 13.8 keI x -rays can be performed with the high energy resolution of ΔE = (17 ± 2) meV. First direct measurements of phonon dispersion curves with x -rays were carried out using single crystals of Be and a diamond. The longitudinal phonons were observed in the acoustic and optical range. © 1989 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Title: Adsorbent-enhanced methane storage for alternate fuel powered vehicles
Affiliations: Union Carbide Industrial Gases Inc., Linde Division; UCAR Carbon Co. Inc., Subsidiary of Union Carbide Corporation; National Fuel Gas Corporation
Authors with affiliations: Bevier, W.E., Union Carbide Industrial Gases Inc., Linde Division; Mullhaupt, J.T., Union Carbide Industrial Gases Inc., Linde Division; Notaro, F., Union Carbide Industrial Gases Inc., Linde Division; Lewis, I.C., UCAR Carbon Co. Inc., Subsidiary of Union Carbide Corporation; Coleman, R.E., National Fuel Gas Corporation
Abstract: The Adsorbent Enhanced Methane Storage program started in 1983 to determine if Compressed Natural Gas could be stored more effectively than by the standard high pressure tank, it was initiated by the New York Gas Group and the New York Energy Research and Development Authority and has been joined by the Gas Research Institute. The work has been conducted by two Divisions of Union Carbide Corporation. The program determined that activated carbon adsorbent has the greatest methane storage potential of the known adsorbents and identified five critical issues to be addressed in the development program: Contamination Heat Management Adsorbent Capacity Encapsulation Safety Four program phases have identified and solved some of the critical issues. © Copyright 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Choudhury P., Dawson G.E., Eastham A.R., John V.I., Parker J.H.
Title: Inductive power transfer to highway vehicles
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Choudhury, P., Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada; Dawson, G.E., Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada; Eastham, A.R., Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada; John, V.I., Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada; Parker, J.H., Dept. of Electrical Engrg., Queen's Univ., Kingston, ON, Canada
Abstract: This paper begins with a discussion of the problems caused by congestion and pollution on the roads of major urban areas in North America, and some of the ways and means of alleviating an impending crisis situation are reviewed. It is argued that electric vehicles can play a role. Recognizing the limitations of electrochemical energy storage technology, it is noted that non-contact energy transfer to automobiles would be advantageous. An open E-core transformer, as used in the Santa Barbara bus project is considered to be a favourable transfer mechanism. A spread-sheet based design study is reported. This approach was validated by comparing experimental results from a 75% scale model of the energy transfer device and finite element numerical analysis. A preferred design is presented, and is shown to be technically feasible by meeting a set of reasonable specifications and guidelines for automobiles. The problems are shown to be associated with high frequency excitation and the large (5 cm) airgap, requiring high magnetizing current for effective power transfer. Some means of improving the design are suggested. © Copyright 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Automobiles; Energy transfer; Highway engineering; Inductive power transmission; Crisis situations; E-core transformers; Electrochemical energy storage; Finite element numerical analysis; High-frequency excitation; Inductive power transfer; Magnetizing current; Transfer mechanisms; Finite element method

Authors: Adlhart O.J., Rosso Jr. M.J., Marmolejo J.
Title: A fuel cell energy storage system concept for the space station freedom extravehicular mobility unit
Affiliations: Ergenics Power Systems, Inc.; NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adlhart, O.J., Ergenics Power Systems, Inc.; Rosso Jr., M.J., Ergenics Power Systems, Inc.; Marmolejo, J., NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, United States
Abstract: The paper gives an update on an advanced development effort carried out under NASA Johnson Space Center (NASA/JSC) NAS 9-17775 by Ergenics Power Systems, Inc. (EPSI). The work was initiated in April 1987 to design and build a Fuel Cell Energy Storage System (FCESS) bench-test unit for the Space Station Freedom Extravehicular Mobility Unit (EMU). Fueled by oxygen and hydride stored hydrogen, the FCESS is being considered as an alternative to the EMU zinc-silver oxide battery. Superior cycle life and quick recharge are its main attributes. Design and performance of a non-venting 28V, 34 Ahr system with 7 amp rating are discussed. The FCESS is comprised of a 32-cell proton exchange membrane (PEM) stack, a metal hydride storage vessel and a control subsystem. The stack design incorporates passive product-water removal and thermal integration with the hydride vessel. The hydride vessel stores enough fuel for 5 hours. The control subsystem provides reactant pressure and flow regulation, automatic startup, shutdown and electronic protection against malfunctioning Copyright © 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Copyrights; Energy storage; Fuel storage; Hydrides; NASA; Product design; Silver oxides; Space platforms; Space stations; Control subsystems; Electronic protection; Energy storage systems; Extravehicular mobility units; Johnson Space Center; Metal hydride storage; Proton-exchange membrane; Thermal integration; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC)

Title: Electric vehicle design considerations for cold weather operation
Affiliations: Electrochemical Science and Technology Centre, University of Ottawa, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Adams, W.A., Electrochemical Science and Technology Centre, University of Ottawa, Canada; Song, G.S., Electrochemical Science and Technology Centre, University of Ottawa, Canada
Abstract: Successful operation of electric vehicles under Canadian conditions requires consideration of the effect of low temperature, not only on the propulsion and energy storage systems, but on the energy required for passenger heating and window defrosting. Thermal management of the propulsion battery is a primary consideration, but other factors such as the protection of the electric systems from road salt are essential. Several approaches to passenger heating and window defrosting are being studied and some systems evaluated in the test fleet. Options based on liquid fuel or all-electric methods will be discussed. The environmental advantages of EVs for winter use are considerable. EVs operating under these winter conditions, i.e., low-speed in congested traffic due to snow and ice and frequent winter accidents, have no toxic gaseous emissions which is particularly good in comparison to ICE vehicles. © Copyright 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Defrosting; Electric vehicles; Propulsion; Temperature; Cold weather; Congested traffic; Electric systems; Energy storage systems; Low temperatures; Snow and ice; Vehicle design; Winter conditions; Accidents

Title: Future vehicles will run with solar energy
Affiliations: Tokyo Denki Univ., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujinaka, M., Tokyo Denki Univ., Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The practical usable solar electric vehicle (EV) was developed, and road test of this system for weather condition were conducted on city roads in Tokyo. In this system, solar energy is converted into electric energy with two types of the photovoltaic (solar) cell, then the output is stored in the storage battery mounted on the EV. This battery-stored electricity is used in driving the motor and propelling the EV. This report describes results of these tests. The main solar cells (=0.7kWp), made of polycrystalline Si, are mounted on the roof of a private house. The sub-solar cells (=80Wp), made of amorphous or single crystal Si, are mounted on the EV. © Copyright 1989 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Beauce A., Fabriol H., Le Masne D.
Title: Seismicity induced during a hydraulic stimulation at the soultz-sous-forets HDR geothermal energy project
Affiliations: Bureau de Recherches Geologiques et Minieres, Institut Mixte de Recherches Geothermiques, France
Authors with affiliations: Beauce, A., Bureau de Recherches Geologiques et Minieres, Institut Mixte de Recherches Geothermiques, France; Fabriol, H., Bureau de Recherches Geologiques et Minieres, Institut Mixte de Recherches Geothermiques, France; Le Masne, D., Bureau de Recherches Geologiques et Minieres, Institut Mixte de Recherches Geothermiques, France
Abstract: During the first phase of the French-German Hot Dry Rock geothermal energy project of Soultz/Forets in Alsace (sponsored by the European Community), a hydraulic stimulation test has been undertaken at the bottom (T = 140oC)ofthe 2000 m deep GPK1 borehole. Important faults dipping 607deg; West affect the thick (1400 m) sedimentary cover and the granitic horst underneath. The seismic network, set up by IMRG to monitor the microseismicity induced in the granite by the stimulation, is made up of three-directional probes (especially designed to stand the rough temperature and corrosion conditions) cemented at the bottom of three observation boreholes. Once the seismic signals digitized in the computing system, an automatic detection and storage of the seismic events is performed in real time. To get a precise idea of the tectonic context at depth, a VSP seismic survey has been carried out. During the 3-day stimulation experiment, despite a rather low water flow-rate (3.3 1/s), 58 seismic events have been recorded on the network. Results show a general trend of magnitudes decreasing with time, and a spectral content within the frequency range 50-250 Hz for geophones sited 700 to 1200 m away from the stimulated zone. Seismic activity starts 2 hours after the beginning of the stimulation. Two main focal zones are concerned: one close to the stimulated borehole and the other one some 100 meters West of it, but only the remote focal zone remains active during the whole survey. © 1989 Society of Exploration Geophysicists. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Boreholes; Corrosion; Flow of water; Geothermal energy; Induced Seismicity; Seismic waves; Surveys; Automatic Detection; Computing system; European community; Frequency ranges; Hydraulic stimulations; Sedimentary covers; Seismic networks; Spectral content; Seismic prospecting

Authors: Somerville W.M., Grylls W., Nicholson G.D., Watson G.R., Jepson M.D.
Title: Foula wind-pump-hydro system - the development of a control strategy.
Authors with affiliations: Somerville, W.M.; Grylls, W.; Nicholson, G.D.; Watson, G.R.; Jepson, M.D.
Abstract: The control strategy for a wind power system with microhydro input and a diesel backup supply for the island of Foula, in the Shetlands group, is described. The microhydro scheme can also act as a pumped storage system to absorb surplus wind energy. The wind and hydrogenerators are to be remotely controlled from the supervisory controller, using a telephone cable link. Progress with the project is reviewed.

Title: Development and construction of a modular system for an autonomous electrical power supply on the Irish Island of Cape Clear.
Authors with affiliations: Grebe, R.; Cramer, G.
Abstract: The development of a modular wind/diesel/battery system for power supply in remote regions is described. The supply system consisted of two wind energy converters, each with a nominal power of 30 kW, a diesel generator unit with a nominal power of 72 kW, and a battery storage array with a capacity of 100 kWh. The installation and testing of the system at Cape Clear Island, Ireland, are described.

Abstract: The use of biogas in Europe has become increasingly important over the past few years: industrial wastewaters, cattle manures, sewage sludges, urban wastes, crop residues, algae and aquatic biomass are used increasingly for the production of biogas and for energy and environmental purposes. This book is a record of a study through the National Energy Research and Development Programme, undertaken at the Catholic University of Louvain, Belgium. Includes a broad overview of the ongoing use of biogas in Europe, summarising available data on storage, purification and engines using biogas, and drawing some conclusions concerning the technical and economic viability of the processes. Problems related to the use of biogas and recommendations for the future are also outlined. -from Publisher

Authors: Grassi G., Pirrwitz D., Zibetta H.
Title: Energy from biomass 4. Proceedings of the third contractors' meeting, Paestum, May 1988
Source title: Energy from biomass 4. Proceedings of the third contractors' meeting, Paestum, May 1988
Affiliations: Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Grassi, G., Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium, Belgium; Pirrwitz, D., Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium, Belgium; Zibetta, H., Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium, Belgium
Abstract: The Commission of the European Communities (Directorate-General Science, Research and Development-DG XII) has implemented a four-year (1985-1988) non-nuclear energy R&D programme for the development of renewable energy sources and, in particular, biomass. This book provides an updated overview of the Commission's activity in this sector. Descriptions of the research programmes and results in the following specific areas were presented at this contractor's meeting: production of biomass for energy and improvement of productivity; harvesting, transport, storage and drying of biomass; biochemical conversion of biomass (ethanol fuels, basic studies on biological conversion); thermochemical conversion of biomass (liquefaction, gasification, pyrolysis). At the end of the meeting there was a general discussion concerning the state of the art in six particular fields of interest: forestry, agricultural crops, harvesting, biological conversion, pyrolysis and gasification. -from Publisher

Title: Archaeological method and theory. Volume 1
Affiliations: Dept of Anthropology, Univ of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schiffer, M.B., Dept of Anthropology, Univ of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA, United States
Abstract: Provides a wide range of articles on recent developments in the methodology and theory of archaeology. The combination of topical updates, case studies, and topical syntheses are sufficiently flexible formats to enable archaeologists to monitor important advances in method and theory. The volume gathers six major papers on a variety of subjects: undirected variation and Darwinian explanation of cultural change; architecture and energy, an evolutionary perspective; domestic storage behavior in Mesoamerica, an ethnoarchaeological approach; geographic information systems in regional archaeological research and data management; and stability or instability, the role of diffusion in trace element studies. -from Publisher

Abstract: The conference was cosponsored by the US Department of Energy and Atomic Energy of Canada Limited. The volume contains 31 invited and contributed presentations, introductory remarks from DOE, a transcript of the general discussion session, and an author index. All papers have been reviewed and edited post-conference. Arrangement is in session theme: the role of statistical methods in the nuclear waste repository performance assessment plans of several waste disposal programmes; sensitivity and uncertainty methods for large computer codes; stochastic hydrology; statistical methods for modelling flow and transport in fractured media; geostatistical methods; the use of subjective information to supplement hard data in performance assessment studies. Authors: Böttcher M., Gernhard K., Lange W., Neumann B.
Title: Intrafollikuläre Stoffwechselveränderungen am Ovar von Schlachtrindern
Affiliations: Sektion Tierproduktion der, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock; Chirurgische Universitätsklinik, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock
Authors with affiliations: Böttcher, M., Sektion Tierproduktion der, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock; Gernhard, K., Sektion Tierproduktion der, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock; Lange, W., Sektion Tierproduktion der, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock; Neumann, B., Chirurgische Universitätsklinik, Wilhelm-Pieck-Universität, Rostock
Abstract: In der vorliegenden Arbeit werden Untersuchungen zur Stoffwechselaktivität in Antralfollikeln (< 10 mm Durchmesser) des exstirpierten Ovars von Schlachtrindern vorgestellt. Die Messungen wurden zum Zeitpunkt der Ovargewinnung (0) sowie nach Aufbewahrung der Organe über 1, 2 und 3 h in Dulbecco‐Medium durchgeführt. Als Stoffwechselparameter wurden Glukosegehalt und pH‐Wert gewählt. Der Glukosegehalt sinkt von 3,28 ± 0,67 mmol/lbei t0 auf 0,16 ± 0,22 mmol/l nach 3 h Aufbewahrung der Ovarien im Dulbecco‐Medium. Gleichermaßen verringert sich der pH‐Wert von 6,91 ± 0,11 auf 6,58 ± 0,26. Im Follikel des exstirpierten Ovars wird die Energiequelle schnell verbraucht, und die Pufferkapazität ist erschöpft. Daraus resultieren verschlechterte Lebensbedingungen für die Oozyte bereits kurze Zeit nach der Ovargewinnung. Für weitere In‐vitro‐Manipulationen scheint eine frühzeitige Gewinnung von Oozyten aus den Follikeln unmittelbar nach der Ovarentnahme aus dem Schlachttier erforderlich. Metabolic changes in follicles on ovaries of slaughtered cattle The present study deals with the metabolism of antral follicles of over 10 mm diameter on the ovary at the time of ovary removal (t0) and after ovary storage for 1, 2, and 3 h in Dulbecco medium. Glucose content and pH were used as parameters to characterize metabolic status. The glucose content decreased from 3,28 ± 0,67 mmolll at t0 to 0,16 ± 0,22 mmol/l after 3 h storage in Dulbecco medium. Similarly, the pH dropped from 6,91 ± 0,11 to 6,58 ± 0,16. The energy resources of th ovary are rapidly depleted after removal and its buffer capacity exhausted. Consequently, conditions permitting oocyte survival deteriorate rapidly. To permit further in‐vitro manipulations, it seems necessary to recover oocytes from the follicles immediately after removing ovaries from slaughtered cattle. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: cattle; follicle; metabolism; ovary

Authors: Waberski D., Weitze K.F., Rath D., Sallmann H.P.
Title: Wirkung von bovinem Serumalbumin und Zwitterionenpuffer auf flüssigkonservierten Ebersamen
Affiliations: Klinik Für Andrologie Und Besamung Der Haustiere, Institut Für Physiologische Chemie, Tierärztlic Hen Hochschule Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Waberski, D., Klinik Für Andrologie Und Besamung Der Haustiere, Institut Für Physiologische Chemie, Tierärztlic Hen Hochschule Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Weitze, K.F., Klinik Für Andrologie Und Besamung Der Haustiere, Institut Für Physiologische Chemie, Tierärztlic Hen Hochschule Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Rath, D., Klinik Für Andrologie Und Besamung Der Haustiere, Institut Für Physiologische Chemie, Tierärztlic Hen Hochschule Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Sallmann, H.P., Klinik Für Andrologie Und Besamung Der Haustiere, Institut Für Physiologische Chemie, Tierärztlic Hen Hochschule Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: An 33 Ejakulaten von sieben Ebern wurden Verdünnermedien mit fünf ver‐schiedenen bovinen Serumalbumin (BSA)‐Präparationen, porcinem Serumalbumin (PSA) und Hühnereialbumin sowie den Zwitterionenpuffern MOPS und HEPES hin‐sichtlich ihrer Auswirkungauf die Motilität und Akrosomintegrität flüssigkonservierter Eberspermien vergleichend getestet. Die im split‐sample Verfahren verdünnten Samen‐proben wurden einem Haltbarkeitstest über 144 Stunden bei + 15° C und anschlieβend einem achtstündigen Thermoresistenztest bei + 38°C unterworfen. Die festgestellte mo‐tilitätsstimulierende und ‐konservierende BSA‐Wirkung scheint unabhängig von den Kontaminanten in kommerziellen BSA‐Präparationen zu sein. Ein möglicher Einfluβ des BSA ‘S und des PSA ‘s auf den anaeroben Energiestoffwechsel der Ebersamenzellen wird diskutiert. MOPS und HEPES stellen geeignete Pufferkomponenten in BSA‐halti‐gen Verdünnermedien zur Langzeitkonservierung flüssigverdünnter Eberejakulate dar. Effect of bovine serumalbumin und zwitterionic buffers on stored liquid boar semen Based on 33 ejaculates from seven boars dilution media containing five different types of bovine serumalbumin (BSA), porcine serumalbumin (PSA) and ovalbumin as well as the zwitterionic buffers MOPS and HEPES were investigated for their effects on sperm motility and acrosome integrity of stored liquid boar semen. The semen diluted by split sample procedure was subjected to a storage test for 144 hours at 15°C followed by a thermoresistance test up to 8 hours at 38°C. A motility stimulating and ‐conservating effect was confirmed which seems not to be influenced by contaminants present in commercial BSA‐preparations. The influence of BSA and PSA on the anaerobic energy metabolism of boar spermatozoa is discussed. MOPS and HEPES are effective buffers in dilution media containing BSA used for longterm preservation of liquid boar semen. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: boar semen; bovine serumalbumin; storage

Title: Optimal design of a rotating bar for kinetic energy storage
Source title: Journal of Mechanical Design, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion—Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Berger, M., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion—Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Porat, I., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion—Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: A thin homogeneous rotating bar of variable width is considered for the purpose of storing kinetic energy. The objective of the design is to find the shape of the bar for which, in the presence of constraints on the geometry and strength of the bar, the Specific Kinetic Energy (SKE) is maximal. An upper bound for the SKE of a finite length bar is derived and a discrete formulation is presented by which an approximate optimal profile for arbitrary design parameters and rotational speeds can be obtained numerically. Applying a parametric study, in which optimal designs for a sequence of rotational speeds were observed, a general configuration of the exact optimal profile was concluded. The parametric study reveals the existence of three speed intervals, each characterized by a common type of optimal design. The optimal SKE corresponding to the ultimate rotational speed reaches a value very close to the theoretical upper bound, namely, that of a thin ring. The model gives insight into the nature of optimal designs and serves as a simple and rapid computational tool for finding the optimal profile for arbitrary bar parameters and rotational speeds. © 1989 by ASME.

Abstract: 1,2-Dimetoxy ethane (DME) has produced 2,3-dimetoxyoxirane [1] of low concentration by autoxidation-reaction during storage for six month. The ESR spectra which can be assigned to 2, 3-dimethoxyoxirane anion radical [1] have been obtained by electrochemical reduction of the DME containing (1) at -50°Q, as shown in Fig. 2. The observed hyperfine splitting constants (hfsc) were nicely supported by molecular orbital (MO) calculation [1]. The temperature dependence of hfsc of [1] (Table 1, Fig. 2) was discussed on the basis of cis and trans formations. The kinetic energy (ΔE) containing enthalpy-fluctuation due to the two inversions is estimated to be — 9.29 kJ/mol from Fig. 3. © 1989, The Chemical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Tanigawa K., Kawaguchi H.F.M., Kato Y.
Title: A Case of Type la Glycogen Storage Disease Complicated by Diabetes Mellitus: Studies of Carbohydrate and Ketone Body Metabolism and Insulin Secretion
Source title: Journal of the Japan Diabetes Society
Affiliations: First Department of Internal Medicine, Shimane Medical University, Shimane, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanigawa, K., First Department of Internal Medicine, Shimane Medical University, Shimane, Japan; Kawaguchi, H.F.M., First Department of Internal Medicine, Shimane Medical University, Shimane, Japan; Kato, Y., First Department of Internal Medicine, Shimane Medical University, Shimane, Japan
Abstract: We examined the kinetics of ketone bodies and blood glucose in a 32-year-old woman, who suffered from type la glycogen storage disease complicated by diabetes mellitus. A fasting test was carried out for 48 hours. Blood glucose and insulin levels were found to be markedly decreased 12 hours after the commencement of testing. Subsequently, ketone body levels gradually increased throughout the remainder of the test period. Ketone bodies as well as blood glucose were found to be elevated 30 and 60 min after administration of glucose. An insulin tolerance test (0.2 U/kg) demonstrated that the lowest levels of both ketone bodies and glucose occurred at 90 min. A steep rebound phenomenon for ketone bodies was observed from 150 min to 240 min, while blood glucose was not restored to its basal value even 240 min later. Thus, the profound biochemical change seen in this case was hyperketonemia. Ketone bodies appear to be efficiently utilized for energy metabolism when blood glucose is lowerd. The pathogenesis as complicated by diabetes mellitus remains unclear. © 1989, THE JAPAN DIABETES SOCIETY. All rights reserved.

Authors: Takahashi H., Obata E., Takeuchi T., Tanaka T.
Title: Simulation of a Maximum Storage Amount of Coal for Preventing Spontaneous Combustion and Degradation in Quality
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Muroran Institute of Technology, 27-1, Mizumoto-cho, Muroranshi, 050, Japan; Department of Chemical Process Engineering, Hokkaido University, Nishi, 8-chome, Kita-13-jo, Kita-ku, Sapporo-shi, 060, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, H., Department of Chemical Engineering, Muroran Institute of Technology, 27-1, Mizumoto-cho, Muroranshi, 050, Japan; Obata, E., Department of Chemical Engineering, Muroran Institute of Technology, 27-1, Mizumoto-cho, Muroranshi, 050, Japan; Takeuchi, T., Department of Chemical Engineering, Muroran Institute of Technology, 27-1, Mizumoto-cho, Muroranshi, 050, Japan; Tanaka, T., Department of Chemical Process Engineering, Hokkaido University, Nishi, 8-chome, Kita-13-jo, Kita-ku, Sapporo-shi, 060, Japan
Abstract: The temperature rise curve due to the natural oxidation of a coal deposit was numerically simulated for a coal bed having a ‘spherical’ geometry. The maximum temperature occurred at the center of the bed when oxygen was fully supplied within the bed and near the surface when oxygen decreased due to the process of the reaction. The rate of temperature rise was significantly affected by the activation energy and frequency factor of the coal. Furthermore, the measurement of the moisture adsorbed on the oxidized coal samples showed that the loss in mass due to oxidation increased remarkably at temperatures above 120°C. In assuming the limiting temperature in coal storage to be 120° C, a maximum allowable amount of coal storage was estimated for various kinds of coal under the conditions of neither spontaneous combustion nor significant loss in mass. © 1989, Hosokawa Powder Technology Foundation. All rights reserved.

Authors: Murai K., Kawashima Y., Nakanishi S.
Title: A Graphical Method for Practical Calculation of Varying-Pressure Steam Accumulator Capacity
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Himeji Inst. of Tech., Himeji 671-22, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Murai, K., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Himeji Inst. of Tech., Himeji 671-22, Japan; Kawashima, Y., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Himeji Inst. of Tech., Himeji 671-22, Japan; Nakanishi, S., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Himeji Inst. of Tech., Himeji 671-22, Japan
Abstract: A practical calculation method for the capacity of varying-pressure accumulators is presented. We introduced previously two functions of pressure for calculation of the amount of self-evaporation. These functions are represented in two diagrams respectively in order to make practical use of the new method. One of the great merits of this graphical method is that the effect of the initial steam space on the capacity of the varying-pressure accumulator can be calculated without need of any additional correction operation. © 1989, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage; Graphical Method; Selfevaporation; Steam Accumulator; Steam Space

Title: Dynamical Heat Transfer Problems in a Thermal Storage Unit with Packed Bed of Encapsulated PCM —Analysis in the case of fusible alloy—
Affiliations: Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Nagoya, Aichi 462, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Asahina, T., Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Nagoya, Aichi 462, Japan; Kosaka, M., Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Nagoya, Aichi 462, Japan
Abstract: It is important to know the dynamical properties of a heat storage unit for effective use of energy at low temperature for air conditioning, hot water supply or dehydration. In this report, a neat system with air and packed bed of small-scale metallic capsules in which the phase change material (PCM) was encapsulated for the improvement of transient response was investigated, where heat could be stored with high density and used in a rather narrow temperature range. Dynamical heat transfer problems in the storage unit were analyzed and the results of calculation were compared with experimental ones obtained with a packed bed of 4400 aluminium capsules, where Rose's metal was used as PCM. Agreement was fairly good, and good performance was confirmed. © 1989, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Encapsulation; Fusible Alloy; Heat Transfer; Packed Bed; Thermal Storage

Authors: Abe Y., Takahashi Y., Sakamoto R., Kanari K., Tanaka K., Kamimoto M., Ozawa T.
Title: Latent Thermal Storage Using Sodium Hydroxide-Based Molten Salts. —Compatibility of molten salts—
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd., Tokyo 100, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Tanaka, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd., Tokyo 100, Japan
Abstract: Although binary mixtures of sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrate and sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrite are promising materials for latent thermal storage in the 200~300°C temperature range, one of the most critical problems for application is the compatibility of these molten salts with metallic materials. The present paper first gives experimental results for compatibility tests on ten different metals at 350°C for up to 4,000 hours. The compatibility study further focussed on the effect of impurity on carbon steels in tests performed at 350°C for up to 10,000 hours. The experimental results showed that carbon steels has the best compatibility with these particular molten salts, and that the content of sodium chloride in the salts has a significant influence on corrosion behavior. © 1989, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Corrosion; Energy; High Temperature; Latent Heat; Molten Salt; Sodium Hydroxide; Thermal Storage

Authors: Kobiyama M., Fukushima S., Koyama T., Murakami T., Satoh Y.
Title: Long-Term and Large-Scale Storage of Natural Cold Thermal Energy in the Winter Season: (1st Report, Theoretical Investigation)
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Kobiyama, M.; Fukushima, S.; Koyama, T.; Murakami, T.; Satoh, Y.
Abstract: It is very important to utilize the local energy, such as natural cold energy in the winter season. In this paper, the authors suggest the house for large-scale and long-term storage of natural cold energy, such as natural ice or snow, in order to use it as a cold thermal energy source in the summer season. This storage house is buried in the ground and is simply construction. By theoretical thermal investigation, it is shown that about 80% of the stored ice in this house remains, even after one year, without melting by circumferential thermal condition and the density of ice or snow must be higher to use this storage house effectively. © 1989, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cold Thermal Energy; Large-scale; Long-term Storage; Storage House; Theoretical Investigation

Authors: Hirasawa Y., Saito A., Sato T., Takegoshi E., Imura S.
Title: A Study on Phase Changes of Heterogeneous Composite Materials
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Hirasawa, Y.; Saito, A.; Sato, T.; Takegoshi, E.; Imura, S.
Abstract: The present study is a basic investigation of the phase-change problem of a TES material consisting of a phase-change material (PCM) and conductive solids to promote the heat transfer rate. As the first step, experiments were carried out, using water containing coiled copper wires as the TES material. The phase-change process was investigated varying factors such as the volume ratio and the arrangement of the wires within the PCM. As a result, it was found that the phase-change rate of the TES material was increased considerably by the addition of the wires despite the small effects of the volume ratio and the arrangement. The heat transfer model of this TES material was proposed, and the numerical calculation was performed to simulate the phase-change process. The calculated results agreed well with the experimental results. © 1989, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Heterogeneous Composite Material; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage; Numerical Analysis; Phase Change; Thermal Conduction

Title: Compatibility of molten salts with advanced solar dynamic receiver materials
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Department of Chemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaworske, D.A., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Perry, W.D., Department of Chemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States
Abstract: Metal-coated graphite fibers are being considered as a thermal conductivity enhancement filler material for molten salts in solar dynamic thermal energy storage systems. The successful metal coating chosen for this application must exhibit acceptable wettability and must be compatible with the molten salt environment. Contact angle values between molten lithium fluoride and several metal, metal fluoride, and metal oxide substrates have been determined at 892°C using a modification of the wilhelmy plate technique. Reproducible contact angles with repeated exposure to the molten LiF indicated compatiblity. Materials with reproducible contact angles included chromel, Haynes 188, Haynes 230, nickel, tantalum, and tungsten. Materials with contact angles that varied with exposure included iron, molybdenum, niobium, rhodium, titanium, and zirconium. © 1989 by the American Institue of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Contact angle; Fluorine compounds; Fused salts; Heat storage; Lithium Fluoride; Metal coatings; Metals; Plate metal; Thermal conductivity; Filler materials; Metal fluoride; Metal oxides; Metal-coated; Solar dynamic; Thermal conductivity enhancement; Thermal energy storage systems; Wilhelmy plate technique; Molten materials

Authors: Chow L.C., Zhong J.K., Beam J.E.
Title: Thermal conductivity enhancement for phase change storage media
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY  40506, United States; Aero Propulsion and Power Laboratory, WRDC/POOS-3, Wright-Patterson Air Force BaseOH  45433, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chow, L.C., Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY  40506, United States; Zhong, J.K., Mechanical Engineering, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY  40506, United States; Beam, J.E., Aero Propulsion and Power Laboratory, WRDC/POOS-3, Wright-Patterson Air Force BaseOH  45433, United States
Abstract: Thermal, energy storage can be used as either a heat source or heat sink for spacecraft energy conversion and heat rejection systems. One major issue that needed to be addressed is that most phase-change materials (PCMs) with high energy storage density have an unacceptably low thermal conductivity. Several enhancement techniques are proposed in this paper. The baseline case utilizes LiH encapsulated in a thin SS304 container. The first enhancement technique uses LiH encapsulated in smaller containers of various shapes contained in a bigger cylindrical container filled with Ii. The total volume of LiH is the sage as the baseline case. The second enhancement technique focuses on a metal/phase-change material (M/PCM) composite. Specifically, 5% Ni is added uniformly to LiH so that the mixture has the same volume as the baseline storage unit. The enhancement techniques are analyzed numerically and their effectiveness is assessed for both constant surface heat flux and constant surface temperature conditions. Results shown include the amount of PCM melted as a function of time and the maximum temperature within the storage units. The M/PCM composite gives the best enhancement in thermal conductivity. © 1989 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Containers; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Heat flux; Heat sinks; Lithium compounds; Phase change materials; Storage (materials); Constant surface heat fluxes; Constant surface temperatures; Cylindrical containers; Heat rejection systems; High energy storage densities; Low thermal conductivity; Maximum temperature; Thermal conductivity enhancement; Thermal conductivity

Title: The rate parameters for coupled rotation-vibration-dissociation phenomenon in H2
Affiliations: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA  94035, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, S.P., NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA  94035, United States; Schwenke, D.W., NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA  94035, United States
Abstract: A theoretical study of the effects of molecular rotation on coupled vibration-dissociation phenomena for H2, undergoing a nonequilibrium relaxation in a heating and cooling environment, is reported. The rate coefficients for the collisional bound-bound and bound-free transitions have been calculated using a quasi-classical trajectory method. These state-to-state transition rates-were fed into the master equation, which was numerically solved to determine the rotational and vibrational population densities as well as the bulk thermodynamic properties. Our results show that (i) the vibrational transition rates of H2 increase monotonically with the vibrational levels, faster than the Landau-Teller model, (ii) the rotation of the molecules helps relax the low vibrational levels, serves as a temporary storage of vibrational energy during the relaxation, and thereby delays the dissociation process, (iii) the dissociation and re-combination rates can be approximated within an order of magnitude using equilibrium formulations and Park’s two-temperature model for temperature averaging, (iv) lower vibrational levels tend to over-relax, and (v) the average energy loss due to the dissociation is about 80-90%of the dissociation energy. © 1989 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Molecular dynamics; Population statistics; Quantum theory; Stereochemistry; Bound-free transitions; Dissociation energies; Nonequilibrium relaxation; Quasi-classical trajectory method; State-to-state transition; Two Temperature Model; Vibrational population; Vibrational transitions; Dissociation

Authors: Fujiyama M., Kawamura Y., Asaeda E.
Title: Dynamic Viscoelastic Properties of Polypropylene Melts
Source title: Nihon Reoroji Gakkaishi(Journal of the Society of Rheology, Japan)
Affiliations: Polymer Development Laboratory, Tokuyama Soda Co., Ltd., 1-1 Harumi-cho, Tokuyama, Yamagnchi 745, Japan; Polypropylene Manufacturing Department, Tokuyama Soda Co., Ltd., 1-1 Harumi-cho, Tokuyama, Yamagnchi 745, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujiyama, M., Polymer Development Laboratory, Tokuyama Soda Co., Ltd., 1-1 Harumi-cho, Tokuyama, Yamagnchi 745, Japan; Kawamura, Y., Polymer Development Laboratory, Tokuyama Soda Co., Ltd., 1-1 Harumi-cho, Tokuyama, Yamagnchi 745, Japan; Asaeda, E., Polypropylene Manufacturing Department, Tokuyama Soda Co., Ltd., 1-1 Harumi-cho, Tokuyama, Yamagnchi 745, Japan
Abstract: The dynamic viscoelastic properties of six commercial isotactic polypropylenes with well-characterized molecular weight and molecular weight distribution were investigated in molten state. For the series of polypropylenes, the molecular weight distribution at high molecular weight range, as expressed by Mz/Mw, was broader as the melt flow index was higher or the molecular weight was lower. Following relations were obtained for the zero-shear viscosity η0, the characteristic relaxation time λ0, and the ratio λ0/η0: η0∝Mw3.1, λ0∝Mz3.3, λ0/η0∝(Mz/Mw)2.7, λ0/η0∝Mz·Mz+1/MwMn. The temperature dependence of η0, λ0, and λ0/η0 was of the Arrhenius type and the activation energies were 10.0 kcal/mol, 5.7 kcal/mol, and -4.3 kcal/mol, respectively: Contrary to the common knowledge, the ratio λ0/η0 increased as temperature increased. The storage modulus G′(ω) and loss modulus G″(ω) increased more slowly as the molecular weight distribution was broader, and the modulus at which G′(ω) is equal to G″(ω) was lower as the molecular weight distribution was broader. Irrespective of the kind of sample and temperature, the plots of log G′ against logG″fell on a curve approximated by a straight line, and hence it was conjectured that the elasticity at fixed value of viscosity does not change over the range of samples and temperatures studied in this experiment. © 1989, The Society of Rheology, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dynamic viscoelastic properties; Melts; Molecular weight distribution; Polypropylene; Relaxation time; Zero-shear viscosity

Title: General Properties of Highly Excited Direct Semiconductors in the Athermal Stage
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna
Authors with affiliations: Heiner, E., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna
Abstract: Starting from first principles and prolonging a series of three previous papers some general and global properties of highly excited direct semiconductors are considered. The evolution of the lengths of the state vectors is considered and some properties are discussed. Furthermore the evolution of the total electron production rate and of the total energy are investigated. Thereby new terms are derived which describe the energy storage due to nonlinearities in the evolution equations. Finally, some aspects of ultrashort pulse duration are considered. Copyright © 1989 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA

Authors: White P.J., Abbas I.R., Johnson L.A.
Title: Freeze‐Thaw Stability and Refrigerated‐Storage Retrogradation of Starches
Affiliations: Iowa State University, Department of Food and Nutrition, 111 MacKay Hall, Ames, Iowa, 50011, United States; Department of Food Technology, Iowa State University, 102 Dairy Industry Building, Ames, Iowa, 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: White, P.J., Iowa State University, Department of Food and Nutrition, 111 MacKay Hall, Ames, Iowa, 50011, United States; Abbas, I.R., Iowa State University, Department of Food and Nutrition, 111 MacKay Hall, Ames, Iowa, 50011, United States; Johnson, L.A., Department of Food Technology, Iowa State University, 102 Dairy Industry Building, Ames, Iowa, 50011, United States
Abstract: A method for the evaluation of freeze‐thaw stability of starch gels is described and compared with refrigerated‐storage retrogradation. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) is used to estimate the energy required to break down recrystallized starch molecules after 10 cycles of freezing‐thawing or after storage at 4°C for 1 week. Different DSC properties were observed for different starches. Chemical modification decreased all DSC values for gelatinization except the gelatinization range of all modified starches examined. Rice and wheat starches displayed the lowest energies of gelatinization compared with other native starches studied. Most chemical modifications completely inhibited the recrystallization of starches during storage at 4°C or after 10 cycles of freeze‐thaw. Mira‐Cleer 340® (modified regular maize starch; hydroxypropyl distarch phosphate) had a slight recrystallization value. DSC endotherms for both recrystallization studies occured at considerably lower temperatures than those of the original gelatinization. Copyright © 1989 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim

Authors: GALDI M., CARBONE N., VALENCIA M.E.
Title: Comparison of Ferric Glycinate to Ferrous Sulfate in Model Infant Formulas: Kinetics of TBA, Lysine and Methionine Changes
Affiliations: Departamento de Bromatologia y Nutricion Experimental, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquimica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1113, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: GALDI, M., Departamento de Bromatologia y Nutricion Experimental, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquimica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1113, Argentina; CARBONE, N., Departamento de Bromatologia y Nutricion Experimental, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquimica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1113, Argentina; VALENCIA, M.E., Departamento de Bromatologia y Nutricion Experimental, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquimica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1113, Argentina
Abstract: Ferric glycinate prooxidant properties were compared with those of ferrous sulfate in a powdered casein‐based infant formula. About 60 ppm of either source were added to experimental formulas, and supplemented formulas stored at 20, 37 or 45°C for 7–12 months. The samples were assayed periodically during storage for methionine and available lysine losses, and malonaldehyde formation. Deterioration rate constants for the ferric glycinate‐fortified formula dropped to 60–75% of those for the ferrous sulfate‐fortified formula. Activation energy values obtained for the glycinate iron source were 15–20% higher than those for ferrous sulfate. Thus, iron had lower prooxidative properties when added to this infant formula as ferric glycinate than when present as ferrous sulfate: Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Some investigations of suspoemulsions
Affiliations: BASF Aktiengesellschaft, Landwirtschaftliche Versuchstation, Postfach 220, Limburgerhof, D-6703, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wigger, A., BASF Aktiengesellschaft, Landwirtschaftliche Versuchstation, Postfach 220, Limburgerhof, D-6703, Germany; Gückel, W., BASF Aktiengesellschaft, Landwirtschaftliche Versuchstation, Postfach 220, Limburgerhof, D-6703, Germany
Abstract: ‘Suspoemulsions’ (SE) is the term used to describe combined formulations of solid and liquid active ingredients as dispersed systems. The parameters influencing an SE were investigated with reference to four examples (one solid and three liquid products) in various mixing ratios. Apart from the type and amount of the partners and the energy dissipation density used, the recipe and viscosity particularly had effects on the formation and properties of an SE. The solid particles in the suspension promoted the comminution of the liquid phase. However, they had practically no influence on the flow behaviour in the three degrees of comminution fineness investigated. The causes of the phenomena discovered are discussed. The storage stability of the SE was equal to that of suspension concentrate (SC) formulations. The advantageous effect of the addition of a thickener on storage stability was similar to that in the case of an SC. Copyright © 1989 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd

Title: SPINACH FERREDOXIN REDUCTION BY MEMBRANE‐BOUND CHLOROPHYLL TRIPLET STATE VIA A DIQUAT MEDIATOR
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: SENTHILATHIPAN, V., Department of Biochemistry, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, 85721, United States; TOLLIN, G., Department of Biochemistry, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, 85721, United States
Abstract: Abstract Laser flash photolysis experiments have shown that the diquat analog containing a propylene bridge (PDQ2+), when electrostatically bound to negatively‐charged vesicles containing chlorophyll, is able to mediate the rapid reduction (k= 1.1 × 105 s‐1) of spinach ferredoxin via electron transfer quenching of triplet state chlorophyll. The kinetics of formation and decay of reduced ferredoxin are consistent with a mechanism involving complex formation between oxidized ferredoxin and vesicle‐bound PDQ2+. Under optimal conditions, approximately 15% of the quenched triplets yield reduced ferredoxin. This process is a model for soluble ferredoxin reduction which occurs in green plant photosystem I, and results in an appreciable storage of electromagnetic energy in the reaction products. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: ROUSE F., LEVI M., KENT J., KING M., ZANTHIER C.V., WATSON S., BAMBADE P., ERICKSON R., JUNG C.K., NASH J., WORMSER G.
Title: Measuring the Mass and Width of the Z0: The Status of the Energy Spectrometers
Source title: Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States; University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, California, 95064, United States; Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States
Authors with affiliations: ROUSE, F., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States; LEVI, M., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States; KENT, J., University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, California, 95064, United States; KING, M., University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, California, 95064, United States; ZANTHIER, C.V., University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, California, 95064, United States; WATSON, S., University of California at Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, California, 95064, United States; BAMBADE, P., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States; ERICKSON, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States; JUNG, C.K., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States; NASH, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States; WORMSER, G., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94309, United States
Abstract: The SLAC Linear Collider (SLC) is a novel electron‐positron accelerator designed to produce center‐of‐mass energies of around 93 GeV, the mass of the Z0 particle. The collisions are between electrons and positrons produced directly by the accelerator. Previously, energetic electron‐positron collisions were produced by counter‐rotating beams of electrons and positrons stored in a storage ring. The beams are discarded, pulse by pulse, at the SLC. They are directed into a beam dump after the interaction point (IP). Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Seasonal Changes in Soluble Carbohydrates, Starch, and Energy Content in Mediterranean Seagrasses
Affiliations: Institut für Pflanzenphysiologic, Universität Wien, Althanstr. 14, Vienna, A-1090, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Pirc, H., Institut für Pflanzenphysiologic, Universität Wien, Althanstr. 14, Vienna, A-1090, Austria
Abstract: Abstract. In all scagrass species investigated, rhizomes were the main storage organs for soluble carbohydrate reserves, and the highest levels were found in Cymodocea nodosa (Ucria) Ascherson. Sucrose was the primary soluble carbohydrate identified in Posidonia oceanica (L.) Delile, and Zostera noltii Hornem. This disaccharide was dominant in Cymodocea nodosa roots, as well as in its rhizome in winter. Myo‐inositol was the main cyclitol in Zostera noltii. In Cymodocea nodosa leaves 1‐chiro‐inositol was the main sugar component; it was also present to a lesser extent in the roots and rhizomes. The amounts of glucose and fructose were correlated with growth to a certain extent in all species. Higher amounts of starch were stored in the rhizomes of Posidonia oceanica and Zostera noltii. The energy content of Mediterranean scagrasses was significantly higher than in tropical species. No distinct seasonal trend in energy content could be observed. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Cymodocea; energy content; Scagrasses. Posidonia; seasonal changes; soluble carbohydrates; starch; Zostera

Authors: BENNETT M.B., KER R.F., ALEXANDER R.McN.
Title: Elastic strain energy storage in the feet of running monkeys
Affiliations: Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Leeds University, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: BENNETT, M.B., Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Leeds University, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; KER, R.F., Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Leeds University, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; ALEXANDER, R.McN., Department of Pure and Applied Biology, Leeds University, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Monkeys are ‘flat–footed’ in comparison to humans, but they are still able to utilize elastic strain energy stores in their feet to reduce the metabolic energy cost of running. During contact with the ground, bending moments act on the foot to produce a ‘reversed arch’, storing strain energy which is returned in the subsequent elastic recoil. This energy–saving mechanism has been investigated in dynamic bending tests and is discussed in relation to the arched foot of humans. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Quantitative determination of low strain amplitude dynamic functions of carbon black filled rubber vulcanizates by statistical analysis of the black secondary agglomeration network
Affiliations: Research and Development Institute, Kranj, 64000
Authors with affiliations: Susteric, Z., Research and Development Institute, Kranj, 64000
Abstract: Deformational breakdown of the secondary agglomeration network, a carbon black aggregate chain association readily formed in rubber matrix and held together by van der Waals forces, is treated statistically. Consistent with observation, the resulting expressions for low strain amplitude dependence of the black filled vulcanizates' dynamic functions, i.e. the storage and loss moduli, provide means for determination of characteristic aggregate chain scission energies. The proposed approach additionally accounts for effects of filler content and temperature, the latter permitting evaluation of van der Waals bond dissociation activation energies, if the black chain scission process is assumed to be thermally activated. Copyright © 1989 Hüthig & Wepf Verlag

Title: The fin musculature of cuttlefish and squid (Mollusca, Cephalopoda): morphology and mechanics
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of North Carolina, CB 3280 Coker Hall, Chapel Hill, North Carolina, 27599-3280, United States
Authors with affiliations: KIER, W.M., Department of Biology, University of North Carolina, CB 3280 Coker Hall, Chapel Hill, North Carolina, 27599-3280, United States
Abstract: The lateral fins of cuttlefish and squid consist of a tightly packed three‐dimensional array of musculature that lacks bony skeletal support or fluid‐filled cavities for hydrostatic skeletal support. During swimming and manoeuvring, the fins are bent upward and downward in undulatory waves. The fin musculature is arranged in three mutually perpendicular planes. Transverse muscle bundles extend parallel to the fin surface from the base of the fin to the fin margin. Dorso‐ventral muscle bundles extend from dorsal and ventral connective tissue fasciae to a median connective tissue fascia. A layer of longitudinal muscle bundles is situated adjacent to both the dorsal and ventral surface of the median fascia. The muscle fibres are obliquely striated and include a core of mitochondria. A zone of muscle fibres with a more extensive core of mitochondria is present in both the dorsal and the ventral transverse muscle bundles. It is hypothesized that these muscle masses include two fibre types with different aerobic capacity. A network of connective tissue fibres is present in the transverse and dorso‐ventral muscle masses. These fibres, probably collagen, are oriented at 45 to the long axes of the transverse and dorsoventral muscle fibres in transverse planes. A biomechanicayl analysis of the morphology suggests that support for fin movements is provided by simultaneous contractile activity of muscles of specific orientations in a manner similar to that proposed for other ‘muscular‐hydrostats’. The musculature therefore provides both the force and support for movement. Connective tissue fibres may aid in providing support and may also serve for elastic energy storage. Authors: REN T.J., TOLEDO R.T., FRANK J.F.
Title: KINETIC PARAMETERS FOR THERMAL INACTIVATION OF PLASMIN
Affiliations: Department of Food Science and Technology, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, United States
Authors with affiliations: REN, T.J., Department of Food Science and Technology, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, United States; TOLEDO, R.T., Department of Food Science and Technology, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, United States; FRANK, J.F., Department of Food Science and Technology, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, United States
Abstract: Plasmin (EC 3.4.21.7) is the principal indigenous protease in bovine milk. Kinetic parameters for thermal degradation of plasmin were determined using a miniature continuous flow pasteurizer designed for heat treatment of small quantities of liquid. Plasmin activity was measured using a pH‐stat titration, which measures the release of H + from a caseinate substrate. Heating milk at various temperatures resulted in significant difference (P > 0.01) in residual plasmin activity and linear decrease in activity at each temperature. The calculated D‐values were: 105, 90, 76.5, 62, and 47 s at 72, 78, 85, 92, and 100°C, respectively. The Z‐value for plasmin inactivation was estimated to be 77.5°C, and the Arrhenius activation energy was 7.04 kcal/mole. UHT milk containing plasmin was heated for an equivalent of 5 D inactivation of the enzyme at 100°C. After storage for 30 days at 4°C, no enzyme regeneration was observed. Title: KINETICS OF LYSINE LOSS IN COMPRESSED MODEL SYSTEMS DUE TO MAILLARD REACTION
