Authors: Kordesch K., Gruber Ch., Gsellmann J., Kalal P., Oliveira J.C.T., Steininger K.-H., Taghezout O., Winkler G., Tomantschger K.
Title: Fuel cell research and development projects in Austria
Affiliations: Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Battery Technologies Inc., Mississauga, Ont. L5L 1J9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kordesch, K., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Gruber, Ch., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Gsellmann, J., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Kalal, P., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Oliveira, J.C.T., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Steininger, K.-H., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Taghezout, O., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Winkler, G., Technical University Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria; Tomantschger, K., Battery Technologies Inc., Mississauga, Ont. L5L 1J9, Canada
Abstract: A five year program on energy storage and fuel cell research has been established in Austria, with the goal to find out what types of batteries and fuel cells could possibly be optimized for commercial applications. In the background there are environmental considerations and others, leading to a future hydrogen economy, also possibly to a use in electric vehicles. The search of the European Space Agency for a suitable system for the HERMES manned space vehicle is contributing considerably to the future prospects. The work in Austria is mainly oriented to low temperature alkaline fuel cell systems and the studies are complementary to a similarly oriented program in Canada, originally started by the Institute for Hydrogen Systems in Mississauga, subsequently continued by private companies in cooperation with the University of Toronto. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources--Austria; Fuel Cells--Research; Alkaline Electrolyte Systems; Alkaline Fuel Cells; Electrochemical Energy Storage; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Kluksdahl N.C., Kriman A.M., Ferry D.K.
Title: Role of structure sizes in determining the characteristics of the resonant tunneling diode
Affiliations: Center for Solid State Electronics Research Arizona State University Tempe, AZ 85287-6206, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kluksdahl, N.C., Center for Solid State Electronics Research Arizona State University Tempe, AZ 85287-6206, United States; Kriman, A.M., Center for Solid State Electronics Research Arizona State University Tempe, AZ 85287-6206, United States; Ferry, D.K., Center for Solid State Electronics Research Arizona State University Tempe, AZ 85287-6206, United States
Abstract: Using the Wigner function formalism, we study the effects of structural parameters on the DC I-V characteristics and on the large-signal transient response of the resonant tunneling diode. We model two types of structures of GaAs/AlxGa1-xAs; first, with symmetric barriers ranging from 3 to 8 nanometers in thickness separated by a 5 nanometer well, and second with a well varying from 3 to 8 nanometers between 3 nanometer barriers. Experimental variation of the barrier thickness and height changes the peak-to-valley ratio in the I-V curve, as predicted by elementary models of tunneling structures. This stems directly from the changes in tunneling probabilities. For the DC studies, we show that the peak-to-valley ratio in the I-V curve is a function of the resonance width, which depends both on the well and barrier thickness. The location of the peak on the I-V curve depends on the location of the resonant energy, which is a function of the well width. Transient switching behavior is compared to earlier numerical studies of tunneling times of wave packets. Charge storage stabilizes the position of the resonant state, thus damping the transients. Consequently, wider barriers yield faster transient settling times, in agreement with the tunneling time results which predicted longer charge storage times for thicker barriers. © 1989.
Author Keywords: resonant tunneling diode; Wigner function
Index Keywords: Semiconductor Materials - Physical Properties; Resonant Tunneling Diode; Tunneling Probabilities; Tunneling Time; Wigner Function; Semiconductor Diodes, Tunnel

Title: Hidden time-scales in nonlinear systems
Affiliations: INGAR-Institute for Development and Design, Avellaneda 3657, 3000 Santa Fe, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Martínez, E.C., INGAR-Institute for Development and Design, Avellaneda 3657, 3000 Santa Fe, Argentina
Abstract: Many physical and man-made systems have hidden time-scales characterized by two singular perturbation parameters. This form often arises for nonlinear dynamic networks due to the presence of small and large storage elements, such as capacitors, material and energy reservoirs, masses etc., interconnected with small and large resistors, weak and strong springs, admittances etc. In this paper we emphasize the physical situation by examples and also present a manifold-based analysis which permits the construction of a nonsingular transformation for expressing the original problem in an explicit form. The interpretation of these hidden time-scales is based on aggregate conservation and hierarchical equilibrium properties, a refinement of those presented previously. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Mathematical Techniques - Nonlinear Equations; Hidden Time Scales; Man Made Systems; Electric Networks, Nonlinear

Authors: Prakash J., Garg H.P., Hrishikesan D.S., Jha R.
Title: Performance studies of an integrated solar collector-cum-storage water heating system with transparent insulation cover
Affiliations: Ramjas College, Delhi University, Delhi, 110007, India; Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Prakash, J., Ramjas College, Delhi University, Delhi, 110007, India; Garg, H.P., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Hrishikesan, D.S., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Jha, R., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: In this paper the effect of transparent insulation on the performance of a 100 dm3 capacity built-in-storage type solar water heater is theoretically investigated. The materials of transparent insulation in covering 1 m2 area of the top surface are Honeycomb hexagonal PS, Honeycomb hexagonal PA and Honeycomb square PC as suggested by Pfluger et al. (paper presented at the ISES Solar World Congress, Hamburg, 1987). Performance of the third material is compared with a glass cover with and without night insulation cover. Also, the performance of a similar system with an area of 0.5 m2 on its top surface but with the same capacity and with transparent insulation on top and on all the side walls is studied. Finite difference forward time step marching technique is used in solving the energy balance equations. A comparison between the three materials shows that the system with Honeycomb square PC presents the best performance, but it is inferior to the system with night insulation cover. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Heat Insulating Materials; Hot Water Supply Systems; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Night Insulation Cover; Solar Collector-Cum-Storage Water Heating; Solar Water Heater; Transparent Insulation Cover; Water Heaters

Title: A control strategy for heat recovery and storage
Affiliations: Centre for Building Studies, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd. W, Montreal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zaheer-Uddin, M., Centre for Building Studies, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd. W, Montreal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada
Abstract: A simple method of finding approximate control strategies for combined heat recovery and storage processes is presented. The system considered is a space heating system employing a heat pump. The technique is based on energy balance principles and a numerical search method which minimizes the operating cost. Two examples are given to illustrate the procedure. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Control Systems, Optimal; Heat Pump Systems--Applications; Cost Effective Control Strategies; Heat Pump Control Sequence; Heat Recovery Control; Energy Storage

Authors: Ohman M.D., Bradford J.M., Jillett J.B.
Title: Seasonal growth and lipid storage of the circumglobal, subantarctic copepod, Neocalanus tonsus (Brady)
Source title: Deep Sea Research Part A, Oceanographic Research Papers
Affiliations: MLRG A-027, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, U.S.A., United States; New Zealand Oceanographic Institute, Division of Water Sciences, D.S.I.R., Kilbirnie, Wellington, New Zealand; Portobello Marine Laboratory, University of Otago, P.O. Box 8, Portobello, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Ohman, M.D., MLRG A-027, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, U.S.A., United States; Bradford, J.M., New Zealand Oceanographic Institute, Division of Water Sciences, D.S.I.R., Kilbirnie, Wellington, New Zealand; Jillett, J.B., Portobello Marine Laboratory, University of Otago, P.O. Box 8, Portobello, New Zealand
Abstract: Neocalanus tonsus (Brady) was sampled between October 1984 and September 1985 in the upper 1000 m of the water column off southeastern New Zealand. The apparent spring growth increment of copepodid stage V (CV) differed depending upon the constituent considered: dry mass increased 208 μg, carbon 162 μg, wax esters 143 μg, but nitrogen only 5 μg. Sterols and phospholipids remained relatively constant over this interval. Wax esters were consistently the dominant lipid class present in CV's, increasing seasonally from 57 to 90% of total lipids. From spring to winter, total lipid content of CV's increased from 22 to 49% of dry mass. Nitrogen declined from 10.9 to 5.4% of CV dry mass as storage compounds (wax esters) increased in importance relative to structural compounds. Egg lipids were 66% phospholipids. Upon first appearance of males and females in deep water in winter, lipid content and composition did not differ from co-occuring CV's, confirming the importance of lipids rather than particulate food as an energy source for deep winter reproduction of this species. Despite contrasting life histories, N. tonsus and subarctic Pacific Neocalanus plumchrus CV's share high lipid content, a predominance of wax esters over triacylglycerols as storage lipids, and similar wax ester fatty acid and fatty alcohol composition. © 1989.
Index Keywords: copepod; growth; lipid; New Zealand; Neocalanus plumchrus; Neocalanus tonsus

Authors: Omar Kh.M., Saad S.S., Darwish N.Z., El-Ashry F.M.
Title: Soliton potential, energy storage and anomalous large angle scattering of alpha-particles incident on 40Ca
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Omar, Kh.M., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt; Saad, S.S., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt; Darwish, N.Z., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt; El-Ashry, F.M., Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt
Abstract: Supplementing the optical model potential by a repulsive core Vc allows the Anomalous Large Angle Scattering (ALAS) model to be applied to α-particles. Motivated by recent discussions, an analytical soliton formfactor is used for Vc that may be interpreted as a "storage" for kinetic energy in compressed nuclear matter. Computed angular distributions and excitation functions agree well with experiment, thus furnishing support for such a parameterization and the value k = 245 MeV (+10%, -15%). © 1989.
Index Keywords: Calcium and Alloys--Radiation Effects; Alpha Particles; Anomalous Large Angle Scattering; Soliton Potential; Charged Particles

Authors: Clarke A., Ellis-Evans J.C., Sanders M.W., Holmes L.J.
Title: Patterns of energy storage in Pseudoboeckella poppei (Crustacea, Copepoda) from two contrasting lakes on Signy Island, Antarctica
Affiliations: British Antarctic Surv., NERC, High Cross, Madingley Rd., Cambridge, CB3 0ET, UK, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke, A., British Antarctic Surv., NERC, High Cross, Madingley Rd., Cambridge, CB3 0ET, UK, United Kingdom; Ellis-Evans, J.C., British Antarctic Surv., NERC, High Cross, Madingley Rd., Cambridge, CB3 0ET, UK, United Kingdom; Sanders, M.W., British Antarctic Surv., NERC, High Cross, Madingley Rd., Cambridge, CB3 0ET, UK, United Kingdom; Holmes, L.J., British Antarctic Surv., NERC, High Cross, Madingley Rd., Cambridge, CB3 0ET, UK, United Kingdom
Abstract: Pseudoboeckella poppei was sampled from Sombre and Heywood Lakes on Signy Island, Antarctica between January 1984 and March 1985. Sombre Lake is clear and oligotrophic with little phytoplankton and a bottom sediment low in organic content. Heywood Lake is turbid and mesotrophic; a substantial phytoplankton develops in summer and the bottom sediments are comparatively rich in organics. Both lakes freeze over for much of the year, forcing the copepods to adopt a benthic feeding strategy over winter. Adult Pseudoboeckella feed on phytoplankton when this is available, but also on detritus, diatoms and short algal filaments stirred up from the sediment. In Heywood Lake, male copepods show a smooth seasonal trend in lipid content with lipid being synthesised in early summer and utilised in late summer and winter. The summer increase in lipid content is associated with an increase in dry weight. Female lipid contents show evidence of 2 peaks of egg production. In Sombre Lake both male and female copepods increase in size during summer and show a wider range of lipid contents than in Heywood Lake, probably due to the poorer winter feeding conditions which necessitate the synthesis of a much larger store of reserves during the summer. -from Authors
Index Keywords: copepod; energetics; Antarctica; Heywood Lake; Signy Island; Sombre Lake; South Orkney Islands; Pseudoboeckella poppei

Title: Collection and storage of solar energy
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lodhi, M.A.K., Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Abstract: Some exotic aspects of solar energy with reference to its collection and storage have been discussed, in that the quality of energy is emphasized at the outset in collecting and storing the solar energy. Several systems have been reviewed for storage of solar energy primarily for commercial purpose with a central power generating plant. Some principles of storage for individual units for domestic, industrial or commercial use have also been briefly outlined. In that the quality of the energy, favorable to natural circumstances and technological know-how are kept in mind. With the quality of energy in view among the large scale projects some of the collection-cum-storage devices, such as helio-hydrogravity, helio-aero-gravity, salt-gradient solar pond and ocean thermal conversion are presented briefly. Among the reflective collector devices, central receiver tower, parabolic trough, parabolic dish and solar bowl are recommended. The solar bowl is primarily highlighted for developing countries. Hot water, rock bed and phase change storage systems are also briefly described for relatively small units. Finally, hydrogen as energy carrier is argued as the most efficient means for collection, storing and transportation of solar energy. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Phase Change Storage Systems; Salt-Gradient Solar Ponds; Solar Bowls; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Bedinger M.S., Sargent K.A., Langer W.H., Sherman F.B., Reed J.E., Brady B.T.
Title: Studies of geology and hydrology in the Basin and Range Province, southwestern United States, for isolation of high-level radioactive waste - basis of characterization and evaluation
Authors with affiliations: Bedinger, M.S.; Sargent, K.A.; Langer, W.H.; Sherman, F.B.; Reed, J.E.; Brady, B.T.
Abstract: The geologic and hydrologic factors in selected regions of the Basin and Range province were examined to identify prospective areas for further study that may provide isolation of high-level radioactive waste from the accessible environment. The six regions selected for study were characterized with respect to the following guidelines: 1) potential repository media; 2) Quaternary tectonic conditions; 3) climatic change and geomorphic processes; 4) ground-water conditions; 5) ground-water quality; and 6) mineral and energy resources. -from Authors
Index Keywords: hydrogeology; radioactive waste storage; regional geology; site investigation; (Southwest); Basin and Range Province; USA

Authors: Ammar A.A., Okaz A.M., Sorour M.M., Ghoneim A.A.
Title: Efficient collection and storage of solar energy
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Ammar, A.A., Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt; Okaz, A.M., Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt; Sorour, M.M., Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt; Ghoneim, A.A., Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: The present paper presents a detailed simulation study for both air and water-based systems. The transient simulation program TRNSYS is used to determine the performance of both heating systems. The simulations were made for a heating season Alexandria, Egypt. In the present study a new sensible storage material called tafla, which is found in Egypt's desert, is used. Tafla gives a better performance, based on the volume of the storage unit, in comparison with a pebble bed. The optimum system parameters were determined for both air and water-based systems. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Materials; Heat Transfer--Computer Simulation; Heating--Solar; Houses--Heating; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Sensible Energy Storage Materials; Solar Energy Utilization Systems; Thermal Energy Storage; Solar Energy

Title: Modelling and analysis of the dynamic behavior of a forced circulation solar water heating system with storage tanks in series
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Faculty of Technological Studies, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Fahmy, M.F.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Abd-el Sadek, M., Faculty of Technological Studies, Kuwait
Abstract: A generalized model for a forced circulation solar water heating system with storage tanks in series is presented in which the loss of heat through an insulation lagging is considered, and the periodic time variation of the intensity of solar radiation, as well as both the ambient air temperature and the temperature of cold water entering the first main tank, is taken into account. Using the Laplace transformation, an exact solution is presented which, under certain conditions, reduces to an approximate solution. The conditions for convergence to the approximate solution are discussed, and figures are presented comparing it with the exact solution for several different sets of conditions. In this communication, the effect of the number of storage tanks on the outlet temperature of the hot water and the effect of various water heating system parameters on its performance have been analytically investigated. Numerical calculations have been made for a typical cold day. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Dynamics; Energy conversion; Heat exchange; Mathematical modeling; Solar water system; System of tanks; Water heating
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Hot Water Supply Systems; Mathematical Models; Solar Radiation; Tanks; Dynamics; Energy Conversion; Solar Water Heating Systems; Storage Tanks; System of Tanks; Water Heaters

Title: Open cycle absorption cooling-A review
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushik, S.C., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kaudinya, J.V., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: This article presents a comprehensive review on open cycle absorption cooling. Basic physical processes, detailed literature survey and current state-of-the-art on open cycle absorption cooling are described. The authors have studied the feasibility of an open cycle absorption cooling system both theoretically and experimentally. Various investigations on heat and mass transfer processes in solar regenerators and thermodynamic modelling and thermal design aspects of open cycle absorption solar cooling systems are summarized. A comparative study of open cycle absorption cooling with closed cycle absorption cooling has also been presented, and it is found that the former is better in performance, less expensive and simpler in technology. A closed cycle vapour absorption cooling system is known to be a casual alternative of conventional vapour compression systems. However, a more promising open cycle absorption cooling system (OCACS) is proved to be a better alternative for solar cooling/air conditioning applications by various researchers from the U.S.S.R., U.S.A., Australia, India and Japan. This review also highlights the importance of open cycle absorption solar cooling system possible applications, and some innovative concepts relevant to open cycle absorption cooling are also mentioned. A detailed list of references on open cycle absorption cooling is given. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Absorption cooling; Heat and mass transfer; Open cycle; Open surface and forced flow solar regenerators; Review work; Solar brine still regenerator; Solar collector/regenerator systems; Thermal design and feasibility studies; Thermodynamic and thermal modelling
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Solar Energy Systems; Cold Storage; Refrigerating Machinery--Absorption; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Thermodynamics; Mass Transfer; Open Cycle Absorption Cooling; Solar Brine Still Regenerators; Refrigeration

Authors: Caruso A., Grakovich L.P., Pasquetti R., Vasiliev L.L.
Title: Heat pipe heat storage performance
Affiliations: A.V. Luikov Heat and Mass Transfer Institute, the BSSR, Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation

Luikov Heat and Mass Transfer Institute, the BSSR, Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Heat storage offers essential thermal energy saving for heating. A ground heat store equipped with heat pipes connecting it with a heat source and user is considered in the paper. It has been shown that such a heat exchanging system along with a batch energy source meets, to a considerable extent, house heating requirements. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Houses--Heating; Water Heaters--Solar; Ground Stores; Heat Exchanging System; Thermal Energy Saving; Heat Pipes

Title: Characteristics of the available wind energy in Bahrain
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Bahrain, P.O. Box 32038, Bahrain
Authors with affiliations: Alnaser, W.E., Physics Department, University of Bahrain, P.O. Box 32038, Bahrain
Abstract: The wind characteristics and the available wind energy in Bahrain has been studied. The mean long-term wind speed and its variation at a height of 10 m above ground level were found to be 4.90 and 0.823 ms-1 respectively. Accordingly, the annual mean wind power density is 69.2 ± 0.34 Wm-2. The size of windmill needed to supply the required domestic power and the number of batteries to provide energy storage for use at a certain continuous rate of energy have been estimated. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Annual Mean Wind Power Density; Long-Term Wind Speed; Wind Energy; Windmills; Wind Power; Bahrain; Wind Power-Availability

Authors: Sexton F.W., Fu J.S., Kohler R.A., Koga R.
Title: SEU characterization of a hardened CMOS 64K and 256K SRAM
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; AT&T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, PA, United States; Aerospace Corp., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sexton, F.W., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Fu, J.S., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Kohler, R.A., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States, AT&T Bell Laboratories, Allentown, PA, United States; Koga, R., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States, Aerospace Corp., Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: The first single-event-upset (SEU) tests of the AT&T 64K and 256K SRAMs have been performed. Feedback resistor values for these parts ranged from 200kΩ to 1MΩ. All were fabricated using the 1-μm 2-level poly, 2-level metal process. Ions used for these tests were Ar, Cu, Kr, and Xe providing a range of effective LET values from 20 to 129 MeV-cm2/mg. With the 64K SRAM operating at 4.5 volts and 90°C, an upset threshold LET of 30 MeV-cm2/mg and saturation cross-section of 1.5 x 10–2 cm2 were measured with a nominal room temperature feedback resistance of 450kΩ. In Adam's 10% worst-case environment using the Petersen approximation, this implies an error rate of 1.3 x 10–7 errors per bit-day. With a nominal 650kΩ feedback resistance, a 256K SRAM had a calculated error rate of about 3 x 10–8 errors per bit-day at 4.5 volts and 90°C. This data agrees well with earlier data for a 1K-bit test chip. The minimal feedback resistance required to prevent upset vs. LET is calculated by assuming an activation energy of 0.10 eV to estimate the decrease in feedback resistor value as a function of temperature. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Argon; Data Storage, Digital--Random Access; Ion Beams; Krypton; Xenon; CMOS Technology; Linear Energy Transfer; Petersen Approximation; Single Event Upsets; Static Random-Access Memories; Integrated Circuits

Title: Design considerations of a total energy power system for a rural health centre in Nigeria
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Lagos, Yaba, Lagos, Nigeria, Nigeria; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Lagos, Yaba, Lagos, Nigeria, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Chendo, M.A.C., Department of Physics, University of Lagos, Yaba, Lagos, Nigeria, Nigeria; Salawu, R.I., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Lagos, Yaba, Lagos, Nigeria, Nigeria
Abstract: A conceptual total energy (hybrid) system design considerations are presented for a Rural Health Centre in a remote village in Nigeria. The design uses a spectrally selective beam splitting technique. The system provides both electrical and thermal energy with electrical needs of the centre being provided by the photoquantum convertor while the hot water and sterilization requirements are met by the spectrally selective heat transfer liquid in the thermally decoupled loop. A critical analysis of the electrical and thermal energy requirements of the health centre including its laboratories, water supply, refrigeration, lightening, etc. and its technoeconomic aspects is also discussed. With appropriate sizing of panels, storage, choice of the spectrally selective heat transfer liquid and other accessories, the PV/PT system using moderately concentrated sunlight is attractive for such application in areas with no national grid lines and normally considered uneconomical for electrification by the extension of the national grid or by the provision of generators which require constant supply of fuel and servicing. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation--Solar Energy; Heating--Solar; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Hybrid Electrical and Thermal Energy Systems; Photoquantum Converters; Rural Total Energy Systems; Spectrally Selective Beam Splitting; Spectrally Selective Heat Transfer Liquids; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Yuqun X., Chunhong X., Qinfen L.
Title: A Study of Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage: Numerical Simulation of Thermal Storage Experiments in Shanghai
Affiliations: Dept. of Earth Sciences, Nangjing University, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Yuqun, X., Dept. of Earth Sciences, Nangjing University, Nanjing, China; Chunhong, X., Dept. of Earth Sciences, Nangjing University, Nanjing, China; Qinfen, L., Dept. of Earth Sciences, Nangjing University, Nanjing, China
Abstract: Abstract This paper proposes a 3‐D convection‐heat dispersion model for a confined aquifer. The governing equation of the model contains not only the traditional convection and conduction terms, but also a heat dispersion term which has often been overlooked in many similar researches. The model is used to describe a series of aquifer thermal energy storage experiments conducted at the Shanghai experimental site, including single‐well injection, double‐well injection / production and multiple‐well injection / prodution tests. The simulated temperatures agree very well with the field data (relative error: 2.8%‐4.5%). A detailed description of the model is given, followed by a detailed comparison of simulated and measured temperature distributions. © 1989 Geological Society of China
Index Keywords: aquifer thermal energy; confined aquifer; convection- dispersion model; double well injection; groundwater heat transfer; injection-production test; multiple well injection; single well injection; thermal energy storage; China, Shanghai

Title: The influence of pressure-dependent density and viscosity on the elastohydrodynamic collision and rebound of two spheres
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309-0424, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnocky, G., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309-0424, United States; Davis, R.H., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309-0424, United States
Abstract: A theoretical description of the low-Reynolds-number collision and rebound of two rigid or elastic spheres separated by a thin layer of viscous fluid with pressure-dependent physical properties is presented. It has previously been shown by Davis et al. (1986) that the hydrodynamic pressure which builds up in the thin fluid layer must become large enough to elastically deform the spheres near the axis of symmetry, if they are to rebound subsequent to colliding. Under these extreme pressures, however, it is expected that the fluid may also compress and that its viscosity may increase by several orders of magnitude. It is shown that these pressure-dependent effects may significantly alter the minimum separation reached during approach of the spheres, as well as the maximum separation and relative velocity attained during rebound of the spheres. In particular, the pressure buildup during the collision process is predicted to become sufficiently large under some conditions so that the corresponding viscosity increase causes the fluid in the gap between the colliding spheres to behave nearly as a solid and to limit the close approach of the opposing surfaces. Also, the storage of energy via the compression of the fluid in the gap allows rigid spheres to bounce as this energy is released subsequent to their collision. However, it is found that this rebound is very weak relative to that which is predicted for elastic spheres. © 1989, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids--Spheres; Fluids--Density; Hydrodynamics; Pressure Effects; Viscosity; Elastohydrodynamics; Pressure Dependence; Spheres

Title: An Electrochemical and Spectroelectrochemical Study of the Behavior of Cobalt Electrodes in Molten Aluminum Chloride: Sodium Chloride Mixtures
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of the Witwatersrand, 2001 Johannesburg, South Africa; Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996 1600, United States
Authors with affiliations: Orchard, S.W., Department of Chemistry, University of the Witwatersrand, 2001 Johannesburg, South Africa, Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996 1600, United States
Abstract: The electrochemical behavior of cobalt electrodes has been studied in NaCl-saturated AlCl3:NaCl melts at temperatures in the range 175°-215°C. Anodic oxidation commences at potentials positive of 0.9V vs. an aluminum reference electrode in the same melt, producing solid CoCl2 and a small amount of cobalt in solution. Spectroelectrochemical measurements revealed that the dissolved cobalt was present as CoCl42-. As the oxidation proceeds and Cl- is consumed, the melt in the vicinity of the electrode becomes acidic; oxidation can then continue at a higher potential of about 1.3 V vs. the aluminum reference. Rapid anodic/cathodic cycling leads to increasing currents at the electrode. This and other observations are most easily explained by postulating that solid NaCl is precipitated on the electrode surface during the cathodic part of such cycles. Implications for the Zebra battery system are discussed. © 1989, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aluminum Compounds; Electrodes, Electrochemical--Cobalt; Electrolytes; Salts--Molten; Sodium Chloride; Aluminum Chloride; High Energy Density Storage Cells; Metal Chlorides; Zebra Cells; Electric Batteries

Title: Energetic aspects of the syngas production by solar energy: Reforming of methane and carbon gasification
Affiliations: Departimento di Chimica, Universita di Roma La Sapienza, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: D'Alessio, L., Departimento di Chimica, Universita di Roma La Sapienza, Rome, Italy; Paolucci, M., Departimento di Chimica, Universita di Roma La Sapienza, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The syngas (CO+H2) production from methane or carbon has been studied from the energetic point of view for solar energy storage applications. Results indicate that, at operating temperatures about 900-1000 K a net enthalpy change, or stored energy, of 192 KJ (CH4+H2O) or 272 KJ (CH4+CO2) is obtainable, per mol of reformed methane. For the carbon gasification a maximum enthalpy change of 131 KJ is aspected. Further developments are submitted to the choice of more selective catalysts and to the building of suitable chemical reactors-heat exchangers designed for solar plants. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Carbon--Gasification; Energy Utilization; Methane; Carbon Gasification; Enthalpy Change; Syngas Production; Solar Energy

Title: Influence of Ferric Bacteria on Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage: Field Verification of a Colloidal Dam Effect
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Umemiya, H.; Mutou, T.
Abstract: In our laboratory, field experiments on the aquifer thermal energy storage method have been continued for six years. As a result, the thermal recovery factor (collected thermal energy/charged thermal energy) has been improved from 23% (1st) to 59% (6th). One of the causes is ferric colloid (Fe2O3·nH2O) made by ferric bacteria such as Gallione, Leptothrix, Metallogenium. We have performed field experiments and come to the following conclusions: 1. The transmissivity and the apparent thermal diffusivity changed their value due to the clogging of the ferric colloidal dam in the vacant of the aquifer, preventing the natural flow of groundwater around the well. 2. The clogging of the ferric colloidal dam was destroyed and washed out by back wash till 1.6 meters in diameter around charge well, but ferric colloid remained farther than 1.6 meters, improving aquifer thermal energy storage ability. 3. Repetition of the charge and back wash process formed a ferric colloidal dam in the aquifer, which increased the thermal recovery factor significantly. © 1989, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Apparent Thermal Diffusivity; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage; Clogging of Ferric Colloidal Dam; Ferric Bacteria; Thermal Recovery Factor; Transmissivity
Index Keywords: Thermal Diffusion; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage; Colloidal Dam Effect; Ferric Bacteria; Thermal Recovery Factor; Aquifers

Title: The thermally stimulated current technique applied to side-chain liquid-crystal polymers
Affiliations: Department of Materials Engineering, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Simon, G.P., Department of Materials Engineering, Monash University, Clayton, Vic. 3168, Australia
Abstract: The thermally stimulated current (t.s.c.) technique is applied to three side-chain liquid-crystal polymers (LCP) and an LCP that contains a highly dipolar dye. The t.s.c. trace is shown to be very sensitive to a number of LCP properties including glass transition, degree of mesogenic alignment and the amount of polarization that can be stored. A strong correlation between such properties and the results of high-frequency dielectric spectra is established. These parameters are directly relevant for the application of these materials as optical storage media and in non-linear optics. In particular, the technique is able to define the optimum conditions for poling these LCP systems. The technique can also be used to determine a number of fundamental molecular properties such as activation energy, molecular relaxation distribution and polymer flexibility and, as such, allows fundamental examination of the relationships between main-chain and mesogenic motions. © 1989.
Author Keywords: liquid-crystalline polymer; optical properties; thermally stimulated current
Index Keywords: Aromatic Polymers; Crystals, Liquid; Dyes and Dyeing; Polyesters; Silicones; Activation Energy; Fuoss-Kirkwood Fit; Glass Transition; Mesogenic Alignment; Polymers

Title: Shoot temperatures and thermal tolerances for succulent species of Haworthia and Lithops
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Laboratory of Biomedical and Environmental Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, California, 90024, United States
Authors with affiliations: NOBEL, P.S., Department of Biology, Laboratory of Biomedical and Environmental Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, California, 90024, United States
Abstract: Abstract. Temperatures of small succulent plants, such as species in the genera Haworthia and Lithops, are highly influenced by temperatures of the surrounding soil. Indeed, the minimum and the maximum temperatures of the upper leaf epidermis of Haworthia retusa. H. turgida. Lithops leslei, and L. turbiniformis were generally within 1°C of the accompanying soil surface temperatures. An energybudget model closely predicted such soil‐to‐plant temperature differences as well as the effect of the greater convective exchange for the protruding Haworthia species compared with the Lithops species, which were flush with the soil surface. Although a lower shortwave absorptance would reduce maximum shoot temperatures, the shortwave absorptances of all four species were similar to those of the soil in their respective native habitats in South Africa. Tolerances of the four species to low and to high temperatures at three different day/night air temperatures (15°C/5°C, 30°C/20°C, and 45°C/35°C) were analysed using cellular accumulation of a vital stain, neutral red. Chlorenchyma cells were slightly more tolerant of extreme temperatures than were cells of the water‐storage parenchyma. In this regard, H. retusa survived low and high temperatures that killed the water‐storage parenchyma but not the chlorenchyma. Acclimation to low temperatures and to high temperatures, which was exhibited by all four species, led to estimated tolerances to 1 h at −16°C and 68°C. Although the low temperature tolerance is not particularly noteworthy, very few vascular plants are reportedly able to tolerate such high temperatures. Copyright © 1989, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Aizoaceae; Asphodelaccae; energy‐budget nodel; Haworthia retusa; Haworthia turgida; high temperature; Lithops leslei; Lithops turbiniformis; low temperature.
Index Keywords: temperature; thermal tolerance; Haworthia; Lithops

Title: Transient analysis for designing and predicting operational performance of a high temperature sensible thermal energy storage system
Affiliations: Energy Division, Building Center of Israel, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Sragovich, D., Energy Division, Building Center of Israel, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Abstract: A practical method for calculation and design of a high temperature sensible thermal energy storage device is presented. This method enables evaluation of the performance of the storage device in transient conditions. A tubular configuration of the storage construction was selected. The method is based on a steady state model, useful for system simulation and preliminary design of performance parameters, and a transient model allowing verification of these parameters. The transient method by J. A. Duffie and W. A. Beckman was adapted to tubular storage construction and compared with other methods; good agreement was obtained. The design, thermal and operational parameters resulting from the simulating were analysed. The phenomenon of a sudden drop in temperature at the storage outlet, at the point of the change from the laminar flow regime to transitional, was observed. This drop permits predicting of operational behaviour of a thermal storage system. Based on the developed method a high temperature thermal energy storage device, working about 1000°C, was designed for the Solar Thermochemical Pipeline System at the Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Thermal Energy Storage System; Tubular Storage; Solar Power Plants

Title: Model of an automotive power steering system via the linear graph technique
Affiliations: Elizabeth City State University, Elizabeth City, NC 27909, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ajumobi, S.O., Elizabeth City State University, Elizabeth City, NC 27909, United States
Abstract: The linear graph technique is used to derive an equivalent electrical circuit diagram (involving capacitances, inductances, resistances, transformers, gyrators and transducers), of the hydro-mechanical automotive power steering system. The model includes six independent lumped energy storage elements: 1. (1) The inertia of the steering wheel and column. 2. (2) The rotary stiffness of the steering column. 3. (3) The inertia of the spool valve slider assembly. 4. (4) The retaining spring of the spool valve slider assembly. 5. (5) The mass of the hydraulic actuator and steering link assembly. 6. (6) The return springs in the steering link assembly. The order of the system is therefore six, corresponding to the number of lumped independent energy storage elements. The six first-order ordinary differential equations are then derived from the linear graph model. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Automotive Engineering; Control Equipment, Hydraulic; Electric Networks - Schematic Diagrams; Graphic Methods; Mathematical Models; Automotive Power Steering Systems; Hydraulic Actuators; Hydraulic Power Steering Systems; Linear Graph Techniques; Steering Columns; Automobiles

Authors: Shimano Y., Goka T., Kuboyama S., Kawachi K., Kanai T., Takami Y.
Title: The measurement and prediction of proton upset
Affiliations: Tsukuba Space Center, NASDA, Sengen, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; National Institute of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa, Chiba, 260, Japan; Institute for Atomic Energy, Rikkyo University, Nagasaka, Yokosuka, 240 - 01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimano, Y., Tsukuba Space Center, NASDA, Sengen, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Goka, T., Tsukuba Space Center, NASDA, Sengen, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Kuboyama, S., Tsukuba Space Center, NASDA, Sengen, Tsukuba, 305, Japan; Kawachi, K., National Institute of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa, Chiba, 260, Japan; Kanai, T., National Institute of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa, Chiba, 260, Japan; Takami, Y., Institute for Atomic Energy, Rikkyo University, Nagasaka, Yokosuka, 240 - 01, Japan
Abstract: This paper evaluates tolerance to proton upset for three kinds of memories and one MPU for space use by irradiating them with high energy protons up to nearly 70 MeV, and predicts error rates of these memories using a modified semi-empirical equation of Bendel et al. Besides, one of the predicted error rates was compared with in - orbit data of the MOS-1 spacecraft. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital--Random Access; Ion Beams; Protons; Spacecraft; MOS-1 Spacecraft; Upset Rates; Computers, Microcomputer

Title: Continuing evaluation of a high-level waste research programme: the Canadian case
Source title: Radioactive waste management 2. Proc. conference, Brighton, 1989. Vol. 1
Affiliations: McMaster Univ., Hamilton, Ontario, Canada., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Shemilt, L.W., McMaster Univ., Hamilton, Ontario, Canada., Canada; Sheng, G., McMaster Univ., Hamilton, Ontario, Canada., Canada
Abstract: The Canadian Program on Nuclear Waste Management conducted by Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) is reviewed. The concept involves a multi-barrier system and includes a 1 km deep vault in the Canadian Shield. Extensive geological, geophysical and hydrogeological work has been carried out in the past eight years. Predictive aspects of this work are being tested through the construction of an Underground Research Laboratory. -from Authors
Index Keywords: radioactive waste storage; repository design; Canada

Title: Simulation of solar air drying of rapeseed
Affiliations: Department of Natural Resources Engineering, Lincoln College, Canterbury, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Patil, B.G., Department of Natural Resources Engineering, Lincoln College, Canterbury, New Zealand; Ward, G.T., Department of Natural Resources Engineering, Lincoln College, Canterbury, New Zealand
Abstract: The feasibility of solar and combined solar-natural air drying of rapeseed was evaluated using computer simulations. Real-time hourly weather data of ambient air conditions and solar radiation for 1968, 1971, and 1974 have been used in the study. Simulations have been carried out for the three harvesting dates of 10 and 25 February and 10 March and the five moisture contents of 25, 22, 20, 18, and 14 %(d.b.) using an airflow rate of 180 m3 (h m2)-1. The complete drying of rapeseed having moisture contents of 20 and 18 %(d.b.) to a safe moisture content of 11.11 %(d.b.) was achieved at depths of 1 and 2 m, respectively, with both solar and solar-natural air drying at all the harvesting dates in all the years studied, except for the rapeseed harvested on 10 February 1974. Both total and actual drying times are increased with increasing depth and initial moisture content. The study of drying parameter profiles has shown that a faster and more complete drying is observed using solar-natural air drying. This is also reflected in the width of drying front being greater when solar-natural drying than when using solar drying alone. The solar-natural air drying regime appears to be superior to that of solar drying alone in respect of the required total drying time and in achieving complete drying within the safe storage time. A saving of actual drying hours is also observed. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Drying--Computer Simulation; Solar Energy--Applications; Drying Parameter Profiles; Rapeseed; Solar Air Drying; Solar Collector Modelling; Food Products

Title: India's hydrogen energy program-A status report
Affiliations: Department of Energy, University of Madras, Madras, 600 025, India
Authors with affiliations: Sastri, M.V.C., Department of Energy, University of Madras, Madras, 600 025, India
Abstract: Hydrogen energy research in India started in 1976 on the initiative of the Government of India and covers almost all areas of technical relevance to the deployment of hydrogen as an energy vector. Specifically, these include its production from water by electrolysis, photoelectrolysis, photo-catalysis and biophotolysis, its storage as liquid hydrogen and metal hydrides, its consumptive use as engine fuel and thermal fuel and nonconsumptive application in metal hydrides-based chemical heat pumps. All this research is sponsored and supported by the Government of India. The genesis of hydrogen energy research in India and its growth during the first 10 years have already been reviewed at the VI-WHEC (Vienna, 1986). The present review is an update of the previous report. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Policy--India; Hydrogen Fuels; Solar Cells--Applications; Water--Electrolysis; Chemical Heat Pumps; Hydrogen Energy Program; Hydrogen Storage; Metal Hydrides; Photoelectrochemical Cells; Hydrogen

Title: Potential of solar ponds in hot climates
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Hafez Ave, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Ali, H.M., Mechanical Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Hafez Ave, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: The lumped parameter model is used to study the potential of the solar ponds in a hot climate. This model is used to study the transient energy behaviour in the storage zone, the pond surface temperature fluctuation and the effect of various parameters on the temperature of the storage zone. Various parameters affecting the behaviour of the solar pond in a hot climate were thoroughly investigated. They are: side wall shading effect, top insulation effect, solar incident angle effect, initial conditions of the pond, thickness of the storage zone and thickness of the nonconvective zone. The results indicate that the solar pond in a hot climate has a high potential. The temperature is fairly high and can reach boiling point, so the solar ponds may be used efficiently in many applications, e.g. desalination, air conditioning and space heating. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Desalination; Heating--Solar; Hot Climates; Salt-Gradient Solar Pond; Side Wall Shading Effect; Solar Incident Angle; Storage Zone; Top Insulation Effect; Solar Radiation

Title: A study of rainfall interception using a land surface parameterization for mesoscale meteorological models
Affiliations: Centre National de Receherches Meteorologiques (DMV/EERM), Toulouse, France., France
Authors with affiliations: Mahfouf, J.-F., Centre National de Receherches Meteorologiques (DMV/EERM), Toulouse, France., France; Jacquemin, B., Centre National de Receherches Meteorologiques (DMV/EERM), Toulouse, France., France
Abstract: A set of 24 h simulations, fully interactive with the boundary layer, is carried out with a one-dimensional model in order to examine the sensitivity of the interception scheme to vegetation properties. The evaporation from the interception reservoir is strongly enhanced by high values of the roughness length. The leaf area index, acting on the maximum storage capacity, modifies the drying time of the foliage. A validation of the interception scheme is made using micrometeorological data from the HAPEX-MOBILHY experiment. Six simulations lasting 24 h indicate that the parameterization reproduces quite well the daily evolution of the components of the surface energy balance for various surface conditions and various rainfall distributions. -from Authors
Index Keywords: interception; land surface parameterisation; mesoscale meteorological model; rainfall; roughness length

Authors: Kustom R.L., Skiles J., Wang J., Vong F.
Title: Digital control of power conditioning converters for superconductive magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Appl, Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kustom, R.L., Univ of Wisconsin, Appl, Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI,, USA; Skiles, J., Univ of Wisconsin, Appl, Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI,, USA; Wang, J., Univ of Wisconsin, Appl, Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI,, USA; Vong, F., Univ of Wisconsin, Appl, Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI,, USA
Abstract: Digital control of power conditioning circuits for superconductive magnetic energy storage is presented. A system is used to model circuits which consist of 10-kVA solid-state converter circuits, an 8-H superconducting coil, and IBM-AT and Apple-MACII computers. The computers are used for control of real and reactive power flow, current sharing, and data acquisition and manipulation. Results of the successful control of charging and discharging the 8-H coil are presented.
Index Keywords: Control, Electric Variables--Computer Applications; Data processing--Data acquisition; Electric converters, Static; Electric utilities; Superconducting devices; Firing Angles; Power Conditioning Converters; Real/Reactive Power Flow Control; Superconducting Coil; Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage; Electric inductors

Title: Thermal comfort in buildings through a mixed water-mass thermal storage wall
Affiliations: Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushik, S.C., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Kaul, S., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: This communication presents a time dependent periodic heat transfer analysis of a non-airconditioned building having south facing thermal storage mixed water-mass wall. The outer surfaces of walls/roof are exposed to periodic solar radiation and atmospheric air temperature while the inner surfaces are in contact with variable inside air temperature. The effects of heat transfer through walls and roof, heat conduction to the basement ground and furnishings as well as heat loss due to air ventilation have been incorporated into the building model. Explicit solution for the inside air temperature and periodic heat flux through the thermal storage mixed water-mass wall have been obtained. Numerical calculations show that a concrete-water concrete mixed thermal storage wall is more desirable than a pure water or pure concrete mass Trombe wall for providing excellent thermal comfort in buildings. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Concrete--Thermal Properties; Energy Storage; Heat Transfer--Analysis; Water--Thermal Properties; Heat Flux; Thermal Comfort; Thermal Storage; Buildings

Title: Theoretical limits for storage of energy in buildings
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mitchell, J.W., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Beckman, W.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: The mass incorporated in the structure of a building has long been used to store energy and offset heating requirements. The amount of mass to employ has been a subject of debate. Existing passive solar design manuals in the United States give recommendations for the amount of mass to employ in different building types, and establish optimum levels for different designs. However, an evaluation of the maximum benefits of building mass on energy consumption has not been performed. In this paper, two limits for the effect of building mass on energy consumption are formulated. The limit for maximum energy consumption is based on there being no mass available in the building for energy storage. The limit for minimum energy consumption is based on there being sufficient mass present to allow excess energy gains to be used at any time during the time period of interest. These limits allow the maximum economic benefit of building mass to be determined. Examples of the application of these limits are presented. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Buildings--Space Heating; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Building Mass; Energy Consumption; Excess Energy Gains; Heating

Authors: Levitan R., Rosin H., Levy M.
Title: Chemical reactions in a solar furnace-Direct heating of the reactor in a tubular receiver
Affiliations: Department of Materials Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Levitan, R., Department of Materials Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Rosin, H., Department of Materials Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Levy, M., Department of Materials Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: The reaction CH4 + CO2 = 2CO + 2H2 was studied as a thermochemical pipe for storage and transport of solar energy. Experiments were run in the 20 kW solar furnace at the Weizmann Institute of Science. A receiver/reactor was constructed consisting of an Inconel reactor tube filled with a Rh on alumina catalyst, and inserted in a tubular receiver made of high temperature resistant alumina. The reactor tube was heated directly by the solar insolation reaching the receiver cavity. Profiles of the wall and gas temperatures were obtained and the composition of the product gases was determined. This was done under a variety of total insolation conditions and the performance of this directly heated tube was evaluated. The total power absorbed in the reaction, by a 50-cm long U-shaped tube, was 3 kW. The temperature of the product gases ranged between 700° and 1000°C. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Chemical Equipment--Reactors; Solar Energy--Storage; Chemical Heat Pipe; Reactor Direct Heating; Solar Furnace; Tubular Receiver; Furnaces, Heating

Authors with affiliations: Ghoneim, A.A., Laboratory of Physics, Mathematical Eng. and Eng. Physics Dept., Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Experiments with energy storage in a high-latitude greenhouse
Affiliations: Institute of Mathematics and Physics, Roskilde University, Box 260, 4000 Roskilde, Denmark COWI consult, Teknikerbyen 45, 2830 Virum, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Sørensen, B., Institute of Mathematics and Physics, Roskilde University, Box 260, 4000 Roskilde, Denmark COWI consult, Teknikerbyen 45, 2830 Virum, Denmark
Abstract: A 12 m2 greenhouse located at 56° N latitude was furnished with a 0.8 m3 water store and solar absorber in the form of four black-painted oil drums. Temperatures were monitored for a little over a year. The system's ability to prolong the growing seasons and reduce extreme temperature excursions is discussed, as well as the behavior during periods of severe frost. It was found that greenhouse soil temperatures were lifted by about 5°C and their diurnal variations damped, while greenhouse air temperatures were less affected. Winter frost in the soil was delayed considerably, and once at 0°C, the water store behaved as a phase change storage system for a period of several months. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Meteorology--Denmark; Temperature Measurement; Greenhouse Soil Temperatures; Growing Seasons; High-Latitude Greenhouse; Severe Frost; Greenhouses

Title: A general design methodology for seasonal storage solar systems
Affiliations: Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Lund, P.D., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Abstract: A novel semi-analytical method to determine optimal dimensions of main subsystems in central solar heating plants with seasonal storage (CSHPSS), the storage volume (V) and solar collector area (Ac), is presented. The results strongly indicate that the non-purchased fraction of energy (f) approximates at optimum the correlation f = αAc (α = constant) for a fixed climate and CSHPSS system parameters. Second-order effects cause some minor nonlinearities in α that are also discussed in the paper. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Central Solar Heating; Energy Consumption; Optimal Dimensions; Seasonal Storage; Solar Radiation Availability; Heating

Title: Storage of solar energy by stands of pondweed and Elodea
Authors with affiliations: Bykovskiy, V.A.
Abstract: The ability of Potamogeton perfoliatus and Elodea canadensis to bind and store solar energy is measured by the product of the amount of organic matter and its enthalpy. The enthalpy is unaffected by ecological factors: it is 4600 ± 50 cal/g for the above-ground parts of pondweed and 4367 ± 62 cal/g for the below-ground parts, and 4610 ± 5 cal/g for the above-ground part of Elodea. The efficiency of the storage process is 0.7% relative to radiation incident on the water surface or 1.9% relative to absorbed radiation. The corresponding figures for Elodea are 1.0% and 2.7%. -from Author
Index Keywords: aquatic macrophyte; energy storage; enthalpy; pondweed; submerged plant; Elodea canadensis; Potamogeton perfoliatus

Title: Hydrogen vehicles: an evaluation of fuel storage, performance, safety, environmental impacts, and cost
Affiliations: Division of Environmental Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: DeLuchi, M.A., Division of Environmental Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen offers the prospect of plentiful supplies of clean transportation energy. This paper is a comprehensive review and analysis of hydrogen in efficient passenger vehicles. It addresses hydrogen production and distribution, on-board storage technology, refuelling, vehicle performance and safety, the environmental impacts of hydrogen use, and life-cycle costs. The environmental impact analysis focuses on NO, emissions from vehicles, the environmental impacts of making hydrogen from coal, and the contribution to the Greenhouse effect of CO2 emissions from the use of coal-based hydrogen. The life-cycle cost model compares hydrogen vehicles to similar baseline gasoline vehicles, and includes estimates of the total retail cost of liquid and gaseous hydrogen from coal and solar-powered electrolysis, the cost of fuel storage equipment, the cost of pollution control equipment, maintenance costs, other ownership and operating costs, and the external costs of hydrogen use. While there is considerable uncertaintly about several important parameters, I conclude that under certain plausible (though not necessarily likely) conditions-low hydrogen fuel and vehicle costs, high nonmarket costs of gasoline use, and moderately strong efforts to avoid a Greenhouse warming-hydrogen vehicles could be the socially preferred highway transportation option. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen Fuels--Storage; Clean Energy; Greenhouse Effect; Hydrogen Vehicles; Liquid Hydrogen; Refueling; Automotive Fuels

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Swensen E., Schainker R.B., Pollak R.
Title: Advanced compressed air energy storage concepts with utilization of the low pressure expander exhaust gas heat for steam generation
Affiliations: Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, , NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, , NJ, United States; Swensen, E., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, , NJ, United States; Schainker, R.B., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, , NJ, United States; Pollak, R., Energy Storage & Power, Consultants, , NJ, United States
Abstract: A number of analyses concluded that in order to be cost effective a compressed air energy storage (CAES) plant should have a recuperator. This article extends the analysis to a CAES/Combined cycle (CAESCC) plant. The thermodynamic cycle is discussed in detail.
Index Keywords: Compressed Air--Energy Storage; Energy Storage--Thermodynamics; Waste heat utilization; Combined Cycle; Compressed Air Energy Storage; Electric power plants

Authors: Gonzalez E.R., Ticianelli E.A., Tanaka A.A., Avaca L.A.
Title: A project for the electrochemical production and utilization of hydrogen in Brazil
Affiliations: Instituto de Física e Química de Sāo Carlos, USP, C.P. 369, Sāo Carlos, SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Gonzalez, E.R., Instituto de Física e Química de Sāo Carlos, USP, C.P. 369, Sāo Carlos, SP, Brazil; Ticianelli, E.A., Instituto de Física e Química de Sāo Carlos, USP, C.P. 369, Sāo Carlos, SP, Brazil; Tanaka, A.A., Instituto de Física e Química de Sāo Carlos, USP, C.P. 369, Sāo Carlos, SP, Brazil; Avaca, L.A., Instituto de Física e Química de Sāo Carlos, USP, C.P. 369, Sāo Carlos, SP, Brazil
Abstract: This paper describes the efforts of the Electrochemistry Group of the Institute of Physics and Chemistry/USP to develop electrode materials for water electrolyzers and of components for phosphoric acid fuel cells. In the last few years, several fundamental studies have been carried out in the electrocatalysis of water electrolysis reactions, particularly on hydrogen evolution, which allowed the development of materials with lower overpotentials, compared with those of conventional cathodes. In the phosphoric acid fuel cell area, substantial progress has been made in the development of teflon-bonded gas diffusion electrodes, bipolar separator plates, and electrolyte-containing matrices. These components have been tested in 50 W and 200 W phosphoric acid fuel cell modules. © 1989 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Brazil; Fuel cell; Hydrogen; Hydrogen program; Water electrolyser
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Brazil; Hydrogen--Electrolysis; Phosphoric Acid; Bipolar Separator Plates; Current Density; Hydrogen Storage; Phosphoric Acid Fuel Cells; Teflon Bonded Gas Diffusion Electrodes; Fuel Cells

Title: Activated carbon adsorption cycles for refrigeration and heat pumping
Affiliations: Engineering Department, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Critoph, R.E., Engineering Department, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: Adsorption cycles were used for cooling before the advent of reliable mechanical compression refrigerators, and are now attracting renewed interest as the basis of solar powered refrigerators for vaccine storage etc. They also have potential for use in heat pump systems. The cycle thermodynamics are reviewed and the suitability of a range of refrigerants with active carbon adsorbents is assessed. Methanol, sulphur dioxide, ammonia, methyl amine, and formaldehyde are of particular interest. Experimental p-T-x data is presented for ammonia and methanol with a range of carbons, together with their calculated performance in refrigeration cycles. Currently available carbons can give good performance, but it is possible that specially developed carbons might show significant improvement. A major development area lies not in changing the porosity characteristics but in trying to improve heat and mass transfer to and from the adsorbent. © 1989.
Author Keywords: activated carbon; Adsorption; heat pumps; refrigeration; solar energy
Index Keywords: Adsorbers--Heat Transfer; Heat Pump Systems; Mass Transfer; Refrigerants--Adsorption; Refrigeration--Solar; Adsorption Cycles; Cycle Thermodynamics; Carbon

Title: How safe is the storage of liquid hydrogen?
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lodhi, M.A.K., Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States; Mires, R.W., Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen as a fuel or as an industrial commodity is being used presently. Its storage and transportation is handled in various ways. Liquid hydrogen is usually stored in standard storage tanks at many industrial sites. A storage tank, otherwise safe, can explode due to a fast process of vaporizing the liquid hydrogen and thus over-pressurizing the storage tank to the point of rupture. The vaporization of liquid hydrogen faster than desired can be caused by a good thermal link between the inner container and the outer jacket of the storage tank. The amount of heat and the heat flux needed to vaporize the amount of liquid hydrogen to produce the required amount of rupture pressure of the inner container and outer jacket can be predicted from the specifications of the storage tank. A theoretical model for these predictions will be presented with appropriate assumptions made and detailed calculations. A case study of liquid hydrogen explosion will be discussed for illustration. The probable cause of liquid hydrogen explosion is obtained by applying this theoretical model. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Energy Resources; Gases, Liquefied--Storage; Tanks--Storage; Liquid Hydrogen; Rupture Pressure; Storage Tank; Hydrogen Fuels

Authors: Iordache Octavian, Isopescu Raluca, Isopescu Alexandru, Soare Gheorghe
Title: Nearly dispersional model for packed bed thermal storage systems
Affiliations: Polytechnical Inst Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Iordache, Octavian, Polytechnical Inst Bucharest, Romania; Isopescu, Raluca, Polytechnical Inst Bucharest, Romania; Isopescu, Alexandru, Polytechnical Inst Bucharest, Romania; Soare, Gheorghe, Polytechnical Inst Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: A nonarchimedian model for simulating a transient characteristics of heat transfer in packed bed thermal storage system is presented. An expansion using hermite polynomials is obtained in the analysis of systems which exhibit scales of heat transfer. The first term in expansion corresponds to the axial dispersion. A comparison of experimental data reported with numerical pedictions shows good correlation.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; Rock--Energy Storage; Solar radiation--Collectors; Dispersional Model; Hermite Polynomials; Thermal Storage Systems; Energy storage

Title: An analysis of domestic biogas storage installations in China
Affiliations: Beijing Agricultural Engineering University, Qinghua Dong Lu, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Datong, Z., Beijing Agricultural Engineering University, Qinghua Dong Lu, Beijing, China
Abstract: This paper analyses the problems of domestic biogas storage installations used in China and introduces a new flexible bag with a rolling axis used for biogas storage. This has the advantages of easy manufacture, low cost and guarantees a steady gas pressure for burning. The bag can hang in the kitchen itself, taking up minimal space, and can be operated easily by housewives. © 1989.

Title: GEOXRF: quantitative analysis program for energy dispersive x-ray fluorescence analysis
Affiliations: Nuclear Research Laboratory, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Srinagar, 190 006 Kashmir, India
Authors with affiliations: Sawhney, K.J.S., Nuclear Research Laboratory, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Srinagar, 190 006 Kashmir, India; Lodha, G.S., Nuclear Research Laboratory, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Srinagar, 190 006 Kashmir, India
Abstract: A FORTRAN-77 program. GEOXRF, is described for quantitative energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence analysis. The program employs the fundamental parameter method for quantitative analysis and corrects for absorption of X-rays, the result of interelement effects, by iteration. To reduce computer storage requirements, parameterized equations for mass absorption coefficients, emission-line energies and absorption-edge energies are utilized. The program is designed to be used in stand alone mode. © 1989.

Authors: Minissale A., Duchi V., Kolios N., Totaro G.
Title: Geochemical characteristics of Greek thermal springs
Source title: Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research
Affiliations: C.N.R. Centro Studi per la Mineralogia e Geochimica dei Sedimenti, Via La Pira 4, 50121 Firenze, Italy; Dipartimento di Scienze delle Terra, Via La Pira 4, 50121 Firenze, Italy; Institute of Geology and Mineral Exploration (IGME), 70 Messoghion st, Athens, 115 27, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Minissale, A., C.N.R. Centro Studi per la Mineralogia e Geochimica dei Sedimenti, Via La Pira 4, 50121 Firenze, Italy; Duchi, V., Dipartimento di Scienze delle Terra, Via La Pira 4, 50121 Firenze, Italy; Kolios, N., Institute of Geology and Mineral Exploration (IGME), 70 Messoghion st, Athens, 115 27, Greece; Totaro, G., Dipartimento di Scienze delle Terra, Via La Pira 4, 50121 Firenze, Italy
Abstract: A systematic sampling of all known thermal springs and gas emissions of continental Greece has been carried out. The main gas and water composition, and some trace elements in liquid phase (SiO2, H3BO3, NH4+ and Li+) have been determined. The chemical composition of most thermal springs analyzed is typical of deep Na-HCO3 rising hot waters which circulate in CO2-rich silicic formations, and which acquire progressively a Na-Cl composition by admixing of colder shallower saline connate waters housed in the rock matrix of marine post-orogenic Tertiary-Quaternary sediments. On the whole the thermal manifestations of continental Greece can be fitted in a tectonic framework where high hydraulic gradients enable waters in hot deep aquifers to reach the surface rapidly along fault systems at the boundary of N-S- and E-W-trending Tertiary basins. Equilibration temperatures of 80-120°C in the main storage zone (130-150°C max in the Nestos-Xanthi basin) have been assessed for most of the study area. High N2 and low H2 and H2S content in gas emissions associated to water samples are consistent with temperatures assessed by using geothermometers in liquid phase. © 1989.
Index Keywords: gas emission; geochemistry; thermal spring; Greece; Geochemistry--Groundwater; Geophysics--Geothermal; Water, Underground--Temperature Measurement; Geothermometry; Greek Thermal Springs; Thermal Water Geochemistry; Geothermal Energy

Authors: Walsh J.L., Ross C.C., Smith M.S., Harper S.R.
Title: Utilization of biogas

Abstract: A comprehensive study of the systems and equipment required to convert biogas into useful thermal and/or electrical energy was conducted, and the results published in the Handbook on Biogas Utilization (Walsh et al., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 1988). The physical, chemical and combustion characteristics of biogas, and the impact of these characteristics on both new and modified combustion equipment, were considered. The study also included consideration of auxiliary equipment for biogas collection, clean-up, compression and storage. © 1989.

Title: Getting waste program in motion again
Source title: Forum for Applied Research & Public Policy
Authors with affiliations: Kraft, S.P.
Abstract: The nation's electric rate-payers have invested some $4 billion since 1983 to finance a nuclear waste storage facility and have little to show for it. DOE's waste management program has been characterized by missed deadlines, schedule delays, bureaucratic entanglements, and lost opportunities. Utilities are concerned by both the lack of progress and DOE's seeming lack of concern for the costs that the delays are imposing on electric utilities and electricity consumers. -from Author

Title: Economic analysis of wind‐generated electricity in remote areas of South Africa
Affiliations: University of Natal, Durban, 4001, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Diab, R., University of Natal, Durban, 4001, South Africa; O'Leary, B., University of Natal, Durban, 4001, South Africa
Abstract: Costs of wind‐generated electricity from a stand‐alone wind generator with a two‐day autonomous battery storage are compared with costs of diesel‐generated and grid electricity for a remote outpost in a game reserve in South Africa. Comparative inflationary costs for diesel and wind were 53 and 33c/kWh, respectively. The cost of connecting to the national electricity grid were estimated to be 248c/kWh. Analysis of the availability of the wind and related power output of a selected wind generator revealed that the wind speeds fell between cut‐in and cut‐out speeds for approximately 80% of the time. In the light of the positive nature of these preliminary computations it is contended that a combined wind‐diesel system, in which the diesel would act as backup storage, would be an economically viable mode of electricity generation in a remote area. Copyright © 1989 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
