Title: The nervous system and adipose tissue
Affiliations: the Department of Dermatology, Queens Medical Center, University Hospital, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dalziel, K., the Department of Dermatology, Queens Medical Center, University Hospital, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Strict physiological controls exist for the use and storage of adipose tissue so that thermoregulatory and metabolic demands for energy can be sustained. Such controls are affected by hormonal and neural mediators, often interacting both at peripheral and central sites. The role of the autonomic nervous system in regard to these functions has been widely investigated in vitro and in vivo in animals and man. The effects of classical sensory or motor components of the nervous system on adipose tissue are less clearly established. For example, pain is a feature of many disorders of fat tissue and the possible role of the autonomic nervous system versus sensory nerves in mediating pain must be considered. The sensory nervous system has been believed to be of little importance to adipose tissue, but the recent finding of sensory nerves within adipose tissue raises issues of interest to dermatologists. In addition to a potential role in pain sensation, neuropeptides released by antidromic stimulation of sensory nerves have been shown to have an important role in cutaneous inflammation, and it is possible that they might also initiate or perpetuate inflammation within adipose tissue. The autonomic nervous system may also play a trophic role in maintaining adipose tissue. In conditions such as scleroderma where autonomic control is deranged, there are profound changes in the subcutaneous tissues. Factors that predispose individuals to local or generalized hypertrophy of adipose tissue are still poorly defined, but there is evidence that the autonomic nervous system may not be functioning fully in obese subjects, either as a primary or secondary phenomenon. The finding that many peptide hormones known to exist within the gastrointestinal tract also act as neurotransmitters in the central nervous system raises the possibility that these hormones may regulate appetite and satiety. © 1989.
Index Keywords: adipose tissue; adiposis dolorosa; adrenergic system; animal; brown adipose tissue; human; innervation; metabolism; obesity; panniculitis; pathophysiology; physiology; review; vascularization; Adipose Tissue; Adiposis Dolorosa; Animal; Brown Fat; Human; Obesity; Panniculitis; Sympathetic Nervous System

Title: Thermoregulatory aspects of adipose tissue
Affiliations: Department of Dermatology, The Slade Hospital, Headington, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gregory, E.L., Department of Dermatology, The Slade Hospital, Headington, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Two important functions of adipose tissue have been discussed earlier in this work, ie, white fat tissue storage of fatty acids and brown fat tissue use of fatty acids for energy purposes, especially heat production. Heat production in response to cold, known as cold-induced thermogenesis, is maximal in newborns who at 24 °C increase their thermometabolic ratio by 60-80%.1 Though less in adults, it can be shown to occur in men,2-4 and in normal young women.5 Some obese subjects exposed to an environmental temperature of 20 °C for 2 hours show a fall in core temperature.6,7 It is now well established that lean persons are more efficient heat producers.8 The presence of brown fat is an explanation for the increased response to cold in some individuals, while clothing, housing, and sophisticated heating techniques make heat production by the adipose tissue an unnecessary or an unrequired response to cold in others. Poverty, disease, and accidents do nevertheless expose men to cold environments. Foreign travel makes all of us aware that some degree of adaption occurs seasonally, so that if we arrive in a cooler environment unprepared, we feel disproportionately cold. Immersion in cold water largely eliminates the value of external thermal insulation such as clothing. Such exposure causes vasocontriction in the presence of which most insulation depends on subcutaneous fat in the area of the trunk and on fat and muscle in the limbs. At 12 °C, fat people can maintain core temperature, while at 25-29 °C some thin people cool progressively. A relative increase in surface area to size makes children do badly in cold water.9. In addition to its role in heat production, subcutaneous adipose tissue also forms an insulating barrier around the shell of the body and is therefore an important means of regulating heat loss. As an organ of substrate storage, heat production and heat conservation adipose tissue plays a major role in body temperature regulation. © 1989.
Index Keywords: adipose tissue; cold; functions of the skin and its appendages; human; physiology; review; thermoregulation; ultrastructure; Adipose Tissue; Body Temperature Regulation; Cold; Human; Skin Physiology

Title: Calculation of the angular and energy distribution of multiple scattered electrons using fourier transforms
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut, Universität Münster, Wilhelm-Klemm Strasse 10, D-4400 Münster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reimer, L., Physikalisches Institut, Universität Münster, Wilhelm-Klemm Strasse 10, D-4400 Münster, Germany
Abstract: The transport equation of electrons in scattering angle θ and energy loss ΔE for describing multiple elastic and inelastic scattering results in a sequence of a three-dimensional Fourier transform, an exponential operator function and an inverse Fourier transform. The two-dimensional Fourier transform in angular coordinates can be reduced to a one-dimensional Fourier-Bessel transform. The results can be calculated and presented with an AT-compatible minicomputer by using a 212×550 matrix or less which corresponds to a reduced storage of a 1024×1024 matrix in θ and ΔE. The method has been tested for aluminum using single-scattering probability functions for the plasmon loss and the L ionization. The results are presented as three-dimensional plots of d2I/d(ΔE)dΩ versus scattering angle and energy loss and by calculating the electron energy-loss spectra with increasing aperture for different thickness up to 20 times the total mean-free-path length. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Transformations - Fourier Transforms; Microscopic Examination - Scanning Electron Microscopy; Probability; Spectroscopy, Electron; Electron Energy Loss Spectra; Landau Theory; Electrons; article; electron; electron microscopy; fourier transformation; methodology

Authors: Gambino R.J., Ruf R.R., Rishi R.
Title: Exchange Coupled CoPd/TbCo Magneto-Optic Storage Films
Affiliations: IBM, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gambino, R.J., IBM, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States; Ruf, R.R., IBM, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States; Rishi, R., IBM, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States
Abstract: Films of CoPd with weak perpendicular anisotropy have been shown to exchange couple to square loop TbCo films on both the Tb and Co sides of compensation. The exchange is sensitive to reactive impurities at the interface and is broken under conditions that produce as little as one monolayer of paramagnetic compound. Even when the coupling at the interface is strong, we show that only a limited thickness of the CoPd layer is spin oriented perpendicular. Many materials with high magnetooptic rotation are not suitable as a storage medium because they do not have perpendicular anisotropy, high coercivity and good square loop properties. By exchange coupling such a low anisotropy but high MO rotation material, the read-out layer (RO), to an appropriate storage layer (ST) it may be possible to obtain stable storage bits in the exchange coupled system with improved carrier to noise ratios (CNR). It has been shown that in the system Nd(FeCo)/Tb(FeCo) that exchange coupling can produce films with high rotation and good square loop properties1. Furthermore, this system has been shown to follow the model of Kobayashi et al2 with respect to the thickness dependence of the switching field1. One of the assumptions of the model is that there is a wall at the interface between the layers when any subnetwork moments are opposing across the interface. This wall energy tends to prevent the subnetworks from aligning in opposition. The interlayer wall energy, σwcan be expected to depend on the exchange stiffness (A) and the anisotropy energy (Ku) as for an ordinary Bloch wall, σw = AKu. In the CoPd/TbCo system, the wall energy is expected to be lower in the CoPd layer because of its relatively low anisotropy energy. The anisotropy depends somewhat on deposition conditions and microstructure as with many Co alloys3,4. Since the wall energy is lower in the CoPd layer we can expect the wall to form in this layer. Also the wall width is given by δ= A/Ku so we can expect the wall to be wider in the CoPd than in the previously studied high anisotropy RETM alloys. CoPd is of interest for short wavelength MO applications because it has been shown to have a broad peak in Kerr rotation at 450 nn5. In many respects, the CoPd/TbCo system can be considered as a model for the study of exchange coupling. Because of its low anisotropy it is similar to the more technologically interesting system of PtMnSb/ThFe6. The CoPd/TbCo system however is easily prepared in a three source evaporator by sequential deposition of the binary alloys onto room temperature substrates. We have studied CoPd films coupled to TbCo films on both sides of compensation. We have also studied the effects of deposition sequence on the strength of the coupling. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical; Magnetooptical Devices; Faraday Rotation; Magnetooptic Recording; Magnetooptic Storage Films; Paramagnetic Compound; Perpendicular Anisotropy; Data Storage, Magnetic

Title: Film-Head Pulse Distortion Due to Microvariation of Domain Wall Energy

Abstract: Experiments show that the location of spurious peaks on the trailing edges of data pulses are strongly influenced by the application of small dc bias currents to the head coil during readback. A simple model of the head response which includes both magnetization rotation and domain wall motion for the case where domain wall coercivity is comparable to signal fields in the head reproduces many of the features of the observations. © 1989 IEEE

Title: Semiconductor photoelectrodes
Source title: Journal of electroanalytical chemistry and interfacial electrochemistry
Abstract: This issue contains 16 conference papers dealing with semiconductor photoelectrodes. The discussion at the conference was centered on the following topics: materials, kinetics, and corrosion. Kinetic studies have shown that in most cases surface chemistry of the semiconductors governs their stability under illumination and also their electrocatalytic properties. This is the origin of more important developments on modified electrodes in recent years. On the other hand, some teams have developed prototypes of cells for conversion or the storage of solar energy.

Authors: Speriosu V.S., Chen M.M., Suzuki T.
Title: Magnetic instability of iron oxide thin films
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, Ca, 95120-6099, United States
Authors with affiliations: Speriosu, V.S., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, Ca, 95120-6099, United States; Chen, M.M., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, Ca, 95120-6099, United States; Suzuki, T., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, Ca, 95120-6099, United States
Abstract: The coercivity Hcand coercive squareness S* of γ - Fe2O3 films made by oxidation of reactive-sputtered, Os-doped Fe304, change by as much as 30 and 50%, respectively, in one day at room temperature. On initial measurement the films are isotropic in the plane and have S* values of 0.5 to 0.7. Along the direction of remanence an easy axis develops with a 10 to 30% higher Hcand an S* of 0.85 to 0.95, corresponding to a global anisotropy in the range of 5 × 104erg/cm3. Reversible changes happen so rapidly that one can see large differences on consecutive VSM loops. These films also exhibit very high susceptibility (x > 10-3G/Oe) and rotational hysteresis (Wr> 105erg/cm3) at 16 kOe, suggesting random local anisotropy with components in excess of 50 kOe. Rotational hysteresis has a strong dependence on the rate of field rotation. In a stationary field the torque decreases initially logarithmically with time, yielding activation energies varying from 0.6 to 0.16 eV as the temperature increases from 24 to 120°C. All iron oxide films made by oxidation of reactive-sputtered Fe304, whether undoped or Co- or Os-doped, show both large Wr and global anisotropy reversible at room temperature. In fact these features are already present in as-deposited, undoped Fe3O4. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Iron Oxides--Thin Films; Magnetic Materials--Hysteresis; Global Anisotropy; Magnetic Recording; Rotational Hysteresis; Data Storage, Magnetic

Authors: Kryder M.H., Shieh H-P.D., Meiklejohn W.H., Skoda R.E.
Title: Improved methods of direct overwrite in magneto-optical recording media
Affiliations: Magnetics Technology Center Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh., PA, 15213–3890, United States; MOVID Information Technology, 889 Morgan Avenue, Schenectady, NY, 12309, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kryder, M.H., Magnetics Technology Center Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh., PA, 15213–3890, United States; Shieh, H-P.D., Magnetics Technology Center Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh., PA, 15213–3890, United States; Meiklejohn, W.H., MOVID Information Technology, 889 Morgan Avenue, Schenectady, NY, 12309, United States; Skoda, R.E., MOVID Information Technology, 889 Morgan Avenue, Schenectady, NY, 12309, United States
Abstract: Two improved methods of achieving direct overwrite without a pulsed magnetic field to write or erase domains, are described. Both were demonstrated in special single-layer magneto-optical media with a compensation point of 125-130oC and a Curie temperature of about 310oC. One of these methods uses two laser beams at different power levels. The first laser beam is set at a low power level which is adequate for erasure, but not for writing. This is possible since the laser energy required for erasure of written domains does not overlap with that for writing. The second beam can then be fired at a higher pulse power required for writing to put in the new data. The second method uses only a single laser beam. Since the pulse energy required to erase data is less than that required to write new data, a single beam, in which the pulse energy of the laser is modulated between a low level for erasure of previously written domains and a higher level for writing of new domains, may be used to directly overwrite old data. Both methods have been experimentally demonstrated for variable-length domains so that the use of pulse width modulation codes is possible. Scanning speeds as high as 15 m/sec have been demonstrated. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Laser Beams; Magnetooptical Devices; Pulse Width Modulation; Direct Overwrite; Magnetooptic Recording; Written Domains; Data Storage, Magnetic

Authors: Tam K.-S., Kumar P., Foreman M.
Title: Enhancing the utilization of photovoltaic power generation by superconductive magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Bradely Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tam, K.-S., Bradely Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Kumar, P., Bradely Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States; Foreman, M., Bradely Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24061, United States
Abstract: This paper demonstrates that a superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) system can enhance large scale utilization of PV generation. With SMES support, power generated from PV arrays can be fully utilized under different weather conditions and PV penetration can be increased to significant levels without causing adverse effects to the power system. Coupled with PV generation, a SMES system is even more effective in performing diurnal load leveling. A coordinated PV/SMES operation scheme is proposed and demonstrated under different weather conditions. © 1989 IEEE

Authors: Choi H.S., Shin B.C., Kim S.D.
Title: Heat transfer in a latent heat-storage system
Affiliations: Department of chemical Engineering, Korea Advanced institute of science and Technology Seoul, 130-650, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, H.S., Department of chemical Engineering, Korea Advanced institute of science and Technology Seoul, 130-650, South Korea; Shin, B.C., Department of chemical Engineering, Korea Advanced institute of science and Technology Seoul, 130-650, South Korea; Kim, S.D., Department of chemical Engineering, Korea Advanced institute of science and Technology Seoul, 130-650, South Korea
Abstract: The heat-recovery rate has been determined in a latent-heat storage unit using Na2HPO4 · 12H2O as a heat-storage medium. The effects of the liquid flow rate and inlet temperature of the heat-transfer fluid on the heat-recovery rate have been determined. The heat-recovery rate decreases sharply at the beginning of the heat-recovery stage. The measured thermal resistances during heat recovery are found to be smaller than the calculated values since the crystals of Na2HPO4 · 12H2O grow in dendritic shapes which act as fins for heat transfer. The thickness of the crystallized heat-storage material has been correlated in terms of Fourier, Stefan, and Reynolds numbers. © 1989.

Abstract: Configurational characteristics of thermomagnetically written domains under a static laser irradiation condition in amorphous TbFe and TbFeCo films were observed by using polarizing microscope. The shape of domains was categorized into 3 distinctly different types; 1) circular domains with a size almost independent of the applied field 2) domains growing in size and assuming smoother boundary with increasing applied field 3) unrecordable at any condition It was confirmed that the domain configurations were mainly determined by which one was dominant controlling factor between the demagnetizing and domain wall energy at elevated temperatures in thermomagnetic recording process. The origin of the bit shape irregularity found in some alloys of TbFe film was attributed to the nonuniformity in magnetic properties inherent to the amorphous structure. © 1989, IEEE. All rights reserved. © 1989 IEEE

Title: The erase process in direct overwrite magnetooptic recording
Affiliations: Magnetics Technol. Center, Carnegie Mellon Univ., Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schultz, M.D., Magnetics Technol. Center, Carnegie Mellon Univ., Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Kryder, M.H., Magnetics Technol. Center, Carnegie Mellon Univ., Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Abstract: The functioning of the erase process is of particular concern in single-layer direct-overwrite magnetooptic recording media. The authors describe the results of three different experiments that studied the dynamics and mechanism of the domain erasure process. Results indicate that the erase process in these direct-overwrite materials is completed about 40-80 ns after it starts. All three experiments show that the erase process in the materials studied is dominated by a simple collapse of the previously written domain, rather than the nucleation of a new domain within the previously written domain. They show that the erase pulse probably has insufficient energy to produce any domain nucleation. © 1989 IEEE

Abstract: Co-Ti substituted Baferrite particles were prepared, and the crystalline and shape anisotropy energies were measured in the temperature range of 78 K to 400 K to determine the crystalline anisotropy field of the particles. The crystalline anisotropy energy and the crystalline anisotropy field at room temperature were about 0.67xl06erg/cm3 and about 4700 0e, respectively. A similar temperature dependence was observed between the effective anisotropy field and the coercivity. This and a high intrinsic coercivity indicated coherent rotation of the magnetic moment in single-domain particles. © 1989 IEEE

Abstract: Anisotropy fields in some randomly oriented uniaxial magnetic recording materials have been determined by magnetometry and the Mössbauer effect. The Mössbauer determination used the polarization parameter. Calculated values of polarization were obtained via Stoner-Wohlfarth theory. Agreement between the two techniques was good for simpler particles. Resolved Mössbauer subspectra may be used for the determination of separate site anisotropy energies, if exchange coupling is sufficiently weak. © 1989 IEEE

Title: Magneto-Optical Properties of Metallic Bilayer Thin Films
Affiliations: SIEMENS AG, ZFE FI, TPH 11, Postfach 3220, 8520, Erlangen, F.R., Germany

Abstract: Metallic bilayer thin films are demonstrated as a novel and encouraging approach to substantially increase the figure of merit R1/2 ·θKin magneto-optical data storage media with a potential gain of more than a factor of two. Kerr-rotation spectroscopy and reflectivity measurements of Fe50Co50chosen as the model magnetic film on top of different reflector metals are presented. It is shown, that a low complex index of refraction (nr<< 1, krlow) of the reflector metal at the desired photon energy is essential. A quantitative theoretical description of the magneto-optical properties of metallic bilayers is given which allows zeneral predictions for optimum metal combinations. © 1989 IEEE

Abstract: A method is described to determine the soft X-ray emission of pulsed plasma sources for X-ray lithography. It is based on a comparison between resist exposures to the plasma sources under investigation and to synchrotron radiation from the electron storage ring BESSY. Title: Optimum design and operation of ice-storage air-conditioning systems under Australian TOU tariffs
Affiliations: CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering Lucas Heights Research Laboratories Menai, NSW 2234, Australia, Australia; Intelligent Energy Systems P/L, P.O. Box 931, Crows Nest, NSW 2065, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Musgrove, A.R.deL., CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering Lucas Heights Research Laboratories Menai, NSW 2234, Australia, Australia; Ehmke, H.-J., CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering Lucas Heights Research Laboratories Menai, NSW 2234, Australia, Australia; Stocks, K.J., CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering Lucas Heights Research Laboratories Menai, NSW 2234, Australia, Australia, Intelligent Energy Systems P/L, P.O. Box 931, Crows Nest, NSW 2065, Australia
Abstract: Ice-storage means the manufacture of ice by refrigeration systems during off-peak periods, to be re-melted to meet cooling requirements during peak demand periods. This paper deals with the economics of using ice-storage systems in Australian commercial buildings and with the role that the differently-shaped time-of-use electricity tariffs on offer in Sydney and Melbourne have on the optimum system design. Using mathematical programming techniques, the optimum store control strategy is investigated for different seasonal and load conditions. In both cities, the use of the ice-storage concept is shown to reduce overall air-conditioning costs significantly. The extra capital costs are paid back with savings in electricity in less than two years for most of the cases investigated. © 1989.

Title: Single residency sintering and consolidation of powder metal alloys, intermetallics, and composites by pulsed homopolar generator discharge
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10, 100 Burnet Road, Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78758-4497, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weldon, W.F., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10, 100 Burnet Road, Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78758-4497, United States; Aanstoos, T.A., Center for Electromechanics, The University of Texas at Austin, 10, 100 Burnet Road, Bldg. 133, Austin, TX 78758-4497, United States
Abstract: Utilizing inertial energy storage the homopolar generator (HPG) is capable of delivering multimegawatt, megampere current pulses into resistive or inductive loads with high efficiency. (1) Such HPG's have been used for many years as power supplies for research in pulsed processing of metal alloy components and systems. Most of these processes rely on extremely rapid thermal excursions in the workpiece(s) caused by resistive heating during the current pulse. A new application of pulsed HPG's that carries great promise is homopolar pulse consolidation (HPC) of powder metal alloys or components.(2) In HPC, powder metal constituents are loaded into a thermally and electrically insulated die, then precompacted to an initial pressure. the "rams" of the compaction press are also the electrodes for homopolar discharge current. While in single residency, the powder compact is heated uniformly by HPG discharge current, sintering occurs, and consolidation is accomplished by hydraulic control of the consolidation press. The process is completed in approximately one sec, with unaided cooling to room temperature on the order of 100 sec, depending on compact mass. Microstructural control is closely tied to beginning particle size and distribution. Traditionally unsinterable alloys have been consolidated using HPC. Novel intermetallic alloys and phases have been produced. Cermets and other composites can be produced, as long as the continuous matrix is conductive. New tooling designs allow for controlled atmospheres, near-net shapes, and automated manufacturing. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Composite Materials--Sintering; Intermetallics--Sintering; Homopolar Pulse Consolidation; Pulsed Homopolar Generator Discharge; Single Residency Sintering; Powder Metal Products

Abstract: Garnet films of (BiSmLu)3 (FeAl)5 O1asupporting 0. 4–0. 45µm diameter bubbles have been studied for 64Mb bubble memory devices. Using CaMgZr: Ggg substrates with a large lattice constant (12. 498Å), the anisotropy energy Ku can be increased to 2.5×105 erg/cm3 by increasing the Sm content in the film. Consequently, the bubble diameter can be reduced to 0. 4–0, 45μm keeping the effective anisotropy field (Hk-47πMs) at more than 1500 Oe. For the films on GGG having a Ku of about 1. 8x105 erg/cm3, (Hk-4πMs) and/or the film thickness h should be decreased compared with the films on CaMgZr: Ggg to reduce the bubble diameter to less than 0. 45µm. © 1989 IEEE

Title: Electrical charge injection and storage in off-stoichiometric SiO2 films
Affiliations: Toyohashi University of Technology, Dept. Of Electrical Engineering, Tempaku-cho, Toyohashi 440, Japan; Centro de Investigacion y de Estudios Avanzados del I.P.N, Depto. De Fisica, Apdo. Postal 14-740, 07000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lopez, M., Toyohashi University of Technology, Dept. Of Electrical Engineering, Tempaku-cho, Toyohashi 440, Japan; Falcony, C., Centro de Investigacion y de Estudios Avanzados del I.P.N, Depto. De Fisica, Apdo. Postal 14-740, 07000, United States
Abstract: The injection and storage characteristics of electrical charge in off-stoichiometric SiO2 films have been studied using two types of capacitor structures: (A) a simple capacitor formed with an off-stoichiometric SiO2 film deposited on either p-or n-type silicon substrate and a metallic (Al) contact, and (B) a structure similar to (A) but with a thin (100 A or 500 A) SiO2 layer between the Si substrate and the off-stoichiometric SiO2. The flat band voltage shifts measured from high frequency capacitance versus voltage curves of these devices were used to study the accumulation of charge in the off-stoichiometric SiO2 layer induced by applied voltage pulses. The width of these pulses was in the range of 10 ms to 100 μs and the amplitude was in the range of 0 to 80 volts. The role of the SiO2 layer in the (B) type structures is to inhibit or reduce charge injection to or from the Si substrate at low applied voltage amplitudes. This effect originates initial shifts of the flat band voltage of opposite polarity to those observed in the case of (A) type structures. The relaxation of the stored charges was monitored by measuring the shifts of the flat band voltage as a function of time when both electrical contacts were connected to ground potential. © 1989, Materials Research Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Szklarczyk M., Kainthla R.C., Bockris J.O.
Title: On the Dielectric Breakdown of Water: An Electrochemical Approach
Affiliations: Surface Electrochemistry Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3255, United States
Authors with affiliations: Szklarczyk, M., Surface Electrochemistry Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3255, United States; Kainthla, R.C., Surface Electrochemistry Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3255, United States; Bockris, J.O., Surface Electrochemistry Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3255, United States
Abstract: The dielectric breakdown of water under static fields has been studied by current-potential relation for six metals. The relations are quasi-linear up to a current density of a few Acm−2. The limiting current continues for a few volts to a few hundred volts, depending on the metal. A glow develops at the electrode and becomes continuous at the end of the plateau, where the current density increases irregularly (breakdown). The breakdown potential does not depend on the field in the water. It occurs at about the same current density for most of the metals. When electrolytes are added, the cell potential at the breakdown is decreased. Adsorbed layers and organic coatings increase the breakdown potential. Electrical energy storage in water is increased by ~10 times by coatings. The breakdown potential decreases with increase of log of rate constant for hydrogen evolution on the various electrodes and with the corresponding work function. The cell potentials for breakdown correspond to fields in the dielectric below that needed to dissociate it. The limiting current is caused by the formation of a H2-steam layer at the interface, which causes increase in the electrode potential at constant current. The H2-steam layer plasmolyzes. When the Fermi level in the cathode reaches the conduction band of water, electrons enter the water and remain stable therein. They interact nonadiabatically with water and are the head of streamers. An analogous model holds for holes in the valence band. “Dielectric breakdown” depends on the Fermi level of the electrons in the condenser plate and the semiconductor characteristics of water. It can be eliminated by modifying the electrode surface. © 1989, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Band Structure--Effects; Dielectric Materials--Electric Breakdown; Electric Breakdown--Electrochemistry; Electric Field Effects; Metals and Alloys--Electric Properties; Condenser Plates Potential; Dielectric Breakdown; Fermi Effects; Static Electric Fields; Water Breakdown; Water

Authors: Al‐Rawi N.A., Al‐Kaisi M.M., Hassen A.K.
Title: Load independent efficient, transformerless inverter for photovoltaic applications
Affiliations: Solid State Electronics Lab, Electrical Engineering Dept, University of Technology, PO Box-35010, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Al‐Rawi, N.A., Solid State Electronics Lab, Electrical Engineering Dept, University of Technology, PO Box-35010, Baghdad, Iraq; Al‐Kaisi, M.M., Solid State Electronics Lab, Electrical Engineering Dept, University of Technology, PO Box-35010, Baghdad, Iraq; Hassen, A.K., Solid State Electronics Lab, Electrical Engineering Dept, University of Technology, PO Box-35010, Baghdad, Iraq
Abstract: The overall efficiency of photovoltaic power systems (PVPS) depends on the efficiency of the PV panels, the storage batteries, and the efficiency of the inverter circuitry. The last is greatly influenced by the connected load, as the efficiencies are severly reduced when operating at low loads. This is especially effective when the PVPS is most likely to operate with a fraction of the full load. The suggested inverter has excellent efficiency characteristics over a wide power range, and because it contains only electronic components further cost reduction can be expected. Experimentally this inverter is designed for a 120 W output using thyristor switching devices; the efficiency obtained is 88% at full load and 85.2% at 10% of full load, with a maximum output voltage of 60 V stepped sinewave with frequency of 50 Hz. However, higher power outputs could also be achieved with this type of inverter. Copyright © 1989 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Title: A second-order marginal costs approximation for energy storage charging and discharging price functions
Source title: Journal of Energy Resources Technology, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Energy Resources and Thermal Systems Development Department, Research and Development Division, Israel Electric Corp. Ltd., Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Vadasz, P., Energy Resources and Thermal Systems Development Department, Research and Development Division, Israel Electric Corp. Ltd., Haifa, Israel
Abstract: A second-order technique is presented for the evaluation of peak/off-peak price functions, based on marginal costs methods, in energy storage technologies. This method is particularly useful in statical optimization of the fundamental parameters required for planning energy storage plants. Its applications permits to transform the original dynamic optimization problem into its statical equivalent, thus reducing considerably the computing time needed. This transformation introduces two additional parameters to be optimized using statical optimization methods, i.e., charging and discharging duration. © 1989 ASME.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Approximation Theory; Dynamic Optimization; Marginal Costs; Price Functions; Energy Storage

Authors: McRee D.E., Tainer J.A., Meyer T.E., Van Beeumen J., Cusanovich M.A., Getzoff E.D.
Title: Crystallographic structure of a photoreceptor protein at 2.4 A resolution.
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States
Authors with affiliations: McRee, D.E., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States; Tainer, J.A., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States; Meyer, T.E., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States; Van Beeumen, J., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States; Cusanovich, M.A., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States; Getzoff, E.D., Department of Molecular Biology, Research Institute of Scripps Clinic, La Jolla, CA  92037., United States
Abstract: The first essential step in protein photoreception is the capture and storage of energy from a photon. We have recently identified and isolated, from the purple photoautotrophic bacterium, Ectothiorhodospira halophila, a 13,000-dalton photoactive yellow protein (PYP) that has a photocycle with kinetics similar to sensory rhodopsin and a very high quantum efficiency. To study the structural chemistry of protein photoreception, we determined, refined, and analyzed the crystallographic structure of PYP at 2.4 A resolution and report here that it is composed of two perpendicular antiparallel beta-sheets that enclose the chromophore. Each of the 10 beta-strands of PYP is connected directly to its nearest neighbor with +1 topology. Globally, an asymmetric distribution of side chains places aromatic and acidic side chains in an ellipsoidal band around the chromophore with a cluster of basic side chains on one side. Locally, the electron density maps place an internal lysine and the chromophore in an apparent Schiff base linkage stabilized by a buried glutamate and a tyrosine side chain. To our knowledge, the atomic resolution structure of a protein with a reversible photoisomerization has not been reported previously. Furthermore, PYP may also represent a class of proteins that bind conjugated molecules and interact with a secondary receptor system.
Index Keywords: bacterial protein; photoactive yellow protein, Bacteria; visual proteins and pigments; article; chemical structure; Chromatiaceae; isolation and purification; metabolism; protein conformation; X ray diffraction; Bacterial Proteins; Chromatiaceae; Models, Molecular; Photoreceptors, Microbial; Protein Conformation; X-Ray Diffraction

Title: Causes and consequences of variation in energy storage in Drosophila melanogaster.
Affiliations: Department of Biology and Genetics Program, Pennsylvania State University, University Park 16802., United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, A.G., Department of Biology and Genetics Program, Pennsylvania State University, University Park 16802., United States
Abstract: Variation in energy storage pools has a proximate cause variation in rates of influx and efflux from the pools, and it may, as an ultimate consequence, result in variation in fitness. The possibility of this chain of causal links motivates attempts to quantify the genetic correlations among pool sizes, enzyme activities and fitness components. In this report, homogenates from 83 second chromosome replacement lines of Drosophila melanogaster were analyzed to determine the amounts of stored triacylglycerols and glycogen as well as the activities of 11 enzymes in relevant metabolic pathways. The viabilities and fecundities of these same lines were determined by a segregation test using the SM5 balancer chromosome. Analysis of covariance revealed significant differences among lines in quantities of stored triacylglycerols and glycogen, as well as in activities of the assayed enzymes. Significant broad-sense genetic correlations were detected for a number of enzyme pairs. Some of the traits showed a significant correlation with viability and fecundity, including lipid and glycogen storage. Multiple regression models that fitted fitness components to linear and quadratic functions of the biochemical traits yielded highly significant fits. The partial regression coefficients indicate the shape of the selection gradient, and instances of significant directional and stabilizing selection were detected.
Index Keywords: fatty acid synthase; glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase; glucose 6 phosphate isomerase; glyceraldehyde 3 phosphate dehydrogenase; glycogen; glycogen synthase; hexokinase; malate dehydrogenase; phosphoglucomutase; phosphogluconate dehydrogenase; phosphorylase; trehalase; triacylglycerol; analysis of variance; animal; article; Drosophila melanogaster; energy metabolism; fertility; genetic variability; genetics; male; metabolism; physiology; regression analysis; Analysis of Variance; Animals; Drosophila melanogaster; Energy Metabolism; Fatty Acid Synthetase Complex; Fertility; Glucose-6-Phosphate Isomerase; Glucosephosphate Dehydrogenase; Glyceraldehyde-3-Phosphate Dehydrogenases; Glycogen; Glycogen Synthase; Hexokinase; Malate Dehydrogenase; Male; Phosphoglucomutase; Phosphogluconate Dehydrogenase; Phosphorylases; Regression Analysis; Trehalase; Triglycerides; Variation (Genetics)

Title: Non-ionising electromagnetic environments on manned spacecraft.
Source title: Journal of the British Interplanetary Society
Affiliations: Gloucester
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, J.R., Gloucester
Abstract: Future space travellers and settlers will be exposed to a variety of electromagnetic fields (EMFs). Extrinsic sources will include solar and stellar fluxes, planetary fluxes, and supernovae. Intrinsic sources may include fusion and ion engines, EMFs from electrical equipment, radar, lighting, superconduction energy storage systems, magnetic bearings on gyroscopic control and orientation systems, and magnetic rail microprobe launch systems. Communication sources may include radio and microwave frequencies, and laser generating systems. Magnetic fields may also be used for deflection of radiation. There is also a loss of the normal Geomagnetic field (GMF) which includes static, alternating, and time-varying components. This paper reviews exposure limits and the biological effects of EMFs, and evidence for an electromagnetic sense organ and a relationship between man and the Geomagnetic field.
Index Keywords: animal; electromagnetic field; human; light; magnetism; maximum allowable concentration; microwave radiation; radiation; radiation protection; radiation response; radiofrequency radiation; review; space flight; standard; Animals; Electromagnetic Fields; Humans; Light; Magnetics; Maximum Allowable Concentration; Microwaves; Radiation Effects; Radiation Protection; Radiation, Nonionizing; Radio Waves; Space Flight; Spacecraft

Authors: Guojun Q., Ziqiang L., Itagaki K., Yazawa A.
Title: High Temperature Phase Relations in Ni–RE(RE=La, Ce, Pr, Nd) Binary and Ternary Alloy Systems
Affiliations: Northeast University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Research Institute of Mineral Dressing and Metallurgy (SENKEN), Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Guojun, Q., Northeast University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Ziqiang, L., Research Institute of Mineral Dressing and Metallurgy (SENKEN), Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan; Itagaki, K., Research Institute of Mineral Dressing and Metallurgy (SENKEN), Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan; Yazawa, A., Research Institute of Mineral Dressing and Metallurgy (SENKEN), Tohoku University, Sendai 980, Japan
Abstract: The liquidus lines of the RE-rich side which are in equilibrium with solid compounds Ni5RE in the four Ni–RE (RE=La, Ce, Pr, Nd) systems or in equilibrium with solid compounds Ni5REj,θREk,(1−θ) (REj and REk represent any two of the rare earths from La, Ce, Pr and Nd) in the six Ni–REj–REk ternary systems were determined experimentally in a temperature range of 1273∼1513 K. On the basis of the phase relations obtained and the available thermodynamic information, a thermodynamic evaluation was carried out for the Ni–RE binary and Ni–REj–REk ternary systems in order to derive a set of coefficients which describe the free energy of mixing of the liquid phases as a function of composition and temperature. Using the free energy of mixing, phase relations were predicted for the Ni–RE binary and Ni–REj–REk ternary alloy systems at temperatures above 1513 K and at high concentrations of nickel above XNi=0.833 (Ni5RE). © 1989, The Japan Institute of Metals. All rights reserved.

Authors: Baughman M.L., Eisner N.A., Merrill P.S.
Title: Optimizing combined cogeneration and thermal storage systems: An engineering economics approach
Affiliations: Associate Professor, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas 78712, United States; Neil A. Eisner & Company, P.O. Box 161508, Austin, Texas 78716, United States; Technical Staff, Texas Instruments, Inc., 12501 Research Blvd., Austin, Texas 78769, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baughman, M.L., Associate Professor, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas 78712, United States; Eisner, N.A., Neil A. Eisner & Company, P.O. Box 161508, Austin, Texas 78716, United States; Merrill, P.S., Technical Staff, Texas Instruments, Inc., 12501 Research Blvd., Austin, Texas 78769, United States
Abstract: A computer program has been developed to minimize the present worth of the electric and thermal energy costs of a manufacturing facility as a function of the type and amount of cogeneration and thermal storage it might install. The model is particularly useful in instances where the rates paid for electricity are differentiated by time of day and season. The program has been applied successfully to two large industrial facilities located in the southern United States. It simulates the optimal electricity production and and thermal energy usage patterns as a function of the equipment installed in the plant over a planning horizon of 15 years, based upon a year's worth of historical data, projected load growth, and projected rates for fuel and electricity. The historical data consists of bihourly information on total electricity consumption and central station chiller electricity usage, as well as bihourly data on the plant’s process steam load. © 1989 IEEE
Author Keywords: Cost Minimization; Industrial Cogeneration Thermal Storage Industrial Energy Utilization; Optimization Model

Authors: Murai Kazuhiro, Kawashima Yosuke, Kaji Masuo, Nakanishi Shigeyasu
Title: Practical calculation method of varying pressure steam accumulators
Source title: JSME International Journal, Series 2: Fluids Engineering, Heat Transfer, Power, Combustion, Thermophysical Properties
Affiliations: Himeji Inst of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Murai, Kazuhiro, Himeji Inst of Technology, Japan; Kawashima, Yosuke, Himeji Inst of Technology, Japan; Kaji, Masuo, Himeji Inst of Technology, Japan; Nakanishi, Shigeyasu, Himeji Inst of Technology, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a practical calculation for the capacity of varying pressure accumulators is developed in detail. To facilitate the calculation of the amount of self-evaporation and the fraction of steam space, two functions of pressure are introduced and are evaluated by using the JSME steam table. Approximate expressions resulting in quick and exact calculations are also given. One of the great merits of the proposed method over existing ones is that the effect of the initial steam space on the accumulator characteristics can be easily and accurately evaluated producing results that are final.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Evaporation; Steam Tables and Charts; Steam--Thermodynamic Properties; Self-Evaporation; Steam accumulators

Authors: Utaka Yoshio, Saito Akio, Niimi Masaru, Nakata Naoki
Title: Method of efficient ice cool energy storage using heat transfer of direct contact phase change between working medium and PCM in an enclosure
Source title: JSME International Journal, Series 2: Fluids Engineering, Heat Transfer, Power, Combustion, Thermophysical Properties
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Utaka, Yoshio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Saito, Akio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Niimi, Masaru, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Nakata, Naoki, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan
Abstract: The objectives of this report are to propose a new method of high performance cool energy storage using ice as a phase change material and to clarify its basic heat transfer characteristics. A working medium vapor layer, a water layer and a working medium liquid layer stratified in this order from the top were kept in an enclosure composed of a condenser, an evaporator and a condensate receiver-and-return tube. Direct contact heat transfers between either water or ice and a working medium in an enclosure was used to achieve high performance cool energy storage and release. In the storage and release processes, water changes phase between liquid and solid, and the working medium circulates naturally with phase changes between vapor and liquid. Experimental apparatus was arranged and R 12 and R 114 were selected as working media. Efficient formation and melting of ice were confirmed by the experiment.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Cool Energy Storage; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage; Phase Change; Ice

Authors: Saito Akio, Imamura Takahiro, Utaka Yoshio, Saito Akihiro
Title: On the contact heat transfer with melting. (Direct contact melting process within an inclined rectangular cross-section)
Source title: JSME International Journal, Series 2: Fluids Engineering, Heat Transfer, Power, Combustion, Thermophysical Properties
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saito, Akio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Imamura, Takahiro, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Utaka, Yoshio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan; Saito, Akihiro, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Japan
Abstract: Experimental and analytical investigations were performed on a direct contact melting process of a phase change material (PCM) which was contained in an inclined rectangular space surrounded by a heat transfer surface and plate fins. The solid phase varied in shape, receiving the latent heat of fusion from the surrounding walls at the contacting spots, and moved within the rectangular space, changing the contacting mode. The numerical method to simulate such a direct contact melting process was proposed. Experiments were also conducted to examine the numerical method, using N-octadecane as the PCM. The experimental and analytical results agreed quite well with each other. It was found from the analytical results that the inclination angle scarcely affected the average melting rate despite the serious effects on the contacting mode and the heat flux distribution over the walls.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Direct Contact Melting; Phase Change Material; Thermal Energy Storage; Heat transfer

Authors: Lightstone M.F., Raithby G.D., Hollands K.G.T.
Title: Numerical simulation of the charging of liquid storage tanks: Comparison with experiment1
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, N2L 3G1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lightstone, M.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, N2L 3G1, Canada; Raithby, G.D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, N2L 3G1, Canada; Hollands, K.G.T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, N2L 3G1, Canada
Abstract: The degree of thermal stratification maintained in hot water storage tanks has a significant impact on the performance of a solar energy system. This paper presents an axisymmetric finite volume model analysis of the charging of a tank with hot water, and compares the predictions with experimental results from the literature. The results show the capabilities and deficiencies of such a modeling technique for this type of problem. The importance of inlet fluid turbulence to tank destratification is demonstrated and inclusion of a simple turbulence model is found sufficient to yield good agreement with measurement. The model predictions also provide insight into when a simple one-dimensional plug flow model will be adequate. In addition, the model is used to evaluate the effect during charging of heat conduction in the tank wall on the temperature field in the fluid. Recommendations are made regarding future work on the development of detailed numerical codes for simulating the charging of liquid storage tanks. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Heating--Hot Water Systems; Temperature Measurement; Charging; Liquid Storage Tanks; Plug Flow Model; Tanks

Title: Elastomeric matrix‐short fibers adhesion
Affiliations: Instituto de Plásticos y Caucho (C.S.I.C.), Juan de la Cierva 3, Madrid, 28006, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Ibarra, L., Instituto de Plásticos y Caucho (C.S.I.C.), Juan de la Cierva 3, Madrid, 28006, Spain; Chamorro, C., Instituto de Plásticos y Caucho (C.S.I.C.), Juan de la Cierva 3, Madrid, 28006, Spain
Abstract: This paper analyzes the effects of the addition of a three‐component dry type adhesive system on the properties of composite SBR (styrene‐butadiene rubber) material containing 20 percent short polyamide (5 mm length and 60 μm diameter). The curing times are extended and green strength is doubled. The replacement of the silica component in the system by a natural silicate is not only feasible, but proves to be favorable for certain properties, such as the storage modulus E′, which becomes less sensitive towards temperature changes. Dynamic property measurements provide evidence of an additional dispersion corresponding to the matrix‐fiber interface located around 40 to 50°C, which does not occur in the composites without adhesive. The activation energies of the main relaxation process of these materials are determined, amounting to 175 KJ/mol for the matrix and 250 KJ/mol for adhesive‐containing composites, as a consequence of the formation of strong bonds between both phases. Copyright © 1989 Society of Plastics Engineers

Title: Studies of radiative cooling systems for storing thermal energy1
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kanagawa Institute of Technology, Atsugi-shi, Kanagawa-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kanagawa Institute of Technology, Atsugi-shi, Kanagawa-ken, Japan; Miura, N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kanagawa Institute of Technology, Atsugi-shi, Kanagawa-ken, Japan
Abstract: The thermal performance of an uncovered radiator and a radiative cooling system was investigated experimentally and theoretically. The net radiative power of a black painted surf ace at ambient air temperature was measured by heat flux plates at night in order to use the results for predicting temperatures of the radiator surface and the fluid in the cooling system on the same night. The net radiative power obtained by the measurements was 40-60 W/m2 on clear nights in the summer and 60-80 W/m2 in the fall and winter. The average temperature of the energy storage tank on clear nights became 2-5°C below the ambient temperature. The experimental and analytical results agreed well with each other. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Refrigeration; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Energy Storage Tank; Heat Flux Plates; Radiative Cooling System; Radiators

Authors: Zurigat Y.H., Maloney K.J., Ghajar A.J.
Title: A comparison study of one-dimensional models for stratified thermal storage tanks
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, 74078, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zurigat, Y.H., School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, 74078, United States; Maloney, K.J., School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, 74078, United States, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Ghajar, A.J., School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, 74078, United States
Abstract: A survey of the stratified thermal storage tank one-dimensional models available in the literature has been conducted. Six of these models were tested and compared against the experimental data obtained at our laboratories and from the literature. Although various factors affecting the performance of a stratified tank can be accounted for by the higher order models, i.e. two- and three-dimensional models, the introduction of empirically-based mixing parameters into the one-dimensional models renders them widely applicable and practical in the simulation of energy systems incorporating thermal storage tanks. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Data Reduction and Analysis; Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Higher Order Models; One-Dimensional Models; Thermal Storage Tank; Tanks

Title: Energy storage in a fluidized bed
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University ot California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Merry, N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University ot California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Rubinsky, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University ot California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Abstract: An experimental study was performed to investigate the possible use of a compound that undergoes solid-to-solid phase transformation for energy storage in a fluidized bed configuration, and to determine the heat transfer characteristics of this system. It was shown that the heat transfer coefficients from a surface immersed in the fluidized bed are a function of the bed temperature and of the temperature of the immersed surface. The heat transfer process is enhanced by the phase transformation by as much as a factor of four relative to the heat transfer in the same material without phase transformation. The experimental results suggest the possible existence of a thermal resistance between the surface immersed in the fluidized bed and the particles, which is responsible for the particular experimentally observed thermal behavior. © 1989 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Packed and Fluidized Beds; Phase-Change Phenomena; Thermal Energy Storage
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Solids--Phase Transitions; Fluidized Bed Energy Storage; Phase Transformation; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Heat Transfer

Title: Optimizing the value-to-cost ratio for central receiver electric power plants1
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Laboratory, Richland, WA, 99352, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dirks, J.A., Pacific Northwest Laboratory, Richland, WA, 99352, United States; Chiang, C.J., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Abstract: Typically, solar thermal power plants are designed to minimize the levelized energy cost. However, to maximize the benefit of a solar plant and, hence, maximize the wealth of an investor or a utility, a solar plant should be designed and operated with the objective of maximizing the value-to-cost ratio. This paper describes a value and cost analysis of solar central receiver power plants using molten salt external receiver technology. These plants were assumed to operate within the service area of the Southern California Edison Company. The SOLERGY computer code was used to simulate the performance of the solar plants using 1984 weather data for Barstow, California. A value-maximizing dispatch strategy that uses thermal storage to shift operation of the turbine from nonpeak demand periods to the utility’s peak demand period, is shown to greatly increase the value of a solar central receiver power plant with little increase in the levelized energy cost. Results are presented as functions of storage capacity, type of dispatch strategy, size of the field relative to the turbine, and turbine size. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Exchangers; Solar Energy--Energy Utilization; Value Engineering; Software Package SOLERGY; Solar Central Receiver Power Plants; SOLERGY Computer Code; Value-Maximizing Dispatch Strategy; Value-to-Cost Ratio; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Faiman D., Feuermann D., Huleihil M.
Title: Numerical model of a rotating prism wall: Its validation and predicted device performance for a variety of situations
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Faiman, D., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel; Feuermann, D., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel; Huleihil, M., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel
Abstract: A numerical model has been developed which describes the temperature distribution as a function of time within the storage elements of a Rotating Prism Solar Storage Wall. The model is tested against data obtained from a full-scale Rotating Prism Wall at Sede Boqer in Israel, and found to reproduce the measured temperatures extremely well. The thus validated model is used to predict the performance of such devices in various kinds of climate and to compare this performance with that to be expected from a nonvented Trombe Wall of standard design. In all cases the Rotating Prism Wall is found to provide considerably more useful energy than a nonvented Trombe Wall. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Walls; Temperature Distribution--Mathematical Models; Rotating Prism Wall; Sede Boqer; Trombe Wall; Solar Energy

Authors: Burri G., Luedi W., Haas O.
Title: Electrochemical Properties of Aluminum in Weakly Acidic Sodium Chloride Solutions: Part I. Influence of the Electrolyte Additives In3+ and Zn2+
Affiliations: Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Burri, G., Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Luedi, W., Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland; Haas, O., Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: The electrochemical behavior of aluminum has been investigated in acidic NaCl solutions over the pH range between 1 and 4. Current-potential curves as well as current-time curves at fixed potentials were recorded with rotating disk electrodes. The faradaic efficiencies of aluminum dissolution were measured as functions of pH at fixed values of potential, and the effect of electrolyte additives on the efficiencies was determined at the optimum pH of 2. Two aluminum qualities were used in the tests, Al 99.5% (welding-rod quality) and Al 99.99%. They yield highly similar results. The faradaic efficiencies fall off only at pH < 1. With 0.0005M InCl3 and 0.08M ZnCl2 as electrolyte additives, the current-potential curves are shifted by about 300 mV toward more negative values of potential, while the faradaic efficiencies at pH of 2–3 rise from 76 to about 95%. X-ray diffraction and SIMS measurements were used to analyze the effect of the electrolyte additives on the electrode surface compositions. © 1989, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Fujii I., Tsuchiya K., Shikakura Y., Murthy M.S.
Title: Consideration on thermal decomposition of calcium hydroxide pellets for energy storage
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Meiji University at Kawasaki, Kanagawa, 214, Japan; Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, I., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Meiji University at Kawasaki, Kanagawa, 214, Japan; Tsuchiya, K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Meiji University at Kawasaki, Kanagawa, 214, Japan; Shikakura, Y., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Meiji University at Kawasaki, Kanagawa, 214, Japan; Murthy, M.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India
Abstract: The reversible chemical reaction of Ca(OH)2/CaO appears to be attractive for storage of solar thermal energy, in view of the nonpolluting and nontoxic nature of the reactants. This paper presents some data on thermal decomposition of calcium hydroxide pellets along with its additives of aluminum, aluminum hydroxide, zinc, and copper. The addition of aluminum and zinc powder enhanced the rate of decomposition considerably at 450° C, but copper had no effect. Considerations on the effect of additives are also discussed in some detail, though their effects are not established with certainty. There is some evidence that heat transfer into the pellet, and the number of potential nucleation sites due to thermal stresses, influence the kinetics and mechanism of decomposition. © 1989 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Decomposition; Solar Energy; Stresses--Thermal; Calcium Hydroxide Pellets; Nucleation Sites; Thermal Decomposition; Calcium Compounds

Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited is developing methods for the management and safe disposal of radioactive wastes. These wastes range from the highly radioactive (high-level) UO2 fuel arising from the nuclear generation of electrical power to the low- and intermediate-level wastes arising from reasearch in various Canadian institutions using radioactive isotopes. This paper reviews the current research programs on materials and processes for the immobilization and containment of UO2 fuel wastes and the technical aspects of programs demonstrating the various technologies needed for implementing a disposal program for low-level wastes.Atomic Energy of Canada Limited is developing methods for the management and safe disposal of radioactive wastes. These wastes range from the highly radioactive (high-level) UO2 fuel arising from the nuclear generation of electrical power to the low- and intermediate-level wastes arising from research in various Canadian institutions using radioactive isotopes. This paper reviews the current research programs on materials and processes for the immobilization and containment of UO2 fuel wastes and the technical aspects of programs demonstrating the various technologies needed for implementing a disposal program for low-level wastes.

Source title: International Journal of Rock Mechanics and Mining Sciences and

Authors with affiliations: Majer, E.L., Center for Computational Seismology, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Earth Sciences Division, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: Several different field experiments have been carried out at two different field sites to develop high-frequency seismological method for the mapping of grout injections in real time. Both sites were in fractured crystalline rock with permeabilities of the fractured rocks ranging from 10-5 to 10-8 m/sec. The injection rates varied from 1 to 200 l/min. The viscosity was also varied. The injection pressures varied from 0.1 to 2 MPa over hydrostatic. Deviatoric in situ stress ranged from near zero (one site was at the surface)_to 15 MPa for the deepest injections. The results of these field tests indicate that there is usable seismic energy between 1000 and 10,000 Hz. There are basically two different types of energy: discrete seismic events (acoustic emission), and in some cases an increase in continuous seismic energy that appears to be associated with the grout sheet when very viscous fluids are used. A field system has been built, that using the results of these experiments, will be used in future experiments for mapping the grout location. © 1989.
Index Keywords: grout injection; mapping; radioactive waste storage; seismic monitoring; Flow of Fluids--Porous Materials; Maps and Mapping; Rock--Fracture; Seismic Waves--Monitoring; Grout Injections; Grouting

Title: Minimization of raw water pumping costs using MILP
Source title: Journal of Water Resources Planning and Management
Affiliations: Res. Triangle Inst., Research Triangle Park, NC, 27709, United States
Authors with affiliations: Little, K.W., Res. Triangle Inst., Research Triangle Park, NC, 27709, United States; McCrodden, B.J., Res. Triangle Inst., Research Triangle Park, NC, 27709, United States
Abstract: With increasing demands for water, increasing costs for electrical energy, and often stagnant budgets, water utilities must begin to investigate alternative pumping policies that achieve cost savings while not sacrificing system performance. A study was performed for the city of Raleigh, North Carolina, to determine efficient raw water pumping policies to take advantage of existing storage and newly available time-of-use power rates. The problem was formulated as a mixed-integer linear-programming (MILP) model. Binary integer variables are used to model commercial demand charges, which are once-per-billing period assessments on the maximum on- and off-peak electrical demands. Other costs to be minimized include commercial energy charges, as well as standby generator costs to avoid on-peak commercial power use. Constraints include satisfaction of water demands, minimum and maximum reservoir levels, minimum and maximum pump run times, and other constraints necessary to ensure feasibility. The model is now being used by the city to achieve substantial savings. © ASCE.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Utilization - Costs; Mathematical Programming, Linear; Cost Minimization; Mixed Integer Linear Programming; Pumping Policies; Raw Water Pumping; Pumping Plants

Abstract: A simple generalization of the Hopfield memory is presented. The model introduced updates simultaneously groups of neurons. It is shown that it minimizes an energy function as in the original Hopfield model. Sufficient conditions on the corresponding connection matrix as to ensure stability are given. © 1989 IEEE

Title: Recirculating mixed convection flows in rectangular cavities
Source title: Journal of Thermophysics and Heat Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Clemson University, Clemson, SC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Clemson University, Clemson, SC, United States; Yuan, T.-D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Clemson University, Clemson, SC, United States
Abstract: A numerical investigation is carried out to determine the flow and thermal structures of mixed convective flow in a rectangular cavity. The effect of aiding and opposing buoyancy on the flow in a vertical downward laminar jet is studied for Re ≤ 200, -1.0 ≤ Ri ≤ 0.5, and 0.5 ≤ A ≤ 5.0. Such flow situations occur in enclosure fires, energy storage, and ventilation systems. Results of the velocity profile, temperature distribution, local friction factor, and heat-transfer coefficient are presented for both hot and cold jets. The flow configuration is found to be strongly affected by the positive and negative buoyancy and also by the aspect ratio of the cavity. Authors: Gurol H., Hardy G.E., Peck S.D., Leung E.
Title: Transient magnetic field and temperature modeling in large magnet applications
Affiliations: General Dynamics Space Systems Division, P.O. Bos 85990, MZ 92–8260, San Diego, CA, 92138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gurol, H., General Dynamics Space Systems Division, P.O. Bos 85990, MZ 92–8260, San Diego, CA, 92138, United States; Hardy, G.E., General Dynamics Space Systems Division, P.O. Bos 85990, MZ 92–8260, San Diego, CA, 92138, United States; Peck, S.D., General Dynamics Space Systems Division, P.O. Bos 85990, MZ 92–8260, San Diego, CA, 92138, United States; Leung, E., General Dynamics Space Systems Division, P.O. Bos 85990, MZ 92–8260, San Diego, CA, 92138, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to discuss a coupled magnetic/thermal model that has been developed to study heat and magnetic field diffusion in conducting materials subject to time-varying external fields. There are numerous applications, both military and commercial. These include: energy storage devices, pulsed power transformers, and electromagnetic launchers. The time scales of interest may range from a magnetic field pulse of a microsecond in an electromagnetic launcher, to hundreds of seconds in an energy storage magnet. The problem can be dominated by either the magnetic field or heat diffusion, depending on the temperature and the material properties of the conductor. In general, heat diffuses much more rapidly in high electrical conductivity materials at cryogenic temperatures. The magnetic field takes longer to diffuse, since screening currents can be rapidly set up which shield the interior of the material from further magnetic field penetration. Conversely, in high resistivity materials, the magnetic field diffuses much more rapidly. A coupled two-dimensional thermal/magnetic model has been developed using the General Dynamics “Thermal Analyzer” code.1The results of this model, showing the time and spatial variation of the magnetic field and temperature. will be discussed for the projectile of an electromagnetic launcher. © 1989 IEEE
Index Keywords: Electric Conductors; Electric Transformers; Magnets; Rocket Engines--Electromagnetic Propulsion; Rockets and Missiles--Launching; Electromagnetic Launchers; External Fields; Large Magnet; Magnetic Field Pulse; Magnetic/Thermal Model; Power Transformers; Magnetic Fields

Authors: Wen C., Sheffield J.W., O'Dell M.P., Leland J.E.
Title: Analytical and experimental investigation of melting heat transfer
Source title: Journal of Thermophysics and Heat Transfer
Affiliations: University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO, United States; Air Force Wright Aeronautical Laboratories, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wen, C., University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO, United States; Sheffield, J.W., University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO, United States; O'Dell, M.P., University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO, United States; Leland, J.E., Air Force Wright Aeronautical Laboratories, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States
Abstract: A computational model is presented for the prediction of the heat transfer between a heat-transfer fluid (HTF) and a phase change material (PCM) of a latent heat storage unit. Two models of flow, hydrodynamically fully developed and developing, of the HTF were proposed in this study. A two-dimensional enthalpy method was used for the computation of the phase change heat transfer in the PCM. A fully implicit finite-difference scheme was utilized for the calculation of convective heat transfer in the HTF. The unknown time-dependent boundary condition between the HTF and the PCM was found iteratively. The predictions were substantiated by their fair agreement with experimental data. Factors affecting the heat-transfer rates between the HTF and the PCM were studied numerically for both the hydrodynamically fully developed and developing flows. It was found that the Nusselt number is significantly increased by the developing temperature profiles. The developing velocity profiles also increased the Nusselt number. However, the influence on Nusselt number due to the developing velocity profiles was less significant than that due to the developing temperature profiles. Other factors affecting the Nusselt number are discussed. Copyright © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1988.All rights reserved.

Title: Effects of increasing injection repetition rate of low-energy injection into a compact storage ring
Affiliations: Osaka Research Laboratories, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Shimaya Konohana, Osaka, 554, Japan; Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sumitomo Electric Industries Ltd, Umezono 305, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, Japan

Abstract: The relation between the injection repetition rate and beam accumulation in an electron storage ring were studied through experiments and beam tracking calculations.The rate is an important parameter which limits beam current storage. It was believed that the stored beam current could not be increased even if the injection repetition rate was increased over the inverse of the radiation damping time of the betatron oscillations. This is an important consideration for low-energy injection.The experiment was performed at 90 MeV using an NIJI-I compact electron storage ring, and a beam current accumulation rate was obtained above the limit determined by the radiation damping time. It was found that beam current accumulation depended on the kick angle of the kicker magnet. © 1989 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Affiliations: Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica, Università di Roma La Sapienza, Rome, Italy; Centro di Studio per la Elettrochimica e la Chimica Fisica delle Interfasi, CNR, Via Castro Laurenziano 7, Rome, Italy

Abstract: Fergusonite, a monoclinic variety of bismuth orthovanadate, has been tested as a cathode in lithium cells. The reduction process, leading to the formation of Bi and Li3VO4, corresponds to a potential of 1.6 V at 100 μA. Button cells, based on the Li/BiVO4 couple, have been built mainly in the IEC R 42 size (100 mA h) and have provided a volumetric energy density of 432 W h/l at 100 μA. This new material also features good capacity retention at low temperatures, under 500 μA pulses, and after storage. © 1989.
